PARA.TAB: The Senate met at 9.30 a.m.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CLERK

TALK.START.PARA: — I advise the Senate that Madam President is unavoidably absent and, under standing order 13, the Deputy President will take the chair.

INTERJECT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston) thereupon took the chair, and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable Amanda Vanstone, the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned protest the proposed education package delivered by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.
In endorsing the supposed `Bright Future for Higher Education' the Federal Government is breaking election promises in the change to the HECS threshold.
It is further disadvantaging the Australian people in creating an elitist graduate class by increasing HECS levels.
Your petitioners ask that you take our grave concerns to the Minister and advise us accordingly.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Gun Control Campaign
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: that the overwhelming majority of Australians support uniform, national gun laws and the associated compensation measures as agreed between the Prime Minister, State Premiers and the Chief Ministers of the ACT and NT.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners ask that the Senate:

PARA.TAB: continue to demonstrate its firm support for these measures;
take all possible action to expedite their implementation; and
resist all calls for the control measures to be watered down or abandoned.

PETITION.TITLE: Telstra: Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators, and to the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that:
As members of the Australian community, considering:

PARA.TAB: the strategic importance of Telstra in the national economy;
the high levels of foreign ownership in the rest of the telecommunications industry;
the growing importance of communications services to the lives of all Australians;
the threat that privatisation poses to the universal availability of both present and future communications services;

PETITION.PARA: We believe that it is in the national interest for Telstra to be kept in full public ownership.

We therefore call on the Federal Government to abandon its proposal to privatise Telstra, the nation's chief telecommunications provider, and to explore alternative means of funding its environmental policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Port Hinchinbrook Development Project
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned humbly request that the Senate honours the obligations of the Commonwealth of Australia to protect its territory that has received World Heritage status according to the World Heritage Convention of which Australia is a signatory.

Significant areas of marine and mangrove ecosystems of Australia's World Heritage Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are directly threatened with destruction by the adjacent construction of Australia's largest tourist resort and marina complex at Oyster Point near Cardwell North Queensland (opposite Hinchinbrook Island).

We implore the Senate to use its powers immediately to permanently halt the construction of the marina and access channel in the World Heritage "Buffer Zone" as recommended by the Valentine Report made to his Department in October 1994.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will be forced to significantly reduce its services in Tasmania in order to meet the Budget cut of $65 million as announced by the Government.
Your Petitioners request the Senate to oppose the funding cuts proposed by the Government and to ensure that:
(a) the ABC can maintain its valuable communication and education services to Tasmania;
(b) ABC Launceston—the ABC's largest regional operation in Australia—can maintain its range of programming;
(c) the Launceston television crew—one of only three in regional Australia—is maintained;
(d) the future of the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra is maintained; and
(e) the Coalition's pre‐election promise of maintaining existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC is upheld.

PETITION.TITLE: Sexuality Anti‐discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That Australian citizens oppose social, legal and economic discrimination against people on the basis of their sexuality or transgender identity and that such discrimination is unacceptable in a democratic society.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

pass the Australian Democrats Sexuality anti‐discrimination Bill to make it unlawful, at a national level, to discriminate or vilify on the basis of sexuality or transgender identity and to provide for a remedy for such discrimination or vilification.

PETITION.TITLE: Point Lillias
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia in Geelong requests that the Senate examine the proposal to set aside land currently protected under the Ramsar Treaty in order to provide for a chemical storage facility at Pt Lillias. Further, we request the Senate to examine whether the proposal to set aside an area alternate to the one now nominated by the Ramsar Treaty is in accordance with the requirement of that Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: Mental Health Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That mental health service consumers and carers are already significantly disadvantaged by the current poor funding of mental health and psychiatric disability support services.
That the 1996 Federal Budget will halve the Medicare rebate where a person visits a psychiatrist more than 50 times in a year.

That people with mental health problems such as chronic depression, eating disorders, dissociative disorders, or who may have suffered childhood abuse require access to long term intensive therapy. Decreased access to service by private psychiatrists will result in increased hospitalisation for those most in need.

That the 1996 Federal Budget will increase the cost of prescriptions for people on the Disability Support Pension. While the cap on the total cost of prescriptions in a year remains the same, people who are already living below the poverty line will be required to pay more from their fortnightly pension until the cap is reached.

That the 1996 Federal Budget will cut $14 million from Commonwealth Mental Health Programs. This funding had been made available to address serious problems and under‐funding in mental health services in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly ask that you will oppose cuts to mental health services and increases in the cost of prescriptions.

PETITION.TITLE: Mobile Phone Towers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned request the Telecommunications Act (1991) be amended to give local government authorities the statutory right to refuse permission for the erection of mobile phone towers if they so decide.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: ATSIC: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, believe the overwhelming majority of Australians uphold the principles of Reconciliation between Indigenous and Non‐Indigenous Australians.
However, we believe the policies being pursued by the present government are working against the process of reconciliation.
We protest most strongly to the funding cuts fo Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Commission (ATSIC).
The petitioners, ask that the Senate demonstrates its firm support for the Reconciliation process through the restoration of ATSIC's funding and autonomy.

PETITION.TITLE: Childcare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows that the quality, availability and equity of child care would be adversely affected should changes proposed go ahead. Namely that:

PARA.TAB: removal of operational subsidies to community based (not for profit) long day centres will increase fees, adding a greater financial burden to parents. Tasmania will be more adversely affected than any other state.
the payment of child care assistance directly to parents will cause considerable administrative difficulties for all child care centres both community based and private.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners ask the Senate to support the retention of operational subsidies to community based (not for profit) long day care centres and that the decision to pay child care assistance directly to parents be reversed.

BREAK.PARA: Petitions received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to prohibit transfer of military equipment to or defence cooperation between the Australian Defence Forces and the armed forces of any State which uses its armed forces to suppress basic human rights, and for related purposes. Defence Cooperation Control Amendment Bill 1996 .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Export Control (Hardwood Woodchips) (Monitoring Fee) Orders (Amendment), Order No. HW1 of 1996, made under regulation 3 of the Export Control (Orders) Regulations, made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) expresses its abhorrence at the Chinese Government's campaign of forcible sterilisation of Tibetan women and girls, and the associated abortion of any foetus;
(b) notes that in some areas of Tibet up to 70 per cent of the female population in the 12‐ to 50‐year age group has been forcibly sterilised as a result of this campaign;
(c) believes that this campaign and its ramifications amount to systematic genocide of the Tibetan race;
(d) calls on the Australian Government to take appropriate action to persuade the Government of China to cease its campaign; and
(e) urges all Australians to boycott `made in China' goods this Christmas as a means of expressing their opposition to the gross violation of the human rights of Tibetan people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) that Senator Newman, in addition to her responsibilities as Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, represents in the Senate the Ministers for Defence; Defence Industry, Science and Personnel; Veterans' Affairs and Health and Family Services,

(ii) Senator Newman's novel proposal in the Senate on Tuesday, 10 December 1996, that in future all questions relating to portfolios she represents be no longer asked in the Senate and that senators should instead `go to the minister responsible in the chamber where that minister sat and ask that minister directly',
(iii) that this would preclude Opposition senators asking questions without notice on defence, health and veterans' affairs in the Senate,

(iv) Senator Newman's total inability to meet the combined demands of her portfolio responsibilities and her representational responsibilities in this chamber, as evidenced by her consistent refusal to provide answers to questions without notice on matters outside her direct portfolio interests, and
(v) that this is the last opportunity to give notices of motion before the 1996 Christmas recess; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) exhorts the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), in the course of his Christmas holidays, to consider relieving Senator Newman of some of her representational responsibilities so that she can at least begin to respond coherently to questions relating to her own portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) is of the opinion that, because of the discriminatory nature of the provisions of the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, it should not proceed to consider the measure further; and

(b) calls on the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice (Mr Williams) to have an alternative bill prepared and presented to the Senate in a form which does not discriminate against the people of any part of Australia and which would enable senators to vote according to their views on the issue of euthanasia on the basis of a possible uniform, national approach to the issue.
I acknowledge that the author of this motion is the Rt Hon. member for New England (Mr Sinclair).

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, at the request of the respective senators, I withdraw the following general business notices of motion:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

I also seek leave to have the report incorporated in Hansard .

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That government business order of the day No. 5 (Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, second reading) be considered from 12.45 p.m. till not later than 2.00 p.m. today.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Woodley)—by leave—agreed to:
That the time for the presentation of the report of the committee on a decision to purchase the Precision Aerial Delivery System (PADS) be extended to 27 February 1997.
Motion (by Senator Bourne, at the request of Senator Lees) agreed to:

That general business notice of motion No. 343 standing in the name of Senator Lees for today, proposing an order for the production of documents by the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, be postponed till 11 February 1997.
Motion (by Senator Bourne, also on behalf of Senators Hill, Faulkner, Harradine, Margetts and Colston), agreed to:
That the Senate—
(a) notes that 10 December is International Human Rights Day;
(b) recognises that human rights abuses continue to be a blight on a world where:

PARA.TAB: (i) communities which have lived for generations, or even centuries, are driven from their homes under programs of ethnic cleansing,
(ii) warlords dominate their societies with utter disregard for the good of the whole, causing violence, starvation and anarchy,
(iii) torture, detention without trial and disappearances are common aspects of many legal systems, and
(iv) minority groups are often forced to live under oppression, disadvantage and injustice;

PROCTEXT.PARA: (c) asserts its belief in the universality and indivisibility of human rights as defined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and reinforced in the covenants and conventions of the United Nations; and

(d) encourages the Government in its efforts to promote and protect human rights through active involvement in international forums and through consistent policies which encourage other nations to develop and maintain the rule of law and respect for the dignity of the human person.

Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I table explanatory memoranda to the bills and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
REFORM OF EMPLOYMENT SERVICES BILL 1996

In my August ministerial statement, Reforming Employment Assistance—Helping Australians into Real Jobs, I outlined the government's vision for the most radical changes to employment services since the establishment of the Commonwealth Employment Service in 1946. Since the release of that statement, the government has undertaken extensive consultations about the government's proposals with interested groups in the community across Australia.

In this sitting I am introducing a package of legislation to provide the statutory framework for implementing the government's reforms to employment services. As well as this bill, the package includes the reform of Employment Services (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1996 which would cover other matters required for the implementation of the government's reforms.
The Commonwealth services delivery agency bill 1996, which has been introduced in this sitting, completes the legislative framework for the reforms.
The primary objective of the government's reforms is to ensure that labour market assistance has a clear focus on real job outcomes and makes a genuine difference to those assisted.

This package of legislation would provide for reforming employment services in a way which is largely consistent with the feedback we have had from the community in that consultation process. At the same time the reforms remain true to the government's belief that labour market assistance must be made more effective by focusing clearly on real job outcomes and opening up the employment placement market to the advantages of competition.

The reforms to labour market services in the bills should also be seen in the broader context of the government's commitments to deficit reduction and budgetary discipline. These commitments are essential for increasing the growth capacity of the Australian economy and ultimately for delivering sustained reductions in unemployment.
. The government's structural reforms will produce an environment in which business, particularly small business, will continue to grow and create jobs.

. The Workplace Relations And Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 allows for more genuine enterprise bargaining, opening the way for more flexible workplace practices and greater productivity and international competitiveness.
. Microeconomic and regulatory reforms will reduce business costs and add to the competitiveness of Australian firms.

No government program can equal the benefit that will flow from getting Australia's economic policy setting right as the base for creating jobs. However, government together with private enterprise and community organisations can play an important role in equipping job seekers with the skills, experience and opportunities to benefit from real jobs growth.

Although the government's reforms are significant and far reaching, much of the machinery to achieve them is not new. We have built on previous arrangements which worked well—in particular individualised one‐to‐one assistance for disadvantaged job seekers. The referral procedures in this legislation for employment assistance have refined and streamlined the current referral procedures for case management. The numerous programs that were operating, either poorly or not at all, and that were, in many cases, simply churning job seekers through those programs without obtaining real outcomes, have been abolished.
My August statement outlined six principles for the reform of employment services. They were:
1. The assistance to job seekers should be based on their individual needs and their capacity to benefit from it in terms of achieving an employment outcome.
2. Providers should have access to flexible forms of assistance that fit the needs of job seekers.
3. The incentive framework should reward providers of labour market assistance primarily for placing job seekers in real jobs, with additional incentives for those most in need.
4. A competitive market for employment placement services should separate purchaser from providers and ensure that providers operate on the basis of competitive neutrality.
5. Conditions for payment of income support for unemployed people should be linked closely with active employment assistance measures.
6. Job seekers and employers should be able to receive high quality and streamlined service from the agencies and providers with which they interact.
This legislation is in keeping with these principles.

The aim of this legislation is to establish the mechanisms to deliver employment services and to establish a fully competitive market for employment assistance to job seekers. In particular, the bill would:
. Enable the Commonwealth to engage entities to provide employment services;

. Define the criteria for participation in the employment assistance scheme ( "employment assistance" as it is called in the bill was referred to as "intensive employment assistance" in my ministerial statement)
. Provide for the procedures for referring participants in the employment assistance scheme to employment placement enterprises (or EPES);
. Outline compliance requirements of job seekers under the bill;
. Allow for the investigation of complaints about the provision of employment services;
. Provide for the review of relevant decisions relating to employment assistance participation and referrals to EPES; and
. Include provisions to ensure the confidentiality of information concerning users of employment services.

This legislation would complement the Commonwealth services delivery agency bill 1996 that would establish and provide for the management and activities of the agency as a provider of integrated government services—social security and employment services in the first instance.

The bill would provide for the provision of "employment services". "employment services" means unemployment benefits within the meaning of paragraph 51(xxiiia) of the constitution. This encompasses both unemployment benefit payments and services which assist the unemployed. In the bill, "employment services" would include:
Self help assistance;
Labour exchange;
. Job search assistance;
. Employment assistance; and
. Entry level training support services.

Self help assistance would be available at the agency to all job seekers. It would include access to: job vacancy displays, other employment and training information and facilities such as computers and telephones.

In labour exchange services, employment services providers would canvass employers for job vacancies to be placed on the national vacancy data base. Providers would also match, refer and place eligible job seekers into vacancies on the data base.

Job search assistance would involve employment services providers delivering the sort of assistance currently provided by job clubs, such as training job seekers in effective job search techniques and providing access to facilities for intensive supported job search.

Employment assistance would be the most intensive form of assistance and would be similar to, but more flexible than, the current case management system. Employment assistance would be provided to eligible job seekers by EPES contracted by the Commonwealth.

Entry level training support services are those services (except labour exchange) which would be provided to eligible job seekers and employers to assist entry into traineeships and apprenticeships. These services would be provided by employment services providers or other contracted agencies.

The legislation would enable the Commonwealth services delivery agency to enter into an agreement with the employment secretary to provide employment services. Under this agreement, and an agreement with the social security secretary, the agency would:
. Register, assess and refer job seekers to further assistance;
. Provide job seekers with self help job search facilities; and
. Activity test job seekers and apply deferment period provisions under the Social Security Act 1991.

The legislation would enable the employment secretary, on behalf of the Commonwealth, to contract entities to provide employment services, including employment assistance. In line with the government's requirement for competitive neutrality in the employment services market, the legislation does not distinguish among private and community providers and the public EPE.
The public EPE will be a company incorporated under the corporations law.

The legislation would also provide for the minister for employment, education, training and youth affairs to make a written determination specifying what matters the employment secretary should take into account when engaging an EPE to provide employment assistance and the procedures which the employment secretary should follow when so deciding.

Employment services providers are to compete for contracts to provide employment services which would be awarded by tender. Selection is to be based on performance, quality and value for money. For labour exchange and employment assistance, providers will largely be paid for getting job seekers into real jobs. In the case of employment assistance there will be higher payments for more disadvantaged clients.

Tenders are to be awarded to entities which have a demonstrated ability or experience to provide the sorts of services required. However, we also want to see credible new private and community players enter the market.

We must also ensure that all areas have access to high quality employment services. Therefore in those regions where standard tendering on an outcomes basis proves unworkable (particularly some rural and remote areas) my department is intending to invite providers to tender on a fee‐for‐service basis. As a last resort it is intended that the minister for employment, education, training and youth affairs will be able to direct the public EPE to provide such employment services as are necessary in the public interest. The Commonwealth will be required to pay the reasonable costs of the public EPE providing this community service obligation.

Under the legislation, EPES could not charge participants for providing them with employment assistance. This does not preclude EPES from charging non‐participants for similar services. This may provide an additional revenue source for EPES.

The government's intention is for employment assistance is to be based on an assessment of the personal needs of each job seeker. Its aim is to enable that person to gain employment or improve their employment prospects. The legislation would provide for the minister for employment, education, training and youth affairs to make a written determination of services which will be taken to be the provision of employment assistance. Assistance may involve training, job search assistance, wage subsidies or other innovative and flexible forms of assistance. EPES would be free to decide with the participant the optimal kinds and mix of assistance needed to get the participant a job. Participants would generally receive employment assistance for 12 months, although extensions will be allowed in particular circumstances.

The agency would be responsible, on behalf of the employment secretary, for deciding which job seekers would be participants in the employment assistance scheme. The agreement between the employment secretary and the agency will specify guidelines for this purpose.

My ministerial statement indicated that (intensive) employment assistance eligibility should be confined to job seekers who have been unemployed for 12 months or more or are assessed as at high risk of long‐term unemployment, and who are:

A recipient of a qualifying DSS income support allowance (Newstart allowance, youth training allowance, sole parent pension, disability support pension and other forms of DSS income support but excluding age pension and mature age allowance); or
A participant in a community development employment project; or
An unemployed young person aged 15 to 20 years and not in receipt of income support.

The legislation would provide for the minister for employment, education, training and youth affairs to make a written determination specifying eligibility criteria for employment assistance. The initial determination will include the criteria I have just listed.

As well, the minister may include in this determination events or circumstances which disqualify people from employment assistance eligibility. The determination may also include matters to be taken into account by the agency, on behalf of the employment secretary, when determining a person is not eligible for employment assistance. This provision would allow the minister to specify criteria which would disqualify a person from employment assistance eligibility on the basis that the person is judged not able to benefit from employment assistance.

Because employment assistance is the most costly employment service, the government is concerned that places be directed to those job seekers who are most in need and who have capacity to benefit from the assistance. For this reason, the legislation would provide discretion on the part of the agency, on behalf of the employment secretary, to ration the flow of people eligible for employment assistance into employment assistance participation. Eligibility for employment assistance does not imply automatic or immediate access to employment assistance.
The referral process for employment assistance that would be provided for in the legislation is as follows.
Staff in the agency would be acting under the authority delegated by the employment secretary.

Depending on available employment assistance places, the agency would notify in writing a job seeker who is eligible for employment assistance (or who is likely to become eligible) to attend an interview. Generally this interview would be with the agency. However, the agency may nominate another person to conduct the interview. This could be, for example, if the agency considers that the person should have a professional assessment of barriers to employment. If the agency considers that the person could reasonably be referred to an EPE for employment assistance, the person must be notified in writing that he or she is now a participant in the employment assistance scheme and should choose an EPE. Whether a person could reasonably be referred to an EPE would often depend upon whether there are sufficient employment assistance places available.

To ensure that participants are fully aware of their rights and obligations, the legislation would provide that the participant must be given written information about employment assistance and informed that he or she will be required to enter into an employment assistance activity agreement (EAAA).
. The EAAA is an agreement negotiated between the participant and the EPE setting out a program of activities aimed at getting the participant a job.
The circumstances under which a person ceases to be a participant will be specified in a ministerial determination. These are expected to include circumstances in which the person:
. Obtains full‐time employment for 26 weeks or more, or other outcome attracting an outcome payment;
. Is assessed as having no capacity to benefit from employment assistance; or
. Fails to enter into or comply with their EAAA without a reasonable excuse; or
. Reaches the conclusion of the agreed period of employment assistance.

If a job seeker is in receipt of Newstart allowance or youth training allowance and fails to attend an interview without a reasonable excuse, he or she may lose qualification for allowance for a period. This provision underlines the importance the government attaches to job seekers taking advantage of the opportunity to participate in employment assistance.

If there is more than one EPE to which a participant could reasonably be referred, the legislation would provide that the participant be given the opportunity to nominate the EPE he or she would prefer. The agency would refer the participant to his or her nominated EPE if it is reasonable to do so. Otherwise, the agency would nominate an EPE for that participant. The agency would also nominate an EPE for those clients who do not express a preference.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Special needs assessment and community support program

SPEECH.PARA: In my ministerial statement I flagged the concept of "capacity to benefit". The public consultation process revealed a community concern that in applying the notion of "capacity to benefit" from employment assistance, the government would permanently exclude some very disadvantaged people from employment assistance and deny them any form of government assistance other than income support.
This is not the case.
After discussions with community sector representatives the government has decided that what is really at issue here is the necessity for some job seekers to have a special needs assessment.
This is not intended to mean that some people will be put on the scrapheap.
It means that the government recognises that it is not fair to require some unemployed people to go through the hoops of preparing for employment when they are in no position to hold down a job.
The vast majority of unemployed people will not require this special needs assessment.

Where a special needs assessment is judged to be required, it will be a formal and objective assessment of a job seeker's personal characteristics to see whether employment assistance of the type and level able to be offered is really fitting for their special needs. The assessment will be administered by specialist or professionally qualified staff in the agency or by expert external providers.

The legislation would provide for a framework within which the agency could refer a person to the new community support program in order to gain assistance in accessing services that will address disadvantages that are acting as a barrier to achieving employment.

Under the community support program people found not ready to benefit from employment assistance will access more suitable and well coordinated Commonwealth, state or community services. Assistance could include drug or alcohol rehabilitation programs, other activities addressing significant or debilitating personal development needs, counselling and assistance with accessing and maintaining stable accommodation. The community support program will ensure that the government is not neglecting its responsibility to assist job seekers who are not ready to benefit from employment assistance. If a job seeker's personal circumstances change during participation in the community support program, eligibility for employment assistance would be reviewed. Similarly, if following participation in the community support program a person's circumstances change so as to allow them to benefit from employment assistance they will become eligible.

The legislation would require participants to enter into an EAAA with the EPE providing their employment assistance. As well as setting out activities aimed at getting the participant a job or improving their employment prospects (such as paid work experience or training), the EAAA would set out the rights and responsibilities of the EPE and job seeker and the timeframe for completing these activities. The terms of the EAAA must take into account the participant's capacity to comply with the agreement, such as their education and the state of the local labour market.

The legislation would require the participant to negotiate and comply with their EAAA. For participants who are in receipt of Newstart allowance or youth training allowance (the majority of participants) the legislation provides that an EAAA would take the place of the Newstart activity agreement for the purposes of the Social Security Act 1991 and the youth training activity agreement in the Student And Youth Assistance Act 1973. For these participants, failure to enter into or comply with an EAAA without a reasonable excuse may result in the loss of allowance for some period of time.

Employment assistance participants who are in receipt of unemployment allowances are required under the legislation to inform the employment secretary of circumstances affecting their compliance with their EAAA. EPES and participants must give the employment secretary information about compliance with the EAAA if requested to do so in writing. This allows the agency to check EAAA compliance if necessary.
The EAAA would provide the clear basis for any penalty imposed on the participant for non‐compliance but it also protects a participant against any unreasonable demands by the EPE.

Officers in the agency, acting in accordance with delegation under the Social Security Act 1991, would be responsible for deciding whether to breach a participant in receipt of an unemployment allowance for failure to enter into an EAAA or for failure to comply with the EAAA, taking into account advice from the EPE.

The legislation would secure the Commonwealth's access to information to enable it to both monitor compliance with contractual arrangements and meet accountability requirements. Because a wide ranging evaluation will be essential to assess the effectiveness of these comprehensive reforms, the legislation also enables the Commonwealth to access information for more general monitoring and evaluation purposes. Monitoring and evaluation data will assist in the promulgation of best practice. This will enable a more effective employment placement market to develop and facilitate the continuous improvement of employment services.

The legislation would provide for the minister to establish a national advisory committee to advise the employment secretary on the provision of employment services. It would also provide for the establishment of regionally‐based area committees which would advise the employment secretary on employment and training opportunities, increase my department's responsiveness to regional labour markets and facilitate links between my department's programs and regional development.
The other provisions in the bill provide for the normal protections and accountability mechanisms for the government, service providers and job seekers that would be expected in such legislation.
These provisions include:
. The means to ensure the confidentiality of information concerning users of employment services;

. Mechanisms within my department to investigate a job seeker's complaint about employment services provided by the agency or an EPE. These mechanisms would also enable the investigation of complaints by an EPE about the referral of employment assistance participants to the EPE by the agency; and
. Appropriate access to review of decisions relating to employment assistance, including access to appeal to the social security appeals tribunal and the administrative appeals tribunal.

The government is firmly committed to making radical and comprehensive changes in the policy framework for labour market assistance for unemployed Australians. Where former policies were working poorly, or in some cases not at all, we have not hesitated to discard them or change them radically. This package of legislation does not represent change for change's sake, for, where former policies were sound and working well, the government has maintained and enhanced them, so that we have embraced the concepts of
. Personalised case management, and assistance tailored to individual needs and circumstances
. Targeting assistance to those most disadvantaged in the labour market
. Using competition to drive improvements in quality, performance and price.

The legislative package, and the associated reform actions, is designed to deliver a better quality of service for unemployed Australians, better and more sustainable outcomes, and better value for money. The bill represents innovative and exciting reforms which offer benefits to all Australians.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
REFORM OF EMPLOYMENT SERVICES (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1996
This bill would make consequential amendments arising from the reform of Employment Services Bill 1996.

The bill would repeal the Employment Services Act 1994, which established the present case management system, the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), Employment Assistance Australia and the Employment Services Regulatory Authority. The case management system would be replaced by new arrangements for the delivery of employment services proposed under the reform of Employment Services Bill 1996.

The bill would provide for the extension of the Privacy Act 1988 to the provision of employment services by entities engaged by the Commonwealth in the same way in which that act presently applies to case management services provided by case managers.

Amendments to the Freedom Of Information Act 1982 provide for members of the public to have rights of access to documents relating to the provision of employment services by entities engaged by the Commonwealth in the same way in they presently have under the case management system.

The bill would also provide for the ombudsman to investigate complaints about the provision of employment services. The ombudsman would be able to refer those complaints to the employment secretary where it is considered the complaint could be more appropriately dealt with by my department.

The ombudsman would be able to provide information on matters relevant to the provision of employment services to the employment secretary without the need to make a formal report to the responsible minister in all cases.
The bill would also amend a number of other acts as a consequence of the abolition of the CES.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of these bills be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the Autumn sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced:
A bill for an act to amend the law relating to fisheries, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The purpose of this bill is to make a number of amendments to enhance the Fisheries Administration Act 1991, the Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984.

The Fisheries Administration Act and the Fisheries Management Act came into effect in February 1992 and the proposed amendments seek to correct minor anomalies in them that have been identified over the last 4 years, streamline their administration and generally improve the efficiency of fisheries management.
With regard to the Fisheries Administration Act, a number of the proposed amendments seek to clarify the wording to put beyond doubt the original intention

About the functions of the australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA). In particular, the amendments make it explicit that AFMA is not only to devise but also to manage and carry out, adjustment, restructuring, exploratory and feasibility fishing programs. Secondly, AFMA is to have the function of providing expertise to and exchanging information with states and territories as well as overseas bodies having functions similar to AFMA.
Another amendment provides for the maximum period for which a person can serve consecutive terms as a director of AFMA to be expressed in years instead of as a number of terms.

A number of further amendments specify arrangements under which subcommittees to fisheries management advisory committees may be established and operate. A minor consequential amendment is also made to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 to enable that tribunal to determine travelling allowances payable to management advisory committee and subcommittee members.
In both the Fisheries Administration Act and the Fisheries Management Act, some definitions are clarified and some new definitions are added.

As far as the Fisheries Management Act is concerned, one of the most significant amendments gives effect to the government's policy announced before the last election to provide greater security of long term access to fisheries. The purpose of these amendment is to protect the fishing industry against changes in government or administrative policy which the revocation of management plans might otherwise entail. This will give greater security of investment to both fishing operators and financiers. Under the amendments, where a management plan for a fishery is revoked, any subsequent plan that covers all or part of that fishery must provide that holders of statutory fishing rights at the time of the revocation will have first option on a proportional basis to similar rights granted under that subsequent plan.

Other amendments to the management act seek to improve arrangements for the registration of interests and dealings in statutory fishing rights and administrative arrangements in respect of fisheries which are managed by a fisheries joint authority under commonwealth law.

Fisheries joint authorities provide one type of arrangement for achieving co-operation between the commonwealth, the states and the northern territory in the management of fisheries. Joint authorities are bodies consisting of commonwealth and state or territory ministers responsible for fisheries.
As things stand, the ministers in the joint authority may delegate powers to AFMA, but AFMA has no intrinsic powers in the management of joint authority fisheries.

The philosophy of the management act is to divorce the commonwealth minister from day-to-day management decisions and, to this end, the primary function of the minister in relation to commonwealth fisheries is to accept plans of management determined by AFMA. This is not the case with joint authority fisheries and, after due consultation with the states, the amendments seek to rectify this anomaly.

The bill therefore amends the management act to create the same relationship between AFMA and joint authorities as it has with the commonwealth minister in-respect of other commonwealth-managed fisheries.

The remaining amendments to the Fisheries Management Act focus on various enforcement, penalty and related provisions, a number of which arise from recommendations made in the 1993 report fisheries reviewed by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

One of these amendments relates to the powers of officers to enter land or premises specified in a fish receiver permit. Currently, an officer may enter such premises only with the consent of the holder of the fish receiver permit or under a warrant.

It is proposed to amend the act to enable officers to enter premises subject to a fish receiver permit for monitoring purposes at any time without the requirement for either consent or warrant and to secure property pending the obtaining of a warrant. However, the power to seize property or documents will still be conditional on the officer having a warrant.

Tn other circumstances, where a warrant is required for a search to be conducted, there has been criticism that the obtaining of warrants under section 85 of the management act is cumbersome compared to obtaining warrants under the Crimes Act 1914. The bill amends the act so that it reflects the crimes act provisions.

Section 95 provides for various offences which, with the exception of offences relating to foreign boats, are dealt with summarily and attract maximum fines of $10,000. This level off penalty is inadequate when the commission of single offences can net the offender in excess of $100,000.

Amendments to section 95 increase the level of penalties, those currently at $10,000 to $25,000, those currently at $5,000 to $12,500 and those currently at $2,000 to $5,000. Maximum fines applicable to certain offences involving the use of foreign boats are set at $50,000 and there is no intention to raise these penalties. However, in line with commonwealth criminal law policy as expressed in the crimes act, opportunity is taken to express all penalties as penalty units, currently with the value of $100 per unit. This enables a change to the unit value in the crimes act to have effect in all commonwealth legislation in which penalties are expressed in these units.

The Torres Strait Fisheries Act, being of earlier origin, lacks some of the features included in the administration and management acts. It is proposed to amend the torres strait act to give the torres strait protected zone joint authority one of the powers considered central to modern fisheries management, namely the power to make management plans. These amendments envisage the making of management plans for torres strait fisheries based on units of fishing capacity, which could be based on inputs or outputs. The amended provisions are in line with commonwealth government policy that aims to eventually bring all
Commonwealth-controlled fisheries under arrangements based on a management plan.
I commend this bill to honourable Senators and I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the Autumn sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced:
A bill for an act to amend legislation relating to the environment, sport and Territories, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

The purpose of the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 is to make amendments to portfolio legislation and to make amendments to other legislation affecting the portfolio.

The Honourable Warwick Smith MP, Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government announced on 4 June 1996 that the National Capital Planning Authority would be known as the National Capital Authority reflecting a greater emphasis on the Authority's statutory responsibility for fostering an awareness of Canberra as the National Capital. The new name more accurately encompasses the broad responsibilities of the organisation in representing the Commonwealth's ongoing interests in the Australian Capital Territory. As well as planning, the Authority has land and asset management responsibilities and has taken over the role of coordinating the Commonwealth's interests in the promotion and marketing of the National Capital and the integration of such activities with tourism strategies. The new name has been in use for non‐statutory functions since 1 July 1996, and the amendment to the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988 will enable its use for statutory functions.

Amendments to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990 contained in this bill include a provision which will enable the Agency to charge a fee where services for and related to drug testing and educational services are provided on a commercial basis.
The Agency provides a commercial drug testing service in addition to its public interest drug testing program conducted as part of the Agency's statutory obligations.

During 1995‐96 over 950 tests were conducted by the Agency on a `user‐pays' basis representing over one third of the Agency's annual tests. Under its commercial drug testing program the Agency has entered into contracts with national sports leagues such as the Australian Football League and the Australian Rugby League and, international sporting organisations. The Agency conducted drug testing at the 1996 World Junior Athletics Championships and at the 1996 International Herald Sun and Commonwealth Bank Cycle tours.

By charging for selected services the amendment will enhance the Agency's ability to further contract professional and international sporting organisations. It will enable the Agency to respond to the demand for drug testing especially in light of the increase in professional sporting competitions conducted by Australian sporting organisations within and outside Australia and the increase in international competitors training or competing in Australia in the lead up to the 2000 Olympic Games.

The integrity of Australia's sports drug testing programs are recognised throughout the world. The Government is committed to the work of the Australian Sports Drug Agency and the betterment of its programs in the lead up to the 2000 Games. The bill will also amend the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990 to provide that a competitor who interferes with a sample by deliberately disrupting the sample collection and sealing process in an attempt to compromise the integrity and accuracy of the sample may be penalised. The inclusion of an act of wilful interference as a doping offence will further enhance the integrity of the Agency's drug testing program and ensure that fairness and equity between competitors is maintained.

The bill makes amendments to the Coral Sea Islands Act 1969. Australia exercises sovereignty over the islands on Elizabeth and Middleton Reefs which are located approximately 600 kilometres to the east of continental Australia and 150 km north of Lord Howe Island. Those reefs already form part of a marine nature reserve established under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. The proposed amendments to the Coral Sea Islands Act 1969 as part of this portfolio bill will incorporate the Australian islands on these reefs into the Coral Sea Islands Territory and thus ensure that there is an adequate system of laws applying to those islands.

This bill makes a number of amendments to the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992. It removes a tautology in the present definition of an "ecological community", and also clarifies the assessment of an "endangered ecological community".

The period within which the Minister must gazette any new inclusion of Endangered Species or Vulnerable Species or other amendments to the Schedules to the act is extended to 90 days from the time the Minister receives advice from the independent Endangered Species Scientific Subcommittee. The increase will allow adequate time for the Minister to make a decision and also recognises the requirement at subsection 23(4) for the Minister to consult with Commonwealth agencies when considering the listing of a key threatening process.

The Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 regulates the substances that can be dumped at sea. The proposed amendments to that act will bring it into line with current practice and ensure that Australia can meet its international obligations agreed at the November 1993 Consultative Meeting of the London Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, known as the London Convention. The amendments are long overdue given that most of the international obligations which flow from the 1993 agreements have already entered into force in Australia.

Current Australian practice does now allow the dumping at sea of radioactive waste or material, nor the incineration of wastes at sea. The amendments bring the act into line with the current practice, with a revised definition of radioactivity (above exempt levels as defined by the International Atomic Energy Agency), and the prohibition of incineration of sewage sludge and industrial wastes at sea.

The ban on dumping of industrial waste at sea came into effect internationally on 1 January 1996. Except for jarosite, Australia does not dump industrial waste at sea. Australia applied to the London Convention for an exemption from this ban to allow dumping of jarosite for a limited time, to the end of December 1997, to allow alternative processes of the waste to be developed.

The amendments also allow for Public Environment Report (PER) processes under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, in relation to an application under the Sea Dumping Act. The Sea Dumping Act already provides for an Inquiry and an Environmental Impact Statement directed under the EP(IP) Act. The proposed amendments will extend the running of the statutory period under the Sea Dumping Act to allow for the completion of procedures relating to a PER under the EP(IP) Act. Other changes to the act are `housekeeping' amendments intended to remove anomalies between existing text and the present amendments.

The bill proposes a number of amendments to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 to correct drafting errors, remove redundant provisions and effect a number of substantive changes. In particular, the bill makes changes to s.38J to clarify upon whom obligations are imposed in relation to the discharge of waste in the Marine Park, with particular application to Defence vessels and aircraft, to avoid an unintended result. Presently, discharges from Defence vessels and aircraft for the purposes of combating pollution incidents or saving lives are not lawful under the operation of s.38J. The provisions in this section were originally not intended to apply to Defence vessels and aircraft, because their activities are closely controlled by Marine Park Zoning plans. The correction of this anomaly will not have an adverse effect on the Park itself. The Zoning Plans allow for the conduct of defence operations in the Park, subject to the reasonable directions of the Marine Park Authority. The Marine Park Authority has worked closely with the Australian Defence Force on matters concerning the Marine Park. This means for example that the Navy's operational guidelines dealing with discharges of waste exceed the standards required of tourism operators. In addition, the Royal Australian Navy has spent around $50 million upgrading existing shipping to meet the requirements of Annex 4 of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships 1973 known as the MARPOL Convention, even though the element of the MARPOL Convention which deals with the discharge of sewage is not yet in force internationally. Given that the Zoning Plans are binding on the Commonwealth, there is already sufficient control over discharges from Defence vessels and aircraft, justifying their exemption from s.38J.

The bill also makes provision for the power of delegation for the Minister under section 7A. Section 7A of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act allows for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to provide assistance to other institutions or persons on matters of environmental management. However such assistance must have the approval of the Minister administering the act. The act prevents approval from being given where the provision of assistance would adversely affect the ability of the Authority to perform its functions under that act.

This amendment allows the Minister responsible for administering the act to delegate his or her powers to grant such an approval to the Authority or the Chairperson of the Authority. In exercising the delegation, the Authority or the Chairperson would be required to apply the same test as the Minister in determining whether to approve the provision of assistance.

The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is an acknowledged world leader in the area of marine management, and the ability of the Authority to provide assistance on this issue on a cost recovery basis to other institutions and persons both nationally and internationally enhances that reputation. It also allows the Authority to take advantage of new ideas and approaches in other areas and modify its approach here in Australia to ensure the best management approach for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. I am of the view that a delegation to the Chairperson of the Authority would be both logistically efficient and accountable.

Finally, with respect to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, proposed amendments will clarify the scope of enforcement provisions which may be made under Plans of Management. The first of the Plans of Management prepared under the 1995 amendments, dealing with the protection of dugong in Shoalwater Bay, will soon be put into effect.

The bill includes minor amendments to extend the Customs Act 1901, the Quarantine Act 1908 and the Migration Act 1958 so that the provisions of those acts may be applied to the Commonwealth Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands. There has been an increase in unauthorised arrivals on the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands. The Government proposes to amend these acts to provide a legal basis for border control, including over possible importation of drugs, for control over vermin and the import of diseased wood or fibres. It also provides a sound platform for the orderly management of persons arriving in the Territory.
The bill makes amendments to the Ozone Protection Act 1989 to clarify matters arising from drafting errors.

The Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area Conservation Act 1994 is amended to update a reference to an Agreement made between the Commonwealth and Queensland, to make clear that it includes that Agreement as amended.

The amendments will not have any significant financial impact, though a minor increase in revenue could result from the amendments to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990 which enable the Agency to raise fees for its services rendered on a commercial basis.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the Autumn sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.
