SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: No. 1—That regulations 1 to 6 (inclusive) of the AUSTUDY Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 261 and made under the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.
No. 2—That regulation 7 of the AUSTUDY Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 261 and made under the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

In moving these two motions together, and recognising that there is only 10 minutes for my contribution this morning, I say that the opposition sees these two government proposals as indicative of the mean spirited approach they are taking to students in the whole education sector. We are talking here of proposals such as these coming as part of a package of an attack on the education sector, which has led to some $1.9 billion in cuts and, in respect of students, some $800 million being taken out of their pockets over a short period.

What the government has sought to do by the regulations that are subject to the disallowance is to increase the age of independence and, in doing so, to reverse an important reform of the previous government which brought the age down from 25 to 22 in three annual steps starting in 1992. The presumption that people up to their mid‐20s have a relationship of financial dependence on their parents is patently untenable. Before we reduced the age limit, it was very much one of the two top priorities of student organisations in their annual budget submissions. To reverse it now, to try to argue that students in their mid-20s should be presumed to have a financial relationship of dependency on their parents, is patently untenable.

What we have here, basically, essentially and starkly, is a grab for cash. It is a baseless excuse to try to argue that students are dependent. The real agenda here can be exposed to be the fact that the original decision in the budget papers would have saved some $242 million from students' pockets over the course of the forward estimates. That decision has been amended slightly. What we are talking about now is savings of some $210 million through the forward estimates.

The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), in the budget statement, referred to this measure targeting the well‐off families. This is double speak. It comes from the minister for double speak. Essentially, the families we are talking about here are families that have very modest incomes. Remember, Austudy starts to taper off at a joint family income of some $22,650.

We are also talking here of a growing number of people who can be classified as being Howard's losers. Some 14,000 people will have their payments reduced and some 12,000 will become totally ineligible for payments. So it is a grab for cash. No matter how the minister tries to justify it, no matter how she tries to describe it, no matter what language is used in the budget statements in terms of targeting well‐off families, we are talking here of ripping some $210 million from students on the pretence that they should be presumed to be financially dependent on their parents until they are in their mid-20s.

That is the first of my two disallowance motions for this morning. The issues are pretty simple. It is a matter of judgment for the Senate as to whether we dig our heads into the sand and argue that people should be presumed to be financially dependent on their parents up to that age.

The second motion goes to regulations which are, I think, particularly mean spirited and particularly devastating in their impact. I have had a number of students come to see me over my years as a member of parliament—students who cannot live at home, students who have been forced out of their homes for one reason or another, and students who are very keen and have been very keen to continue with their secondary education.

You get some real heart wrenching cases. Time and time again, you look at their statistics, you look at their income, you look at what they need to keep them at school, what they need to basically realise their ambitions of finishing year 12 and going on thereafter, and quite often it is a little amount of assistance that is needed to either buy the books or give them the capacity to stay at school. If they do not get that assistance, they are forced into taking unemployment benefits or they are forced into leaving school and seeking work.

It is a vicious circle that they find themselves in. Quite often, I have gone through situations with young people and tried to work out with them their income and how we can top up that income. What the previous government did was to introduce a schooling incidentals allowance. It is an allowance which is paid to homeless secondary students, an allowance which cost some $11 million over four forward estimate years, which is what we are arguing about here, and a measure which is assisting some 8,500 students—students living basically on the breadline. What the government is seeking to do is to take away this financial assistance of some $300, payable at the beginning of each year, to help homeless Austudy and Abstudy students complete their secondary education by assisting with such expenses as books, equipment and course costs.

This measure was going to have full effect from the beginning of this year. It is obviously justified as a measure that helps young people at critical times. It is much more important to them than it is to the budget revenue outlays. It is much more important for individual students. I just cannot understand the logic behind taking this particular measure away from young people, who find it quite critical. The government says that it will be abolished subsequent to a review of 1995-96 budget measures. But there really has not been a comprehensive review about this. Once again, the minister for double speak is coming in here and saying, `Well, we have reviewed it and it should go.'

In essence, we are talking about depriving people of assistance—people who critically need it. We are also talking about a self-defeating measure. You force kids out of school, they have to go on unemployment benefits, they have to seek work and at the end of the day it costs government more by withdrawing this sort of measure. This is the same group that will be hit by another exceptionally mean budget measure—that is, the cessation of case management of secondary students who are on the student homeless rate of Austudy or Abstudy. That measures saves $14½ million. The government says, `Oh no, we are going to maintain or re-establish the job placement employment training program. That will cost us $11 million.' You are still talking about a big reduction of funds—some 25 per cent—as opposed to the previous measure that was in place.

I just cannot work out how a minister for education can deprive young people—people on the borderline—of assistance in this particular instance. Case management of young students is basically geared towards achieving family reconciliation, assistance to them and working out their particular needs. That measure has gone. With it has gone the supplementary measure, which is quite critical. We are talking here of $11 million over the forward estimate years. As I said, it means nothing in terms of the budget bottom line but it means a hell of a lot to young people who are forced to make hard decisions based on, quite often, less than $100 that they need to keep them at school.

The opposition is keen to ensure that these two sets of regulations go down this morning. We cannot see any justification for them. We see them as particularly mean-spirited. We also see them as having no justification in a policy sense. No matter what the minister says about them, no matter how the government tries to argue that they are ripping money away from well-off families, that is just not the truth, and they should not continue with that particular line.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the disallowance motions put forward by the opposition today. On many occasions we have expressed our concerns and our opposition to the increase in the independent rate age—that is, from 22 years to 25 years. Senator Bolkus is quite right—the matter of the age at which students are eligible for the Austudy independent rate has been one of the top priorities for student organisations for many years. Indeed, I remember lobbying Senator Bolkus on this very issue quite a few years ago as a student. The ALP certainly took its time to reduce the age of eligibility. It had actually reached a point where it was 22 years. We supported that, although we continue to have concerns about the lack of parity between the Austudy benefits level and that of unemployment benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats also oppose what Senator Bolkus has described as a mean-spirited measure, but certainly one that we consider quite callous—that is, the proposal by this government to remove the schooling incidentals allowance. It was only introduced this year, providing $300 to secondary school students receiving the homeless independent rate of Austudy. Senator Bolkus pointed out that this was a measure designed to assist students in that category, with the purchase of books and equipment.

We find the removal of such money particularly repugnant in light of recent findings and the report School students at risk—one that people in this place may be aware of—that was released this week. This report challenges the common perception that homeless youth are somehow all street kids, saying that homeless school students often move between various forms of temporary accommodation. This report called on schools and governments to become more caring institutions. Certainly that caring element is not reflected in the measures before us proposed by this government. The report also found that up to 14 per cent of high school students are at risk in this nation and the greatest proportion of those students who were at risk were in years 10 to 12.

The removal of a one-off grant—$300—for books, paper and all the other requirements that a student needs at the beginning of the school year, we consider quite miserly and mean-spirited. It is certainly not the act of a caring institution. In light of the radical and unfair changes to the higher education sector—the changes that passed this place within the past week—we must remember that student financial assistance, be it in the form of Austudy, Abstudy or TEAS, its predecessor, has proven that it has been shown to be a key factor in ensuring that traditionally disadvantaged groups, particularly young people from lower socio-economic backgrounds, have had a shot at education, at a TAFE level, at secondary school and at a tertiary level.

What we are talking about here is something quite fundamental to ensuring a degree of access and equity in our higher education and secondary school systems. We are talking about removing one of the very props that assist those students to enter education at a number of levels. We consider the removal of the schooling incidentals allowance, combined with the increase in the independent rate age, to be two promises not only that the coalition has broken but ones that will have a devastating impact on current students as well as aspiring students. It is worth remembering that the coalition government went to the last election promising that they would maintain Austudy. They certainly made a lot of promises in the education sector, which have since been broken. I plead with the government that this is one area in which you should certainly not be breaking those promises.

As Senator Bolkus outlined, the current age for the Austudy independent rate is 22. That in itself we consider an anomaly. We know that young adults pay the same kind of living expenses as other adults, whether they are 18 or 25. At 18, 21 or 25 you incur the same living costs as an adult. I think that that is perhaps a wider debate that we should have at some point in this chamber—at what age are young people classified as independent and adult in this community, because it is quite an anomaly that you have to be 25—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty-one in this place.

—Or 31 in this place, as Senator Brown suggests. We are not talking about a luxurious benefit. We should never forget that Austudy—and I am sure the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) will remind us of this—was designed as an income supplement, but we have moved away from that even. Let us not forget that the majority of students who obtain Austudy are living on 38 per cent of the poverty line and the independent rate is around 68 per cent of the poverty line.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that when TEAS—the forerunner to Austudy—was introduced back in the 1970s it was at 117 per cent of unemployment benefits. These days even the maximum Austudy allowance at the independent rate is well below the single rate of unemployment benefit, and we do know that most students receive far less than this.

The millionaire Wright family was splashed across the headlines of papers many months ago. We have all debated long and hard the mythical Wright family and we threw in a couple of kids and a Range Rover. But that sinister example put to the estimates committee perpetuated some kind of stereotype that Austudy was both easy to access and plentiful in its benefit—neither is the case.

Research this week demonstrates this quite markedly. Academics from Monash University who are well known for their work on Austudy—and I refer to Ian Dobson and Bob Birrell—show us the impact of the proposed changes—that is, the increase in the age rate from 22 to 25. Dobson and Birrell in their document, People and place, Vol. 4, No. 1, page 81, show us that 60,000 current higher education students will be affected in some way by this change. This is a lot of young Australians. They will receive lower benefits or they will become ineligible for Austudy. The impact will worsen as the age of independence changes—it will become further entrenched.

BREAK.PARA: Again I ask the minister—this is a question I have asked before and in estimate committee hearings—is it still the case that the eligibility for the independent rate will be assessed at the point of enrolment? That is, you could be 24 years and nine months old—that is, below the age of 25—enrolled in a course, do that course for two, three, four, five or even six years, and you could be a 30‐year‐old and still not be deemed eligible for the independent rate. I have had no satisfactory answer to that question. I again ask the minister to explain if it is the case that students' eligibility will no longer be assessed on their birth date, but at their point of enrolment.

In October 1996, 50,305 students were in the 22‐ to 24‐year age group. While they have apparently been protected by the grandfathering of these changes to the age of independence, we can reasonably expect that a similar number of students will be dealt a harsh blow by the passage of these regulations in the near future. We can also assume that a substantial proportion of the 16,269 students over 25 years of age in 1996 and who started their course prior to turning 25 would be deemed still dependent on their parents' income under the proposed new rules.

Dobson and Birrell predict that 17 per cent of those currently in receipt of Austudy—nearly one‐fifth—would become ineligible and over 50 per cent would have their benefits reduced. We are talking about thousands and thousands of young Australians, both students and aspiring students.

Already it is not easy to be eligible for the independent rate. To be eligible for the independent rate, one requirement is that you have to have worked 35 hours per week for three years out of the last four years. This discriminates against those who maintain their independence through part-time or casual work—something I would have thought this government would have promoted for young Australians; certainly, that is the impression I get from the Minister for Social Security.

So, as Senator Bolkus pointed out, with massive changes to the labour market and high levels of youth unemployment, it is crazy that we should be making these changes. These changes, coupled with those radical and regressive changes to the higher education system last week, will further put education at every level out of the hands of those disadvantaged in our community. It is now time to stop using young Australians as a means of plugging this government's black hole.

I urge the minister to respond to that question about eligibility being at the point of enrolment. I hope that other senators in this place will support the disallowance motion before us today and give those young Australians aspiring to be educated through our system some hope for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with the previous speakers, and the Australian Greens will support the disallowance motion moved by Senator Bolkus. I think the reasons have been already well canvassed. Listening to Senator Stott Despoja I am reminded that it was not until the 1930s that the world shook off the idea that women should not have the vote until they were 32 years old. It was okay for men at 21 years of age, but not for women until 32 years of age.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) is trying to reinstitute the philosophy of the early part of this century that people are not independent minded until they get to the age of 31 or 32. She is at least taking the sexism out of it. She is going to ensure that men are also recognised as being unable to think for themselves, act for themselves and be independent until they get to the age of 31 or 32; they are still tied to the parents' strings at home and should not be getting any recognition for independent means or assistance to be independent.

Whilst Senator Vanstone may not have got it quite right, at least she is evening up the discriminatory idea that people over 25 who have got into their course before they turn 25—even if it is a six-year course—are tied to their parents and should not be recognised as independent and, therefore, should have their Austudy allowance cut out. It seems pretty mean and silly, and it is going to hurt a lot of people.

BREAK.PARA: However, I wanted to talk a little more about the abolition of the schooling incidentals allowance, which is $300 to be given for books and incidentals to assist those kids who, through no fault of their own, are down on their luck in our community but want to make a go of it.

This government is supposed to be about assisting those who will help themselves. It parades at the top of the masthead the idea that enterprise should be given every assistance. But here we have those Australians who are having a tough time. They are very often on the emotional roller-coaster of their teen years. They have often lost contact with or the support of parents and frequently have come from abusive households. They are out on the streets or they are certainly away from the supportive family background that gives people the full right to opportunity. Here is $300 to help them get a go at secondary schooling. What is the minister and this government going to do? It is going to cut that $300 away from them.

Let us look at what else the government is doing, because it says this is part of making up for the so-called $10 billion black hole. These kids cannot come and have a business lunch or dinner with Senator Vanstone. They are not going to very readily be able to find their way into the precincts of this building to twig the ear of the government when it is making budgetary considerations.

The government—at the same time it was considering cutting this paltry $2.8 million per annum spending in the interests of that $10 billion black hole that Senator Vanstone speaks about so much—was also considering cutting $800 million a year out of tax rebates to the major mining companies like BHP, MIM and CRA. That is the diesel fuel rebate. The miners did have access to this place. They were able to twig the ear of a compliant government. They got their $800 million a year restored. For what? Basically to go across and enhance their profit line.

When you look at BHP alone, there are six executives there earning over $1 million per annum, and there is one who is very close to earning $3 million per annum, assisted through the government's diesel fuel rebate. That $3 million per annum for one person, influential on the government, is equivalent to the $2.8 million that the government is cutting from some 8,000 struggling kids in Australia. It is when you take this equation that you see how out of kilter and how divisive this government's priorities are. Take $3 million from 8,000 homeless and struggling kids and hand it across to one BHP executive. That is where the equation ends up.

This can only be described as callous, unethical, immoral and abusive of the whole idea that this country of ours is about having a fair go. I think there is no other component of the budget that underscores how the government's priorities are about money and adding to the privilege of those who already have it at the expense of those who do not have influence.

It is just such a remarkably callous attack on the unfortunate in this country and such a patent hand across to those who have power, influence and money and, therefore, an open door to this government. It is an abhorrent little piece of penny‐pinching from the poor. The government should be ashamed of it. I cannot understand how the government and the minister have the hide to stand up and defend this while, at the same time, they are handing $800 million across on a platter to their friends in the mining corporations to help line their pockets or, as Senator Margetts would have it, the bottom line, which is the profit line that those companies will be posting on the stock exchange.

I know it is going to fall on deaf ears. At the moment there is only one government member in a seat opposite and one in the chair, Mr Acting Deputy President Watson. They simply are not listening to this debate. The mind is made up; the heart is closed; the deed is done. I just hope that we do muster the numbers in the Senate today to stand up for those people who cannot stand up for themselves and give them a bit of a fair go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the disallowance motions moved by the opposition. I do so because I think it has to be understood that the measures being undertaken by this government are exceptionally callous. We all understand that the government seeks from time to time to raise money. But to raise money in this particular manner suggests to me we are dealing with a government that is heartless, callous and determined to reduce the level of equity in access to higher education than we have come to expect in recent times.

SPEECH.PARA: Austudy beneficiaries total some 481,000 people in this country at the moment. According to the annual report at page 155, that is the figure. However, I noticed that the figures actually increase slightly in terms of the numbers the department has advised me of this morning. For secondary Austudy, there are 211,000 beneficiaries. For tertiary Austudy, there are 297,000 beneficiaries receiving assistance. These are not all wealthy people by any stretch of the imagination. Do you recall the infamous Wright family matter? It arose out of the desire of this government to secure savings in this particular area—a total savings in excess of $500 million over the next four years. About $500 million is being proposed to be gathered from this.

The department invented the Wright family to try to convince the electorate so that it could justify these punitive measures. That was on the issue of the means test in particular. But this is the sort of context in which we are working. This government is seeking in its regulations to remove the schooling incidental allowance for students. This allowance is a one‐off payment of $300—the princely sum of $300. What is this money used for? It is payable to secondary students who are receiving the homeless independent rate of Austudy—that is, they are unable to live at home with their parents, they are orphans, refugees or state wards, or have parents who cannot exercise parenting responsibility. What is the allowance used for in particular? It is used for the purchase of books, equipment and other educational expenses.

We are talking about a measure which, in the end, will affect some 8,500 people; 8,500 homeless people who are receiving a schooling incidental allowance of $300 each. What sort of money are we talking about? We are talking about $2.75 million in the first full year of its operation. It is a miserable amount of money. It is designed to attract a very small part of the overall package of measures. On top of that, this is a measure which is designed to raise the age of independence for Austudy purposes to 25. That affects some 13,700 students. Some 6,720 females and 6,980 males are beneficiaries and receive higher benefits to qualify for assistance. About 12,000 people—nearly 6,000 females and 6,000 males—will also lose benefits. This device is aimed at attracting savings of $62 million in the first year. Measures totalling $138 million are proposed by this government. These regulations amount to only $2.75 million in the first year, and $62 million in terms of raising the age of independence in the first year.

I am not suggesting for a moment that these measures in themselves are insignificant. The amounts of money might be insignificant for the state of the government as a whole. In the scheme of a budget which is seeking to take some $4.2 billion out of this portfolio, it might be insignificant. But, for the individuals, I think you can say it is very significant. I repeat that we are talking about $300 payable to secondary students receiving the homeless independent allowance—that is, they are unable to live at home with their parents, they are orphans, refugees or state wards, or have parents who cannot exercise proper parenting responsibilities. This $300 is used for school books, equipment and other educational expenses. In the scheme of things I do not think this government is going to be bankrupted. I do not think the budget is going to be blown apart if the Senate accepts these propositions. But, for the individuals, it means a considerable amount.

I want to draw attention to the annual report. The annual report indicates that the proportion of dependent beneficiaries on low incomes is some 96 per cent of dependent Austudy beneficiaries. Some 96 per cent of persons are on low incomes. The number of beneficiaries whose family incomes are in the lowest 40 per cent of all Australians are on special assessments. These are not necessarily wealthy people. The actual means test that this government is seeking to introduce does seek to address some issues in regard to people who are arranging their tax affairs in such a manner as to reduce their taxable payments and, therefore, reduce the amount of money so that they are able to attract certain benefits. This is not one of those measures. This is for homeless people. It is for people who are refugees, orphans or state wards. This is a callous move by a callous government. I do not think that the Senate ought to support such a proposition. Therefore, I would ask the Senate to agree to the disallowance of these particular regulations.

This is a government that is quite determined to reduce access to higher education. If you look at it in the context of the recent changes to HECS, the introduction of up‐front fees and, of course, the changes to ancillary fees, then the burdens that are being imposed on students are quite considerable. This government is seeking to raise $1.2 billion in revenue. I quote directly from attachment A of this government's regulations:

In keeping with the targeted nature of student assistance and the community's expectation that families are primarily responsible to provide for their children's education, the level of AUSTUDY payments to most younger students is based on an assessment of their parents' ability to support to them.
This is a travesty of the notion that people have a right to expect support from their government.

Under this measure, we are talking about people who are 25 years of age. We are not talking about little kids in terms of the proposals to raise the age of independence for Austudy. We are talking about citizens of this country with the full rights and expectations of citizens of this country. Amongst these expectations is the expectation they are entitled to have: that the government will provide assistance to them in the form of decent educational facilities so that they can be active participatory members of our community. In turn, they give back huge benefits to our society by their capacity to contribute fully when they are fully trained and skilled. I think it is wrong to suggest that persons who are 25 years of age have to be dependent on their parents. It is quite clearly a measure that the Labor government sought to address by reducing the age of independence.

BREAK.PARA: In summary, what have we got here? A proposition that seeks to impose measures to restrict the schooling incidental allowance benefit of $300—affecting 8,500 Austudy and Abstudy beneficiaries on the homeless rate who would have schooling incidental allowances paid—and measures that affect some 13,700 students who are beneficiaries and who will lose benefits as a result of this government's actions to raise the independence level for Austudy, and some 12,000 further students who are continuing.

New students are expected to be totally ineligible under this measure by this government. The net result is, as I say, seen in the context of changes to HECS and the introduction of up-front fees. The introduction of ancillary fees are measures that can only be aimed at reducing equity and participation in higher education. This is a device that clearly cannot be sustained on equity grounds, Minister. I would ask senators to support these disallowance motions moved by the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate the support of the Greens (WA) of this motion for disallowance of both the abolition of the schooling incidental allowance—$300 a year for books and pencils and assistance for homeless secondary school students on Austudy—and the increase in the age of independence from 22 back up to 25.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Brown has mentioned a number of the issues in relation to the schooling incidental allowance. I just want to emphasise that it may mean the difference between attending or not attending school for a number of these students. It is mean spirited and it is not worthy.

In relation to the increase in the age of independence from 22 back up to 25, the government is cutting over $500 million from student income support by tightening the means test, increasing the age of independence to 25 and restricting access to migrants and permanent residents. Altogether, it is a fairly substantial package of cuts and burns.

To Austudy alone, there are cuts of $514 million over the next four years. This will affect one in five students eligible for Austudy. One in five Austudy recipients will either have their Austudy taken away from them and be made ineligible, or have a cut in their payments. One hundred and twenty‐five thousand Austudy students will be worse off without any student income support.

The Greens disagree with raising the age of independence back up to 25. It was 25, however, and it has been progressively falling to 22. We support 18 as an end goal in the definition of independence. We do not believe that anyone who is 22 or 25 and is independent should be deemed to be on their parents' income. The notion is ridiculous. It smacks of compulsory families—I think that has been the theme of the budget in general—and increases the financial burden of children on parents. This actually is a trigger point for family tension and conflict.

The government has not been honest in saying that 25 is the top end of the age of independence, because the definition is applied to age upon initial enrolment. This means the student could be anything from 28 to 31 by the time they finish their degree and will still be deemed to be on their parents' income even if they have moved out and are completely independent.

Now we come to the bogus bourgeois Wright family. It is a sad state of affairs when the government has to make up a whole lot of rubbish about rorting rich families just to cover up its massive Austudy cut to needy families. Make no mistake: these are cuts to low income earners—people with low incomes and assets beneath the threshold to qualify for Austudy for their secondary school and tertiary aged children. There are some very disadvantaged people within this group. Many are homeless, young, from broken homes and with histories of abuse. It is totally unfair and inappropriate to be attacking these people and slashing their incomes.

The Wright family fabrication has reinforced the fact that the government is making large‐scale policy changes in a great experiment without planning based on statistics or proper problem identification, and without heed to any of the negative impacts. The massive Austudy cuts are compounded because they are occurring in a context of thousands of students living in housing related poverty because the government refuses to bring Austudy up to the amount of the dole and supplement it with a rent assistance component to assist students with their housing needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the budget, the government has taken this action as part of its budget measures. My approach to budget measures is that of course the Senate should not be merely obstructive, but that we should exercise our functions of scrutiny and review—this is what we are doing now—and that certain principles should be applied. Once those principles are applied to the budget decisions, if those budget decisions conflict with those principles, then of course the principles should prevail.

SPEECH.PARA: Having got that off my chest, I would like to simply say that there are certain principles which are offended by this particular measure. I will deal firstly with the question of raising the age of independence from 22 to 25. That assumes that the parents will be paying for the cost of the education of those persons from 22 to 25 years of age. The government assumes that, but the taxation department does not assume that. The taxation department assumes that the parents pay not one cent for those students—not one cent. That is a matter of considerable concern to me.

Indeed, I remind the chamber that, at the end of the higher education debate, it was a principle that I was concerned with as well, only on that occasion the principle was that expenditure on self‐education should be tax deductible. I remind the chamber that everybody—except Senator Colston—voted against that matter. Had the Australian Democrats, the Greens and the Australian Labor Party voted for it—had that principle been applied—the burden on tertiary students and graduates who had become eligible for repayments would have been reduced by a third. Now you come into this chamber and virtually support the principle by saying that you propose to disallow the government's proposal, based on the assumption that the parents have to pick up the tab. But, as I have said, the taxation department does not make that assumption. The government should have a look at this. It should realise that its tax threshold ceases to apply to people at the age of 18. I applaud the government for its actions on the family tax initiative, but the tax threshold for children still ceases at age 18. So it is even more important for the government to relook at this matter.

In addition to that issue, it is very important for the government to look at the sibling concession, which was abolished by the previous government. It is a matter in which I have had a considerable interest for a considerable time. I am not going to bore senators by reading out the file relating to it, but I remind people around the place that I raised quite considerable concerns when the concession was abolished by the previous Labor government.

Take the example of a family with three children in tertiary education who are receiving Austudy, and the parents' income is getting close to the stage where it would be affected. Under those circumstances, the concessional rate was 25c for every dollar earned by either of the parents, so the Austudy would have been reduced by 75c. That was the result of tightening the Austudy income test for families by removing the sibling concession, which was done in 1992. The effect was that, if you had three children on Austudy, you would have lost three times 25c—which equals 75c—in Austudy for every dollar earned by a parent, either by the primary earner or by the secondary earner in the family.

I pay tribute to former Senator Sowada, who vigorously opposed the government on that matter, as honourable senators would remember. I supported her very strongly as well. But, sadly, we were not able to disallow that regulation. The government should have a really good look at this at some stage. Frankly, until they do, I am not in a position—having applied that principle even to this budget measure—to support the government on this matter. Unless some very substantial information comes from the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), I will be supporting the motion for disallowance.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to hear from the minister on the matter of $300 for books, incidentals and educational materials for secondary school students who are `homeless'. I know that there is discrimination involved. I know a large number of families who are even more in need than some of the students who are getting this money. Those young people, the sons and daughters, are going to secondary school and are deprived of being able to get the books and educational materials that would be appropriate for them.
Some of the best intellects around are being deprived in that regard. There are very few scholarships these days. So there is an element of discrimination with this $300.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finding someone worse off and then saying it is not so bad—that is not an argument, Brian.

—No, I have not said that. I raise with the minister that particular issue very strongly. If you have kids who have left home and are getting the $300 and you have kids who are staying at home and are in equal need—if not, more—and they are not being helped, then it seems to me to be discriminatory on that basis. So I would like to hear what the minister has to say on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That regulations 7.1, 7.2 and 7.4 of the AUSTUDY Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 246 and made under the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 , be disallowed.

I apologise to the Senate for not moving this motion earlier today. I am moving it now because the government is anxious to have some degree of administrative certainty. The Democrats are happy to oblige. I am also aware that this disallowance motion does not have the support of the majority of the chamber, so I will speak very briefly.

PARA.BREAK: This motion relates to the independent at home rate. The measure was imposed by the former Labor government, was recently disallowed by the Senate, as people would recall, but is now in front of us in the form of coalition policy. The categorisation of a 22-, 23-, or 24-year-old living at home as some how not independent is yet another example of how both the ALP and the coalition have been prepared to jeopardise the future of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: In effect, the regulation takes $20 every week from the full independent rate if you live at home. This forces people in this situation to live on $216.70 a fortnight. While independent students qualify for rent assistance, obviously that component of the allowance is not necessarily applicable here; however, it was a mean and penny pinching measure designed to yet again ensure that Austudy would never necessarily be enough to live on. We consider the removal of the $20 as callous and quite hypocritical. I think both the parties stand condemned on this particular issue in the eyes of students.
When the coalition were in opposition, as recently as last June, I believe it was Senator Tierney who in 1995 criticised the independent at home rate. He said:
Why is the reality, that these students will leave home or cease study, being ignored?
I ask that of the Senate today: why has the coalition chosen to ignore these students now that they are in power?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly refer to each of the points raised, starting with that raised by Senator Stott Despoja. I thank her for moving that motion today. It will allow some administrative certainty. I think she is correct in her assertion, reluctant as it is, that she does not have majority support for her proposition. What the senator is seeking to do there is disallow a portion of some regulations that were reintroduced. I will not go into the history of that; I am sure all senators understand how those regulations were inadvertently disallowed. It would be uncharitable of me to rehash those arguments today, so I will not. I just say thank you to Senator Stott Despoja.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I come to the schooling incidentals allowance. I understand what Senator Harradine says with respect to two kids, one of whom might be classified as, as he says, `homeless'—it is not true that every child who is classified as homeless is living on the streets; I am sure Senator Harradine understands that—getting this allowance while the other, in equally impecunious circumstances, does not. That is the case. But there are other concerns with this. This was announced as a sort of pre-election bit of sweetening, if you like, by the previous Labor government, as I understand. Like a lot of things that are done in a hurry, it did not turn out as it ought to have, and there is actually no requirement that this money be spent on books or equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Food.

—It is just extra money. Senator Carr interjects that they spend it on food. That is a case for changing the allowance as a whole, not for saying, `We are giving you an incidental book allowance and, by the way, we don't care whether you spend it on books.'

SPEECH.PARA: Let us try to be a bit generous here on both sides. Perhaps I could seek your generosity so that I do not take up any more time than I need. You could let me have my 10 minutes, as others have graciously let each other have, to try and get through the agenda. So the government is concerned that this does not have to be spent on books. It is just extra money, and it is extra money that does not go to children who might be in equally impecunious circumstances.

Let us not forget that this government is spending a very substantial amount of money on the reintroduction of the JPET scheme, which is primarily targeted at young, homeless people—$11 million a year over two years. We can come into this place and look at one change and say, `You should not be doing that. Isn't it dreadful.' But if you do not consider it in the broader context of the other changes then, with respect, senators, I think you are being a little bit unreasonable.

We have reintroduced the JPET scheme. A number of them are going already and we are spending $11 million a year for two years on that. That is of particular assistance to young, homeless people. We have expanded access to JPET to include refugees. This is not a mean-spirited government. If you take one issue that is being lost then, fair enough, you can say, `That is mean spirited.' But it is not issue by issue; a whole range of things are being done here. It is $11 million to reintroduce JPET and expand access to it to include, for example, refugee kids.

In addition to that, of course, we have the homeless youth pilot project, which is of particular interest to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). He got that going very soon after getting into government. We are spending $8 million over two years on that. Those two measures together represent a very substantial commitment.

On balance, I think you would have to agree—when you put the two together and add them up and look at this small savings measure, recognising that it does not need to be spent on books and recognising that other kids in equally impecunious circumstances do not get it—that this money is much better applied to something like JPET or the homeless youth pilot project, where it can really do some good and where we can guarantee that. That is the government's reasoning for this.

Let me shift to the issue of age of independence, on which I have heard a lot of discussion, some of it not as straightforward as I might have liked. After all, it was the previous government who for 18 years had 25 as the age from which the independent rate for Austudy would apply. This is the independent rate for Austudy, not the age at which the government says you are independent in every other respect. This provision was changed only recently, yet suddenly there has been this road to Damascus conversion, as if what the previous government did for so long is now completely unacceptable. I think that is unreasonable.

I am not sure how old Melanie Howard is—she must be 20, 21 or 22. If you think the Prime Minister's daughter should get Austudy by virtue of her age, if you think Alan Bond's kids who are living at home should get Austudy simply because of their age, then fine—support this disallowance. If you want to say, `It does not matter how wealthy your parents are. It does not matter if you are living at home. We don't care if your parents are millionaires. We think that once you turn 22 you should be able to get it. We don't care if your father is the Prime Minister. We would like to tip a bit of Austudy into you,' then you have a different perception of targeting of assistance than this government has.

We used laugh at Labor when they were in government and say, `There you are with your rich mates.' But I never thought I would see the day that you would actually come in here and vote that the Prime Minister's daughter ought to be able to get Austudy. It is a misconception. I will move on from that because I do not want to be too ungenerous at the end of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the Wright family was actually the Howard family, was it?

—Senator Margetts cannot help herself. She has to go back to unpleasant times. It is Thursday and we do have another day to go and the senator so unkindly raises the Wright family, which turned out to be the wrong family. That is so unkind. It would be inappropriate of me not to make sure that Senator Margetts understands exactly what the situation is vis-a-vis a family such as the Wright family.

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, we said it was an actual family and it was not. We admitted that and you can all have a good old laugh and stir the pot as much as you like. But what is also agreed is that a family such as the Wright family would, in the absence of the actual means test introduced by the previous government for the express purpose of getting at people who could get around an income and assets test, get Austudy and social security benefits.

That is the substance of the issue that goes to the community at large, that a family such as that would in fact be able to get Austudy in the absence of the actual means test. I give Labor credit for having introduced it. You did manage to do a couple of good things in the time you were in. That was a very sensible move.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you believe that you'd believe anything.
—I notice that Senator Faulkner said, `If you believe that you'd believe anything.'
—I wasn't talking to you.
—I think he is saying that if you believe Labor did a couple of good things when they were in you would believe anything.
—I would not believe anything you said.
—Order!

—Let me just move on. It appeared from their speeches that both Senator Margetts and Senator Stott Despoja have not turned their minds to the actual regulations as they relate to the 25‐year‐old threshold. As I understood the portions that I heard, and as I have been informed about the bits I did not hear, Senator Stott Despoja is still of the view that a student who enrols at 24 and does not get the independent rate by virtue of their age under the new regulations would continue to not get it for the rest of their course. Is that right?
—I've just got the estimates committee answers back.
—Subsequent to that, the regulations have been changed. This is a caring and listening government, Senator.
—Try and keep a straight face when you tell lies.
—Order!

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am trying to get through this as reasonably and as courteously as possible and it is not easy when someone of bad faith, unlike a lot of other people on the other side, comes in and stirs the pot—the foe leader of the Labor Party comes in here stirring the pot without Senator Ray behind him telling him to button up.
—You're the pot, are you?
—Order! Some of these comments are not helpful to this debate. I hope we can get on with the job and not be still stuck here on Saturday morning.

—If you had taken the time to look at the regulations—it is always a handy trick to look at the regulations you are voting on—you will have found that anyone, once they turn 25, will be able to access Austudy. The regulations do not reflect what the budget statement initially indicated was going to be the case. A number of senators have raised those matters with me—Senator Colston and a number of others. I think you may have at one stage even asked me a question about it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of some amazement to me that, having asked a question about it, you did not realise the ball has gone past and the game has changed. You are not focusing on the issue here, Senator. You raise an issue and then do not bother to follow it up and realise what the hell you are voting on. What you are voting on now are some regulations that have taken into account some community concerns that were expressed. Senator Margetts, I say to you: ditto. You understand the argument. But you apparently also do not understand that the regulations have been changed.

All this government wants to do is say: should you get Austudy simply because you are the 22 and for no other reason? We say no. The other side used to say no. We ought to shift the age threshold back to what it was—25; that when you turn 25, irrespective of your enrolment and course dates, et cetera, you will get Austudy.

It is important to get your facts right. I want to take a couple of minutes more. I know we have a time problem but I do feel I have to raise this, Senator Stott Despoja. The Democrats have a slogan `Keep the you‐know‐whos honest' as if to say, `You should get your facts right.' You are not being dishonest in coming here misunderstanding the regulations. You just did not bother to look at them. Shake your head as much as you want, Senator. That is what the facts show.

Senator, I have had some interest, as you know, in your home page and every now and again I have a look at it. I am somewhat amazed to see the scuttlebutt that was around, vis-a-vis this government's higher education budget statement, that Austudy would be turned into a loans scheme.

Opponents of this government were keen to run around and frighten the hell out of everybody saying this was what was going to happen. Senator Stott Despoja very quickly thought, `I had better get access to my very poor student constituency that all have computers and are searching my web page. I will put a heading on there "Oppose the loan scheme". I will give them a draft letter clearly implying that there is a loans scheme on.'

On 9 August it was abundantly clear that Austudy was not going to be converted to a loan scheme. Did Senator Stott Despoja rush back to her home page and say, `That is a bit misleading. I had better get that off there. I want to keep the you‐know‐whos honest.' No, no, no. Every couple of weeks she goes back, and there it is: `Oppose the loan scheme. Message to the minister. To make your personal protest against proposed changes to Austudy which will make the grants based system a compulsory loan scheme, fill in the form below and press the submit entry button. Your message will be forwarded to me.' It is as clear as a bell. `Make your personal protest against proposed changes to Austudy which will make the grants based system a compulsory loans scheme.'

TALK.START.PARA: —When was this?

—This has been on the Internet for heaven knows how long, but well after the budget was announced, well after the higher education budget was announced. The Democrats, the people who want to keep everybody honest, have been holding out to the community at large that Austudy was going to be converted to a loans scheme. Senator, hang your head in shame.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator BOLKUS (South Australia) (10.54 p.m.) I wish to speak very briefly in response. I could not help thinking whilst Senator Vanstone was speaking of that Ever Ready Jacko bunny. You are endless. You just do not know when to stop.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have got the batteries.
—You have the batteries all right, and you are battering us with them in the process. We could have come to a vote on this issue a bit earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a couple of points to make. Caring and listening is what you assert to be, but there is nothing caring and listening about these particular proposals. One thing about all programs, whether it is this one or any other, is if you look at the exception and the unintended consequences and base your policy on them, you will have no programs at all. If you look at the assistance that Senator Newman's husband might be getting, for instance, and pay to everyone else income support on the basis of that, you could deprive everyone across the country. What you have to do is look at the areas of need and, if there are unintended consequences like Melanie Howard getting benefit, it is very easy to fix that up. Just ring her father and say, `Listen, your daughter should not be on it.' See what answer you get.

We really need to look at those areas of need. As Senator Carr pointed out very succinctly earlier, if you look at the number of dependent Austudy beneficiaries on low incomes, you are talking about people who are basically in the lowest 40 per cent of all Australian family incomes as being those targeted by Austudy assistance. For instance, 96 per cent in 1995-96 was the proportion of dependent beneficiaries on low incomes. They are the sorts of people these programs are targeted at. This 96 per cent of the 275,000 or so are the ones that you will deprive of assistance, not the odd Bond daughter or Melanie Howard. You could easily target them.

In terms of targeting, let us also remember that Austudy starts to taper off at a joint family income of $22,650. It would be very hard for Melanie Howard, given her stated dependence, to avoid that particular provision. Mention was also made of the JPET scheme. The argument used by Senator Vanstone is a bit bogus. That scheme has been reintroduced, and it has taken the place of a scheme which cost a lot more money and which provided case management, individual student by individual student, to basically assist them and give them some career support. To argue that that is a subsidy I think is inadequate.

In terms of the incidental allowance, I have listened to the debate this morning very closely. No-one has come up with an argument against the allowance. Senator Harradine has suggested that there are other people in need who could also be assisted by a similar scheme but no-one has actually put forward any evidence to say that the allowance is not assisting students who are in a situation of need and crisis. So there is an argument for perhaps extending it but not an argument for doing away with this particular scheme as it now operates.
On the advice of the minister's advisers, I seek leave to reframe my notices of motion.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reframe my notice of motion No. 1 to refer to items 3 to 6 and No. 2 to refer to items 1 and 7.

—Is it the wish of the Senate that the three motions be put separately? There being no objection, it is so ordered. I now propose to put motion No. 1 moved by Senator Bolkus, which has now been changed to read, in part, `relating to the disallowance of regulations 3 to 6,' which is the age of independence of the Austudy regulations as contained in the statutory rules 1986.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that business of the Senate notice of motion No. 2, in the name of Senator Bolkus, as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the motion moved by Senator Stott Despoja be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

That this bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Sherry had moved by way of amendment:
At the end of the motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government's betrayal of election promises by its decision to:
(a) change the tariff concession system so that businesses will have to pay higher taxes on a greater range of their inputs (raising $300 million in revenue);
(b) limit the reduction in the uplift factor on provisional tax to 1996‐97 alone;
(c) impose a new $1.5 billion superannuation tax;

(d) increase tax collections in 1996‐97 by $8.6 billion or 4.5 per cent in real terms and then a further $7.8 billion or 3.4 per cent in real terms in 1997-98; increase income tax on individuals by $5 526 million or 9.1 per cent (approximately 6.4 per cent in real terms); increase tax revenue from 23.9 per cent GDP in 1995‐96 to 24.3 per cent GDP in 1996‐97; and
(e) introduce major revenue measures in the 1996‐97 Budget with a net impact of $979 million and further net impact of $1 955 million in 1997-98 (costing each Australian taxpayer more than $260)".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted, I was nearing the end of my presentation. I would like to say that, in relation to the ALP second reading amendment, we have supported a number of the ALP second reading amendments. Paragraphs (a) and (b) seem okay, but I would find it difficult to support the rest of the amendment. On this occasion, I will not be voting with the ALP on its second reading amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Our second reading amendment effectively changes the dividend imputation from 100 per cent to 50 per cent. I seek leave to table table 1.6 of the report Funding options for employment, industry and regional development by Phillip Raskall of the Social Policy Research Centre dated February 1994. This table makes clear the implications of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, did you mean table or do you want to have it incorporated?
—I am suggesting that it be tabled. I have circulated it to the various parties.
—I am getting an indication from the minister that he has not seen it.
—I gave one to each party. I am afraid that if the Whip did not pass it on there is not a lot I can do.
— Maybe you might just clarify for the minister what it is.

—That is what I was about to do. The table makes clear the implications of dividend imputation and also makes clear the kind of manipulation possible by the rich. It was table 1.6 of a published report called Funding options for employment, industry and regional development . It is by Phillip Raskall of the Social Policy Research Centre and is dated February 1994. There is another copy here. I am happy for you to see it. I will continue because I have only two minutes. I am happy to pass that on for you to have a look at in the meantime.

SPEECH.PARA: It shows that for those making over $500,000 per year, dividend income increased by nearly 11 times in the year dividend imputation was introduced and increased another five times the next year to a level 54 times that pre-imputation. This was at a time when company tax was paid at 49c. Average tax paid per person in this category dropped by 70 per cent—and this was because dividend income was effectively tax-free income. We believe that dividend imputation—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Margetts, your time has expired. Is leave granted for the tabling?

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1966 amends the tax and superannuation law in several areas, including measures relating to offshore banking units, gifts, expenses of complying superannuation funds, taxation of foreign source income, forgiveness of commercial debt and the use of tax file numbers for superannuation purposes. The bill implements the coalition's election commitment to double the FBT minor benefits exemption to $100. The FBT reform will help reduce compliance costs of FBT for employers who provide minor benefits to employees and will ensure that employers who provide only irregular minor benefits of less than $100 avoid paying FBT altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition has moved a second reading amendment. The amendment, which the government will not be supporting, has no real relevance to the bill whatsoever. We will not, of course, be giving any support to it. Let me just make a few comments about the opposition's second reading amendment.

The government has delivered on its election commitment to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor from Labor's eight per cent to six per cent. The superannuation contribution surcharge will make the superannuation system more equitable for all Australians while ensuring that superannuation remains an attractive option. I understand the Labor Party supports the concept of the surcharge.

Senator Sherry made comments on debt forgiveness. I wish to make two brief comments on his remarks. Labor did announce this measure in the 1995 budget. Legislation was not introduced until November 1995, and the bill lapsed because of the election. The provisions were incomplete. We did not delay the measures. The measure was to commence on 9 May; however, the bill containing those measures lapsed. The change of government created a situation of uncertainty, given that full details of the new rules were not available. In response to these business concerns, we decided to make the rules apply prospectively.

In addition, Senator Margetts raised some issues in relation to the use of tax file numbers for superannuation purposes. I think Senator Margetts has a copy of the letter that we have received from the Privacy Commissioner on that issue. We have consulted widely with the Privacy Commissioner. The purposes for which the tax file numbers can be used are limited to locating, identifying, amalgamating and transferring superannuation accounts. Some of those issues may be explored further in the committee stage.

It will not surprise Senator Margetts that we will not be supporting her second reading amendment. It proposed that an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) would serve to ensure that the tax obligation of a company cannot be reduced to a level below 20 per cent of the company's net income. Under this rule companies would pay the greater of the tax calculated under the current law or an alternative minimum tax—the so-called AMT.

The central objection to an AMT is that it would impair equity and efficiency in the taxation of companies. For example, all deductions, including carry-forward losses, allowances, rebates and other concessions available to companies are deliberate policies, the product of tax laws considered and passed by parliament. If parliament were to leave those tax laws as they are but at an AMT, the availability of concessions would be determined arbitrarily. A company's tax assessment would not be determined by anything which could specifically entitle it to the concessions but by the operation of an arbitrary ratio. In short, an AMT would be an arbitrary and unpredictable limit on the availability of tax concessions.

TALK.START.PARA: —On you, Rod.

—Thank you for your support, Senator Conroy. In addition, in relation to the drawbacks in terms of equity and efficiency, an AMT would have two unwelcome effects on companies generally. First, administrative and compliance costs would be increased as companies would be required to maintain two sets of accounts. Secondly, an AMT would create uncertainty about the company's future tax liabilities and cash flow. For those reasons and others, we will not be supporting the second reading amendment proposed by Senator Margetts.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "That", substitute "the bill be withdrawn and redrafted to incorporate amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to ensure that the income from companies, taken after all deductions due to the actual costs of production of that income are made (as indicated by book profits included in annual reports), is taxed so as to ensure that the tax obligation cannot be reduced to a level below 20 per cent of a company's net income."
Contrary to what I said in the last few minutes, my second reading amendment is actually in regard to minimum company tax, which I have spoken about in the second reading debate.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 8 (after line 24), after Part 1, insert:
Repeal the formula, substitute:

TAB.TAB: 2 1‐CR

SPEECH.PARA: Repeal the formula, substitute:

TAB.TAB: 2 1‐CR

SPEECH.PARA: Omit " Franked amount " means", substitute " FA is".
Omit " Company tax rate means", substitute " CR is".

I have actually spoken about this amendment to a certain extent. Our amendment effectively changes the dividend imputation from 100 per cent to 50 per cent. This is worked out by a formula in section 160AQT. That relates to the assessable income related to franked dividends. A 50 per cent imputation is arrived at by halving the franked amount in the formula.

People who get dividends get rebates of 36c in the dollar for every dollar they get in dividends. Any battler may own a few shares, just as they may have a lotto ticket. The main recipients of dividends are unequivocally in the top 10 per cent of income earners. Halving the 160AQT assessable income formula has the effect of halving all the various dividend tax rebates. It halves the amount of money people can claim as already having been paid as tax. It would cut additional benefits of dividends from 36c in the dollar to 18c in the dollar.

I thank the Senate for allowing me to table table 1.6 of that report by Phillip Raskall. It does make clear the implications of dividend imputation and makes clear the kind of manipulation that is made possible for the rich as a result of this action.

For those making over $500,000 a year, dividend income increased by nearly 11 times in the year dividend imputation was introduced. It increased another five times in the next year to a level 54 times that pre‐imputation. While the total income in the over $500,000 bracket grew by 13 times, the average tax paid per person in this category dropped by 70 per cent. This is because the dividend income was effectively tax free. In the following year the company tax dropped, so they got it both ways. The tax free status of dividends ended and these people, who were very wealthy by any standards, suddenly shifted their income base and dividend income dropped back to around 12 times the pre-imputation levels while tax paid per person more than doubled.

We believe that dividend imputation results in a massive benefit for the wealthy. With this amendment, as with my earlier one, I seek to address this balance. One hundred per cent dividend imputation is not fair, just or equitable. It is entirely anti-progressive and has been used as a rort as much as any other legal means of tax minimisation. I would rather see this rort closed, since it is aimed at the top end of income earners. I would rather see this than some of the mean spirited cuts that have been made as a result of this budget because the government said they had no choice. Well, they do have a choice, and so do the opposition. In this sense we are giving that choice to the Senate. I urge the Senate to support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: — The Democrats, like Senator Margetts, have been concerned about the unfairness of dividend imputation for a long time. That has been the subject of many budget submissions we have made to governments. Senator Margetts has highlighted how it is overly generous. I want to point out that it costs $2 billion a year and that it does deliver massive benefits to high income earners—67 per cent of imputation credits flow to high income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: The benefits have been extended to non-resident shareholders, so that adds a further $700 million to the cost. I agree with the political point which says: `Why do you make the choices in government via appropriations to cut so excessively when really you could make a much more courageous and fairer choice and look at tax design flaws?'

Most other OECD countries have opted for partial, rather than full, dividend imputation. The OECD itself has argued that the cost to revenue often exceeds the rise in private sector savings. We are being told by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) that we want to do something about national savings. Here is a good place to start.

Monash University's tax economist, Professor John Head—as I recall, a designer of this system—has now said that it is time to take a look at it. Other Australian researchers, including ACOSS's Professor Julian Disney and the University of New South Wales' welfare project, have all criticised full dividend imputation as a policy not meeting its original objectives, unless you wanted to design a policy which has as its objective a costly sop to the rich. That was not its objective. It is not meeting its objective and it is clearly time to review it.

Treasurer Costello can start his attack on the so-called riddles and rorts in this country by looking honestly at the tax system and at the several major design flaws—dividend imputation is one of them and tax deductibility of interest is another. The point I want to make is that any review ought not be retrospective because a lot of people have developed their financial planning based on current rules and they do have to have the time to adjust accordingly. This applies particularly to self-funded retirees who always write in volumes whenever you start talking about dividend imputation in any form.

It is true that these people rely heavily on this. It is very important to them. On their behalf, I say to Senator Margetts that it would not be fair to pass this amendment today. It would have a retrospective impact because it applies to all investments even when people have acted with knowledge of the current law and arranged their affairs accordingly.

I support Senator Margetts' objective in moving this motion because I do think we need to point out to the government and to Australians that there are other choices. You do not have to cut dental programs for the poor when you have got a choice of doing something about dividend imputations which flow to the rich. Those are the sorts of choices I want to see this coalition government making—fair choices, choices where people can afford to pay. But because I do not believe that we should do things which have a retrospective impact, I cannot support this amendment today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor will not be supporting the amendment moved by the Greens to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996. Currently, under existing tax law, companies can pass on the full benefit of having paid tax on company benefits by way of franking credits on dividend distributions to their shareholders. This was introduced by Labor to end what was, in effect, the double taxation of company dividends. The Greens amendment could see this effectively halved.

SPEECH.PARA: One important point to make about such a move is that it would have a very significant effect on superannuation funds and, therefore, on superannuation fund beneficiaries. Many superannuation funds invest in companies that pay franked dividends in order to take advantage of the franking credits. According to the tax statistics of 1993-94, super funds receive $1.7 billion in gross dividends and claimed $548 million in franking credits to help offset the payment of the tax on superannuation fund earnings, which is entirely legitimate.

BREAK.PARA: Under this proposal, there would be a shift of hundreds of millions of dollars from the accounts of superannuation fund members into the government tax collection coffers. We believe that the more money people can save for their retirement, the better off they are. Unfortunately, this amendment would only undermine the savings of superannuation fund beneficiaries by shifting money from their accounts into Treasury.

That is not the only reason why we oppose this amendment. I just highlight that as an undesirable consequence of Senator Margetts's amendment. The other reason, broadly, is that we do not believe it is appropriate to significantly write the tax acts in an unconsidered way in dealing with an omnibus taxation laws amendment bill, which is what this is. It is a very inappropriate manner in which to consider what are very important taxation measures. For those reasons, we will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not surprise the chamber to learn that the government will not be supporting the Greens amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996. I have a great deal of sympathy with the remarks made by Senator Sherry on this issue. It does not have anything to do with this particular tax bill and it is an inappropriate amendment to move.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not support it in principle. As Senator Sherry said, the imputation has been around for a significant period of time. It was brought in by the Labor government and has the support of the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unchanged. You are not ever going to look at it.
—I will tackle the issues which you have raised in a moment, Senator Kernot.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment moved by Senator Margetts would halve the imputation or the franking rebate available to resident individuals and superannuation funds for franked dividends. Senator Margetts would be aware, as would Senator Kernot, that the dividend imputation system removes the double taxation of company income that applied under the classical system of company taxation. Full imputation represents an equitable rather than a concessional treatment of dividend income by ensuring that in most cases company income distributed to resident shareholders bears the same total tax as other forms of income.

A substantial behavioural response to the introduction of partial imputation would be likely, which would erode some of the revenue gained from such a measure. Companies would obviously look for tax minimisation and tax shifting opportunities because of the reduction in franked dividends to shareholders compared with the situation under full imputation where they may well retain rather than distribute profits. The proposed amendments would reduce the franking rebate available to residents by not affecting non‐residents, who would continue to be exempt from dividend withholding tax on franked dividends.

The substance of the argument of Senator Margetts and Senator Kernot—and I notice that Senator Kernot is not supporting the amendment, but she clearly has some sympathy for the sorts of views that were put forward by Senator Margetts—seems to be based on the assumption that the dividend imputation only has impact on high income earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, neither of us said that.

—I think Senator Sherry made a very useful point in relation to superannuation funds. I am advised that there are large numbers of taxpayers whose income includes franked dividends. As I said, the advice I have received is that 80 per cent of them have taxable incomes of less than $50,000. To argue that this is a measure which benefits only the rich is quite wrong—
—Disproportionately.

—I have mentioned a figure, Senator Kernot. I do not wish to labour the point. I repeat: the proposed amendment would not impact on high income earners only. There are large numbers of taxpayers whose income includes franked dividends, and 80 per cent of them have taxable incomes of less than $50,000.
—What? Will not?
—There are large numbers of taxpayers whose income includes franked dividends, and 80 per cent of them—
—No, it was what you said before. You said something `would not impact'.
—No, the proposed amendment would not impact on high income earners only. That was the point.
—You left off the `only' just then.
—I think I have said that a couple of times, but I think we are in general agreement. There may be some dispute over the proportions.

SPEECH.PARA: Many taxpayers with low or middle incomes have shareholdings in an indirect form, as Senator Sherry said, through superannuation and life insurance or have shares in companies which have undertaken large floats with widespread participation by the public—for example, Woolworths, Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank. A move to partial imputation would diminish taxpayers' effective returns from these sources. We will not be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Margetts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a brief question. My advice is that people in superannuation funds already get some preferred tax treatments, so the implications for them are not the same extent as they would be for the high income earners. The most important question is: is there any move on the government to look at this issue seriously in the future? That is very important, and I would like to see if there is any indication that there is some move in the future to look at this issue.

—The taxation regime which is applicable to super funds is well known. It seeks, among other things, to encourage people to invest in superannuation. I am not sure that the point you are making is a strong one. The reality is that—
