—It is a simple question. There are ameliorating factors in the tax treatment for super.
—Senator, the fact of the matter is that you will be seeking to remove a benefit that a lot of lower income people receive.
—Just answer the question, will you?

—I know it is difficult, because you like to stand up and hold yourself out as a supporter of people on lower incomes. But the reality is that what you are proposing would be to the detriment of many people on low incomes. We have mentioned the issue that many of them may hold shareholdings in companies in which franked dividends are available and, of course, increasing numbers have investments in superannuation. What you would be doing with this is removing a benefit which they are currently receiving. So we will not be supporting that measure.

—I am not asking for a debating point. I am not asking for an answer to the question. I am not trying to waste time. Would you please not waste time and answer the question. There are ameliorating factors in superannuation, which means that the impact is not as great. Is that true or not?
—Senator, you are moving something which will be to their detriment. I have answered the question.
—No, you haven't.

—It has been a long week, Senator, and you are not the only one who is a bit tetchy. What I am telling you is that the taxation regime for superannuation is well known and, among other things, provides incentives and encourages people to invest in superannuation. That is point one. Point two is that many lower income earners in increasing numbers are having access to superannuation. Point three is that under the current regime many superannuation funds invest in companies and are entitled to franked dividends. So what I am saying to you is that your measure would be, among other things, to the detriment of many low income people. That is the answer to your question.
—The second question was: is there any move on the government to look at this in the future?
—The government supports the current regime on the imputation for dividends.
—Look, I'm not asking for a debating point. I am looking for an answer to the question. I am not trying to waste time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make one point about the figures that the minister has used. I did not bring my larger table in here. I do accept that a lot of self‐funded retirees who rely heavily on shares have incomes less than $50,000 a year. Fifty thousand is still a bit of income when you consider those poverty statistics that were published recently. Many Australian families live on less than $25,000. I just want to put on the record again that my research shows that 67 per cent of imputation credits flow to high income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: So, while I am not supporting the amendment, I am saying to you that, as a government, you have a choice of designed formulation so that you can pick up exactly what level of income earner you want to aim at. This is part of a tax system which had an objective. The designer of this, Professor John Head, now says, `Sorry, this is not the way it should be.' As a government, you ought to review the design and its impact. You have a choice as to how you reformulate it. I personally think you should reformulate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, I have looked towards my advisers to see whether I can give any further comment on the figures that you have put before the committee. I do not have that advice available to me, but this debate will continue. I think that we will have to agree to differ on this issue. As I have said, the divided imputation system removes the double taxation of company income that previously applied. The government supports the current system.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) oppose Schedule 4. We simply oppose the bringing in of tax file numbers to superannuation at this time. We have two major concerns on the issue, and they have not been addressed. The first is the slippery notion of `voluntary', used by the government. When you say, `You don't need to give the number but, if you don't, you'll be taxed at the highest marginal rate of 47 per cent,' this may fulfil guidelines, but it is hardly voluntary in the ordinary meaning of the term. In fact, it probably fits the legal definition of coercion.

SPEECH.PARA: We are particularly concerned that proposed section 299Q would assume that employees have agreed to provide a tax file number when their employer provides it. When we brought this up with government advisers, the response was that 299P allows the commissioner to set an approved manner for quoting tax file numbers, and that this would or could require employee permission. We have got no assurance that it will. There was some indication that there would be a form to fill in, but that is not part of this bill, obviously.

We are also worried that the rhetoric of permission may be legally fulfilled by a note on a form saying that, in supplying an employer a tax file number `voluntarily', an employee is taken to have authorised the employer to pass that tax file number on to the superannuation fund. Legally, there may be an implication that the employee, having read this note, can decide to prevent the employer from passing on the number to a superannuation fund by refusing to supply it to the employer, and of course paying punitive tax.

We have suggested a statement that there will be a separate line requiring a separate signature, without which the employer is not authorised to pass on a tax file number to a superannuation fund. We have just received a draft version of such a form specifically authorising an employer to pass on a tax file number to a superannuation company. I was going to seek leave to table it, but I guess the government is in a better position to table it than I am. Perhaps the government could table it. If I could get an assurance that such a form will be provided, this may go part way to addressing my concerns.

PARA.BREAK: The second issue is that access to tax file number data goes well beyond what is re quired. I understand that there are restrictions on using data for other purposes, but I cannot see why superannuation funds even need access to non‐relevant information included in the tax file number database. It would seem a reasonably simple matter to provide some sort of filter so that the Australian Taxation Office makes available only relevant information—that is, address, phone number and information about other superannuation fund moneys. No other information should really be necessary. No other information should really be accessible to the commercial sector. If we could get an assurance that measures would be put in place to prevent access by superannuation funds to other information, it would go some way to addressing our concerns, although we retain major reservations.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue at stake is that tax file numbers are increasingly used to collect and integrate a broad range of information, including economic information about major purchases, bank accounts, wages, superannuation and so on. It includes information from social security. Since anyone receiving family payment of home child‐care allowance—which is a broad cross‐section of the population—receive it from Social Security, those with access to the tax file number database have access not only to existing commercial and economic information, but a range of personal information as well.

I can see why there is a greater pressure on various departments to have access to this number, but it was never said to be designed for this purpose. It certainly was not what Mr Keating said when he introduced it. He said that this would not be a de facto Australia card. Guess what? That is exactly what it is becoming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. Senator Margetts, like us all, is concerned to ensure that there are proper privacy provisions in relation to tax file numbers. Senator Margetts raised a number of questions. I will respond to those. I think one of the questions was why tax file numbers are required. They are required for four reasons: firstly, to reduce the numbers of loss beneficiaries in the superannuation system; secondly, to reduce the numbers of small amounts in the superannuation system; thirdly, to facilitate the efficient administration of superannuation; and, fourthly, to assist in properly supervising the superannuation industry.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been very keen, Senator Margetts, to consult with the Privacy Commissioner on this basis. The government does this because we have great concerns, like you do, about privacy issues which are raised. You would be aware that there was a letter that has been passed to you, signed by Mr Kevin O'Connor, to Mr Shawn Fracchia, regarding the use of the tax file numbers in this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you wish to incorporate that?
—I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—
Human Rights Australia
Our reference: 95/212 COWCH 96157
Mr Shawn Fracchia
Tax Law Services
Australian Taxation Office,
PO Box 900
CIVIC SQUARE ACT 2608
Dear Mr Fracchia
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT ACT (No.2) 1996—TAX FILE NUMBERS AND SUPERANNUATION

I refer to previous correspondence and discussions on this matter and to your recent request that I confirm in writing the views I have put to date on the proposals in the Bill for the greater use of tax file numbers in the administration of superannuation.

In commenting on the proposals to date I have sought to ensure that they are consistent with the provisions of the Tax File Number Guidelines, which I am required to issue under the Privacy Act, and that the same protective framework will apply to the proposed uses of tax file numbers in the superannuation industry as applies to uses authorised by taxation and assistance agency law.

In particular I have been concerned to ensure: that the principle of voluntary quotation of tax file numbers by individuals is maintained; that individuals are properly informed of a range of matters, including that quotation of their tax file number is not compulsory and the consequences of not quoting this number; that superannuation funds are permitted to use tax file numbers only for the limited purposes set out in the Bill; and that superannuation funds will handle tax file numbers in a secure way that accords with the Tax File Number Guidelines.
I am now reasonably satisfied with the way that the Bill, and its accompanying explanatory material, addresses these matters. The provisions specify, among other protections, that:
. individuals may be asked (by superannuation funds or their employers) but not required to provide their tax file numbers for superannuation purposes;
. superannuation trustees may only use file numbers to locate, amalgamate, identify and transfer benefits for members;
. tax file numbers may only be used to identify amounts held for a particular person where other information is insufficient to identify the amounts; and
. the tax file number is not to be used as a general administrative number.

I have recently prepared and had tabled in parliament amendments to the Tax File Number Guidelines which ensure that the Guidelines will apply to any current or proposed uses of tax file numbers for purposes authorised by superannuation law.

Some minor uses of the Tax File Number in the superannuation area were previously covered by the definition of taxation law in the Guidelines. Given the scale of the uses now proposed I have recognised this by introducing a new definition of superannuation law. The revised Guidelines make it clear that Tax File Numbers are now authorised by law to be used in three areas of administration—the original area of taxation, the assistance agency area introduced in 1990, and now superannuation.

I am continuing to consult with the Australian Taxation Office and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission about such matters as the content of the proposed circular setting out the responsibilities of superannuation trustees and the approved form for the manner of collection of tax file numbers by superannuation trustees and employers.

I ask you to note that the comments in this letter should not be interpreted as an endorsement of the proposals in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.2) 1996. I have consistently recognised that the public interest balance in relation to the tax file number system is set by the Government and Parliament.
If you wish to discuss the matter further the contact officer is Ms Chris Cowper on 02‐9284 9651.
Yours sincerely
KEVIN O'CONNOR
Privacy Commissioner
3 December 1996

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be useful for the record. You raised the issue of the voluntary nature of this. As Kevin O'Connor says in this letter:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the principle of voluntary quotation of tax file numbers by individuals is maintained; that individuals are properly informed of a range of matters, including that quotation of their tax file number is not compulsory and the consequences of not quoting the number; that superannuation funds are permitted to use tax file numbers only for the limited purposes—
I think that was another issue that you raised—
set out in the Bill; and that superannuation funds will handle tax file numbers in a secure way—
I think that was another issue that you raised—
that accords with the Tax File Number Guidelines.

I incorporate that letter and indicate that we have been consulting very closely with the commissioner. The privacy laws, of course, require that the employee explicitly, voluntarily and with adequate information authorises the use of their tax file number. I think that is important to recall.

There is the issue of a form. I am not sure what form Senator Margetts was referring to, but there was a draft form to show how this could be used. There are a number of pro forma forms around. We can assure you that we will make sure that the rules which apply to the use of tax file numbers are applied and that that is done in a way which fully complies with the laws regarding the use of tax file numbers. It will be done in closest consultation with the Privacy Commissioner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In the meantime, I have found a copy of some short advice from tax law services, Australian Taxation Office, in relation to tax file numbers, including an indicative example of a tax file number notification, which is what the government is saying they have got. It is disturbing that they still have not got it or have not worked out the detail. I seek leave to table this advice.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to refer to two parts of the letter from the Privacy Commissioner. On the first page, he says:

SPEECH.PARA: I am now reasonably satisfied with the way that the Bill, and its accompanying explanatory material, addresses these matters.
This is the principle of voluntary quotation of tax file numbers and all that comes with that, the fact that they have to be properly informed, et cetera. He says:
I am now reasonably satisfied with the way that the Bill . . . addresses these matters.
But it draws to our attention to page 2, where he says:
I ask you to note that the comments in this letter should not be interpreted as an endorsement of the proposals in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996.
He goes on:
I have consistently recognised that the public interest balance in relation to the tax file number system is set by the Government and Parliament.
While I found this letter useful, I do not think we should rely on it. Neither do I think that Mr O'Connor would want us to rely on it as the final word.
The point I made earlier in the second reading debate is that we have so many multiple accounts for superannuation that it probably is an appropriate measure this time.
Schedule 4 agreed to.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Kemp) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FURTHER BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 October, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me commence my contribution on the social security legislation by indicating that the Labor Party will be moving a second reading amendment to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill. This second reading amendment sets out our view on the activity test regime that is being proposed by the government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Howard government has no commitment to assist the unemployed. The government will, with the passage of this legislation, make the lives of Australia's unemployed people harder, and it will make it harder for them to find a job. When they cannot find a job because there are no jobs to find, they will be subject to hoops and hurdles to get the income support they and their families need. In a decent society like ours, this is not acceptable.

These bills seek to give effect to almost all of the social security measures—largely harsh ones—announced by the coalition government in the 1996 budget. If passed, they will see the safety net that was built and strengthened by Labor in government seriously compromised. They go a long way in turning our social security safety net into a social security tightrope.

The overwhelming majority of these arise not from good policy but rather from an ideological zeal on the part of the government to slash government spending. These measures are a long way from meeting the coalition's election promises. These bills are another demonstration of the coalition's betrayal of the Australian people. They have broken promises and revealed their true colours on so many issues of importance to Australians.

They wooed voters with weasel words and rhetoric about delivering to families and about protecting the poor, the needy and the most vulnerable in our community. They said they were pro family, and they said they were about reducing unemployment. Yet they present us with legislation such as this which breaches many of their commitments, which assaults the poor, the needy and the most vulnerable in our community and which undermines the wellbeing of families.

Labor's response to this legislation and, indeed, to all the measures announced in the 1996-97 budget is based on how the measures weigh up against three principles: does a measure betray a promise, is it equitable and does it contribute to national savings? When we looked at these bills in detail, we discovered that in a great many respects the proposed legislation falls sadly short of meeting these three principles. It does betray many promises; it is inequitable; and some of the measures proposed will certainly not contribute to national savings.

The removal of a massive $1.5 billion over four years from the social security safety net alone underlies the betrayal of the government. This has to be the most cynical broken promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) because it was a promise that meant so much to the community and so many people believed it. I have to say that we in the Labor Party will not stand by and allow Australians to be betrayed.

This legislation does not reflect a commitment to protect the poor, needy or most vulnerable in our community. In fact, it is an attack on them. Many of the measures contained in the proposed legislation will actually worsen the plight of unemployed people and other social security recipients. Rather than address the issue of unemployment, the government has chosen to implement measures that will slash the range of benefits to unemployed people and to income support recipients more broadly.

As we said in our minority report, the proposed legislation is based on the premise that unemployed people are seeking to rort the system. The reality is that the majority of unemployed people are honest and genuine job seekers. The excessive and unworkable measures to tighten the activity test and expand the breach provisions, coupled with the abolition or tightening of a number of schemes that actually assisted job seekers, makes this bill very anti-unemployed. Labor believes the government's efforts should be devoted to reducing unemployment rather than to cutting people off payments.

BREAK.PARA: We are determined to amend sections of the bill to reflect a commitment to equity and to attempt to keep John Howard and his government to their commitment to protect the poor, the needy and the most vulnerable in our community. Labor cannot and will not stand by and allow the most vulnerable in our community to pay the price for the coalition's ideological obsessions.

While I do not propose now to deal with all of the measures contained in these bills in detail, I do want to refer to some of the more significant measures. Schedule 3 of the budget and other measures bill seeks to abolish the minimum rate of payment to under‐18-year-old sickness allowance, newstart allowance and youth training allowance recipients. The Labor Party will be opposing the measure by seeking to omit the schedule from the bill. The government is proposing to introduce a youth allowance from January 1998, merging all major forms of income support for young people. It will be means tested on parents' income and will cover young people aged 16 to 20 years old and students up to 25 years old.

The government is consulting on this new youth allowance, and rightly so. The proposal has far‐reaching implications for our young people and on their incentives to train and look for work. Rather than prematurely legislate to bring social security payments to young people in line with Austudy arrangements, we believe that these changes should be considered in the context of the community consultation process. Abolishing the minimum rate of youth training allowance and cutting under‐18‐year‐olds off payments on the basis of parents' income opens the door to doing the same for young people up to 25 years of age. It would be premature in the extreme to pursue this measure in the absence of the results from the consultation process.

Schedule 5 of the bill seeks to tighten the activity test administration and simplify the penalty periods that apply to newstart allowance and youth training allowance. Schedule 6 seeks to tighten the provisions relating to unemployment due to industrial action. The opposition has serious concerns about the measures contained in this schedule, and we have prepared amendments to attempt to address these concerns. I would like to make it clear that, while we support tough measures in regard to fraud and compliance, we do not believe that people should be cut off from payments without good reason, or for inordinate periods of time.

We believe that the proposed new activity test regime is one that is excessively harsh and unreasonable, particularly in the absence of positive measures by the government to assist the unemployed to return to the work force. We believe that elements of the proposal are unworkable and unfairly penalise honest and genuine job seekers.

Part 1 tightens up the use of employer contact certificates. We believe that it is unreasonable to require completed employer contact certificates to be provided with an initial claim for unemployment payments. Our amendments ensure that the employer contact certificates can continue to be utilised, but not until the person is actually receiving a payment.

Part 2 introduces a new and extreme definition of unsuitable work. The new definition puts the onus on job seekers to negotiate and overcome issues that may make a job unsuitable. It is unreasonable to compel job seekers to undertake any work offered where there is no training provided or where they lack the qualification, skills or experience necessary. The requirement to provide proof of an attempt to rectify a situation with the employer where the work conditions constitute a risk to health or safety, self-employment or a move away from home and communities to look for a job which may not exist places unreasonable obligations on job seekers to negotiate with prospective employers despite their not having the knowledge, skills, confidence or capacity to do so. We will be seeking to omit large parts of that schedule. We do concur with the government that it is unreasonable to compel a person to enlist in the reserve forces as part of taking up a job offer, and we support them on that matter.

Part 3 of schedule 5 extends the penalties for breaches of the activity test to six weeks for the first breach and 13 weeks for the second and subsequent breaches. The activity test regime that we introduced while in government is a tough one, but it was developed under an arrangement of reciprocal obligation where the community undertook to pay income support for those actively seeking work, and to provide the labour market assistance and the employment services that unemployed people need to get back into the work force. In turn, unemployed people were obliged to meet the conditions of the activity test. Penalties were tightened further under the Working Nation job compact, where people were given greater access and variety in training and guaranteed at least some work experience.

The government has abandoned the concept of a job compact and reciprocal obligation. In these circumstances, we believe the proposed penalty regime is too harsh. We will therefore be moving amendments to limit breach penalties to the equivalent of just over four weeks non-payment for a first breach and just over six weeks non-payment for a second or any subsequent breach.

We have been convinced by the case that has been put to us by community and welfare groups to impose penalties in the form of rate reduction rather than non-payment, and our amendments reflect that. We will be moving amendments which ensure that all penalties for activity test breaches or administrative breaches are served by way of a reduction in the rate of payment rather than a non-payment period.

We propose that payments be reduced by 16 per cent, slightly higher than the current withholding rate of 14 per cent. Under this regime, people's payments would be reduced for 26 weeks for a first breach—a long reminder, I might say—and for 39 weeks for a second or any subsequent breach. Under this regime, the capacity for significant savings remains without causing undue hardship.

Part 3 also introduces a period of rate reduction instead of non-payment periods for administrative breaches. We support this measure in principle but are of the view that the 25 per cent reduction is too harsh. Again, we propose a regime of a 16 per cent reduction for 13 weeks, rather than a 25 per cent reduction for eight weeks. The same principle applies to those current administrative breaches designed to become activity test breaches under part 4 of schedule 5.

Part 5 extends the non-payment period for moving to an area of lower employment prospects from 12 to 26 weeks. We believe that this measure is extremely harsh and unfair, taking little account of the range of reasons an unemployed person may seek to move home. We seek to omit this part from the schedule.

We believe that the measures contained in schedule 6 to tighten industrial action provisions to ensure that, where a person is unemployed as a result of industrial action, the person will not be eligible for a payment for six weeks after the industrial action has ceased are also unreasonable and ideologically driven.

Our concerns are detailed more fully in the minority committee report but, overall, we believe that the proposal does not sufficiently take into account the new industrial relations regime created by this government through its workplace relations legislation. The proposal is unreasonable, unworkable, untenable and unduly harsh. As a result, we will be moving to omit the schedule from the bill.

I said at the beginning of my remarks that this bill breaks election promises—promises which over the course of time have become non-core and disposable promises. It is a blatant breach of election commitments such as the commitment not to abolish the earnings credit scheme. The coalition said that the earnings credit scheme will be retained by a coalition government—black and white. This bill represents a complete breach of that—a direct broken promise, a real betrayal of the Australian people.

It is the same with employment and education entry payments. The coalition said, `The coalition will maintain the current employment and education entry payments.' That is not true—a direct broken promise, a betrayal. That is something that Labor will not allow to happen. On entering employment most social security recipients encounter considerable costs associated with the purchase of clothes suitable for work force participation and payment of child care and transport costs. These are particularly high costs for disability pensioners and those who may have to purchase additional supports or require attendant care. It is also true for people entering education. The employment and education entry payments introduced by Labor were a recognition of those costs and gave assistance in meeting them to further remove barriers to employment and education for social security recipients.

I just want to touch very briefly on schedule 13, which tightens the eligibility for disability support pension by inserting new impairment tables. We are concerned that some 34,000 people are expected to lose eligibility for disability support pension as a consequence of being reviewed under the new impairment tables and that a further 5,000 people a year on average are expected not to qualify for disability support pension under the new tables. Alternative income support payments such as Newstart allowance may not be available in all cases.

The opposition will be moving amendments to schedule 13 to restore the impairment ratings for minor disabilities not considered under the new impairment tables to contribute to a person's continuing inability to work. We will also be moving an amendment to insert a provision which allows the department to take account of non-medical factors like illiteracy in determining a person's eligibility for disability support pension if the person has an impairment rating of 15 but not the otherwise required 20 under the impairment tables.

Schedule 14 limits the payment of child disability allowance arrears to three months before a claim is made. We will be opposing this measure by seeking to omit the schedule from the bill. Again, the measure fails to recognise the hardship which can be suffered by the parents of children with disabilities which take over three months to diagnose or where it takes more than three months to establish a pattern of extra care and attention.

PARA.BREAK: Schedule 20 relates to the application of the below threshold deeming rate. We will be opposing this measure by seeking to omit the schedule from the bill. Labor supports measures which encourage social security recipi ents to maximise the return on their resources but this measure relies on pensioners and allowees being able to access safe accounts which pay interest at the deemed rate. In the current climate where interest rates have been officially cut and where the minister must again consider whether or not to cut deeming rates, the concession on the first $2,000 for a single pensioner or $4,000 for a couple is especially critical to pensioners and allowees.

BREAK.PARA: There are a number of other measures in both the bills that are before us and we will be needing to deal with all of them in tedious detail through the committee stage. But as I said earlier, I will be moving a second reading amendment to this bill, which has been circulated in the chamber. The amendment reflects the remarks that I have made in relation to the government's proposals to tighten the activity test. Labor believes it is very important to have a tight activity test regime for unemployment payments to ensure compliance and to maintain the integrity of and Australian support for our social security system. We have always believed that, and I think our actions in government confirmed that belief.

At the same time, we believe that such a regime can only be equitable if it is part of a reciprocal obligation between government and unemployed people. It is the government's obligation to provide labour market assistance and other employment services for unemployed people, that level of assistance that they need to re-enter the work force. We were the ones when in government who tightened the old work test to increase compliance and developed it to the current activity test regime. We implemented the reciprocal obligation where `an unemployed person is required to actively look for work and in return society accepts an obligation to pay income support'. That was accompanied by the reciprocal obligation on society to provide training and retraining programs for those who are expected to meet the conditions of an activity test.

We took that approach in the 1990s and further toughened up the penalties following the One Nation statement. That tightening was combined with a job compact where we gave more to unemployed people by offering them a six-month subsidised job. The government has reneged on its part of the bargain with this legislation and the activity test regime in this legislation is unconscionable in the context of the government's failure to meet its obligations to unemployment. For that reason, I move:
At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate is of the opinion that:

PARA.TAB: (a) it is important to have a tight activity test regime for unemployment payments, to ensure compliance, and to maintain the integrity of, and Australians' support for, the social security system;

(b) such a regime can only be equitable if it is part of a reciprocal obligation between government and unemployed people. The government's obligation is to provide the labour market assistance and other employment services that unemployed people need to enter or re‐enter the workforce; and
(c) the activity test regime proposed in this legislation is unconscionable in the context of the government's failure to meet its obligations to unemployed people, as evidenced by:

TAB.TAB: (i) its decision to discontinue the Job Compact;
(ii) its cuts to labour market programs;
(iii) its privatisation of the employment services functions of the Commonwealth Employment Service;
(iv) its abolition of assistance such as the employment and education entry payments and the earnings credit scheme; and
(v) its failure to even set itself targets for job creation."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The social security bills before us today implement policy changes announced in the August budget relating to the social security portfolio. As such they give us a clear indication of the attitude that those in the National-Liberal government have towards social security recipients, in particular, towards the unemployed. Unfortunately, that attitude does not seem to be one of compassion, support and encouragement but more one of enforcement, suspicion and oppression.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes without saying that this year's budget was a particularly tough one for unemployed people. The estimate from the Australian Council of Social Services was that over 30 per cent of the budget cuts over the next two years will come from low income and unemployed Australians. The cumulative impact of the budget changes which will affect unemployed people will I believe be a downward spiral into poverty.

People will have to use their savings before qualifying for an unemployment payment. The conditions on receiving a payment will be substantially tightened. The penalties for breaching one of those conditions will be increased. And all this is set against a background of $1.8 billion over the next four years being cut from Labor market programs; programs designed to help the unemployed return to the work force. In other words, as a direct result of government policy, it is going to be harder to get an unemployment allowance, harder to stay on that allowance and harder to get off the allowance and back into full-time work.

As Michael Raper from the Welfare Rights Centre recently said, `There seems to have been a shift in emphasis from seeing unemployment as the main issue to making the issue the unemployed.' ACOSS president, Robert Fitzgerald, has been reported as saying that in Australia the welfare needs of middle income earners are being put above those of the unemployed. He believes that we are adopting a system that divides middle income earners and the unemployed as the deserving verses the undeserving poor; those in true need and those not quite in need; those that we should support wholeheartedly and those we should be suspicious of. This is a dichotomy which the Democrats reject completely.

PARA.BREAK: Unfortunately, this current government seems happy to allow suspicion of the unemployed to remain in the community, and I suspect the reason for that is that it minimises the political cost of making massive cuts to the social security portfolio, which is exactly what the August budget has done. Not once since the election can I recall having heard a government minister speak with any compassion about the plight of the long-term unemployed, the difficulties faced by older unem ployed people or the desperate situation of youth unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead, what we have heard are numerous statements on how widespread welfare fraud is and the need to crack down on that alleged fraud. These statements have not been backed up with any factual evidence but instead play upon the worst misconceptions that some in our community hold in relation to our welfare system. The evidence that is available would seem to completely contradict the impression that some in government ranks and the media have been trying to put across. Let me give you an overview of the last few years in this regard. In 1993 a visiting fellow to the ANU, Dr Richard Weatherly, undertook a study looking at the compliance policies of the Department of Social Security. Dr Weatherly found:

There is no basis for the commonly held belief that fraud is rampant within the system. Compared to other domains, public and private, the incidence of Social Security fraud is modest. An analysis of overpayments identified by DSS contravenes public impressions of widespread cheating.
To my knowledge, Dr Weatherly's findings have not been criticised or challenged, yet they quite clearly contradict the line that this government has been pushing on welfare fraud.

Recently released departmental figures showed that, of over $380 million of overpayments made by the department, convictions for deliberate fraud involved just $4.7 million—about 1½ per cent. Yet the government continues to focus its attack on alleged social security fraud while saying very little about tax fraud or doctors defrauding the Medicare system; activities which cost the public purse far more than social security fraud.

In 1993 an Auditor-General's report conservatively estimated that Medifraud and doctors' overservicing of patients account for about seven per cent of the Medicare budget—in other words, over $320 million per year. In contrast, overpayments made by the Department of Social Security in the same period amounted to $130 million, with only a small proportion of that figure being due to deliberate fraud by social security clients.

BREAK.PARA: A 1994 article by community lawyer Jude McCulloch noted that despite these figures the policing of social security recipients is far stronger than that for doctors. McCulloch made a number of observations. Firstly, the system of paying Medicare claims to doctors remains essentially an honour based self‐assessment scheme, while Social Security utilises stringent personal identification requirements, data matching between government departments, regular customer reviews and other compliance measures.

Secondly, while DSS seeks prosecutions through the courts for all those committing welfare fraud, doctors are more likely to be required to undertake counselling and conciliation by a group of their peers. In 1991-92 DSS undertook more than 2½ million reviews and prosecuted more than 2,000 people. In that same year, despite the enormous amount lost through Medicare overservicing, just four doctors were prosecuted. Finally, while little public attention has been devoted to fraud by doctors the concerns about social security fraud have in McCulloch's words `taken on the dimensions of a moral panic.'

As a recent Four Corners program noted, even the terminology used when discussing these issues is different. Social security recipients are `rorters' and `cheats' while doctors have merely been `practising inappropriately'. Regrettably, what we are seeing is a hardening of the community's attitude to social security recipients and an encouragement of the suspicion of the unemployed about which Robert Fitzgerald spoke. Genuine social security recipients are being made to feel that they are a drain on the community, and there is little acknowledgment that many of them are out of work due to circumstances over which they have no control.

It is in this climate that the government has introduced the bills we are looking at today. They are bills that will give the department the power to force the unemployed to move to another town or lose their payment; prevent around 2,500 widows each year from receiving the widows pension; impose grossly unfair penalties on unemployed people who fall foul of the rules; force disabled people on to unemployment queues; force people to use up their savings before being able to receive a range of social security payments; and force older unemployed people to eat into their superannuation. The list goes on.

The Democrats are disappointed to see this legislation brought on. We totally reject the philosophy which underlies it. It is a philosophy that says it is everyone for themselves and, if you are unemployed, you deserve to do it tough. It is a philosophy that says that unemployment is the fault of the individual, that there are jobs and that unemployed people simply need to be pushed harder to look. It also says that people should be reduced to poverty before the government has any obligation to support them. The Democrats will not be supporting the tougher aspect of these bills.

I will finish with an analogy. One thing that this government has done in order to support its attack on the poor is to employ scapegoats. I will tell the Senate where the word `scapegoat' comes from. It comes out of the ancient Hebrew sacrificial system. The scapegoat was a real goat. The goat was paraded in front of the assembled nation and before the people. It was then identified by the high priest laying his hands on its head. The confession of every sin of all the people was then transferred to the goat so that the people were thereby absolved of their sin. The goat was then taken into the desert and released. The fate of the goat was of no further concern to the people. The idea was that it should never return.

PARA.BREAK: It is easy to see how that idea was adopted and adapted to become part of the English language and culture. Other cultures have similar concepts. In our culture, a scapegoat is one who is identified in the mind of the community as a focus for all that is wrong in society. That person is vilified as one to whom blame for all the community's ills should be attributed. The community is thereby absolved of responsibility and guilt. The scapegoat is in a position of weakness and, therefore, has no power to resist. It is driven out to the edges of society, where what happens to it is of no further concern to the community. All sense of guilt for the scape goat as a victim is transferred from the community to the scapegoat as the burden bearer for the community's sins. This government has clearly identified the poor as the scapegoat that it will drive to the outer edges of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I made a comparison between the largesse that this government is extending to its friends in big business, including multinational corporations, and the mingyness it is extending to hundreds of thousands of Australians.
—Is that a new word?
—If `mingyness' is a new word, it has been evoked by the attitude of this government.
—Try `stinginess'.

—No. I will stick with mingyness. On the one hand, the government is cutting $1.7 billion in four years out of the social security payments to the most vulnerable people in our society, and there are millions of them. These extend from pensioners to disabled people, the unemployed and the homeless. At the same time, it is giving $800 million per annum to a handful of mining corporations.
—Oh, you're not on that again! For God's sake, save us, will you.
—It appears that I have hit the spot as far as Senator Panizza is concerned. He will get his opportunity a bit later. I, too, would be thoroughly embarrassed if I were you.
—You don't know what you're talking about.
—Order! Address your remarks through the chair, Senator Brown.
—I am not embarrassed one bit.
—Senator Panizza, it is not helping the debate to call across the chamber. It is also not pursuant to standing orders.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I will address my remarks on the unorderly interjections opposite through you. Senator Panizza has already been thoroughly embarrassed by reference to the fact that this government—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Whether I am embarrassed or not—which I am not—has nothing to do with the debate. Will you please bring this speaker into order.
—That is not a point of order.

—You would think the government whip would know that that is not a point of order. It will not prevent me from continuing to point out to him that this government, in the matter of a fortnight, went weak at the knees when a few mining companies arrived in town and said, `We want to keep our diesel fuel rebate.' An amount of $800 million per year is being given on a platter, with $100 million going to BHP alone and tens of millions of dollars going to CRA and MIM.
—How much will that put into the economy, you fool!
—Order! Those sorts of comments are not helpful. They also reflect on another senator. I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw it.
—Senator Brown, it might be helpful for you to get on with the debate, given the timetable we have. You should at least refrain from provoking and responding to some interjections.

—As I was saying, the government should be thoroughly embarrassed, as some senators opposite are already embarrassed, by the fact that within a couple of weeks, when the mining corporations arrived in town, they went weak at the knees and backed off from a proposal that involved $800 million per year going towards filling the so-called black hole. That money has instead been diverted into the profit lines of a handful of mining corporations. We are talking about a four‐year period.

SPEECH.PARA: On top of that, the government has acknowledged that there is $800 million per annum of tax avoidance in this country by the mega‐ wealthy. This year it is going to manage to peel back perhaps $100 million of that, in other words, $700 million of tax avoidance will not be coming into the coffers this year alone. Multiply that by four years and you have got $2.8 billion dollars. Over the next four years, the government coffers will be deprived of $6 billion which will go out to the mega‐wealthy in this country, including a number of executives who are on income—not earnings, because they do not earn it, nobody could earn it, no human being is worth it—of up to $3 million per annum. These are chief executive officers who write the prescription for their own incomes and have it passed by boards in the interests of shareholders against the interests of the poor in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes—hit them with a jealousy tax.

—The honourable interjector opposite says I am jealous. I am not jealous—maybe he is. I am appalled. I hope he takes the advice from the honourable minister that his interjections are further embarrassing that side of the chamber. I am standing here because the same government that is giving $6 billion over four years to the big corporate wealth sector of town is pinching $1.7 billion out of the pockets of the needy in this country. They used to sit on the opposite side here, you will remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, and say that the Keating government was increasing the gap between rich and poor, and so it was, because it was set down this economic rationalist pathway. The parameters showed that, and the then opposition—the coalition—were able to bring out the figures. Having complained about that direction being taken, what do they do when they get into government? They tread on the accelerator. They move to turboprop and they will be moving to jet thrust in the future where the rich get richer, the poor get poorer and the social cohesion that we have taken for granted in this country gets swept away as we move to an American style social set‐up where there will be people begging on the streets.

SPEECH.PARA: You might ask: how come? Under this legislation, people who infringe in the gaining of social security either through the activities test or the administrations test, can find themselves, instead of being off the social income for two weeks, off it for up to six months. It is a summary penalty. People will be penalised by the loss of up to $4,000 in social security because they have infringed—$4,160 is the six‐month penalty. That is greater than fines common for assault in the courts of $200 to $500. They will have no income and they will be left to turn to neighbours, to friends and, the minister has said, to the Salvation Army. She is going to give more money to the Salvos and to other charitable groups to help with handouts to the new destitute that this government will create. The reality is that that is not going to cover the lot of them. There are going to be many of these people panhandling on the streets of Sydney, Melbourne, Hobart and the other large cities around this country, because they have to have some money.

Panhandling in the United States, where there are 35 million people living in poverty because of similar social attitudes to the one inherent in this legislation, is the better side of it. The worst side of it is the huge numbers of people breaking through windows, getting in back doors, invading other people's cars and stealing things, and creating a black market so that they can live. In New York, 25 per cent of the economy these days is black market, due to gangsterism and corruption, but also due to the fact that there are millions of people who just do not have enough money to make ends meet in increasingly expensive life circumstances.

Let me go back to the beginning analogy between the government handouts to the mining corporations and the government take‐aways from the poor in this country. Under the diesel fuel rebate scheme 1992‐93 to 1995‐96, BHP was given $303 million and Western Mining Corporation was given $140 million. That is a total of $443 million. This government, by continuing that over the next few years, is going to meanwhile be making people who do not comply with the rules, or who refuse to move out of an area of unemployment because their partner has a sick parent, for example, who is not covered under these rules, lose their benefits for up to 26 weeks—110,000 people affected in any given year with $377 million saved, according to the minister's figures. On the one hand, 110,000 people at the lower income level in this country will have $377 million taken out of their pockets, while two mining corporations will get $443 million put into their pockets.

If we look at CRA, it will be getting $124 million handed to it on a platter. This is tax they have paid being handed back to them, `Here you go. Put this onto your profit line. Pay your mega‐rich executives with this'—for CRA, $124 million over three years. But they are going to cut the rent assistance to young people who happen to be sharing a house by $110 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted and we will move to consideration of government business.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —This government's budget has been one of broken promises, betrayal and lies. Nowhere is this more demonstrated than in the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill that is before the Senate today. Just three days before the election, the then shadow Minister for Employment, Training and Family Services, David Kemp, wrote to the Australian Early Childhood Association saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the [Coalition] policy also states our continuing support for the community‐based long day care sector, and we regard the operational subsidy as one of the key supports of that sector. The Coalition has no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy.

There must be a lot of people out there in the community child‐care sector who wonder very much about the real commitment of this government to what they call their mandate. Part of a mandate is not only carrying out actions that you have promised and were elected on but also desisting from taking decisions and taking away funds where it has been promised that that will not occur.

The government's first budget has cut more than half a billion dollars from child care over the next four years. That is really a tragic situation. This includes the abolition of operational subsidies for community based long day care centres, cuts to child-care assistance, means testing of the child-care cash rebate and the withdrawal of funding for 5,500 new community based centres that were scheduled to be built in the next couple of years.

The government says that it has cut the operational subsidy to put the private sector on the same footing as community based child-care centres. But the fact is that all over Australia local government bodies are finding that they have less money to provide the child-care places than they had before. Just as one example, Gosford City Council wrote to me when they first became aware of this issue and said that, for their seven long day child‐care centres, they will lose $287,000 each year from the taking away of this operational subsidy. This is repeated over and over again in each local government area across Australia.

There were 380 submissions to the community affairs committee which examined this legislation, and only five argued for the abolition of the operational subsidies. Even in these submissions, it was acknowledged that there needed to be transitional arrangements for these sweeping changes. It was also recommended that operational subsidies be extended to private sector centres to meet specific objectives such as quality or educational standards.

There is an overwhelming picture out there in the community that fees will rise by approximately $25 a week per child. If you are a family with a couple of children, struggling to make ends meet, that is a lot more out of your pocket and an amount of money that a lot of people will just not be able to afford.

I have received a huge number of letters on this issue. I want to read a couple of them to indicate the depth of feeling that the community has about this particular issue and the real betrayal that people feel about having lost a subsidy that this government promised it would not take away. I have a letter here from a parent in New South Wales. It says:

I am a concerned parent of two children currently attending a council managed centre. While I am at work trying to maintain an average standard of living, I know that they're both well cared for and well fed in a happy and friendly environment. My baby is fed and changed and my son is taught basic writing. Cuts to operational subsidy will take away this wonderful care and will also take away my choice to work and provide for my children. Finances mean I must work, and I would rather have good care than none. These cuts are wrong and will affect our children in the future.

I will also read a few interesting messages that I received, which I might hand over to the Minister assisting the Minister for Health and Family Services (Senator Newman) before I go today. They say:
Who will change my baby's nappy while I am at work? I hope you will.
And:
Do you have a family? Why?

To those people who do not have to struggle to make ends meet, who do not have children in child care, who have never had to face those difficulties, it may mean little to you, but the fact is that the cuts to these operational subsidies will mean that a lower standard of care is provided. It will mean that those centres will receive less cleaning and they will not be able to provide the comprehensive educational training that they do at the moment. In some cases, they will not be able to provide the hot cooked meals that they are at the moment.

Most importantly, to those who really have sought child care in the general community, if you have a child between the ages of zero and two, you are not going to be able to find a place for that child within the private sector. For children above this age, the private sector is particularly good. But, because of the cost difficulties of providing that service for young children, if you want child care for a very young child, the only place available is in community based care. If that were the only reason—and it is not—to preserve the operational subsidy, I think that in itself would be enough. I want to express very strongly my opposition to this move and the general eroding of the provision of child‐care services in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Neal has said it all pretty well. The same situation that pertains on the central coast of New South Wales pertains in Tasmania, where at least 95 per cent of all Tasmanian long day care centres will lose their subsidies. A very critical hardship is awaiting many people if the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 goes through.

SPEECH.PARA: In Hobart the axing of subsidies to the Lady Gowrie Child Centre, which provides child care to 354 families through two centres, would cost Lady Gowrie $110,000. That will force fees up by about $20 a week. Of course, it will force many parents into unregulated backyard child care. That is the fate awaiting many people—this means many children below school age—as a result of this money-getting exercise, again, by the government, at a time when it is able to afford hundreds of millions of dollars through the diesel fuel rebate and through the failure to pick up on tax avoidance schemes to the rich and wealthy in this country.

In Launceston the children's playhouse at Ravenswood is about four kilometres outside the city centre, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is not the most privileged area in Tasmania and it is somewhat isolated from the rest of the city. Unemployed parents and students there take advantage of the children's playhouse for their children. It may have to close. It is faced, as are many similar centres around the country, with closure simply because many of the parents whose children use these centres do not have the extra money in their pockets for the extra fees that will have to be charged.

It is a process of privatising and a process of increasing the distortion between the haves and have-nots again. It is a process of giving advantage to those who have money in their pockets and making it harder for those who do not. The bottom line on this occasion is the children themselves. We all know in this place that those first few years are the most important years as far as education and care is concerned for the rest of our lives—in setting how we perform, how we are fulfilled and what we achieve in the rest of our lives.

It is pretty incredible that this government should be truncating the opportunities for everybody to access the sorts of facilities that they are so used to. Instead, the government is handing child care across to a profit oriented system which will not primarily be interested in the struggling, the disadvantaged and those children who come from the most difficult backgrounds. It will aim at improving facilities for those who already have the money to make sure they get the best for their kids. It is unfair, unnecessary and I think it is a pretty appalling delivery of social policy. The Greens are totally opposed to this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate on the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 because community based child care is important to the community in which I live in Brisbane. It has been non-profit and it has been developed over a period of time since 1970. It has always ensured high quality, affordable and accountable child care, predominantly for those who are least able to afford child care.

SPEECH.PARA: The predominant feature has been the parent involvement in community based child care in the management area, whether it be in the staffing arrangements, funds management or responding to community needs, as opposed to the private sector, which has limited the role of parent involvement primarily just to fundraising. They are distinctly different groups. Of course, the community based child care has in itself developed a real ethos and a real spirit within the community.

The operational subsidy has been very important to community based child care because in some ways it recognises the large amount of voluntary time spent by parents. This countervails the private sector, where the people who run those establishments draw salaries and are profit driven. Community based child care has, in effect, offered choice—a choice that has been extremely warranted for those who are less fortunate. Community based child care has turned any surplus after cost to the centre rather than to profit. So the ethos of these centres is very important and, of course, it builds a community spirit.

The loss of the operational subsidy will mean either a cut in services or increased fees or both. To examine this, I looked at a centre in one of the electorates close by me—that is, the federal electorate of Bowman. I looked at the Bayside Community and Child Care Centre at Wynnum. The loss of the operational subsidy at that centre will mean that $39,000 per annum will be taken away from that centre. The number of places at that centre is 43; the number of families affected is 65. One in three of the places at that centre are occupied by full-time children in child care and two out of three of the positions are occupied by children in part-time care.

The result of what the government is proposing in that particular centre sees that centre changing its fee structure from $126 per week to $141.50 per week. That is an increase of $15.50. Whilst it does not reach what we expected would be the limit, it nonetheless is a very significant increase for parents at that centre. The loss of the subsidy will, in effect, mean that the loss per place at that centre will be $17.44 per week. Therefore, there is an amount to be absorbed in the whole process. The amount to be absorbed will be in the order of $1.94 per place, which does not sound a great deal. When you convert it to a weekly amount, it is $83.42 or $4,337.84 per annum, which will not be covered by the fee increase which has been put into place in the Bayside Community Child Care Centre at Wynnum. That $4,337.84 has to be found somewhere or, in this case, it will mean a cut in the services or some other sacrifice within the operation of that particular organisation.

Whilst it does not sound an enormous amount in terms of the budget of this parliament, it is a very significant amount in terms of a small organisation, such as the community based child‐care centre at Wynnum. This has undoubtedly meant an increase in cost for families. They are absorbing part of the increase—$15.50 per week. Put this together with other government initiatives which are attacking child care, and you will find that even with the family tax initiative the battlers will still be behind.

The importance of community based child care is that it is more likely to accommodate infants under the age of three, children with special needs—particularly those from non‐English speaking backgrounds—and those with disabilities. It seems that the government, in trying to create a level playing field for community based child‐care centres and the private sector, has overlooked the fact that we are not comparing apples with apples. What is coming to the fore is more of the economic rationalist pragmatism of the government, and we see community based child‐care centres being caught up in the ideological battle that the government wages. It is very hard to tell people in the disadvantaged groups that there is a level playing field when, in effect, child care is going to cost them more.

The other side of this debate that interests me is what is going to happen in rural and regional centres. I understand that, in the portfolio budget statements that came out, the government did give certain undertakings in respect of country centres. But I have looked at a list of 16 towns in Queensland and I wonder what their fate will be, even with the government undertakings. Whilst there is some undertaking to maintain some subsidy or some element of subsidy where there is disadvantage, what we are going to end up with, if that is the case, is two different classes of community based child‐care centres: those that have an operational subsidy, and those that have no subsidy whatsoever.

That then raises the question of what will happen if those particular centres that are given some exempt status now are, in the future, faced with a private competitor. That is a concern, when you look at the range of centres that currently in Queensland rely wholly and solely on community based child care. They may be exempt today in some country centres, but they may be out of business tomorrow, because from what I can see there are no guidelines from the government at this stage for the support of rural and regionally based child‐care centres, which are the sole providers of child care in those places.

The government has offered some money to assist community based child‐care centres to purchase the financial management ability to enable them to restructure. Basically, this money will go to accountants and consultants who will know about the economic imperative of running some of these community based child‐care centres but will not know about the social imperative of the underlying social ethos that occurs in these places.

I believe the department has already written to a number of community based child‐care centres, advising them of the list of consultants, even before this legislation is passed. That is very pre‐emptive at best, and tacky at worst. I question the value of this change and of the assistance that has been given. While the assistance will nonetheless be important in these centres, when you look at the turnover of personnel in the community based child‐care centres over a short period of time, you can see how that assistance, which is confined to 12 months, really needs to be given over a longer period of time. I have looked at the second reading speech, and it is devoid of any real detail as to who will get the assistance, how long they will get the assistance for, and the criteria to be applied in the case of regional and rural community based child care.

The other fear that has been expressed to me in this debate is this: whilst the operational subsidy is in focus today, is it going to be the capital works grants that will be in focus tomorrow? This manic, driven desire to reach a level playing field may well cause the capital works grants to become the focus in years to come, although not currently. The government's move to remove the operational subsidy to community based child care is ill timed and ill conceived, and it ignores completely the community spirit in the community based child‐care centres. It is something that is completely unwanted by this child‐care sector, which is so important in our community today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, although more in sorrow than in anger, I have to say. I must remind the Senate again that it is very depressing for me to read the letter of 28 February this year from Dr Kemp—I do not have it with me, but I have it in my office—advising that there was absolutely no intention to alter or change the operational subsidy and that there was no intention to run down, or in any way move against, community based child care.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said in a number of debates that, if that was the promise and the argument being put to the people of Australia in the run‐up to the election, a lot of people in the community could feel extraordinarily cheated as a result of this government's actions immediately it had won the election. The government has absolutely savagely attacked the community based sector. There is no commitment to expand the community based child‐care sector. All further development of this area has now ceased. That is so deliberately and directly contrary to the empty assurances that Dr Kemp was giving that I believe people could feel—and very properly—well beyond annoyed: betrayed, actually.

The operational subsidy to the community based sector has been an ongoing concern for a long time, particularly in the debate about how to get some kind of equity between the private child‐care centres, which do not get the operational subsidy, and the community based centres, which do. It is not the first time that there has been discussion or debate about this. But it certainly is an extraordinary move to abolish it completely in one fell stroke and to not really address, with any serious dollars, what it is that has made the community based sector deliver a different sort of child‐care centre and, in very large manner, to justify the operational subsidy dollars.

I believe it is going to be very critical for government to establish some kind of close monitoring, perhaps even more than the accreditation program, of the quality between the two sectors—and, in particular, of the ongoing quality within the community based sector—as a result of these dramatic changes. I cannot argue it any better than the back of the explanatory memorandum, which points out, under the heading `Financial impact', that the savings from removing the operational subsidy will be $108.8 million over the first four years—that is net, as I understand it—after taking into account $10 million for support for children with high additional needs, especially children with disabilities.

I presume that that is an amount of money extra to the supplementary allocations, which presumably will not be changing—but I do not hold my breath on that. There will also be $8.3 million over two years for advice to services, and $4.1 million per year for supplementary grants for severely disadvantaged areas. A lot comes out—$108.8 million net in savings—as against something like $22 million going back in. It is laughable that you could possibly expect that centres that are going to lose $108 million will be able to seriously continue with anything like the same sort of quality child care, when they have so much less money to assist them.

I suspect that there is always room for efficiencies in child care, as there is in schools, in parliament and everywhere else. You should never rest on your laurels by thinking that you have got it perfect. But this is way beyond any ordinary understanding of what might be efficiencies in the system. I am very concerned because, as my colleagues have explained, the fees will rise very dramatically.

Most centres have indicated that their fees will rise from 1 January because that is going to assist them with spreading the increased costs over the year. It is also, of course, when parents are more likely to join up for child care and it makes good sense for centres to set their fee rise from that time. I am not sure that all centres will do it, but I certainly have advice that many will.

That means that, as of 1 January, while parents are getting their $4 tax handout in one hand they will be losing at least $20, if they have littlies in child care, from the other. It lends a whole new flavour to the notion of a fistful of dollars: while they are giving you money with one hand in the front, they are picking your pocket around the back—and taking far more than they are giving. Families will know that. Indeed, they know it now and they are very concerned about it.

I appreciate that a lot of the arguments are directed at the impact on working families. Some of my colleagues have also highlighted that the increased fees will not only hurt working families. They are going to hurt families who are preparing to go back to work, where somebody may be studying or training and simply cannot take up those opportunities if they do not have child care; at that stage, they may well be receiving no extra income. So, for the benefits for their family, all they will see will be an extra $20 going out per week, and that is with just one child. I am giving a ballpark figure; according to some estimates, it could well be much more than that.

There is also a great concern in this place that child‐care centres were—to quote some of those opposite in times past—dragging children out of the home, taking them from mothers' breasts and putting them into the hands of the state. I think we have passed that kind of rhubarb nonsense, although there are a few from the Lyons Forum who probably still use that sort of language. But the real problem is that there is a failure to recognise that many people using child care use it for occasional care. They use it for appointments, for visits and voluntary work, and to take a break, to get some respite, from the pressures of littlies. They are going to have those opportunities in the balance because of increased fees. For many families it just means that they will no longer participate.

We have heard so many people explain that the benefits of child care are far greater than just having a place to put the little one while you go and work. It has never been like that. It has never been the intention of child care to be up‐market baby‐sitting—anything but. The one strong word coming out of child care, just as much as it comes out of families, is that it is the quality of care that is provided to our children that matters. What child care has been doing all along, at least from the Labor Party's point of view, is assisting families in the invaluable work they do in rearing children. It has not been supplanting them; it has been supplementing them. For many families, that supplement—the extra assistance, the socialising for the children and for parents, the expanding of ideas of what little ones can do or what parents might provide to do with their children—will now be going.

I cannot say it better than my Tasmanian colleagues have done in highlighting the challenges for so many of the child‐care centres around Tasmania. I cannot claim to have visited them all, but I have certainly visited many. And so many of them are in areas where there is only a limited option for employment. Many of the parents using those centres are using them more under the occasional care banner and they simply will not be able to continue to do so.

There are a few questions I would like to ask the minister, or put on notice, and I think it is important to have answers to them. In the explanatory memorandum, on page 2, there is a comment in relation to the child‐care cash rebate—another broken promise. It says:
The Childcare Cash Rebate will not be claimable for care provided by a partner in a child care business to the dependent child of another partner in that business;
I would certainly like some elaboration on that point as to exactly what sorts of children are meant. That is, does this mean those partners are still partnered and not separated?

It is not quite clear in the explanatory memorandum exactly what circumstances this would cover and what payments would be prevented by it. I would appreciate some comment on that. I would also like to know where these changes fit with the government's claim for a national plan for child care. These steps will quite clearly make a very significant inroad into community based child care. There was also the promise in the budget that there be no further community based child care. How does that fit with a national plan for child care? Will we be seeing private child‐care centres taking up whatever further requirements there will be for child care? Is there any proposal to moderate and assist the closure of child‐care centres, which so many of us anticipate will be required as a result of this legislation?

BREAK.PARA: One of the harsh things for me is to have seen, over three years, a significant coming together of the two sectors of child care—the private and the community based. Indeed, I am very struck by the powerful combination of those two sectors now working very closely together to see the continuation of viable child care. I do not believe that this piece of legislation will assist the development of child care. It will not assist families—in fact, families will be the most injured. It is also important to note that the number of people employed in child care will now be under significant threat.

This legislation is a major concern to me, especially when I look at this piece of legislation in conjunction with the industrial relations changes. The commitment to equal remuneration has gone, and the award protection for part‐time and casual work has gone. Eighty per cent of workers in those areas are women. When we look at the changes for part‐time work—the lack of protection and ongoing income security—and now this increase in child‐care fees, we can make only one conclusion, and that is that this government would like to see a significant move of women in the work force out of the work force and back into the home. I do not believe that this supports the choices of families. Also, asking families to take $4 with one hand and pay out $20 to $25 with the other is not assisting them. This piece of legislation should be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, having particular regard to its effect on working women. I start with this quote:
