SPEECH.PARA: We have long accepted in the Coalition that the provision of adequate, affordable available child care facilities ought to be part and parcel of the armoury of facilities and policies that are available for both men and women in Australian society in the 1990s.

It may surprise people on this side of the chamber, and parents concerned about the future operation of community based long day care centres, that that was, in fact, a quote from an address that Mr Howard gave to the Coalition Women's Forum in 1995. I know it surprised me because it is far removed from the actions of the coalition government in announcing the budget plans for child care.

I want to touch briefly on the issue of women in the work force, and particularly their struggle. I bring to this debate experience from the trade union movement, from a union which represented a significant number of women who were employed in many occupations in the work force, including women working in child‐care centres. I bring to this debate the experiences of a great many women who work in many industries and also the direct experiences of women who work in child‐care centres, particularly in Tasmania.

I can say that with regard to the women who work in the centres I have not met a more dedicated group of women, young and old, and my organisation worked to see that they were properly represented with respect to pay and conditions. They are not a militant bunch of people. They are very dedicated, like nurses and other of the caring professions, to the duties that they have.

Those centres that we have visited operate in all of the areas of the state of Tasmania, from the west coast, north‐west coast, rural and remote areas, and Launceston—the city that the minister resides in. We heard earlier mention of the Ravenswood Centre, which will be threatened by these measures, as will many centres in Hobart and in the surrounding environments. All of those centres exist for one reason, and that is because there is a need for care. They do not exist because there is a government policy that there should be child‐care centres. They do not exist because there is funding. They exist because there is a need for care, and, predominantly, the care is provided for working families.

If child care is not affordable then, firstly, as has already been stated, people will forgo child care. They will either withdraw from the work force, or they will seek inferior, perhaps backyard, options. But the withdrawing from the workforce will be a significant event for many of the women who use care. Many women go to work because there is an economic necessity. But they work also because they want to be a contributing part of their household. They want their skills recognised not only in the home. Many of the women in the workforce contribute skills and their time and work very hard in the home, as well as performing an occupation. Affordable child care has been an important aspect in making that possible and dealing with the aspirations, as well as the living standards, of working women in the community. Without that provision, there will be a diminution of the quality of life and the expectations of a lot of women in the Australian community.

I want to draw senators' attention to the repeated word `choice' that time and time again this government has bandied around. I refer senators to the address to the coalition women's forum on 23 June 1995. Mr Howard then said:
The second great principle is that and this is very important to many of the tenets of debate about policy these days and that is that it is the role of government to provide and facilitate choice.
Let us have a look at the type of choice that Mr Howard is offering parents of Australia.

They have the choice to pay exorbitant fees for quality child care, or they have the choice to use backyard child care, or they have the choice to leave work because affordable child care does not exist. Probably, some will have the choice of moving to another child‐care centre because some people cannot afford choice, and the first centre will close because it becomes economically unviable. A centre like Ravenswood, in particular, will be affected. That centre has been struggling because it is in a high unemployment area and the provision of care in that area has made it difficult to keep the centre economic. If more people withdraw from it, then I have no doubt that the Ravenswood centre will close, unless there is money handed to it, which seems to me to be rather contradictory to the intent of this bill.
I once again refer to John Howard's address to that women's forum. He said:

I want to say something about the principles that the Liberal party would bring to policies affecting women and then to say a few more specific things. The first and most obvious of all the principles that one has to state is that we do believe in a society which is built on the notion that every individual is special and important in his or her own right, and the most valuable, ongoing thing that any Government can do is to create a society where people have the opportunity to fulfil their own aspirations and their own hopes and their own dreams, to make their own opportunities and to have a feeling of self‐fulfilment which is so very important for all individuals, be they men or women.

That is obviously not true. It is, in fact, yet another non‐core promise that was fed to the voters of Australia. The coalition promised many things to working parents of Australia. Dr Kemp, on 28 February this year, said:

The policy also states our continuing support for community based long day care centres, and we regard the operational subsidy as one of the key supports of that sector. The coalition has no plans whatsoever to change the operational subsidy.

That was in February. In July, the coalition announced the abolition of the operational subsidy for community based long day care. What a short‐term promise. I believe that Australians will find that such a blatant disregard of the truth and of the needs of working parents is not only wrong but offensive.

This is not the only attack on child care in the coalition budget. Over the next four years we will see cuts to the tune of half a billion dollars. We will see cuts to child‐care assistance. We will see means testing of the child‐care cash rebates and we will see the withdrawal of funding for over 5½ thousand new centre based places to be built over the next few years.

I ask the coalition: who will suffer the most as a result of these draconian measures? Make no mistake about it, women, in a majority of cases, will be the parents who have to make the decision to leave work, to leave study and to leave the careers that they fought so hard to attain. I will now quote from a letter that I received recently from a constituent. She says:

It seems incredible that after studying extremely hard for 5 years at Uni, at some hardship, that I may now have my future career put in jeopardy by such shortsighted funding cuts. I am sure I am not the only person who finds themselves in the situation where it is barely worthwhile financially to make the effort to work. It seems that the more we honest Australians try to better our lives and the lives of our families the more is taken away from us . . . I work . . . so that my family can maintain a reasonable standard of living which we cannot do on my husband's salary. We do not enjoy a lavish lifestyle by any stretch of the imagination.
The writer goes on to implore the Senate to do the following:

Oppose this budgetary measure and allow us to continue to improve our future and that of our child. Don't let Australia return to the old draconian times, where only one parent could contribute to the family's income.

It is becoming blatantly obvious that what the coalition will do, by implementing these measures, is force women out of the work force and back into full‐time child‐care roles. Where is the choice in that? Mr Howard said:
But when it comes, importantly when it comes to the matter of childcare arrangements, it is parents who are best able to decide what is the best childcare arrangement for their children
He further said:
. . . it's a question of whether we give people enough mechanisms to enable them to choose the kind of lifestyle that they want.

I agree with the Prime Minister there and that is why I am at a loss to understand why the coalition government chooses to remove mechanisms that enable women, particularly working women, to choose the lifestyle that they want for themselves and for their families. I urge the Senate to oppose this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. The primary justification for the abolition of the operational subsidy for community based child care is to encourage services to become more efficient and cost competitive with the private sector. Taking that into consideration, and when I have visited community based long day care centres located in the townships of Tasmania, I have always been vigilant about any inefficiencies in a particular long day care service. Not on any occasion, to date, have I, after visiting and speaking to the dedicated coordinators, committee members, staff, volunteers and parents, come away with the view that a particular centre does not do its utmost to provide a service second to none.

SPEECH.PARA: Services such as the Ulverstone Child Care Centre—I know the Ulverstone Child Care Centre very well because it is where my office is situated—epitomise the picture that was presented to the committee of despair and unhappiness on the part of centre operators faced with the abolition of the operational subsidy. The Ulverstone centre, established 22 years ago, is licensed to care for 56 children. It is currently providing a quality service to approximately 200 children from families living within the town and outlying areas, with some families travelling up to 40 kilometres for care.

The present fee charged is only just affordable to parents, due to the fact that the area remains economically depressed—and I think Senator O'Brien touched on that. Many of the parents work in rural industries on a seasonable basis. Many are undergoing retraining or studying, or they are looking for work. Almost 50 per cent of parents utilising the centre are in receipt of the maximum child‐care assistance. Many other parents receive child‐care assistance at a very high level.

In recognition of the clients they serve, the committee, in conjunction with the local government, has always been conscious of operational costs and has ensured that staffing, which makes up 80 per cent of the budget, has been as flexible and yet as workable as possible. They roster their staff on and off at times when it suits the people who leave their children there. The centre has maintained a commitment to those families in the district and to ensuring that they remain receptive to the wants and the needs of the parents. The operational subsidy has been central to the maintaining of a high quality child‐care service to these many parents.

The centre has operated, year in and year out, as a break‐even proposition, with no money being set aside or invested but, rather, with money being pumped back in to provide, for example, much needed care in the district for children under the age of two. I understand there are only limited places in family day care for those two years old and under. The committee has advised that a fee increase for parents of between $22 to $24 a week is expected with the loss of the operational subsidy. Care for children under two will probably go altogether. A private centre has just opened in the town and it does not care for children under two either.

Since this debate began, that scenario at Ulverstone has been repeated to me from Circular Head Child Care Centre, which is in the far north‐west of Tasmania, to the Rosebery Centre on the west coast, from the Children's Playhouse at Ravenswood in Launceston to the Blackmans Bay Centre in the south of Hobart. East, west, south and north—all of Tasmania's community based long day care centres are up in arms about this bill.

The unhappiness being experienced by the hardworking staff and volunteers is well‐founded. They fear that, with this measure, an option will be taken away from some parents and others will have to suffice with poorer quality child care. In many respects what is so irksome for staff and volunteers is the knowledge that, with the loss of operational subsidy, they have to wind back the level of service that they have striven so hard to achieve over the years in ensuring that they remained the No. 1 long day care centre in their region.

They cannot come to terms with this measure as many have heard the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) state, in justifying the abolition of the operational subsidy, that 70 per cent of long day care places are provided by the private sector and 30 per cent by the community based sector. That is not the case in Tasmania, where the reverse is true. Seventy‐three per cent of child care in my state is community based; the remainder is so‐called private. However, a number of these private services are not, in fact, true private or operated for profit services as they are sponsored by schools or hospitals. So operators of centres in Tasmania are saying to me that the level playing field argument of the economic rationalists has no relevance.

Many in Tasmania see the abolition of the subsidy, which was introduced with no prior consultation, as a national measure mooted by the National Commission of Audit with no regard to what may have been the position in Tasmania. There has been no effort by the government to explain to the centres and parents in Tasmania why they have to become more cost competitive when there are so few private players, except in places like Sandy Bay.

Tasmania is getting the rough end of the stick on this matter, at a time when parents cannot afford the impost of a fee increase, let alone the dismantling of a system that was working perfectly well. An argument may be raised with regard to the cost‐competitiveness of long day care centres in Melbourne or Sydney, but the economics arguments do not hold water in Tasmania. There would not be too many economic rationalists in Tasmania. I have not yet heard any speak. I appeal to the government to look very carefully at the Tasmanian situation and take into account that, as I have already stated, our percentage figures are very different from those in the rest of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the arguments against the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill. I wish to address my remarks to the aspect of the bill that seeks to abolish the operational subsidy to long day care centres. First, I must declare my interest as a consumer of their services. I have two young children currently enrolled in a community based child‐care centre and, as a result, I benefit from the payment of the operational subsidy to that centre, the Subicare Centre in Subiaco, which receives in the order of $40,000 per annum to help meet its operating costs.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to congratulate my colleagues on their contributions to the debate. Their interest and their contributions have made out the case that the removal of the operational subsidy cannot be justified. We are particularly concerned as this measure is just one of a number of measures which the government introduced in the budget which represent a widespread attack on child care in our community. They also therefore represent an attack on the ability of women to be able to work and to know that their children can be placed in quality child care, if they choose to take that option. It does, as Senator O'Brien pointed out, remove the choice that is open to families.

BREAK.PARA: I have spoken with, and have been written to by, hundreds of Western Australian women and by men. They are all concerned about the government attack on child care funding; about what it will mean in increased costs to them; about what it means for the quality of child care in Australia; and about what it means for the values that they hold as being important in the provision of child care. It is some of those issues regarding values that I want to address in a few remarks today, because some of the other arguments have already been well put by my colleagues.

I am an advocate of community based child care. Over the past 20 years, those centres have performed an excellent job in providing high quality child care for young children in our community. They grew from voluntary community action; from groups of people in our community seeing a need and working together to establish, as a community initiative, centres that would provide a resource for working families and their communities. Their objectives had educational and philanthropic aspects. The centres have become part of their local communities—an important and integral part—and they help to build our society and our communities by contributing positive values and positive aspects to people's lives.

Their priorities have become a benchmark for the industry. Child development principles; the use of quality, trained staff; support for parents: all have become priorities of the whole industry, as the private sector has sought to try to emulate the standards set and the values that community child‐care centre staff brought to the job that they did. They have been very crucial to the building of the child‐care industry in this country and to the building of the values and the ethos of that industry.

They are providing Australia with what is, as I understand it, one of the best quality child‐care industries in the world. The work of the community based centres has helped shape the whole industry by providing a positive contribution and positive values to our communities. In addition, as other speakers have said, they have provided specialist services to disadvantaged persons and to children with disabilities, and they have filled what would otherwise be a gaping hole by providing services for children under the age of two.

One of the great concerns I have about this measure is that I suspect that it will lead to an enormous shortfall in places for children aged zero to two in child care in Australia. The community based centres have effectively used the subsidy to provide staffing in child‐care rooms which provide for children under the age of two. It is an area where private providers have not been keen to provide places because of the extra staff and the resources required in providing care for those younger children.

As someone who has placed both his children in child care before the age of two, I think that people are more apprehensive about this prospect when the children are so young. They are very concerned to ensure that the quality of care is of a high standard and that all the facilities are provided. So, it is a labour intensive and costly exercise. It is a fact of the history of child care in Australia that the community based centres have provided a lot of those places because of the unwillingness of the private centres to take on that work and because, as I say, of the ethos of community based centres.

The government really needs to answer the question as to what is to happen to those places. How is it going to ensure that those places for children under the age of two continue to be provided as community based centres start to deal with the fact that they have a large section of their income withdrawn by the removal of the subsidy? They will have to make hard decisions, and those decisions will go to the question of numbers of trained staff, provision of places for disabled children, places for children under the age of two, and to some of the other quality issues that have become a feature of community based child‐care centres.

I do not want to labour the point, but I do want to make the point that the government has no mandate for these changes. The government wrote to concerned groups prior to the election saying that it would not remove the subsidy. It committed itself to the maintenance of the subsidy. So, parents and women, in particular, around this country are angry because the government misled them and reneged on its undertakings in making this enormous attack on child care and, particularly, in its attack on the community based centres. Those parents and those centres have a right to be angry with this decision and that is why, I think, all senators would be justified in opposing this bill.

What most concerns me about this measure is that it reflects ideology at work, rather than good management from the government. I am not sure, seeing their changes to child care announced in the budget, what their view of the future of the industry is. I do not see what the grand plan for child care of this government is—
Senator Newman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be very glad if you would, Senator Newman, because I have read the debates in the House of Representatives and it certainly was not clear to me. I suspect that what happened when Cabinet were going through the budgetary process was that someone said, `Here are a few hundred million dollars we can save.' I have some very real concerns that the government does not seem to have a view of the industry, or the long‐term future of the industry. We have obviously had the EPAC report and that raises a number of vital policy issues.

BREAK.PARA: I suspect that the previous government had a view of the role of child care in society, its role in helping women return to the workforce after having children, its positive role in maximising the potential of their productivity and for using their skills and abilities. I do not think this government has that view. I do not think that by these changes they are doing anything to support the very important national objective of allowing women to contribute to the national economy, to use their skills and to maximise their personal abilities and potential.

I think that as a result of this move by the government, we will end up with a privatised child‐care industry. I have spoken to a number of community centres that have said that they will struggle to continue. But, even in the case of those that are able to maintain their position, one wonders what will happen to the values and the quality of care they provide because, effectively, they have been told that they have to compete on the same basis as private centres. That is fine, but that means that the sorts of things that community based centres did that the private centres were not able to do will now no longer be able to be afforded, and that is my great concern.

What will happen to those community values, to the role that parents and other members of the community play in the control of those centres, in helping to develop curriculum and policies, in fundraising and in the general life of the community? As someone who helped deliver some material for the annual fundraising fete for our child‐care centre the other day, I know that the centre is very much an important part of the community. What role will there be for those community values, for parents and other members of our community, in this new world of privatised child care? It seems to me that we would not accept such a move by the government if it was in primary school education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't give them any ideas, Senator Evans.

—We would not accept a situation where, say, all primary school education had to be private, and where government or community based schools were told that they had to operate on a for‐profit basis. I know that is not an exact comparison but it seems to me that the government is saying that there is no role for the government or the community in the provision of child care.

BREAK.PARA: If those early years are the most important developmentally, if it is a vital time of a young child's life, why are we so keen to ensure that the community is driven out of a role in the care of these children but rather leave it to market forces in private centres? I cannot accept that that is a good result. I cannot understand the logic and, quite frankly, I reject the suggestion utterly.

The government seeks to make a big play of the equity argument and, to be honest, there are some issues here that need to be examined. The government argues that people in need in some areas do not have access to subsidised centres, whereas people like me, who live in middle‐class areas, have access to subsidised centres. I think there is an important argument there.

I concede to the government that there are issues there that need to be addressed. But I do not know that the answer is to say, `We will take away the whole subsidy to all community based centres. Therefore, there will be equity because no‐one will be getting any support.' All centres will be reduced to the lowest common denominator, and the standards and the values that those community based centres have built will be wiped out but everyone will be equal, everyone will be even on this lowest common denominator platform.

I do not know that that is a constructive way to deal with the issue of equity in the provision of the operational subsidy. I think there has to be a much more clever response than that. As I said, I think this government's response is driven by the demand to reduce outlays in the budget. It is not driven by a view of how we can reshape the industry, or how we can reorganise or redesign the payment of operational subsidy to ensure that the values of the community centres—high quality staff and community values being represented within the centres—are maintained. I think there is an equity issue that has to be addressed. I think the government ought to be looking at those longer‐term issues of location of subsidised centres, of equity between those in community based centres and those in private centres.

But to destroy that section of the industry that has provided the standards, the leadership and the quality care for many thousands of Australian children is not the answer. We will not solve anything by destroying community centres in this country. We ought to be ensuring that their standards and their values are spread throughout the industry so that we continue to have a very high quality child‐care industry.

With those comments, I conclude my argument. I have not covered all of the issues that I would like to cover but they have been addressed in other debates. I think my colleagues have addressed them very competently. It is my honest hope that the Senate will reject this change and force the government to think far more constructively and imaginatively about the future of community based centres in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 that we are considering introduces two of the major changes to child care which were announced in the budget: the abolition of operational subsidies for community based long day care centres and the introduction of means testing for the child‐care cash rebate. This government justifies abolishing operational subsidies for community based child‐care centres on the basis that it will force these centres to compete on an equal footing with privately operated child‐care centres. That is, this government believes that by abolishing operational subsidies it will create a level playing field—one of the most overused and misused phrases in the English language—within the long day care sector and that this will lead to more efficient child‐care provision.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats do not believe that the government has fully considered the effect this decision will have on many families. That is reinforced by the extensive number of visits I have made to child‐care centres, both private and community based, and by the many deputations I have had from individuals and peak bodies. We are not convinced that leaving the future development of long day care centres to the mercy of market forces is necessarily a desirable or realistic thing to do. In fact, we would say that it is simply saying, `Our children are commodities to be split up, bargained for or auctioned, if you like, in the marketplace.' That is really what we are saying when we say that market forces will sort it out.

PARA.BREAK: I was very interested to read the majority report of the Community Affairs Legislation Committee's hearing on this issue. What intrigued me most was to see how closely that report followed the official coalition party line on operational subsidies. I have been in the Senate long enough to know that political considerations usually take precedence over most other things. However, even given that qualification, I find it very difficult to under stand how the majority of members on that committee could reach the conclusion they did when only five out of 380 submissions voiced any support for this course of action at all. Mathematically, it makes the mind boggle.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee members who signed the majority report are members of the coalition. I guess that is probably not all that hard to understand after all. But while I accept that the old adage `It's quality, not quantity' may ring true in some situations, I really think that giving that much weight to five submissions out of some 380 does draw a very long bow. Let me remind the Senate that the commitment to abolishing operational subsidies contained in the majority report flies in the face of the coalition's pre‐election promises—but that does not seem to be a consideration these days.
As David Kemp explained to the Australian Early Childhood Association on 28 February this year, just two days before the election was held:

The Coalition policy also states our continuing support for the community‐based long day care sector, and we regard the operational subsidy as one of the key supporters of that sector. The Coalition has no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy.

That is plain enough, I would have thought. Since the budget was handed down in August, I have had thousands of letters—and I mean that quite literally—from parents and community day care workers expressing concern about the possible impact of abolishing operational subsidies and the impact that will have on the cost and quality of child care.

Some of the concerns which have been raised with me include these: fees in community based centres will rise by up to $20 per child per week; some community based centres will be forced to close because parents will not be able to meet the increased fees; some families, particularly poorer families, will be forced to withdraw from child‐care services; and the standard of quality in some community centres will be compromised. Whether or not all of these fears eventuate remains to be seen. But we need to underline in this chamber that the state where this will impact most heavily is Tasmania. I do not need to comment on that any further.

The Democrats do not believe that this government should be taking such a drastic step as abolishing operational subsidies without first undertaking a comprehensive review of the role this funding plays and determining what will be the likely effect abolishing operational subsidies on families. Perhaps such a review would confirm that operational subsidies no longer play the role they were originally intended to. Perhaps a review would also confirm that operational subsidies need to be better targeted. But until such a review has been undertaken we cannot know. We will oppose this section of the bill today and we will remain firm in our opposition to the abolition of operational subsidies until the government undertakes a full and comprehensive review of this whole area.

The Democrats deplore the way this government has attacked families. We believe that increasing the costs of child care, of medicine, of tertiary education, of home and community care services—and the list goes on and on—makes a mockery of this government's pledge to make things better for families through the much heralded family tax initiative. There is little doubt that, for many families, the additional cost of living which will result from this government's policies will far exceed the amount this government is giving them through the family tax initiative. This bill is really about a very massive experiment in radical social engineering. It is a change from community values to profit based child care, as though children have no value unless it is a dollar value.

I will now turn to the second major change contained in this bill: the introduction of means testing for the child‐care cash rebate. After weighing up all the arguments with regard to means testing this benefit, the Democrats have decided to support the government on the implementation of this measure. I would like to point out, however, that this was not a position that we arrived at either lightly or easily. I want to acknowledge that there is a strong case for not means testing this benefit.

BREAK.PARA: However, the case against the introduction of means testing for the child‐care cash rebate hinges on the view that child care is a legitimate work related expense and that all families should be entitled to some recompense for the cost of work related child care. Those who support this perspective draw comparisons between child care, which is not tax deductible, and other work related expenses, such as union fees, stationery items, uniforms and protective clothing, which are tax deductible. In an ideal world, the Democrats would be happy to support this position. However, we do not believe we can justify not means testing the child‐care cash rebate when so many other crucial programs, in areas such as unemployment, health care, aged care and disability services, are also facing such brutal and significant cuts in funding.
Debate (on motion by Senator Newman) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, I refer to your continued inability to accept that the scrapped Commonwealth dental health scheme is inevitably going to impact on the poor, the sick and the vulnerable. Are you aware, Minister, that Victoria has now followed New South Wales in abolishing its free dental health service, forcing thousands of school kids, pensioners and concession card holders to pay up to $100 for dental treatment?

PARA.BREAK: Is your response simply to pass the buck, as you did on Tuesday when you said the New South Wales decision is purely a matter for the New South Wales government and that the dental health program `is and always has been the states' responsibility'? Is your colleague the Victorian Minister for Health, Mr Knowles, wrong in claiming that he has been forced into this decision by your budget cuts? Is the head of Dental Health Services Victoria, Mr Dooland, wrong in saying, `The blame goes to the Commonwealth absolute ly—they have been heartless, nothing short of it'? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the Labor Party is particularly interested in this issue. I suppose it is not surprising since it introduced the extra funding to help the states out with their long queues. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth was involved in funding dental health schemes for only three years. The purpose of the extra funding was to bring down the size of the queues, as I said. I am advised that that funding has had a substantial impact on reducing those queues.

ANSWER.PARA: In the difficult economic climate we inherited from the previous federal Labor government, we were forced to make savings in areas where one might not in other circumstances have chosen to. I have said this before in this place. Nevertheless, the dental health schemes in Australia have always been the responsibility of the states. I stand by that. I have said it before several times and I say it again. Victoria's decision to introduce a co‐payment for dental services is its management decision of its scheme. It is a matter for which the state has responsibility.

I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that, prior to the recent funding scheme from the Commonwealth, some of the states did charge co‐payments. It is not a new phenomenon in the practice of the states. It is not clear why the cessation of Commonwealth funding after 3½ years should suddenly cause Victoria to charge for services which had been provided free of charge long before the Commonwealth had become involved.

The Commonwealth expects that the states will continue to meet their traditional commitments. If there is blame, let the blame go right to the guilty party. The blame goes to the Labor government that left the federal books in such a mess that $10 billion had to be found to get them right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you claim your government is protecting the poor, the needy and the vulnerable, yet at the same time you are forcing the states to charge the poor, the needy and the vulnerable for dental care and, as Minister Moylan admitted yesterday, for health and community services. Can you find a shred of compassion for people like Betty Blackmore of the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation who, after Mr Knowles's announcement yesterday, said in despair, `Why not give us a cyanide pill so we can take it when we have had enough'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of those stupid questions that you expect are designed for reproduction upstairs. The reality is that the Labor Party has no monopoly on compassion. This government has an extraordinary amount of compassion for those people who were put out of work, stayed out of work and have been out of work for far too long in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The poor and the vulnerable in this country are largely—not entirely—from two sources: the results of marriage breakdown and the results of long-term unemployment. While I do not blame the Labor Party for all the marriage breakdowns in Australia, financial stress on many marriages has contributed to the breakdowns. Because of the previous government's lack of concern when the number of unemployed in this country rose to a million, because of its total lack of consideration for people in that position and because of its pretend schemes for work, it makes me sick to hear that question. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, my question concerns the government's massive increase in funding for Australia's environment following the Senate's approval for the one-third sale of Telstra.
—It is not a massive increase.
—Senator Collins, it is over $1 billion—that is a massive increase. Could the minister outline the benefits of this $1.1 billion funding through the establishment of the Natural Heritage Trust?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a great night for Australia last night in that the funding base was secured for the largest environmental rescue package in the history of this nation. No government has ever been as committed to the environment as the Howard government.
—That is rubbish.

—Well, no government has ever been prepared to set up a Natural Heritage Trust with a capital base now of $1.1 billion to reinvest in our natural heritage. That $1.1 billion, I am pleased to say, increased by $100 million over the processes of the last few weeks.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Senate that we have delivered on our family tax initiative. We have delivered on lower interest rates. We have delivered on relief for small businesses. We have delivered on reform for workplaces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is the economy going flat?
—Senator Schacht!
—Now we are putting in place a Natural Heritage Trust, which will deliver in a much greater way than ever before on our promises in relation to the environment.
—Why is the economy going down?

—I will remind them, and they should listen to this. For the revegetation program, we promised $254 million; Labor, $29 million. We promised $163 million for the Murray-Darling; Labor, $98 million. We promised $100 million for the coast and clean seas initiative; Labor, $53 million. We promised $279 million for landcare; Labor, $188 million. Of course, the other great distinction is that Labor could not fund it. Labor was simply going to put it on the tab, add it to the $10 billion of budget deficit that we inherited.
—Rubbish!
—You had to sell Australia's best asset.
—Senator Schacht, you have been persistently interjecting during this answer. There is an opportunity for you to debate the issue later. It is not to be debated during the answer.

—I can see why Senator Cook cannot understand this, because it was Senator Cook who said that the budget was in the black. The budget was $10,000 million in the red, and he said there was no budget deficit at all. So I can understand why he still says they were able to pay for it. That was the way Labor paid for it. You put up the taxes and you borrowed more.

ANSWER.PARA: In contrast, we are able to establish this fund from capital. We have chosen to sell part of one capital asset, a telecommunications company, and reinvest it in another capital asset—the natural heritage. It will be able to remedy revegetation problems, the Murray-Darling problems, the coast and sea problems. We are putting in place a really effective national reserve system, a water and soil audit.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens in four years when the $700 million is gone?
—Senator Schacht, you are persistently ignoring my request to remain silent.
—That will give benefit not only to this generation but to future generations, and for that it should be applauded.

ANSWER.PARA: We will now be in a position to accelerate the processes of the trust. We will now, pursuant to promises earlier given, be able to get funding to accelerate the setting up of the new partnership agreements between the Commonwealth and each of the states through which the fund will be implemented.

This will be an integrated package. We propose that all relevant Commonwealth-state initiatives relating to biodiversity and sustainable agriculture will, for the first time, be drawn into one package—as they should have always been—in the same way that we have brought together the department of primary industries and the department of the environment to ensure that you get not only good decisions in relation to natural resource management but good decisions in relation to the environment. We will now be in a position to encourage the states to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is hardly new.

—Your two ministers would not even speak to each other, Senator Cook. Mr Beddall and Senator Faulkner would not speak to each other. This is an historic day, and it is a great day for all Australians. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, will you confirm that the capital gains tax rollover relief is available to people irrespective of their personal wealth? Specifically, will you confirm that someone who may have non-business assets, such as an art collection or an antique collection, worth many millions of dollars will also be eligible for CGT rollover relief, provided their net business assets are under $5 million?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the question on the capital gains tax rollover relief which, as Senator Sherry knows and as the Labor Party knows, is one of the many promises that the coalition government has delivered—not delivered 100 per cent, Senator Sherry, but delivered 110 per cent. This is a policy which has been widely welcomed throughout the community, particularly the small business community, which Senator Schacht would know from his previous experience.

ANSWER.PARA: You will be well aware of the tests that are actually involved and the net asset value limit of $5 million. What I will do, Senator Sherry, is look to see whether there is any merit in any points that you have made in your question. The issue is for active assets, and you would be aware of the test for small business enterprises which have a net asset value of $5 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. As usual, no answer. Minister, do you stand by the budget estimates as to the cost to tax revenue from this measure, given that you replied in an answer to me on 25 November that, `There is insufficient information available to be able to say how many small businesses will be eligible for rollover relief'? Given this, Minister, on what basis do you calculate the cost to tax revenue of this measure?

—Senator Sherry, I do not know why you seem to be so critical of this measure. My memory is that you asked this question in Senate estimates, and it was mentioned to you, Senator Sherry, that it is based on the best estimates which are available. We have indicated now that this is a $200 million injection into small business which—and I have to tell you, Senator Sherry—despite what the Labor Party may think, is widely welcomed.

—My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Now that the Telstra bill has been passed, can the minister confirm the benefits that will flow to the Australian people as a result of last night's historic vote? Can regional Australia now look forward to access to telecommunications infrastructure on a par with their metropolitan counterparts? Did the Labor Party help the government to deliver these outcomes to regional Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great day for all Australians, except those who are bitter and twisted on the other side of the chamber, who fought tooth and nail to stop these magnificent reforms going through the parliament. It should have been in place months ago. We all know the benefits that will flow from partial privatisation—lower costs and better quality of service. Look at the UK experience. You know what it has done around the world.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, if you look at what Alan Ramsay had to say, there is a very big lesson here for a lot of people on your side of politics. He said:

Even so, Oppositions don't often lose as sourly as Labor is doing in the Telstra debate. The whingeing, moaning, fingerpointing, confected outrage and all‐round bad‐mouthing in the Senate since last week's vote has been a thing to behold.

He said that there were two unassailable facts about the Telstra debate—they are both very instructive. The first thing is that, if there is one thing that is absolutely crystal clear, it is that John Howard had a unequivocal mandate to proceed with this. Mr Ramsay also said:

The second fundamental truth is that, unlike the Democrats, Labor doesn't have a shred of credibility when it comes to the issue of selling public assets. It was as opportunistic in opposing the sale of Telstra last election as it had been for years in government in flogging just about anything of any consequence, including the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas.
And not once, unlike Howard, did either Bob Hawke or Paul Keating ever go to any election, in all the 13 years they were there, openly telling voters what they proposed to do.

In other words, they lied their heads off. Is it any wonder you do not have any credibility on this issue? You have been patting yourselves on the back for the last 13 years, saying how smart you were, pinching all our policies and parading yourselves around Australia as nouveau right wing. And now, of course, you find you have nowhere to go. Gary Johns told you a couple of years ago that if you pandered endlessly to minorities at the expense of the mainstream it would be electoral suicide. And so it has proved.

I am asked about rural Australia. Rural and regional Australia know that for the first time ever they will start to get some very significant benefits in terms of telecommunication facilities. No longer will they be regarded as second‐class citizens. Your contribution to rural Australia was to set up travelling circuses which you called caucus rural task forces. I presume it was just a means of ensuring that you got extra TA.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on my left. Order!

—The end result is that we now have 31 seats in the bush and Labor has five. That does not come about accidentally. It comes about because of your deliberate and studied neglect of rural Australia over all those years. So let me give you some advice. If you want to spend your Christmas profitably, if you want to make a comeback, if you ever want to get back into government, then go to some of those union‐sponsored health farms and beach resorts, and all those wonderful places where you will be spending the next four to six weeks—
—What is the number we ring you on in Hawaii?

—I am more than happy to send you a postcard from Hawaii. I am prepared to make the supreme sacrifice. There are a number of cultural venues that require my attention overseas. While you are here, spend a bit of time thinking about it. Think about how you could be constructive in government. Stand up for the bush for once.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.
—Why don't you release the Mansfield report before you go?
—Order! Senator Collins!

—Madam President, he is a classic example of how you suffer from policy fatigue when you are in opposition. He is a bloke who has got the nominal title of shadow minister for primary industry. All he ever does is get up and ask questions about Aboriginal affairs. That is a classic example of how you have dropped the ball. You are not interested in the bush. You do not give a damn whether they have a second‐class telecommunications service. You have not even been grateful for the fact that the Northern Territory got some very good money out of this. Senator Sherry made a 15‐minute contribution. Not once did he acknowledge the benefits to Tasmania—indeed, he didn't even look at the problems in Tasmania. He is not interested. He spends as much time as he can on the mainland. It is typical of the Labor Party. (Time expired)
—I have a supplementary question for the minister. Minister, you mentioned that the ISDN update will be expedited. What differences will this make to regional areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose one of the first things it will do is give many people in regional Australia the opportunity to ring in first‐hand and complain about Labor's neglect. They will be able to get access to the Internet, so they will be able to give you a home site where you can have a whinge about Labor. I suppose you know that Senator Schacht finally dismantled his home page. I presume he did not do it himself. No doubt he got some expert advice on how to access the system. He has finally taken it down. So, here we are, about 12 months after he last updated it. If we want to know Labor's policies on the Internet now, it is just a big, gigantic black hole.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht, you have been interjecting persistently.

—The fact is that Labor has got nothing to contribute. The people in the bush will have the opportunity to find out about our policies because they will be readily available on the Internet. What you may well find is people actually sending you a bit of advice, telling you to be constructive, telling you to get out in the bush and have a bit of a listen. Wander around, get out of the cars, hear what they have got to say, and come back with some decent policies. There are some votes out there if you will only start to look for them. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Parer, representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Minister, is it true that the franchising sector comprises nearly 10 per cent of the Australian economy, is growing at around 14 per cent a year and employs 270,000 people? Is it also true that, of over 600 franchisors in Australia, 10 per cent of them are currently engaged in litigation and another 15 per cent are in serious dispute with their franchisees, making a total of 25 per cent in significant disputes? Why has the government thrown the prospect of workable self‐regulation in this sector out the window by both slashing the funding to the Franchising Code Council and refusing to introduce legislation against harsh and unconscionable conduct?

—Basically, I think the statistics that Senator Cook gave are correct. I am aware of a review being undertaken by the minister of the franchising code. In fact, there was a brief here, but I can't find it. So, let me refer the rest of the question back to the minister. I will get you an answer after question time.

—I have a supplementary question in view of that answer. Minister, could you explain to the Senate—if you have to take this on notice, maybe you will—and to the small business franchisees in Australia the circumstances and, in particular, the reasons for the resignation last week of Mr Robert Gardini, the independent chairman of the Franchising Code Council?

—This is my recollection of my brief that I have not got. My understanding was that Mr Gardini did a good job—I think the minister congratulated him for it. While he has resigned, the other members of the committee decided that they would not resign; they will continue with the code.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Arrest of Legislative Councillors in Hong Kong

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the government's reaction to the arrest in Hong Kong yesterday of independent legislator and pro‐democracy campaigner, Emily Lau, and other members of the Legislative Council who were all protesting over the election of the new Chief Executive Officer, Mr Tung Chee-hwa? Is the government concerned for the future of activists such as Ms Lau, who would be viewed under Chinese law as subversive, the maximum penalty for which is the death penalty? Is the government currently framing legislation which would deny current Hong Kong activists the possibility of residence and eventual citizenship in Australia? If not, will Australia consider allowing Hong Kong democracy campaigners to take refuge in this country before 1 July next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I know, from press reports, that in the demonstration involving up to 40 people outside the venue of the section committee meeting 29 demonstrators were arrested by Hong Kong police.
—She has already said that.

—Well, I am confirming it. They included legislative councillors Emily Lau, Andrew Chang and Lee Chuk Yong. They were arrested and, I understand, released on bail. They were of course arrested for breaches of domestic law, as is sometimes the case. The experience of others throughout the world has been that they get arrested for breaches of laws during protests. It will be dealt with under the Hong Kong laws. That is not really a matter for our consideration at all.
—Blood on your hands.

—That is a stupid thing to say. As to whether any special provisions are being made or contemplated within our immigration laws to allow for Hong Kong activists to receive access to this country, I am not aware of any. I will inquire about that.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind Senator Bourne that we have a very generous immigration program in relation to refugees, with the humanitarian program and the family reunion program. That is strongly supported by this government. I am also aware, as no doubt she is, that there has been very extensive migration to Australia from Hong Kong in recent years, particularly from those who have decided to make an alternative choice for their future domicile, bearing in mind the government which is to take power in Hong Kong in the middle of next year.
As I say, I do not know of any suggestion of any special immigration provision. But I will ask the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs whether he has any such idea in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. I draw his attention to part two of what I asked, which was about whether he is concerned that, after China takes over Hong Kong, people who have been arrested—even arrested for demonstrating—will be considered to be subversive, something that can attract the death penalty in China? Also, following on from his last part of the answer, is it the case that in Mr Downer's meeting with Mr Chris Patten, which I think was earlier this year, he in fact was asked by Mr Patten whether Australia would take any activists as refugees, and he said no?

—If the latter is right, what Mr Downer is saying is consistent with what I have just said, and that is that I did not know of any plan for any change to our immigration laws to allow a special category for what you refer to as Hong Kong activists.
—It is already there. Why don't you have a look at the act?

—I know the act is already there. Am I concerned about the lot of Hong Kong residents when they are going to live under a new set of laws which are going to be very difficult for people who have experienced the traditional freedoms of living in Hong Kong? Yes, I do have some concerns about that. But I think most people who think about these issues have concerns about it as well.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I refer to the study entitled `Impact of proposed changes to Austudy eligibility on higher education students' by Ian Dobson and Bob Birrell, which was reported on in yesterday's press. Minister, do you contest the study's finding that at least 60,000 Austudy recipients will potentially be affected by the new measures that you have introduced? Do you accept the conclusion that 17 per cent of all students currently receiving Austudy will be ineligible under your changes and just over half will have their benefits reduced? What do you have to say to the claim that families of 36,000 students from middle and low socioeconomic backgrounds will suffer as a consequence of your changes? Are these not the same families whom you promised to assist by offering them the price of up to three movie tickets a fortnight with your family tax initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr, I have seen the article that you refer to, and I do not agree with its conclusions and even you, I suspect, would understand why. That is because the figures are no longer applicable. The figures that were provided by the department to those researchers to do that study were provided prior to the changes that were made to the government's intentions vis‐a‐vis Austudy. As you well understand, the regulations that have been successfully, if you like, passed this morning, if I can put it that way, will mean that someone between the age of 22 and 25 who otherwise might have got Austudy next year—we are not talking about existing students; they have been grandfathered—living at home and from a wealthy family, will not get Austudy.

ANSWER.PARA: I think I raised the case with you that if you wanted to support Melanie Howard being able to get Austudy, good luck to you. But there would be a lot of other people who would think that it was unfair and inappropriate to design a system where she could apply if she wanted to and where you would pay it—just as you would pay Alan Bond's kids simply—because they turned 22.

Senator, you understand full well that for many years—18, in fact—the Labor approach was to make 25 the age of independence for Austudy. It is only recently that you dropped it down. It is not as if this is some huge change that you are unable to accommodate.

We have taken a fiscally responsible approach to income support. We have maintained a grants scheme. You do not need to believe what you read on the Democrats' home page, which says, `Fight the campaign to turn Austudy into loans.' That is not true, and everybody would have understood that from 9 August. Senator Stott Despoja, if she was not busy doing other things, would have recognised that. Because the Democrats want to keep the you-know-who's honest—as they always do—they would have taken that off their home page and not pretended that we were trying to turn Austudy into loans.

Even you, Senator Carr, who might disagree with a lot of things that my side of politics would do, would not engage in such a disgraceful misrepresentation as the one Senator Stott Despoja has engaged in on the Internet. As I have indicated to you, the department provided that material to the researchers. The figures relate to the plans for Austudy prior to the changes we made, which was that, as soon as someone has turned 25, they will get Austudy irrespective of whether or not they have completed their course. That is the change that we have made.

It is interesting, though, that you have raised the question of the socioeconomic stratum that would be affected—or which the study indicates would be affected—by these changes. It clearly showed that, by far, the greatest majority of people who would be affected are those who live in middle and upper income socioeconomic stratum postcodes—by far the greatest majority. So the percentage of people who are going to be hit by shifting the age of independence from 22 to 25 for future students is about 85 per cent.

If you have the study there—I do not have it with me—you might be able to tell me. Yes, 85 per cent come from the medium to high socioeconomic postcodes. Yet again, this budget measure—which you wanted to oppose—is going to take by and large a benefit from medium to high income people. I frankly am at a loss to understand why you, coming from one of the many left factions in Victoria, would oppose such a measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you for that answer, Minister. Could you please indicate to the Senate why the answer that your department gave me on 30 October 1996, which identified that 125,076 students all up would be adversely affected by these changes to Austudy, was wrong? What is the difference that has emerged since you proposed these new regulations? Will you undertake a detailed examination of the study by Dobson and Birrell to identify why it is that they are wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have already indicated to you that one of the reasons that the conclusions in the study is wrong is that events have overtaken the figures that were provided. I am not saying that what they said in the first instance was wrong, just that the regulations have changed from that point on.

ANSWER.PARA: I indicated in the estimates committee that, as to the assumptions about the numbers being affected, I was not completely satisfied. In fact, I invited the committee to ask questions on that so that we could get further to the bottom of it. Senator, you can look at the numbers that will be affected next year, or you might like to look at the numbers in two years, three years or four years—if you wanted, you could look at the numbers affected in 20 years—and get a larger and larger number. As to the specific question you are referring to—out of the many hundreds that were put on notice—I will go back and have a look at the answer that you were given on that specific question and compare it with the now out‐of‐date study that you refer to. I will come back to you with an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources. Is it a fact that the Australian Fishing Management Authority is meeting today to decide under what condi tions a 12-fold increase in trawling will be allowed in the waters surrounding Heard Island? Will this massive increase be subject to an environmental impact assessment? Is it a fact that the Perth based company Austral fisheries has the inside running for getting access to this fishery, and that Austral's Mr Murray France was the first-ever industry representative to attend the meeting of the CCALMR—the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Living Marine Resources—earlier this year on the Australian delegation? Why did the government facilitate someone with an obvious vested interest attending that meeting which approved the 12-fold increase?

—I am aware of the fact that the AFMA board is meeting today but, to be frank, I have no idea as to the terms of the agenda. Senator, if you are referring to a decision that was made quite some time ago in regard to patagonian toothfish, a decision was made whereby the volume went up from a couple of hundred tonnes of scientific fishing to the level of about 2,000. So I guess that is the 12 to one factor that you are talking about.
—3,800. I'll answer it for you.

—Senator, if you listen I will give you the answer. This is something that was cleared through the Antarctic division and I think through Senator Hill's office. As part of that program, scientific people will be permanently on board that vessel—
—Two scientific people.

—Two scientific people. Thanks, Senator Campbell. He is heavily involved in this. Two scientific observers will be there full time. There is a limitation in that fishing will not be permitted within about 10 or 12 kilometres or nautical miles—whatever it is—of the island. The whole program has been done in a proper scientific way that can only be of benefit to the industry and to the fishing resource.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I specifically ask the minister, then: how was Mr Murray France of Austral fisheries selected by the government to be part of the delegation to CCALMR which made that decision for a 12-fold increase? Why did the government facilitate somebody with such an obvious vested interest being on that particular delegation?
—The senator will be aware that this experimental fishing was started a year or two ago under the previous government.
—It is not experimental; it is profit driven.

—Profit driven! It amazes me, Madam President: Senator Brown comes into this place and the great evil of this world is profit. He is not recognising the fact that if there were no profits he would not have a job. Where do you think you get your money from? You get it from wealth creating industries.
—The Senate is definitely a non-profit organisation.
—Not very productive, Senator Collins, and I think Senator Brown would be the epitome of that.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Why is the meeting of departmental secretaries being held in Sydney on Saturday when 17 of the 18 departmental heads in fact reside in Canberra? Is it being held in Sydney because Mr Max Moore‐Wilton, the head of the Prime Minister's department, resides in Sydney? How much will the meeting cost? Is this yet another example of the government moving from Canberra to Sydney?
—I will get information on that matter and refer back to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate during the next question time.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Just like so many other issues, Senator Hill has got something to hide, with the next question time being in February. Even Senator Hill ordinarily could do a little better than that. Minister, do you answer the question in that way because the rumours are that that is going to be a last supper for many of the departmental secretaries? If it is, will the government at least give those secretaries that get the axe this time from the government the courtesy of informing them before they are moved aside or terminated?

—Not all meetings are held in Canberra. I can think of a lot of good reasons for a meeting such as this to be held in Sydney. With regard to the last part of the question, I must say that the secretaries I have contact with are all doing a great job.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Particular groups of unemployed people face special problems in returning to employment. These groups can include the young, disabled persons and those with a combination of disadvantages. Can the minister outline how the government has taken into account the special circumstances of these groups in framing its reforms to labour market assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coonan for her question. She has taken a particular interest in the development of a much better delivery system of labour market services to unemployed Australians. She raises the case today of disadvantaged Australians. The government aims to assist disadvantaged groups through providing them with a much more flexible system than what was available before—much more choice and opportunity.

ANSWER.PARA: The labour system under the previous government relied on a very rigid and inflexible structure. The government's targeting of labour market assistance for disadvantaged groups recognises the special circumstances that these people face. For example, we will make assistance available through the community support program in helping people who are not ready for employment at this stage to access services designed directly to address their needs and difficulties.

BREAK.PARA: For people on that program there will be a relaxation of the job search activity test while they are receiving this assistance. This will enable them to return to direct labour market assistance once their particular difficulties have been overcome. In working out the program details, we will work very closely with community groups who in fact raised this problem with us and with whom we have been consulting since the announcement of these changes.

There are people who face multiple barriers to employment. There are groups of unemployed persons who have a combination of difficulties in returning to employment but whose disadvantages do not preclude them getting and holding a job, provided we give them some assistance. The government has recognised the difficulties these people face as well by providing significantly greater incentives for the successful placement of people in this group into employment compared with other unemployed persons. There will also be an extension in the period of time available for case managers to assist people in this group, from a maximum of 18 months to two years.

Disabled Australians also face difficulties in returning to work. A disabled person unable to return to work on a full-time basis will be able to take advantage of the incentive structure facing contracted employment placement agencies. The full outcome fee will be paid to an employment placement enterprise for placing a disabled person into employment for the amount of hours per week that the person is assessed as being capable of working. That is, they do not need to return to full-time employment if they are not capable of it. But if they can be placed in the equivalent of what their capacity is, then the full outcome fee will be paid.

Young people, particularly because of the youth unemployment rate, face a particular problem in getting jobs. For that reason, the employment placement enterprises will receive the highest possible outcome fee for a young person returning to full-time education or training, which is the first foot in the door to getting a job or a better job.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts: Overseas Travel

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, with regard to your upcoming taxpayer funded Christmas holidays, I ask: will you undertake during the London leg of your travels to discuss with the BBC the utility of merging TV and radio news, as proposed by our ABC? During your visit to New York, will you examine how the Corporation for Public Broadcasting is responding to political pressure to abolish television funding? While you are in Los Angeles, will you examine how production houses supply material to the networks rather than the networks doing it in-house? Finally, when you are enjoying the tourist facilities at Waikiki will you give some thought to the 600 ABC employees who are about to lose their jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President—
—How about releasing the Mansfield report before you go?
—You promise to read it, do you, Bob?
—Absolutely, along with thousands of others.

—As a matter of interest, the 600‐odd employees of the ABC who will be leaving over the next 18 months will be taking voluntary redundancies. Let there be no misunderstanding. The announcement that was made the other day I thought was a very positive one.
—Don't add insult to injury, Senator Alston.

—If you look at the actual statement by the chairman and the manager director you will see that a number of those changes were already in the pipeline. It was a recognition of the fact that you had a number of ABCs operating private fiefdoms—television, radio and other divisions. For the first time they will be brought together under the one ABC.

ANSWER.PARA: I have no doubt that the ABC can manage to cope without my presence for a few weeks in January. I am indebted to Senator Evans for reminding me there are a vast number of things that are relevant to the communications portfolio that will undoubtedly occupy the bulk of my waking hours while I am away.

I have to confess, however, that for a very small portion of the time I will be overseas I will be taking a few days off for private purposes—I have a brother away. Just in case anyone thinks that is somehow not acceptable, the Senate might be interested to know that in 1989 Senator Ray managed to be away on a trip that took 22 days.
Government senastors interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait! There's more. Of that 22 days, 15 days were on private personal business. What was the principal purpose of that trip? It was to attend a three‐day conference. I presume that the reason Senator Ray was able to offer me such useful gratuitous advice about popping into conferences and just signing the guest book as you arrive was that he was practising what he preaches. It is a tragedy for someone on the other side of the chamber to somehow squander those wonderful opportunities to visit places like the Courtauld galleries, the Whitney museum, the Tate Gallery, the National Portrait Gallery—all of these things, to cast pearls before swine.

ANSWER.PARA: But if you had been minister for the arts and you had understood that it is very necessary to have a comprehensive world view of culture then you would understand how important it is that on your behalf and in the interests of taxpayers in general I upgrade my cultural knowledge to include a tour of many of those fine institutions. I can assure Senator Evans that I will also be paying a visit to the BBC to make all the necessary comparisons. I will take a very keen interest in the views of telecommunications analysts and advisers.

When I come back our policies will be even better than they have been to date. I will be able to offer Senator Schacht some very constructive advice on how we can get that post‐1997 package through the Senate in the shortest possible time. The taxpayers of Australia will be very grateful to us all as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I note that Minister Downer will be launching a UNICEF report today at 4.00 p.m. which calls for an end to child labour, which it dubs 20th century slavery. Is it not rather contradictory for Minister Downer to be launching this report when the government recently refused to ratify trade and investment agreements with the European Commission and other western countries which link labour standards to trade liberalisation and therefore the rights of children around the world?

—No, not at all. We regard them as separate and distinct issues. I have answered a similar question to this before. It is our preference, as it was the preference of the previous Labor government, to have trade agreements deal with trade matters and human rights agreements deal with human rights matters. There is nothing new in that. That remains our preference and our negotiating position.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his response. I again ask: how can the minister justify separating the issue of child labour from that of trade when we know that the labour of children contributes to products sold in this country and that as a result of this labour millions of children are being denied a decent standard of living?
—They are separate and distinct issues and the issues of child labour are being addressed by Mr Downer today in the way that Senator Allison indicated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I refer to the answer you gave on 19 November in which you stated:

QUESTION.PARA: I am informed by the Minister that all relevant documentation in respect of the company—
that being Lochreagh Investments—
has now been lodged with the Australian Securities Commission.

How do you explain the fact that the ASC records show that all relevant documentation had not been lodged by 19 November and in fact was not lodged until 3 December? Were you advised at any stage that your statement of 19 November was incorrect? Do you accept that your statement of 19 November was incorrect? Are you willing to apologise for misleading the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is one of the more absurd questions that we have had in a very thin question time. The reality is that the Labor Party will not ask these questions of the individual involved. What you hope to do, Senator Ray—and we understand what you hope to do—is get a headline in relation to the question you have asked about Mr Fahey but these questions are not being put directly to him. It does strike me that you are not really interested in the answers. You will note that the answers I have given have been on the advice of the Minister for Finance.
—Yes, indeed.

—As exactly I should. Each time you have posed questions to me I have drawn those questions to the attention of Mr Fahey. Where he has felt it appropriate, answers have been given. You will note that on 10 December there was a further statement which I tabled in the Senate. That statement read as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Finance has been advised by his accountant that the documents sent in November to the Australian Securities Commission in respect of the private company Lockreagh Investments Pty Ltd have been processed. The company was reinstated on 5 December last. As I have said earlier in this place, the Minister for Finance has been advised by his accountant that there are no outstanding tax implications in respect of this company.

That is the advice which I have received. I have precisely answered the question. The questions that I have responded to involve the personal affairs of the Minister for Finance.
