Quite properly, I have drawn those questions to the attention of the Minister for Finance. Where he has felt it was appropriate, I have come back to this chamber and responded to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Newman excuse that the minister goes to. However, these are questions not about the behaviour of Mr Fahey but about the accuracy of your statements. Minister, is it a fact that the statement you made here on 19 November has now proved, either on advice or not on advice, to be inaccurate? When did you first learn that it was inaccurate, and when did you correct the record?
—The statements which I have provided, as I have said, have been provided on the advice of the Minister for Finance.
—It doesn't matter.

—Yes, they have. Where he has wished to respond to the matters which you have raised, Senator Ray, I have again come back to this chamber and responded in kind. We have trawled through this now for a long period of time. As you would expect, as these matters involve the personal finances of the Minister for Finance and as they involve advice which has been sought from the Minister for Finance, where he has wished to, I have responded to this chamber and informed the chamber of that advice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. In its resources policy for the last election, the Howard government committed itself to production of a white paper on sustainable energy policy for Australia. Can the minister tell us what progress has been made on production of this white paper? Will he also assure the Senate that avenues will be available for all interested parties to put their point of view? How will this be done?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Chapman very much for that question. As he said, it was the policy before the last election of this government to produce a white paper on sustainable energy with a 25-year time frame. In developing this critically important policy for the future, the government is intent on effective consultation with the community to give all interested parties—industry, environmental groups and individuals—a chance to provide their views. The government will therefore release a green paper, which I will do next week, setting out the issues which need to be considered in a sustainable energy policy to stimulate input from the community through the provision of submissions to the government.

ANSWER.PARA: The green paper draws attention to the high growth in demand for energy expected over the coming decades, especially with the economic growth forecast for the developing countries within our region. Globally and for Australia, energy consumed is likely to increase some 40 per cent between now and the year 2020. The green paper identifies some of the key influences which will impact on Australia's energy future. I point out that the green paper will not be a statement of government policy. That will come in the form of a white paper after the government has consulted with the community. Rather, the green paper is intended to stimulate the community's thinking about energy policy and to encourage informed debate on the issues.

To help keep in touch with community views, the government has established both a ministerial and business round table and an energy policy forum to obtain views from principal stakeholder groups, including business, environmental groups and energy users. State and territory governments will also be fully consulted in the process of developing the white paper. We have allowed ample time for the community to prepare submissions in response to the green paper, and the closing date for receipt of submissions will be 31 January 1997.

The pervasive character of energy, its importance for industry, commerce, transport, households and recreation, means that getting the policy right is essential for our ongoing wellbeing. The expenditure on energy consumption in Australia is of the order of $35 billion per annum. Our exports of energy commodities—coal, gas and uranium—generate some $12 billion per annum in export earnings. Our exports of energy technologies are worth over a billion dollars per annum. This means jobs and a very significant contribution to our standard of living.

It has been estimated that up to 20 per cent improvement in energy use efficiency may be achievable in Australia. This translates to a saving for this country of some $6 billion or $7 billion per year. Even if only half of this is realised, it is very significant. The electricity and gas microeconomic reform process is already achieving major benefits. We are seeing the increasing development of cogeneration, and this is bound to continue.

The commercial energy services industry, which drives efficiency and conservation through various technologies, is becoming more robust and more mature in this new environment. The essence of a sustainable energy policy, therefore, is to integrate economic, social and environmental objectives so that the welfare of the current generations of Australians is advanced while protecting the options available to future generations. The government's aim is to release the white paper setting out its policy in the first half of next year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, I refer you to Minister Fahey's answer on 21 November regarding Lochreagh Investments Pty Ltd, where he stated, and you have stated on a number of occasions:

QUESTION.PARA: The company has no revenue.

If the company has no revenue, how can the directors loan from Lochreagh to Mr Fahey be repaid in the normal manner, as it is obviously not a loan at arm's length or on a commercial basis, as no interest is being paid on the loan? As no interest is being paid on the loan, as admitted by Mr Fahey in his statement that the company has no revenue, why is the loan not a deemed dividend under section 108 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and, therefore, taxable?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are drawing a long bow there.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —As someone said, it is a pretty long bow. It is the same old story. Your colleagues in the other place obviously do not believe that these questions are worth asking. Mr Fahey, the Minister for Finance, is in the other place.
—You are here.
—You are certainly here. You are going to be over there for a long time.
—You cannot even handle your own interjections. You have to recycle them from the back bench.

—Look how serious you are in wanting an answer to this question. You want to stand up and make unsubstantiated imputations against the Minister for Finance. What you do is stand up in this place and ask questions. You do not in the other place pose those questions directly to the Minister for Finance relating to his personal affairs which would enable him to directly respond to those questions.

ANSWER.PARA: You have raised a question regarding the personal finances of the Minister for Finance. I will refer those matters to him. I do not accept that what you say is correct. I will obviously have to seek advice on it, and that is precisely what I will do. If you were over this side, which you are not—you will not be for a long time—that is precisely what you would do as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister keeps giving us incorrect answers about this matter. Minister, I remind you that you have some direct responsibilities to the Taxation Office. In light of the admission by the Minister for Finance, will you now refer to the tax commissioner this matter of why the minister has failed to declare his loan as a dividend, when it is clear that he has a `mates rates' loan, as it is known, on which he is paying no interest?
—There are a whole range of assumptions involved in that question which go to matters of fact.
—Refer it to the Commissioner of Taxation.
—Refer it to the tax office.

—Senator Cook, Senator Sherry and anybody else who wants to ask such a question can take it from me—they asked a question about the personal finances of the Minister for Finance—that I will refer those questions to the minister and see whether he wishes to respond. If he wishes to re spond, I will come back to this chamber and provide advice to you. But I have to say that it is a pretty weak effort.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper or otherwise asked in February.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time, Senator Cook asked me a question about the Franchising Code Council. I have a response from the minister. The minister advises that he has held extensive consultations with the code council over the past few months. The council has given serious consideration to identifying the most appropriate strategy for self-regulation in the franchising industry.

QUESTION.PARA: The majority of council members consider that the council is best placed to continue as the administrator of the code of practice and are keen to continue operations. This view was not supported by Mr Gardini. He reviewed his position in the light of the council's decision and resigned. The council has indicated that it will continue to work closely with the government to address a range of issues that have impeded its progress in the past six months.
The government has given a commitment to the council to provide adequate funding over the next two years based on the council's own assessment of their requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—The government has allocated $648,000 to the Franchising Code Council for this financial year, which is exactly the same amount promised by the previous government. The minister advises me that Mr Gardini told him, the minister, just two months ago that the council needed $400,000 per annum to continue.

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Cook also referred to disputes. The advice I have is that almost 90 per cent of franchisors and franchisees claim to enjoy a healthy commercial relationship. On average, 70 per cent of franchisees are happy with the system and would recommend it to prospective buyers. The minister is aware of claims from the opposition that there has been a significant increase in the level of disputes. However, he points out that the proportion of disputes in the industry has dropped since 1994. Statistics show that most disputes in the franchising sector concern issues of normal commercial dealing.

A parliamentary inquiry has been convened into unconscionable conduct and other fair trading issues. Historically, 72 per cent of franchisors and 24 per cent of franchisees involved in disputes have effectively resolved them through mutual negotiation. With an almost 50 per cent increase in the development of the franchise industry and advisory services in the industry over the past two years, mediation is becoming more common.
On the issue of the Franchising Code Council itself, the minister points out that new directors have already been chosen to take the place of directors whose terms finish this year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
QUESTION.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I have three answers. Senator Gibbs asked me on 10 December a number of questions about International Human Rights Day and Queensland offices. I would like to provide those answers. The first question was this:

QUESTION.PARA: Why has the government on International Human Rights Day closed the doors of the three Queensland offices of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission this morning?

The answer to that question which I have been provided with is that the existing cooperative arrangement with Queensland expired on 9 December 1996. The Attorney-General had put a broad proposal to the Queensland Attorney-General in June this year to negotiate a new arrangement consistent with the national approach and where contributions are reflective of the work done. This was followed up by one meeting of officers in August and then a number of Queensland press releases claiming that the Commonwealth had withdrawn from the current arrangements. That was not the case.

In the majority of states where cooperative arrangements have been in place—Western Australia, Victoria and South Australia—the commissions are run by the states. In respect of complaints brought under federal law, the state body acts as agent for the Commonwealth and those bodies are paid by the Commonwealth for so acting. This is in line with Commonwealth-state arrangements for service delivery in many other states. Such a national approach to cooperative arrangements was recommended by the review of HREOC, which was established by and reported to the previous government.

The arrangement which had existed in Queensland operated under a reverse arrangement. The Queensland commission, established by the federal government, acted as agent for Queensland in respect of complaints under Queensland law. That was despite the fact that approximately 80 per cent of the cases were state cases and 20 per cent were Commonwealth ones. Under the arrangement that has now expired, Queensland contributed only 50 per cent of funding for 80 per cent of the commission's output. This funding arrangement was clearly inequitable and was aberrant in terms of the funding arrangements that exist in other states.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate it, like everyone else is.
—Senator, if you want to wait for the answer until another day, it suits me.
—No, incorporate it.
—Senator, I give you the choice.
—Order! Senator Vanstone, you have the floor.

—Thank you, Madam President. The Queensland government has announced that it will have an interim anti‐discrimination commissioner and an interim office in Brisbane by 10 December 1996 with local service delivery points in Cairns, Townsville and Rockhampton. Because of this and the fact that more than 80 per cent of all complaints received are handled under Queensland legislation, the decision to close the HREOC offices in Brisbane, Cairns and Rockhampton was also taken. I should emphasise that negotiations are continuing and I am hopeful that a cooperative arrangement will be agreed to in due course.

BREAK.PARA: That, I think, is the essential thrust of the answer to the question that was put. It is important to put this on record today, not simply to put it in the Hansard for someone to read later. There were a further three questions asked and it is perfectly acceptable to the government to have the remaining answers to Senator Gibbs's questions incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the answers read as follows—

(2) Arrangements for the handling of complaints under the federal legislation have been put in place. These arrangements include HREOC's toll free 1800 telephone service. The new procedures for handling federal human rights complaints will be co‐ordinated from HREOC's Sydney office. This is already the case with disability complaints in SA and WA. It is also proposed that circuit trips of conciliation staff will be held. The use of conciliation circuits has been highly successful in Victoria, SA and WA and is cost effective. In February, HREOC intends to review and consider the effectiveness of these new procedures.
(4) HREOC have advised that for the 1995/96 financial year 1,597 written inquiries were received, 619 complaints were lodged under the Queensland Act and 79 under Federal legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
QUESTION.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 December, Senator McKiernan asked a question of me in relation to some comments that Justice Nichols of the Family Court had made. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an answer provided to me by the Attorney‐General.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

Senator McKiernan asked Senator Vanstone on 4 December 1996 whether she was aware of reports that Justice Nicholson of the Family Court had stated that cuts to legal aid funding are placing the welfare of children at risk?
The Attorney‐General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Chief Justice Nicholson was reported as saying that the welfare of children could be at risk as a result of new legal aid guidelines imposed by Victoria Legal Aid (VLA); in particular, he commented upon the imposition of a $15,000 cap imposed by VLA on funds spent on separate representation for children.

There is a need to be clear about the reasons for changes to VLA's guidelines; in a speech made to the Law Institute of Victoria on 2 December 1996, the Managing Director of VLA, Mr Rob Cornall set out the serious financial difficulties which VLA inherited from the former Victoria Legal Aid Commission.

Last year, well before the Government's position on legal aid was announced, VLA ran at a cash deficit of $6.4 million on a budget of $83 million; this year, it was to budget for a deficit of $3.3 million.
The Commonwealth will meet its obligations for legal aid funding, including for children in the Family Court under the revised arrangements to operate from 1 July 1997.

QUESTION.PARA: But Mr Cornall has also pointed out that legal aid needs to get smarter about the way it is doing business.
Legal aid needs to be spread over more cases, otherwise equally deserving clients will miss out.
This is the reason for introducing the funding caps that Chief Justice Nicholson is so concerned about.

PARA.TAB: And while the Commonwealth provides legal aid funding, it must be remembered that the Commonwealth also provides funding for a Court.

QUESTION.PARA: There is a responsibility on the Court to ensure its processes are efficient so that legal aid funds are not expended on just a few cases.

PARA.TAB: The changes to the VLA guidelines would have happened irrespective of the Government's decision to restrict Commonwealth funds to matters of Commonwealth law;

QUESTION.PARA: I should make the comment that the management of VLA is the responsibility of its Board of Management.
It had to move to bring its budget under control.
The New Employment Services Regime

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
QUESTION.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 December 1996, Senator Mackay asked a question of me in relation to the new employment services regime. I have an answer which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

Senator Mackay asked a question about whether I was aware that a group of officers from my department in Tasmania had made inquiries about tendering to become an employment placement enterprise while they were public servants.

I regard the possibility that current employees could use the knowledge they have gained in the course of their duties in the Department to gain contracts as an employment placement enterprise very seriously. However, as I have said previously, I do not want to rush to make any judgment.
The Department has started investigating the Tasmanian case but so far has not been able to confirm or deny the rumour.

I understand, though, that there are reports from other areas that the same thing is happening. I have, therefore, asked the Secretary of the Department to conduct a full investigation into the whole matter.
The Department will make sure all its staff are warned about legislation and about rules of conduct for public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been called upon to table, by 12 December, details of progress being made in implementing the national anti‐racism campaign. I, therefore, table the information.

—During question time, Senator Brown asked me a question in regard to Murray France. I have additional information for Senator Brown. The Australian delegation to the 15th meeting of the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources included advisers from the fishing industry and the environmental movement. The fishing industry and the environmental movement each had one position. The industry was represented by Mr Bernard Bowen during the first week of the meeting and then by Murray France during the second week of the meeting. The environmental movement was represented by Sharon Moore who is, I understand, from the Southern Oceans and Antarctic Coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate in the committee stage of the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 there was some discussion of the word `breadwinner' versus `primary income earner'. I was asked at the time of that debate whether I could make a statement in the parliament in relation to any unintended consequences of accepting an amendment along those lines. I have a statement now which I have discussed with the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Kernot and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
STATEMENT BY THE ASSISTANT TREASURER IN RESPONSE TO DEBATE IN THE COMMITTEE STAGE OF THE FAMILY (TAX INITIATIVE) BILL 1996 IN RELATION TO USE OF THE TERM `BREADWINNER'

Senator Margetts proposed that the family tax payment legislation, the Family (Tax Initiative) bill 1996, should be amended to replace the terms `breadwinner' and `breadwinner's partner' with the terms `primary income earner' and `lower income earner'.
At the time, the proposal was not accepted because there was concern about unintended consequences, but I undertook to consider the matter further.

In fact, the amendment moved by Senator Margetts would have required a consequential amendment to the related income tax legislation, the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Act 1996 (the Rates Act) to maintain consistency between the tax law and the social security law. Section 20D of the Rates Act refers to the `income ceiling of the breadwinner's partner', which is an amount calculated by reference to Table E in point 1070‐E5 in section 1070 of the Social Security Act 1991. It would be confusing to continue to use the `breadwinner' terminology in the income tax law, when the social security law no longer referred to `breadwinners'.
The terms `breadwinner' and `breadwinner's partner' are convenient shorthand expressions for defined terms.
`Breadwinner' is defined in point 1070‐D3 in section 1070 of the Social Security Act. In relation to couples, the definition covers:
in most cases, the member of the couple who is the highest paid income earner, whether male or female; or

in certain situations, it can instead refer to the member of the couple who earns the least income. This can happen at the discretion of the Secretary of the Department of Social Security if the Secretary believes that it will give the greatest benefit to the couple.
The definition also covers people who are not members of a couple. It would be confusing to use the word `partner' in relation to a person who is not a partner.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—A couple of months ago, in the context of the debate on the new Federal Court fees, Senator Vanstone promised to bring in some new regulations. I think it is important that the Senate know where those regulations are. Can Senator Vanstone give us an indication by close of business today as to when those regulations will be implemented?
—Yes.

This motion represents what is best described as a rolling guillotine. It is important to place on record that it is a guillotine not enforced by the government on the Senate. The opposition, for its own part, may well take a very different view of a guillotine that was proposed by the government, if the intention of such a guillotine was, in our view, to improperly restrict debate. What this particular motion represents is a cooperative attempt to deal with a heavy legislative program in a very limited time frame.

The guillotine means that each measure that the government has granted urgency for does receive an appropriate amount of time for perusal by the Senate. I think that is an important principle—not that we just move and see a range of very important bills dealt with without debate. That is one of the strengths of dealing with legislation in this way.

The opposition was happy to take this initiative. I must say that it is something that we would have liked to have been able to achieve in government. We would have supported it when we were in government for the same reasons that we support it now. I must also say that this is something that the coalition would never contemplate when they were in opposition. We do hope that when we are on the government benches again we will see the same approach adopted by the coalition when it is in opposition.

I suggest to the Senate that this is a commonsense resolution, a sensible way to deal with a difficult situation before the Senate. On that basis, I take what I think is the unusual step, as Leader of the Opposition, or as a senator representing a non-government party, of proposing a guillotine. I suspect it is probably unprecedented. But I think the arguments for this cause of action are strong. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just take a moment to note Senator Faulkner's comments that this is a cooperative attempt—and it is unusual. I remember so many years here when we had long and acrimonious debates about whether we would have the opportunity to impose a rolling guillotine, albeit one that was discussed by all the parties. I remember sitting here all that time copping the abuse.

SPEECH.PARA: So it is not surprising to me that the government today does not actually want to move this guillotine, but they are very happy to accept it. It is a very generous offer from the opposition. We support it. We are glad to have been part of the consultations. I hope the government at least has the graciousness to say thank you for something they are not prepared to do but which they really want us to do anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I also reluctantly support the move. I think the Labor Party should be congratulated for the magnanimity with which it has allowed this to happen. I was not here then, but everybody tells me that, at least in the last three years, the current government, which was then in opposition, took a far more obstructive—
—Don't hold your breath.

—When the Leader of the Opposition says that he hopes he will get a cooperative arrangement like this when he is back in government, Senator Abetz says, `Don't hold your breath.' This not only says that the past experience of the government was obstructionist but also that they are going to be like that again when they get back into opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: So I give double marks to the opposition for their magnanimity on this issue. The cooperation from the Australian Democrats and the Greens on this issue has also been important, because we do want to see sensible debate in what is a very limited time on some very important issues which should, let's face it, be getting far more time for debate because of the impact they are going to have on the Australian electorate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank all honourable senators for their cooperation in this matter, which will enable a vote to be taken on key budget related bills. I think it is important that that occur. It will also enable it to take place within a time frame which will, in turn, enable the Senate to rise late tomorrow night. I am sure all the staff of this place, families of senators who are elsewhere and others will be pleased that this session will be brought to a conclusion. It is a level of cooperation that is very much appreciated by the government.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Child support scheme—operation and effectiveness of the scheme
The Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues tabled its report `Child Support Scheme—An examination of the operation and effectiveness of the scheme' in December 1994.

On 29 March 1995, the previous government tabled an interim response. This response dealt with 53 recommendations in the Committee's report that related to the administration of the Child Support Scheme by the Child Support Agency. These recommendations had no budgetary, legislative or policy implications.
As part of the 1995/96 Budget, changes made by the previous government were announced which addressed another eight of the Committee's recommendations.

The government currently has the outstanding recommendations from the Committee's report under active consideration. Many of these recommendations have budgetary or policy implications. A final response to all outstanding recommendations will be tabled in 1997.

BREAK.PARA: Following the 30 June 1996 report of the Australian Broadcasting Authority `Investigation into the content of on‐line services', the government is considering a national regulatory framework for on‐line services. A response to the Select Committee's reports, Regulation of Computer On‐Line Services (Parts 1 and 2), is being held over so that it can reflect the outcome of this consideration. As an interim measure to assist government consideration of a regulatory framework for on‐line services, an amendment to section 171 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 has been introduced in the Senate to ensure that the Minister's power to direct the Australian Broadcasting Authority to conduct investigations can extend to further investigation of the future regulatory arrangements for the on‐line industry. This amendment is currently in the Senate awaiting debate.

PARA.TAB: ‐ since the half yearly accounts of Telstra are publicly available, the Committee recommends that they be presented to the Parliament so that they may be examined by the Senate (paragraph 3.7); and

‐ similarly, any other government business enterprises which are required by the Corporations Law and Australian Stock Exchange listing rules to produce half yearly reports of their accounts should present their half‐yearly reports to the Parliament so that they may be examined by the Senate (paragraph 3.8).

BREAK.PARA: The government's agreement is provided on the basis that tabling in Parliament occurs after the half‐yearly report has been publicly released. The normal protocol would be for the Minister responsible for the Government Business Enterprise to table the half‐yearly report in Parliament. This is the final government response.

The future of performance pay arrangements will be canvassed in the next few months in the context of consideration of the future Australian Public Service employment framework.

The government response has been delayed because a question arose as to the correct portfolio responsibility for reporting the activities of one of the bodies referred to in the Committee's recommendations. PARA.EMPHASIS: Property management in the Australian Public Service

BREAK.PARA: The government response has been deferred until the government considers the report of the Commonwealth Property Committee, which was established by the Budget to review property holdings. The Committee is to report to the government shortly and the government response to the Parliamentary Committee report will follow as soon as possible thereafter.

The government is conscious of the need to conduct asset sales as expeditiously as possible, having regard to the public accountability framework within which it works. For this reason, following the election in March this year, the government gave serious consideration to the issue of the administration of existing and future sales of Commonwealth assets.

The government announced in the recent Budget that it intended to establish the Office of Asset Sales (OAS) to replace the three existing Asset Sales Task Forces (ie the Asset Sales Task Forces A and B and the Airports Sales Task Force). The OAS commenced on 1 October.

Many of the issues arising from the ANL sales process will be addressed through the establishment of the OAS. At a broader level the government is confident that under the new framework more efficient and timely sale outcomes will be achieved within the privatisation program. This is the final government response.

BREAK.PARA: The Committee recommended that the government amend sub‐section (1) of section 96 of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 by extending the time limitation on charges from three to five years.

The Committee's recommendation raises concerns about legal issues, including the exercise of jurisdiction under the Defence Force Disci pline Act 1982 . Accordingly, the views of a number of agencies, including the Attorney‐General's Department and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, have been sought.

Not all the advice has been received and, accordingly, consideration of the recommendation has not yet been finalised. A final response will be made when all aspects of the recommendation have been fully considered.

This recommendation was:
‐ since the half yearly accounts of Telstra are publicly available, the Committee recommends that they be presented to the Parliament so that they may be examined by the Senate (paragraph 3.7); and

‐ similarly, any other government business enterprises which are required by the Corporations Law and Australian Stock Exchange listing rules to produce half yearly reports of their accounts should present their half‐yearly reports to the Parliament so that they may be examined by the Senate (paragraph 3.8).

The government's agreement is provided on the basis that tabling in Parliament occurs after the half‐yearly report has been publicly released. The normal protocol would be for the Minister responsible for the Government Business Enterprise to table the half‐yearly report in Parliament. This is the final government response.

PARA.EMPHASIS: ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION, COMMUNICATIONS AND THE ARTS REFERENCES

INTERJECT.PARA: The government response to these reports is expected to be tabled before the end of the 1996 Spring sittings.
The government response is being amended in light of Budget decisions and will be tabled at the earliest possible date.

No final government response is proposed as the interim response addressed all the recommendations and the report has been overtaken by significant developments with performance pay in the Australian Public Service. The future of performance pay arrangements will be canvassed in the next few months in the context of consideration of the future Australian Public Service employment framework.

The government response has been delayed because a question arose as to the correct portfolio responsibility for reporting the activities of one of the bodies referred to in the Committee's recommendations. This matter is currently the subject of consultations between the respective portfolios. The final government response will be tabled as soon as the matter is resolved.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Property management in the Australian Public Service

INTERJECT.PARA: The government response has been deferred until the government considers the report of the Commonwealth Property Committee, which was established by the Budget to review property holdings. The Committee is to report to the government shortly and the government response to the Parliamentary Committee report will follow as soon as possible thereafter.

The government is conscious of the need to conduct asset sales as expeditiously as possible, having regard to the public accountability framework within which it works. For this reason, following the election in March this year, the government gave serious consideration to the issue of the administration of existing and future sales of Commonwealth assets.

The government announced in the recent Budget that it intended to establish the Office of Asset Sales (OAS) to replace the three existing Asset Sales Task Forces (ie the Asset Sales Task Forces A and B and the Airports Sales Task Force). The OAS commenced on 1 October.

Many of the issues arising from the ANL sales process will be addressed through the establishment of the OAS. At a broader level the government is confident that under the new framework more efficient and timely sale outcomes will be achieved within the privatisation program. This is the final government response.
