DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO POLAND, HUNGARY AND POTSDAM, GERMANY

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Poland, Hungary and Potsdam, Germany, which took place during September and October 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Economics References Committee on outworkers in the garment industry, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report, to incorporate a tabling statement in Hansard and to make some additional remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
Outworkers in the Garment Industry
I present the report of the Economics References Committee entitled Outworkers in the Garment Industry , together with the transcript of evidence.
I move: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 31 August 1995, the Senate referred the matter of the conditions experienced by outworkers in the garment industry to the Senate Economics References Committee for inquiry and report. The matter was re-adopted on 9 May 1996 after the com mencement of the new Parliament. For the three month period from 1 June until 30 August 1996, work on this inquiry was held in abeyance while the Workplace Relations Inquiry was conducted.

The Committee received 40 submissions from a range of individuals and organisations, including community groups, government departments and agencies, peak industry groups, garment companies and from the ACTU and the Textiles Clothing and Footwear Union of Australia. The Committee also received one petition, signed by 522 people.

In an effort to reach migrant outworkers, the Committee advertised in relevant community newspapers in 10 languages and on SBS radio. In addition, the Committee established a dedicated 1800 telephone line with a translator service for receipt of oral submissions. The Committee held public hearings in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Canberra, and visited a number of garment manufacturing companies and outworker homes in Sydney and Melbourne.

Outwork in the garment industry means sewing clothes in a private home. The number of outworkers has increased dramatically over the last decade as a direct result of recent major restructuring in TCF industries. Outworking is now so prevalent that it is not just a characteristic of the industry, the entire garment manufacturing industry is structured around it.

With the addition of a large outworker labour force and their associated intermediaries, the chain of garment production has lengthened. In some instances, as many as seven parties may be involved. Because the chain of garment production is so long, it has become easy for responsibility to be passed off from one element to another along the chain.

While there was debate about the absolute number of outworkers, with estimates ranging from 5O,000 and 330,000 people involved either on a full-time or part-time basis, the Committee concluded that there are sufficient people involved in the industry for concern about them to be warranted.

Most outworkers are migrant women, aged between 25—35, who have young children at home. Some are assisted by their husbands. Most have very poor English language skills and are thus unable to find work elsewhere. Elderly people and children assist in many outworker families with ancillary tasks.

Problems experienced by outworkers include: low piece rates which translate to low hourly rates; impossible deadlines for completion of work; late payment, underpayment, non-payment for completed work, rejection of work and unreimbursed expenses; physical and verbal harassment from intermediaries, including blackmail, threats, coercion and bribes; substandard working environments; and worries associated with combining work with family responsibilities. In short, outworkers are isolated, unseen, unorganised, non-unionised, and ignorant of their employment rights. For these reasons the Committee believes that outworkers, as a group, require special consideration.

Through the availability of the various clothing trades awards, mechanisms exist for outworkers to be paid wages equivalent to factory employees, and some outworkers are paid award wages. However, the structural complexities of the garment manufacturing chain, and resultant ease with which various parties can shed responsibility, mitigates against full award compliance and it appears that the majority of outworkers are not paid award wages. Some outworkers are seriously exploited. In this context, the Committee notes that the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 will change the circumstances under which outworkers may be employed by providing for individual Workplace Agreements with scrutiny of such agreements available through the Employment Advocate. It is the Committee's view, however, that in accordance with the nature of outwork and past experience in the industry, it is probable that most outworkers will not be required to sign any contract and will continue to be employed in the same manner as they have been in the past.

The Committee notes that occupational health and safety of outworkers is a neglected issue. Although the magnitude of occupational and secondary stress induced health problems is not known, the Committee is concerned that because outworkers are treated as contractors rather than as employees, the ultimate cost of accidents and illness among them may be being borne by the public sector. A number of recommendations were made to the Committee by Worksafe Australia and the Committee has endorsed those recommendations.

Evidence indicated that children are involved in outworking and the Committee concluded that there was sufficient evidence to suggest that some children are involved to an unreasonable extent. However, the Committee concluded that the situation endured by exploited children will only be ameliorated through an improvement in the employment conditions experienced by their parents. The Committee thus suggested to the Government that, having regard to Australia's international and national obligations to protect children from exploitation, consideration of this matter was warranted.

The issues of taxation obligations and eligibility for welfare benefits were found to be of concern to some outworkers, particularly those who may have been coerced into infringements. As evidenced by the introduction of the Reportable Payments System and the Social Security amnesty for outworkers, these issues were clearly also of concern to the relevant government instrumentalities. The Commit tee concluded that both schemes had merit. In particular, the Committee concluded that the Australian Taxation Office could take greater advantage of the Reportable Payments System to fully investigate taxation avoidance in TCF industries. In terms of the social security amnesty, the Committee has suggested to the Government that it consider its reinstatement.

The Committee notes that despite a low participation rate, the Labour Adjustment Program has been of benefit to a number of people in TCF industries and the Committee has recommended that the government consider extending the cut-off date for prior employment of the Labour Adjustment Program to a date in the future to be determined in consultation with the Union.

The Committee notes that Australia has not become a signatory to the ILO Convention and Recommendation on Home Work, and the Committee has undertaken to review the Government's position in relation to the Convention in 12 months time.

The Committee noted that a grant by the previous Government to the Textiles Clothing and Footwear Union of Australia for outworker related activities, which had resulted in a number of beneficial outcomes, had been cancelled by the new Government. Thus the Committee has recommended to the Government that in evaluating proposals for expenditure from the TCF 2000 Development Package, consideration be given to the need for outworker projects similar to those carried out recently by the Union.

The Committee endorsed the approach taken by the Union in promoting and establishing Deeds of Cooperation between the Union and garment retailers, manufacturing companies and government purchasers of clothing and has recommended to all government agencies involved in clothing procurement that they consider whether outworkers are used in the manufacture of that clothing and, if so, whether they are able to enter into such Deeds of Cooperation.

The Committee concluded that the draft voluntary industry `Homeworkers Code of Practice', originally promoted by the Council of Textile and Fashion Industries of Australia, could be an important step in changing the circumstances under which outworkers are employed, and has recommended that the Code be adopted by all participants in the garment retailing and manufacturing process.

In attempting to resolve the problems faced by outworkers, quite a number of recommendations were made to the Committee by various government, industry and community groups. It is clear from the number of suggestions that a combined and coordinated approach is needed. Of those recommendations made, the Committee endorsed and recommended a range of other actions. These are detailed in the Committee's report. In brief they include:

PARA.TAB: a voluntary label declaring that the employment conditions under which the garment was made have complied with legislative requirements;
a National Outwork Committee, coordinated at government level, and including representatives from industry, unions, community groups, and government agencies;
a comprehensive survey of the number of home-based workers across all industries to be carried out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics;
a review of federally funded arrangements for English language education with a view to increasing accessibility for migrants involved in outwork;
a government review of educational arrangements in TCF industries for industrial relations and small business management; and
the rapid allocation of funding from the TCF 2000 Development Package for projects specifically relating to outworkers;

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the Committee has undertaken to review in 12 months time outworking in the garment industry, with particular reference to the recommendations contained in its report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to take note of this report of the Economics References Committee. Following my work on the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, I am pleased to be able to say that this report from the references committee is a consensual report involving a fairly lengthy and serious consideration of problems existing amongst outworkers in the garment industry and recommendations to the government with respect to those problems.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the overwhelming findings of the inquiry was that special consideration is required with respect to the difficulties faced by outworkers in the garment industry, both with respect to the potential number of workers involved working within the industry and the overall treatment faced by workers.

Whilst the Workplace Relations Act will introduce individual contracts across industries and some protections will be available to workers who would come under individual contracts, the committee felt that they are unlikely to reach outworkers, given the nature of past regulation and the ability to enforce that regulation amongst outworkers. Award provisions, for instance, have been very difficult to enforce and often only by the department relying upon union intervention. In some respects that intervention will be restricted by title provisions on right of entry. I am sure we are all aware of this, given that we have debated it in the past in the workplace relations bill.

I would like to highlight the various forms with which outwork is exploited in the garment industry. It is not only in relation to the workers themselves but in the wider community that many difficulties can be highlighted. Outwork may be exploited by the garment manufacturing companies directly and indirectly in several ways. There is a table on page 34 of the report which highlights many of those ways. They include non-payment of award wages, reduced payments for acceptance of cash and complete non-payment of wages in some instances, all of which contribute to a reduction in the wages component of a garment manufacturer. When you calculate that to an hourly rate, there was evidence before the committee that in some cases that could be as low as about $2 per hour.

Other difficulties include non-payment of outworkers for time spent on ancillary tasks such as unbundling, learning design and cutting threads. Costs normally paid by the manufacturing factory can often be borne by the outworkers—for example, cotton, thread, electricity, machinery repair and the leasing of machinery. Also, the deeming of outworkers as contractors often results in a shift in cost from the manufacturer to the outworker over such things as superannuation and insurance premiums. The payment in cash and inaccurate record-keeping results in losses in taxation revenue.

Unregulated hours of work results in overwork, with consequent health and safety problems among outworkers, the cost of which is then borne by the public sector through Medicare claims and welfare benefits. Also, the use of intermediaries to keep the work force one or more steps removed from the manufacturing companies allows the shedding of many of the responsibilities. In some cases, these are picked up by the social security, taxation and health systems.

The other problem which was identified by the committee and which we hope will be resolved by further attention in this area is the exploitation of children. Families under pressure carrying out work at home can, according to some evidence before the committee, involve an inordinate amount of work by children in order to complete tasks in a hurry. This was found in some instances to be far from reasonable.
The committee made a number of major recommendations in relation to these difficulties. Page xv of the report states:

The Committee notes the cancellation of the grant by the current Government to the Textiles Clothing and Footwear Union of Australia for outworker related activities. The Committee believes that the grant made by the previous Government to the Union for outworkers activities had already resulted in a number of beneficial outcomes. The Committee recommends to the Government that in evaluating proposals for expenditure from the TCF 2000 Development Package, consideration be given to the need for outworker projects similar to those carried out recently by the Union .
Another major recommendation of the committee states:

The Committee strongly believes that the Australian Taxation Office could take greater advantage of the Reportable Payments System to fully investigate taxation avoidance in TCF industries. The Committee notes that an important additional benefit of the Reportable Payments System is that it will assist in identifying all parties involved in the garment manufacturing chain, particularly those at the level of intermediary. In addition, the Committee notes that information gained from the Reportable Payments System is able to be used by the Department of Social Security to investigate welfare benefits fraud.

A further recommendation of the committee is that the government should look at further ways of facilitating voluntary regulation from within the industry. I would like to note at this stage that, during the inquiry and perhaps to some extent arising from the inquiry, some improvements were made in the relations between different parties within the industry in how the difficulties and the problems could be regulated.

BREAK.PARA: The committee found that there are two basic ways in which actions can be taken to improve conditions under which outworkers perform their work: legislative and voluntary. The union had proposed legislative action for the enactment of sale of clothing legislation. In contrast to this, both the union and the Council of Textile and Fashion Industries of Australia have promoted voluntary deeds of cooperation or an industry home workers code of practice.

The committee was mindful of the arguments put forward by both parties and concluded that voluntary action should be supported in the first instance and, in particular, that the proposed industry code of practice should be fully embraced by all parties involved. Should voluntary action fail to have any effect, then legislative action may need to be considered.

The committee recommended that an industry home workers code of practice be adopted by all participants in the garment retailing and manufacturing process. However, we regret that further progress had not been made at this stage. A couple of weeks before the conclusion of this report, negotiations had broken down. It was with disappointment that only a few retailers had become party to either an individual deed of cooperation or the industry code of practice.

Therefore, the committee has undertaken that we should review in 12 months time both this recommendation and several other recommendations within the report to see if further recommendations are required, particularly what progress has been made in relation to voluntary regulation within the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly on the Senate Economics References Committee report entitled Outworkers in the garment industry . I do support many of the things that Senator Jacinta Collins has said. This has been a very important inquiry. The issue was raised initially in this chamber by former Senator Sid Spindler. But the terms of reference that were eventually drawn up were endorsed wholeheartedly by all parties in this chamber because of the very important nature of this inquiry.

BREAK.PARA: As the chairman of this inquiry for the initial stages and, indeed, for a considerable time in the public hearings, I can say that the inquiry was conducted in an excellent manner and we were provided with a tremendous amount of information to help us look into what was perceived to be a very serious problem in the outworking industry.

I think this inquiry is an example of the Senate committee system working at its very best. People from all parties worked together to come up with a report on this inquiry. With only one exception, the recommendations are unanimous. That involved a little bit of give and take on both sides to make sure that the recommendations were unanimous—or as near to as possible. As I said, there was that one minor exception where government members recommended a different course to one of the recommendations.

Out of this inquiry, we hope some good will come to those people whom we were looking into. There was always going to be one danger from the very start of this inquiry. When we had completed this inquiry, we wanted to make sure that those people whose hardships we were looking into would thank us for the work we were doing. There was always the danger that, in uncovering some of the injustices that do occur, some of these people may find themselves out of a job. They may not thank us for doing that. I think the report has been handled in a sensitive enough way and the recommendations have been put in such a way that the people whom we have been trying to help will indeed get some benefit from the report.

PARA.BREAK: This is a very difficult industry to look into because it seems as though the problems that were being highlighted to us were caused by the chain of production. It was impossible for us at some stages to identify the intermediaries involved in that chain of production. They are the people we would really have liked to get at, because they are the ones who we think were putting some unnecessary pressure on home workers and outworkers at, one might term, the bottom end of the scale. I am very sorry that at some stage during the inquiry we could not identify some of these middlemen or intermediaries who were mak ing life for the outworkers or the home workers in the industry as difficult as it appeared to be from some of the visits we made.

BREAK.PARA: I am conscious of the time. I am not going to talk about other things in the report, because it is there for everybody to see. But there were some issues that were highlighted. I think it is a very important report for people in the Senate to read and to understand because we spent almost 12 months looking at it and making sure we covered every angle. I commend the report to the Senate.

In closing, I particularly commend the secretariat of this committee. The secretariat of this committee has had a horrendous year with the workload that has been placed upon it. When you consider—and this is the same secretariat as had to handle the workplace relations bill, which was a very constant workload—the amount of work that the secretariat put into this inquiry and the other matters of legislation that have been put before our committee, I can only say my thanks to the secretary, Rob Diamond. In the case of this report, I especially want to thank Dr Pippa Carron, who was involved throughout the inquiry and did much of the work in writing the report. I also thank Geoff Dawson and Merrilyn Pyle. Those four people actually form an outstanding secretariat in this place, and I can only commend them for their outstanding work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate system has great value in drawing attention to problems and creating a public discussion. Outworking is a perfect example. I would like to compliment the Chair of the committee, Senator Jacinta Collins; the Deputy Chair, Senator Ferguson; and the secretariat.

SPEECH.PARA: Outworking is an exceptional problem. It is on that basis that I want to draw attention to it. We fail to take action on outworking at our peril because of the social issues that are involved. Some of the salient features of outworking are worth while repeating: low piece rates, which translate to low hourly rates; impossible deadlines for the completion of work; late payment or underpayment or non-payment for completed work; rejection of work and non‐reimbursement of expenses; physical and verbal harassment from intermediaries, in other words, blackmail and threats and coercion and bribes—and all of this to a group of workers that we identified as being, generally, migrant women who are 25 to 35 years of age and have children.

So there are substandard working environments, and the worries are so shaded with combining work and family responsibilities. These stresses are compounded by the lack of English language and the inadequate training in so many cases. What the committee has discovered is a haemorrhaging of industrial standards and health standards. We found taxation abuse and social security abuse.

I would commend the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Union for the excellent work it has done over a number of years and over a number of governments. It has struggled, in some ways on its own, until fairly recently, to deal with this tremendous problem.

What we have is a detailed report, and the detailed recommendations must be acted on. I believe they are both exceptional and serious. There is hope because the valiant efforts of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Union and the responsible attitude of the Council of Textile and Fashion Industries of Australia had moved to the situation where they had an advance draft of voluntary code of practice. I hope we hear more of that because—although, unfortunately, we have seen a setback in that process, with some of the retailers retreating from the signing of the voluntary code—we believe it is essential. In its recommendations, the committee said:

The Committee recommends that an industry `Homeworkers Code of Practice' should be adopted by all participants in the garment retailing and manufacturing process. The Committee regrets that further progress has not been made towards establishing a voluntary Code and undertakes to review progress towards voluntary regulation in a further 12 months.

So we will look at the matter in 12 months time. The problem is that some of the retailers have moved away, but very significant names in Australia are involved already. Target, Just Jeans, Country Road, Ken Done and Australia Post have signed. Significantly, we recommend that government authorities should sign that code. I will not go into the detail of that. But, because of moral and ethical reasons, there is every reason why every government authority should be involved in taking that stand.

We will review these issues in 12 months. All I want to say—because I am conscious of voluntarily cutting my speech short—is that it is an important issue. I have not seen a better report for identifying the problems. It now requires government and the participants in industry to find the ultimate solution. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventh report of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1996 and the Racial Discrimination Act, together with submissions received by the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave move a motion and to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
The statement read as follows—

On 19 November the Senate resolved to continue a reference of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1996 to the Parliamentary Joint Committee for further consideration. The Senate resolved on a motion that I moved pursuant to a recommendation of the Committee's sixth report which had examined the Bill.

The issue at stake for the continuing reference and the issue that is the focus of the seventh report concerns the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 (RDA). That is, do the proposed amendments to the Native Title Act 1993 (NTA) offend the RDA?

The Howard Government respects the Racial Discrimination Act. The Prime Minister has made that clear this year in statements to the parliament. Further, the Prime Minister has confirmed the Government's commitment to Mabo and the preservation of the integrity of the High Court's decision. The Committee has re‐examined the amendment proposals from the perspective of the RDA to ascertain whether the RDA would be overridden by the amendments: that is, whether the amendments are inconsistent with the Prime Minister's assurances. The Committee's seventh report clearly concludes that the amendments supported by the Committee's sixth report are not inconsistent with the RDA.

Reasons for the Committee's conclusion are quite transparent. The Native Title Act was regarded as a `special measure' under the RDA; the Preamble and Prime Minister Keating's Second Reading speech make this clear. Special measures may be provided to disadvantaged racial groups without breaching the principles of racial discrimination. The Attorney-General's Department advised the Committee that the traditional legal position in Australia has been that any laws covering racial matters must provide either `formal equality' or be a special measure. The benefits endorsed under the Native Title Act are special measures.

Importantly, special measures are endorsed out of a political judgement that they are justified. Being provided by the legislature, special measures can also be withdrawn or modified without inconsistency with the RDA. Nevertheless, the Committee has not taken the approach that special measures may be modified at will. Rather, the Committee's sixth report acknowledges that the right to negotiate is a valuable asset and should not be extinguished wholesale without sound reason.

In its examination of this matter the Committee heard an alternative view to the effect that the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and the RDA require `benign discrimination' or measures ensuring `substantive equality'. The Committee's seventh report argues against this alternative view. Not only is it confronted by the fact that the courts have not adopted such a view, but it depends mainly on a footnote to a page in the High Court's judgement in Western Australia v. the Commonwealth (1995). The Committee cannot accept that the High Court relied on the alternative view in that case. It also cannot accept the argument of the alternative view that it is likely to be adopted by the High Court in the near future.

If the Convention and the RDA do not require substantive equality but only formal equality, and if special measures may not only be endorsed but also modified, then amendments to the NTA affecting existing statutory rights are possible without inconsistency with the RDA.

Where the NTA has proven unworkable, to the disadvantage of indigenous and other parties, then it arguably should be amended in the national interest. In the Committee's view this is possible without overriding the RDA.

There is one further matter that deserves mention. The Committee has carefully considered the first minority report's proposal to amend the NTA by giving precedence to the RDA. The generality of the proposed clause would entail its unpredictability in the unlikely event of a conflict between the amendments and the RDA; this makes for bad legislation. Even more importantly, there is an implied admission in the minority recommendation that the RDA clause could apply in an uncertain fashion. If the minority was confident in its judgement of ways in which the RDA might be offended by the proposed amendments, then it should identify them and argue the case. The minority's RDA clause would result in a request to the courts to make sense of the amending legislation. It would abdicate our responsibility to unelected judges, and compound the scope for litigation. I enjoin the parliament, in consistency with the RDA, to fulfil its obligation to legislate for a more workable Native Title Act and I commend the Committee's seventh report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of Senator O'Chee, I present a statement on behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances relating to an apparent breach of parliamentary propriety. I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard and move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
Apparent breach of parliamentary propriety

Honourable Senators are aware that the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances scrutinises all disallowable legislative instruments to ensure that each instrument complies with its high standards of personal rights and parliamentary propriety. The Committee then reports to the Senate on any breaches of these standards and on action which it has taken to correct the problem. Usually the responsible Minister will meet these concerns by undertaking to amend the enabling Act or the instrument itself, or by giving further details about the background of the operation of the instrument which satisfies the Committee. It is therefore with regret that I report to the Senate on matters relating to a legislative instrument which the Committee believes has breached parliamentary propriety and in respect of which the Committee has not yet received satisfactory undertakings.

The instrument in question is the Crimes Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1996 No 7, made on 24 January 1996. The Regulations were quite short and had only one purpose, which was to exempt the Australian Securities Commission from provisions of the Spent Convictions Scheme. That scheme provides for important personal rights whereby, if a person was convicted of an offence more than 10 years ago, was sentenced to less than 30 months imprisonment and has not reoffended, then the conviction is spent and the person is legally able to claim, on oath or otherwise, that they were never convicted of the offence. Also, other people who are aware of the offence must generally not disclose the conviction without the consent of the person affected and must not take the conviction into account in any decision making process. The enabling Act, however, provides for the Regulations to prescribe exemptions from the scheme. The Crimes Regulations in question exempted the ASC from the Spent Convictions Scheme in regard to all offences for the purposes of considering whether to prosecute, making submissions as to sentence, and assessing the suitability of a person to be employed by the ASC.

The Committee scrutinised the Regulations and noted the advice of its Legal Adviser, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan, that the parent Act provided for the Privacy Commissioner to receive applications for exemptions from the Scheme and to advise the Minister on whether an exemption should be granted. The Committee noted that neither the making words of the Regulations nor the Explanatory Statement even referred to this requirement, much less that it had been observed, or to the substance of the Privacy Commissioner's advice, the obtaining of which was mandatory. The Committee assumed that this was because the matter was routine in nature, with no unusual or unexpected features. Nevertheless, the Committee wrote to the Minister on 15 April 1996 asking for confirmation that the Privacy Commissioner was consulted and, if so, of the result of those consultations.

The reply from the Minister, dated three and a half months later, advised that the Privacy Commissioner was indeed consulted, as required by the Act, but that the Minister had overruled the Commissioner's advice that the exemption should not be granted.

This advice was of considerable concern to the Committee. It meant that the sole provision of the Regulations was contrary to an express recommendation of the Privacy Commissioner in respect of his statutory duty to provide such advice. The concern was compounded by the fact that, as a consequence of the delay in replying and of the making words and the Explanatory Statement omitting any reference to the Privacy Commissioner, the Committee assumed that there was nothing untoward about the Regulations and did not give a protective notice of disallowance. Also, importantly, the incomplete Explanatory Statement also meant that individual Senators with an interest in legislation affecting personal rights were not alerted to a matter of interest.

The Committee emphasises that it did not draw any conclusions about the desirability or otherwise of the substance of the exclusion of the ASC from the Spent Convictions Scheme. The Committee was concerned, however, that the important questions which the Regulations raised were concealed, whether inadvertently or not, from the attention and scrutiny of the Senate. In this context I add that the non‐partisan Committee stays well clear of policy issues, but does attempt to ensure openness and accountability so that Senators should have every opportunity to take whatever action they see fit in respect of individual instruments.

After receiving this startling advice from the Minister the Committee replied, setting out its concerns and suggesting that, in the circumstances, it may be appropriate for the Regulations to be repealed and remade, with a complete Explanatory Statement. The Committee noted that this would preserve the options of the Committee and the Senate but would not disrupt the present arrangements pending informed parliamentary scrutiny. The Committee also advised that it would write to the Privacy Commissioner and, after considering his reply, decide whether it would be appropriate for members of the Attorney‐General's Department to attend a meeting of the Committee.

The Privacy Commissioner subsequently advised the Committee that he was not aware that the Explanatory Statement failed to refer to his views on the exemption and that he appreciated the continued support of the Committee in seeking to promote a more open approach by agencies in relation to differences of view with his office, particularly where legislation is concerned.

The Minister then replied to the Committee advising that, in his view, the Explanatory Statement was adequate because it set out the provision of the Act under which the Regulations were made and general background, even though it did not mention the statutory obligation to receive advice from the Privacy Commissioner, or the result of that adverse advice. The Minister also advised, however, that he was prepared to adopt a practice under which the views of the Privacy Commissioner, if not included in the Explanatory Statement, would be communicated to the Committee at the same time as any future Regulations were tabled. The Minister advised that he could not agree that the Regulations should be repealed and remade.

The Committee then met with officers of the Attorney‐General's Department to discuss the matter. The Committee is grateful to the Minister for releasing these officers. The Minister also advised that the delay in replying was unfortunate. In addition, a member of the Minister's staff wrote to the Committee advising that the Minister was conscious of, and regretted, the delay.

After considering the Minister's reply and the discussions with the officers, the Committee advised the Minister that it remained concerned at the way in which this matter was handled. The Committee advised that, in its view, any suggestion that the Explanatory Statement for these Regulations need not advise either that the enabling Act expressly required the Privacy Commissioner to receive and examine relevant requests for exclusion and to advise the Minister on whether an exclusion should be granted, or that the Privacy Commissioner in this case recommended against exclusion, but was overruled, is not supportable. In the present case the Committee considers that it is a breach of parliamentary propriety.

The Committee also advised the Minister that his offer to communicate the views of the Privacy Commissioner to the Committee at the time of tabling of any future Regulations, if they were not included in the Explanatory Statement, would not be a satisfactory solution. This was because Senators would not be informed of relevant matters. Individual Senators give many notices of disallowance which may not be directly related to issues raised by the Committee. For instance, Senators may wish to disallow an instrument, or a provision of an instrument, on policy grounds. The Committee, on the other hand, does not raise matters of policy and operates in a non‐partisan fashion.

In this context the Committee advised the Minister that it noted that present Commonwealth drafting practice for legislative instruments appears to be to include sometimes lengthy recitals in the making words that statutory consultation requirements have been met. The Committee gave instances of such recitals. In the case of another instrument, which the Committee understands was drafted by officers of the Attorney‐General's Department, the making words actually recite that the instrument was made after consultation with the Privacy Commissioner.

The Committee advised the Minister that it supports this practice and assumes that if the relevant consultations or advice led to results which were unusual or unexpected, such as a decision to override the Privacy Commissioner, that this would be explained in the Explanatory Statement.

The Committee advised the Minister that it would, therefore, appreciate his advice that any future Explanatory Statements intended for tabling should include advice of any mandatory statutory consultation before the instrument was made and of the result of that consultation.

With regard to the delay of three and a half months in replying to the Committee's first letter, with the result that the Committee did not give a protective notice of disallowance of the Regulations, the Committee advised the Minister that it accepted the advice that he regretted the delay.

The Committee also advised that it would write to the Minister responsible for the Federal Executive Council Handbook, asking for the Handbook to be amended to provide for Explanatory Statements to advise of any mandatory consultation. The current edition of the Handbook expressly refers to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

At this point I emphasise again that the Committee made no finding on whether the ASC should or should not be exempted from the Spent Convictions Scheme. This is a matter on which informed and well intentioned people may differ. It is, however, also a matter affecting the personal rights of those who come within the scheme and as such it is a matter upon which the Senate should have been fully informed. It is, as I say, a matter of regret that this was not done and a breach of parliamentary propriety.

I will report again when the Committee has received further replies. In the meantime the Committee considered that it should inform the Senate of its actions, which it is hoped will result in a better quality of both legislative drafting and of explanatory material.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator O'Chee—who is, unfortunately, indisposed—and the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I present the traditional end of sittings statement on the work of the committee and seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard and move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: During the present sittings the Committee scrutinised the usual large number of disallowable legislative instruments tabled in the Senate, made under the authority of scores of enabling Acts administered through virtually every Department of State. Almost every legislative scheme relies on delegated legislation to provide the administrative details of programs set out in broad policy in enabling Acts which authorise such delegated legislation.

The Committee acts on behalf of the Senate to scrutinise each of these instruments to ensure that they conform to the same high standards of parliamentary propriety and personal rights which the Senate applies to Acts. If the Committee detects any breach of these standards it writes to the Minister or other law‐maker in respect of the apparent defect, asking that the instrument be amended or an explanation provided. If the breach appears serious then the Chairman of the Committee gives notice of a motion of disallowance in respect of the instrument. This allows the Senate, if it wishes, to disallow the instrument. This ultimate step is rarely necessary, however, as Ministers almost invariably take action which satisfies the Committee.

As usual, by the end of the sittings Ministers have given the Committee undertakings to amend many provisions in different instruments or enabling Acts to meet its concerns, reflecting a continuing high level of cooperation from Ministers in its non‐partisan operations. The Committee is grateful for this cooperation.

During the sittings the Committee scrutinised 889 instruments. Of these, 192 were statutory rules, which are generally better drafted and presented than other series of delegated legislation. The other 697 instruments were the usual heterogeneous collection of different series.

Each of the 889 instruments was scrutinised by the Committee under its four principles, or terms of reference, which are included in the Standing Orders. There were 101 prima facie defects or matters worthy of comment in those 889 instruments. The defects are described below under each of the four principles.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Is delegated legislation in accordance with the statute?

BREAK.PARA: The Committee interprets this principle broadly. Together with the Committee's fourth principle, it covers not only technical validity, but also every other aspect of parliamentary propriety. The Committee noted that there may have been problems with instruments for the following reasons.

Legislative instruments are invalid if they subdelegate legislative power without express authorisation in the enabling Act. One Ordinance purported to grant power to the Minister to make Determinations, which would themselves be disallowable instruments, without any apparent legislative authority. Two other instruments purported to confer upon individuals what appeared to be legislative power. Three instruments made by a statutory authority subdelegated legislative power to itself.

Under s.49A of the Act Interpretation Act 1901 legislative instruments may, in general, only incorporate material as it exists at the time the instrument was made, not as the material exists from time to time. In one case, the enabling Act expressly authorised some material as amended to be incorporated, but not the actual documents as amended which the instrument purported to incorporate. Another enabling Act authorised the law of a foreign country as in force from time to time to be incorporated, but the instrument incorporated material as amended which did not appear to be part of that law. Another instrument purported to incorporate amended material for which there appeared to be no provision in the enabling Act to affect the operation of s.49A.

Under s.48(3) of the Acts Interpretation Act delegated legislation generally ceases to have effect if not tabled in both Houses within 15 sitting days of making. On 3 December 1996 the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Bill O'Chee, made a detailed statement to the Senate on recent failures to table. Earlier in the present sittings, however, two legislative instruments ceased to have effect because they were not tabled in time. The sole purpose of both instruments was to provide for the payment of money from one Commonwealth agency to another and this was validly done within those 15 sitting days. The Committee points out that this procedure is undesirable because it means that the Senate is not given an opportunity to scrutinise such instruments.

There were other problems affecting validity. One instrument was neither signed nor dated. Another had insufficient information to identify who made it, the date of making or the authority under which it was made; some of this material was included in a covering letter, although part of this information was wrong. The Explanatory Statements for three instruments included errors which, if correct, would have made the three instruments void. A Note to another instrument advised that, to avoid doubt, the instrument commenced on making, while the Explanatory Statement advised that it commenced on gazettal; if it actually commenced on making it would have been void for prejudicial retrospectivity. One instrument provided that it would take effect from a specified date although the Appendix to the instrument advised that it would take effect from another date. One instrument included a report on a matter while the Act required a record of the matter. Another instrument did not effect its legislative intent. A number of instruments did not comply with an earlier undertaking by the Minister to ensure that the instruments complied with the requirements of the enabling Act. The Explanatory Statement for another instrument advised that it would be administered according to what its provisions were intended to be, not what they actually were.
The Committee considers that the quality of drafting of legislative instruments should not be less than that of Acts. This standard was not always met.

Regulations which implemented firearms controls after the Port Arthur killings provided for guns to be tested by dropping from a height of not more than 45 centimetres, when it appeared that not less than 45 centimetres was intended. One instrument provided for offences with no apparent penalties. Another provided for approved persons with no provision for approval. Several instruments had no numbering while others had the same numbering. One instrument included apparently contradictory provisions. The Explanatory Statement for one instrument advised that it was removing an unworkable provision; the Committee asked why an unworkable provision was included. Other instruments included reference errors and deficiencies in drafting style. Three sets of Regulations were made on the same day, amending the same principal Regulations.

Under s.48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act legislative instruments which operate retrospectivety are void if they adversely affect any person apart from the Commonwealth. The Committee, however, will write to Ministers about any unusual retrospectivity, or delay, even if it is valid. One instrument, not amended since 1984, included references to provisions of Acts repealed a decade ago. One instrument, providing for the imposition of tax, operated with four years retrospectivety. Another provided for grants of money to private companies which could have been made a year earlier. Another provided for 10 months retrospectivity even though the authorities had known for three years that the instrument would be needed.

Due to the initiative of the Committee all legislative instruments are now accompanied by Explanatory Statements. Some of these, however, do not give sufficient information to enable informed scrutiny of the instrument by individual Senators. One Explanatory Statement gave insufficient details of an important new primary dispute resolution process. Others were too brief to be useful. Others did not advise that the purpose of the instrument was to implement an undertaking given by a Minister to the Committee. Others did not advise of the date of gazettal of instruments which commenced on gazettal.

It is a breach of parliamentary propriety if a legislative instrument provides for inappropriate delegation of administrative powers. Several instruments provided for wide delegation of power, in one case to any person at all.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Does delegated legislation trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties?

BREAK.PARA: The Committee also interprets this provision broadly, to include every aspect of personal rights. The Committee noted possible breaches of personal rights for the following reasons.

Legislative instruments which provide for administrative decisions to be made should include appropriate safeguards. One instrument provided for time limits for some decisions but not for others. Another provision required notice in writing of a decision to be given but not, as appeared appropriate in the circumstances, for a statement of reasons for the decision. Another expressly advised that a decision maker could take into account the commercial reputation of an applicant, but there was no requirement for the applicant to be made aware of any adverse material or to respond to it. Another provided subjective criteria for a decision maker to apply, including the criterion of any other matter which the decision maker considers relevant. One instrument, which was made partly to provide for the 2000 Sydney Olympic Games, reduced the existing rights of competitive athletes selected for drug testing. Another instrument provided an international organisation with a 10 months retrospective right to sue. The Explanatory Statement for another instrument advised that it removed an existing right because legal advice was received that the enabling Act did not provide the authority for such a right; the Committee asked if the Act would be amended to provide such authority.

The Committee protects personal privacy. One instrument provided for the disclosure of personal information, subject only to subjective criteria, but gave no indication of to whom the information could be disclosed. Another instrument provided that a class of agent must provide information about people for whom the Agent acts when required to do so by a government agency. A number of instruments provided for the disclosure of private information in circumstances where it would have been appropriate for the Privacy Commissioner to have been consulted.

The Committee ensures that legislative instruments which affect business operations should operate as fairly as possible. One instrument prescribed four well known private companies as the only companies which could do certain work for a government agency, including work connected with the 2000 Olympics; but the Explanatory Statement gave no indication of how the companies were chosen. Another instrument provided for unfair and apparently unintended restrictions on certain business activity, while another unrelated instrument provided for an unfair and unintended interruption to a permission to carry on business. The Explanatory Statement for another instrument advised of potential inconvenience for business people affected by an aspect of the official launch of the logos and mascots of the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games.

The Committee questions changes to taxes, charges and financial provisions generally, which in the circumstances may not operate fairly. One instrument increased a fee from $368 to $500 while another instrument increased a similar fee from $368 to $800, with no explanation for the difference. Another instrument increased an allowance for Commonwealth public servants by 40 per cent, four years after the previous increase. Another instrument had the potential to operate unfairly in respect of the recovery of medical and dental costs from members of the Australian Defence Force. One instrument provided only a Canberra telephone number for inquiries from everywhere in Australia from athletes selected for mandatory drug testing, but the number was not a free call. One instrument provided that agents must keep separate accounts for those whom they represent, but there was no requirement that the separate accounts be trust accounts. One instrument, made to correct an earlier instrument, inadvertently resulted in a hiatus in the payment of an allowance to Commonwealth public servants.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Does delegated legislation make rights unduly dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to independent review of their merits?

BREAK.PARA: Many legislative instruments provide for Ministers, statutory office holders and other public offices to exercise discretions. The Committee considers that such discretions should be as narrow as possible, include objective criteria to guide and limit the exercise of the discretion, and provide for appropri ate review of the merits of a decision by an external, independent tribunal, which would usually be the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

A number of instruments affecting business did not appear to provide for review of administrative decisions. One instrument provided for discretions relating to compliance by miners with mandatory requirements. Another granted a power to withdraw accreditation of commercial premises, with only subjective criteria. A number of amending instruments provided for unreviewable discretions although the principal instrument provided for review of similar discretions; one of these included a number of decisions affecting the commercial operations of a casino operator. One instrument provided a discretion to recover the costs of an inquiry into a business operator. Another provided a discretion to release commercially sensitive information. The Explanatory Statement for another instrument advised of review rights in respect of a discretion, but it was not apparent what these were. One instrument provided a discretion to exempt certain containers and packs from mandatory standards. The Explanatory Statement for another advised that a discretion was intended to operate as a sanction for a certain commercial decision. Another instrument provided a discretion relating to the operation of a pharmacy.

A number of instruments did not appear to provide for review of decisions affecting individuals. These included power to refuse to provide hearing services, to affect superannuation benefits and to import firearms. Other discretions were to undertake or discontinue inquiries about disputes with a statutory authority, to authorise people as counsellors and mediators and to exempt people from the payment of fees.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Does delegated legislation contain matters more appropriate for parliamentary enactment?

BREAK.PARA: The Committee raises this principle less often than its other principles. It is a principle, however, which goes to the heart of parliamentary propriety and complements the first principle of the Committee, that an instrument should be in accordance with the statute.
In addition to its main task of scrutinising delegated legislation, the Committee was active in other ways during the present sittings.

On 16 October 1996 the Chairman, Senator O'Chee, together with the Chairman of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, Senator Cooney, tabled a Position Paper on Scrutiny of National Schemes of Legislation.
The Chairman made the following special statements to the Senate:
Instruments made in respect of the Australian Census; 22 August 1996
Instruments made under the Native Title Act 1993 ; 10 October 1996
Legislative Instruments Bill 1996; 21 November 1996
Late tabling of legislative instruments; 3 December 1996
Aspects of the Crimes Regulations ; 12 December 1996

During its scrutiny of the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 the Chairman, the Legal Adviser and the Secretary had two lengthy meetings with the Attorney‐General, the Hon Daryl Williams AC QC MP. The Committee is grateful to the Minister for his personal attention to its concerns.

During its scrutiny of the Crimes Regulations officers of the Attorney‐General's Department attended upon the Committee. The Committee is grateful to the Attorney‐General for releasing these officers.
On 22 August 1996 the Committee hosted a visit by the Scrutiny of Acts and Regulations Committee of the Victorian Parliament.
On 3 December 1996 the Committee made a submission to the inquiry by the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee into the Administrative Review Council.
The Committee would like to record its appreciation of the sterling work of its independent Legal Adviser, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan AM.
The Committee is grateful for the support which it has received from the Senate during the present sittings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives agreeing to the amendments made by the Senate in the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Herron) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
This debate is about passing a bill that protects the vulnerable—or about leaving them exposed to pressure, abuse and a loss of autonomy:
It is not a debate about territory rights;
It is not about the separation of church and state;
It is not about regulating current practice; and
It is not a simple issue of personal autonomy.

Territories do not have rights—they have responsibilities, particularly to protect the ill and the vulnerable. This parliament has been prepared to override states, most recently Tasmania, in the national interest.

In this case, parliament has express constitutional power. Yet we hear urgings that we should ignore our responsibilities on the spurious grounds that one small territory, with the population of a suburban municipality in Melbourne or Sydney, by one vote, without any house of review, without attempting to state why a law rejected by every major inquiry in the world was proper, and in face of the universal opposition of its aboriginal population—whose remonstrance I bring before the parliament with this Letter Stick; that territory can pass a law that affects many Australians and then claim, nay, demand, that we wash our hands of our responsibilities.
If the parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia cannot resolve a matter that goes to the life and death of its citizens, then what is the purpose of this parliament?

Secondly, it would be strange if only those without religious belief could express an opinion on such a profound matter. The fact that no other parliament has passed such a law is striking evidence of the breadth of the opposition—something which Hippocrates expressed thousands of years ago when he said: "I will neither give a deadly drug to anybody if asked for it, nor will I make a suggestion to this effect."

People like Colleen McCullough with no religious beliefs, and Professor Malcolm Fisher who describes himself as a "born again heathen" strenuously oppose lethal injections. There are religious and non religious people on both sides of this debate. Let us deal with the arguments.
One of the arguments is "Its happening already, so we should regulate it."
This is like saying, "some people will obtain high powered automatic guns, so we should regulate, but not ban them."
If a person is willing to disregard a law which says lethal injections are never allowed, why will they be constrained by a law which says lethal injections are sometimes allowed?

If some doctors are prepared to take the law into their own hands and reject the clear requirements for knowledge and consent, why will they change their attitude, especially when dealing with an incompetent patient? An independent South Australian study found that 49 per cent of doctors and nurses who said they had assisted a person to die, did so without the knowledge and consent of the person concerned.

As the Dutch Attorney‐General, Professor Remmelink found, many cases of euthanasia were certified as death by natural causes. The law will have no impact on these circumstances. Indeed, the Northern Territory law is so poorly drafted that not only are the definitions of terminal illness and depression wide‐open, a coroner has no basis to investigate any death once a certificate is signed by the doctors involved in giving the lethal injection. Despite its procedures, the Northern Territory legislation has major flaws. If the safeguards are disregarded, the only witness is dead.

Just as the law against automatic weapons won't stop possession of all automatic weapons, laws against homicide won't stop a minority of doctors from practising euthanasia. But the law does send a message, and in the case of many people, will protect them from abuse and save lives where people would have changed their minds.
Euthanasia legislation sends a powerful message to the community that the vulnerable are expendable and not valued. What we legislate to allow, we approve and encourage.
Nor is this is a debate about personal autonomy. A lethal injection is not an autonomous action, even with the use of a machine. If only one person is involved, it is not euthanasia.
Can anyone recall the death of a family member or acquaintance that effected no‐one else? As the House of Lords Committee stated:
the issue of euthanasia is one in which the interest of the individual cannot be separated from the interest of society as a whole.

With euthanasia, the patient gives up all control to the doctor. John Stuart Mill insisted that one could not in the name of freedom sell oneself into unfreedom. This is why we maintain that people cannot freely sell themselves into slavery. This is why our laws reject consent to bodily harm as a defence in a court.

Euthanasia involves quality of life judgments by the doctor about the patient. If a physically well person is suicidal, we provide them with counselling and care. Witness our response to the tragedy of youth suicide. If an ill person is suicidal, the Doctor decides that care is no longer required. In the doctor's mind, death becomes an option.

This is not to mention the pressures, subtle and otherwise, on the elderly and infirm, many of whom already feel a burden to others. This is why groups representing the disabled and the elderly have rejected pro‐euthanasia positions.
But consider the objectives of euthanasia proponents, such as Peter Singer:

We should treat human beings in accordance with their ethically relevant characteristics. . . They include consciousness, the capacity for physical, social and mental interaction with other beings, having conscious preferences for continued life, and having enjoyable experiences. Other relevant aspects depend on the relationship of the being to others, having relatives for example who will grieve over your death, or being so situated in a group that if you are killed, others will fear for their lives.

In other words, the unconscious, the incompetent and the incapable have lost some or all of the characteristics which demand the protection of the law. Even being alone, having no‐one to "grieve over your death", may be sufficient to justify intentional killing.
As the authors of the Remmelink Report [the official report by the Attorney‐General into euthanasia in the Netherlands] state:

But is it not true that once one accepts (voluntary) euthanasia and assisted suicide the principle of universality forces one to accept the termination of life without explicit request, at least in some circumstances, as well? In our view, the answer to this question must be affirmative.

Indeed, Professor Singer has extended his principle to the conscious, but handicapped infant. And the Coalition of Organisations for Voluntary Euthanasia [COVE] has, as one of its commitments, that legalised euthanasia should apply to people with disabilities even if they do not have a terminal illness, a position that Professor Baume confirmed just yesterday.

A logical consequence of this policy is the finding of the Dutch Supreme Court that a doctor could give a lethal injection to a 50 year old woman whose husband had left her and two sons had died, but who was without physical illness and who refused bereavement counselling.

Proponents of euthanasia already argue that a lethal injection can be given to a person incapable of consenting. The events of the past century reveal that once voluntary euthanasia is accepted, the language of rights will be employed to argue that those who are incapable of giving consent also have a `right'—as determined by another—to a lethal injection.

Far from enhancing autonomy, euthanasia will lead to more control over the lives of many people. This is revealed in the Dutch findings that 27 per cent of people given a lethal injection had neither expressed consent nor had knowledge of their impending death.

These are the consequences of a choice in favour of euthanasia. The discouragement of suicide is removed for certain categories of people on the judgement of others that their lives are unworthy of living because of sickness or disability. How can we establish categories of people who, if they are suicidal, are to be given a lethal injection, without devaluing all the people in these categories? What is so compassionate about telling people who feel worthless that they are better off dead?
The steps in the Northern Territory Act do not address these issues. Euthanasia makes a mockery of autonomy.

Three‐quarters of the population believe euthanasia is about turning off machines. This bill does not prevent the discontinuing of treatment, or providing patients with the most effective forms of pain relief, even if that treatment coincidentally hastens death.

The purpose of this bill is to restate the clear principle that the Legislative Assemblies have no power to make laws which permit or have the effect of permitting the form of intentional killing of another, whether conscious or unconscious, called euthanasia (which includes mercy killing) or the assisting of a person to terminate his or her life.
It restates the existing law in every state and territory, with the exception of the Northern Territory.
Some say that there is no difference between turning off a machine or refusing treatment and a lethal injection.
Many of us know of someone who has decided against another course of chemotherapy. We do not say that is the same as a lethal injection.
If a person is given a lethal injection, it is the injection that kills them. Presumably, another injection would be given if the first didn't work.
If we turn off a machine, it is the illness which leads to death. If, as has occurred in many cases, the person continues to live, we care for them. There is no intention to kill.
There is a simple test for euthanasia—that is to ask: "What would you do if the person lived?"
If you discontinue treatment and the person lives, you continue to care for them. If you provide pain relief which risks hastening death, you only provide more doses when required to relieve pain.

Intention is the cornerstone of our ethical and legal systems. A person may shoot another, but not be guilty of homicide, if the shooting was in self defence, was provoked, or was an unforeseen accident. It is the intention to kill that makes the action an offence.

At a time when health costs are escalating, the population is aging, there is a contraction of hospital beds, the community is reluctant to raise taxes, the Economic Planning Council [EPAC] and others such as Bill Hayden have discussed euthanasia in the context of the cost of health, it is naive to think that economic judgments are not being made and that pressures will intensify on the elderly. Consider also that it costs some $5—6,000 on average for palliative care for a dying patient—but just $25 for a lethal injection.

We have a conscience vote about how we respond to a person who says "I want you to end my life." A wise and prudent judgement must take account of human nature as it is. To believe that with the stroke of the Administrator's pen all people will act altruistically, is to condemn people to unconsented deaths. In the analogous situation of capital punishment, we maintain that if one innocent person is going to be killed, even after the very public and due process of the law, that's too high a price.
What we should do is to provide high quality palliative care and enact modern refusal of treatment legislation, neither of which has been done in the Northern Territory.

And we should take note that every major committee of inquiry in the world, that no parliament bar one, that the aboriginal people, the various religious groups, the world medical profession, and those representing people with disabilities have rejected euthanasia.
They have rejected it because of one unifying principle: The people who are most at risk are the most vulnerable, and a law which fails to protect vulnerable people will always be a bad law.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the Autumn sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FURTHER BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —To conclude what I was saying this morning, the mining companies are being handed $800 million on a plate at the same time as the poorer people in this country are having $953 million taken out of their pockets over three years. I want to conclude by giving a few more examples of how this works.

SPEECH.PARA: The deeming rate on bank deposits held by pensioners is to be extended to cover smaller amounts of cash that pensioners have in their bank accounts. It means that, if the banks are not paying them interest at what is called the deeming rate, they are taxed on that interest anyway. So they do not get the money, but they are taxed on it. This will recoup an extra $40 million for the government. Meanwhile, Newcrest, a big mining corporation, is to be handed $53 million through a rebate of its taxes on diesel fuel. So, while $40 million is to be taken away from the pensioners, $53 million will go across to the mining corporation.

The $67 million which is currently available for incidentals to help people get a new job, get set up in the new job and, in particular, to make sure that they make the transition from unemployment—particularly long‐term unemployment—into a job, is to be abolished by the government. Meanwhile, in a three‐year period, Mt Isa Mines has had $63 million handed to it on a platter in tax rebates. So $67 million is to be taken out of the hands of those people who are struggling to get a job—money which would help give them a bit of advantage in getting that job rather than staying unemployed—but $63 million was handed across to Mt Isa Mines—no questions asked, thank you very much. Similarly, CRA has been given $124 million over three years. But, in the coming four years, rent assistance for single people in shared accommodation is going to be cut by $110 million. The government will rip it out of the pockets of young folk in particular, simply because they are sharing accommodation with somebody else—young folk who are struggling to make ends meet and who will be down to $40 or $50 to live on—but hand it across on a platter to one giant mining company that has executives on more than a million dollars a year.

Hundreds of thousands of Australians are being denied a little bit of money to help make ends meet, while a few huge mining corporations are being handed money for something they have not done. It will essentially assist their continued hike in chief executive officers' pay lines of 12 or 13 per cent per annum. Some of them take home more than a million dollars a year. It is a pretty dastardly line of operation for this government. It should be ashamed of it. We will be voting against the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 cognately. I wish to make some comments specifically about one grossly unfair measure for elderly Australians. This relates to the matter of deeming the earnings of superannuation for people who turn 55. In commencing my remarks, I would like to quote—this is an unusual procedure—the words of the Chair of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, Senator John Watson. He is not a Labor senator, very obviously. Senator Watson provided the best summary of the magnitude of the uncertainty and instability that schedule 1 of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 has caused. Senator Watson said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a problem for people such as our witness that, at a time of life when they are really increasingly out of touch with the financial community and with colleagues et cetera who may know something about these issues, we are expecting them to take advice on pretty technical issues that all of us have trouble coming to grips with. Yet you are asking our elderly citizens to look at rearranging their affairs. They have been pushed into a position of having to make fairly complex decisions and readjust their financial affairs and their manner of living in order to access benefits.
I remind the Senate chamber that they are the words of Senator Watson when considering the evidence presented before the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on this matter.

On budget night, the Liberals announced the removal of the means test exemption on superannuation assets and rollover funds for people aged 55. In announcing this measure, the government stated that people aged 55 and over who have retired and who will have poor prospects of returning to work should use all the assets at their disposal, including superannuation assets, to provide for themselves before turning to the community for support through the social security system.

This measure will immediately and directly affect 67,000 Australians who are currently aged between 55 and the age pension age using income support payments in order to survive. The Liberals' claim, certainly initially, was that this measure will catch rorters and double-dippers.

Sadly, for the 67,000 Australians who will be affected by this measure, it is a vastly different story. Of the 67,000 Australians affected, about half are currently in receipt of a disability support pension. And of the 67,000 Australians, less than seven per cent—and I emphasise this: less than seven per cent—have over $200,000 in superannuation or rollover funds. These are not the wealthiest members of our society. For many of the 67,000 Australians affected, their only real chance of long-term security and stability is the superannuation asset or rollover fund they will have when they turn 60 or 65.

The Liberals speak of the 67,000 Australians directly affected by this measure as being effectively retired. Yet the people that I spoke to and those who provided evidence—there have been many, many hundreds of people who have written to the Labor opposition about this matter and there were at least five or six who gave direct evidence to the committee—want to work. They want to be able to provide for themselves. They do not want to rely on income support payments.

Many of the 67,000 Australians affected have been retrenched and are unable to find new employment, for a range of reasons. We all know that the work force has undergone dramatic and radical change over the last decade—dramatic structural change, technological advances and trends towards casualisation and much greater mobility—for example, contracting out. These trends are well known in the employment market.

PARA.BREAK: Demographically, what is interesting about the 67,000 people who will be affected by this measure, those in their late 50s, is that, overwhelmingly they are white men who have lost their job, usually as a result of redundan cies or retrenchments as a consequence of structural changes in our economy. It is structural unemployment. It has also been shown that, for the majority of the men retrenched or made unemployed in this age bracket, the likelihood of finding new employment is extremely low.
