SPEECH.PARA: We had some heart-rending evidence given to us by a 55‐year‐old former rail worker from Port Pirie in South Australia who cannot get another job. We had some heart-rending evidence provided by a bank employee from Launceston, in my home state of Tasmania. At the age of 55 and single, he can get another job, on occasions, but certainly not as a bank employee. He is supporting and putting his two children through university. We had the heart-rending story of an electrician who was made redundant by the Victorian Liberals. He is 55 and cannot get another job. This is fairly typical, unfortunately, of many people in this age bracket.

The cynics would suggest that this effective retiring of unemployed people at the age of 55 is a means for the Liberals to appear as though they are tackling the problem of long-term unemployment, because it will certainly reduce it by some 60,000-odd people. As I have said earlier, half of these 67,000 people, 35,000 Australians, affected by this measure, are currently on the disability support pension. These are people who are sick or disabled and therefore incapable of working. To require these people to draw down on their superannuation is a sign of a government without compassion.

I remind the Senate: where was this measure in the Liberal Party's election manifesto? Where was it in Meeting our Commitments? You can search it, but you will not find this particular harsh draconian measure on aged Australians anywhere in the Liberal Party manifesto. The government wants people who have turned 55 and who are on government benefits to retire and use their superannuation so it can claim that it has tightened the social security net and made net savings on the budget.

There are two points to be made in this context. People will have to formally retire—that is, never again seek work in excess of 10 hours a week—so they may access part or whole of their superannuation assets or rollover funds. These individuals will have to sign a statutory declaration, having turned 55, stating that they are no longer seeking work—even if they want to—and will not seek work in future so that they may access their superannuation funds. They have no alternative. They have to access their superannuation because their government benefit—be it unemployment benefit or disability pension—has been cut. Once they cease to look for work, they will no longer satisfy the activity tests for jobsearch or newstart allowance, rendering them ineligible. At this point, the only money they will have to survive on will be their superannuation.

Secondly, what will happen when, in 10 years time, these people have used a part or all of their superannuation and they are totally reliant on the provision of the age pension? Gone will be the dream of many Australians to have a comfortable and relaxed retirement and old age. They will be rendered completely dependent on the continuing provision of the age pension. Some Australians will have to live in relative poverty that has haunted—and been a great fear of—their parents and their grandparents.

Labor introduced the superannuation guarantee charge in 1992. Labor introduced universal superannuation so that all Australians would have the opportunity to have a comfortable, relaxed and secure retirement. What this government is doing is effectively delaying social security expenditure. The more people who are dependent on the age pension, the bigger the drain on the budget. By forcing people to fund their own sickness or unemployment benefits at the age of 55, the government is making all future Australian taxpayers fund the baby boomers' age pension requirements.

It was interesting that, when we took evidence from the department, it did not show the effect of requiring people to take their superannuation in part or in whole when they reached the age of 55 and what the extra costs will be in five or 10 years time when those people reach retirement age and are collecting in part or in whole a higher pension.

BREAK.PARA: As I said, the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation asked the Department of Social Security about modelling showing the effect on the budget and on national savings. The department was told the committee had not undertaken any modelling, nor had Treasury and Finance. That is, there are no figures that show how this measure will affect the budget over the longer term, and there is no modelling as to the effects of this measure on national savings.

It will undoubtedly increase costs to the budget longer term in respect of pensions, and the department admitted that. It will undoubtedly reduce national savings—again, the department admitted that. But they could give us no specific figures because they had carried out no specific modelling. Remarkably short‐sighted!

In addition, this measure will actively discourage Australians to save. The irony of this measure is that it directly discriminates against the 67,000 Australians who, over the last 10, 20 or 30 years—under both Labor and Liberal governments—have decided to forgo income, to sacrifice recurrent expenditure and to put money away in superannuation for their retirement. They were actively encouraged by both this government and the former Labor government to do so. They were told that it would be available for their retirement years. Now, when they need help to continue work or need to be cared for during sickness or disability, they are being told they will have to use their retirement savings nest egg—their superannuation—when they reach the age of 55.

PARA.BREAK: As ASFA and the Retire Investment representatives informed the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, this measure has caused massive uncertainty and instability in the general community over the purpose of a retirement savings policy. It does not just concern those people who are very close to the age of 55 or who are already 55. About 900,000 Australians are currently aged between 50 and 55. There are 1.2 million Australians aged between 45 and 50 who are now asking themselves: was it worth putting money aside—in many cases voluntarily—and sacrificing expenditure for the sake of super annuation? Again, we could get no modelling from the government on this matter.

BREAK.PARA: It is likely that over the next 10 years the figure of 67,000 people affected in part or in whole by this very harsh measure will grow to 300,000, perhaps to 350,000 or 360,000. They will be required to draw on their superannuation asset when they are 55 because they cannot access unemployment or disability benefits in part or in whole.

This measure will affect so many Australians over the next two years because of the effects of the superannuation guarantee contribution. As I said earlier, Labor introduced this measure in 1992. It is currently at six per cent, growing to nine per cent. There is the possibility—I say `possibility' because I think the government will renege on this promise—of an additional three per cent employee contribution and a three per cent government co-contribution. So the moneys in superannuation accounts over the next decade is going to rise exponentially.
Currently, members have an average of $38,000 in superannuation. I know the minister is very fond of quoting this figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —So is Jenny Macklin.

—Yes, because I gave Ms Macklin the figure. Do not laugh. When you laugh you show your contempt for elderly and ageing Australians. You do not understand this measure. Just listen, Senator Newman, and understand the effect of it.

BREAK.PARA: The level in superannuation is currently $38,000. It has doubled over the last five or six years because of the effect of the superannuation guarantee charge. It will double over the next five years. The average, Minister, will be in the $70,000s over the next five years. It will double again five years later. The average amount in superannuation accounts within a decade will be approaching $100,000. That is why it will not be 67,000 people who will be affected by this very nasty attack on superannuation; it will be the hundreds of thousands, Minister. You can laugh.
Why have you not done the modelling on this? Why have you not worked out how many elderly and ageing Australians will be hit by this very harsh measure?

TALK.START.PARA: —Getting it back to what it was—treating all savings the same.

—That is another favourite line of yours, Minister: treating all savings the same. In making that declaration, you show your ignorance of, and your failure to fundamentally understand, the nature of superannuation. It is a different form of asset from other forms of saving, whether it be in a house, in shares, in stocks or in some other form of investment.

BREAK.PARA: It has to be recognised, Minister—particularly by you and the government—that superannuation is long-term saving for retirement. That is what it is specifically meant for. That is what your government and our government encouraged superannuation for—retirement. It is not something people should be forced to live on, in part or whole, when they reach the age of 55.

TALK.START.PARA: —Effectively, compulsory retirement.

—As I said earlier, it is effectively compulsory retirement for many of those unfortunate Australians who reach the age of 55 and who regrettably cannot find alternative employment. Unfortunately, for people who reach that age, the opportunities for further employment are much more limited than those for the rest of the community. This money in superannuation will double in the next five years, and by the year 2010 most Australians will have a superannuation asset of between $50,000 and $70,000. So the average is increasing very dramatically.

BREAK.PARA: Contrary to the rhetoric of the minister, the money an individual accrues in superannuation is not a great deal. It is well recognised in the industry that, currently, an asset of $100,000—which the minister asserts is a lot of money—will buy an income stream, a pension or an annuity of approximately $6,500 to $7,000 a year. Seen in that context, $100,000 is not a great deal of money.

That is an income stream of less than the current age pension of $8,300. Superannuation of $100,000 will buy a pension of between $6,500 and $7,000 a year—less than the current age pension—yet there will be many thousands of people in the Australian community, many ageing and elderly Australians, who will be hit by this measure and who have less than $100,000.

In response to this particularly vicious and harsh measure against elderly Australians, we have had more communication from individual Australians concerned about the possibility of this measure than on any other measure in the budget. This is unsolicited correspondence and it does not take the typical campaign form that we often get in response to budget measures.

I am proud to say that Labor continued to actively encourage people to put money into superannuation. I am proud to say that Labor introduced national superannuation for all Australians, not just for those very few who were fortunate enough to have it prior to 1983; that is, less than four in 10 of the Australian work force. Now, some 92 or 93 per cent of Australians have superannuation. I am proud to say on behalf of the Labor Party that people's superannuation is growing rapidly. I am proud to say on behalf of the Australian Labor Party that we will oppose this measure. We will be moving two fundamental amendments to this particular measure when we get to the committee stage.

This measure is a nasty, vicious attack on elderly Australians, not just the 67,000—the railway worker, the teacher, the electrician and the bank clerk—who have lost their jobs and have little prospect of finding alternative employment, but also the hundreds of thousands of elderly and ageing Australians who will be affected. This comes from an uncaring government and was contained nowhere in their election manifesto. I am proud to say that Labor will be fighting hard against this in order to minimise its effect and, hopefully, defeat it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Schedule 13 of this bill revises the disability impairment tables used in assessing a person's eligibility for the disability support pension. Impairment tables were first introduced by the ALP in the late 1980s to stem the growth in the number of people claiming the invalid pension and long-term sickness allowances.

BREAK.PARA: The introduction of these tables was one of the first steps in a very strong push to move people with disabilities off income support and into the work force. This was also a driving force behind the ALP's decision to replace the invalid pension with the disability support pension and its associated policies in 1991 and it is one of the driving forces behind the revised disability impairment tables that we are considering today.

To qualify for a DSP, a person must meet three basic criteria. First, they must have a physical, intellectual or psychological impairment. Secondly, that impairment must be assessed at the rate of 20 per cent or more under the current impairment tables. Thirdly, their inability to work must be a continuing one. These criteria will not change under the new legislation, but the revised impairment tables would make it harder for people to qualify for the DSP.

The reason these new impairment tables will make eligibility harder is that they lower the ratings attached to many impairments and they do not allow the department to take into account non-medical factors which might impact on an individual's work related abilities. As a result, many people who currently receive the DSP will be thrown off this benefit if these tables are adopted. They will also become ineligible for the many programs which are specifically designed to help them.

An estimated 34,000 people will lose their eligibility for DSP if these tables are adopted, and a further 5,000 people a year who would previously have been eligible will no longer qualify. These people will have to move over to other forms of income support, principally newstart. They will have to look for work and they will have to meet the relevant activity test, with any breach of this activity test being punishable by the withdrawal of income support for extended periods of time. Clearly, schedule 13 of this bill has the potential to leave many people with disabilities without any form of income at all.

The Democrats believe that there are a number of problems with this bill. These include the fact that once people are deemed ineligible for the DSP they will have reduced access to employment programs specifically designed to help them. People who are currently receiving the DSP will be forced to compete with 8.7 per cent of unemployed Australians for jobs which we know do not exist. Meeting the activity tests applicable to newstart and other benefits may be very difficult for some people with disabilities, particularly those with intellectual disabilities and mental illness. People who breach the activity test associated with newstart will be left for extended periods without any income and no real support to help them get a job.

The Democrats simply cannot see how throwing people with disabilities off income support and other programs specifically designed to assist them can be either a positive or a desirable thing to do. I am not saying that there is not a very real place for encouraging and assisting people with disabilities to enter or re-enter the work force if that is what they are reasonably able to do, nor am I saying that people should be able to get the DSP without having to meet some kind of criteria, but there is a need for policies and mechanisms which ensure that people are not able to abuse the system in this area. However, when it comes to addressing the needs of people with disabilities, there is also a need to fully recognise the additional burdens that many of these people face.

Let us be brutally frank here: people with disabilities are still amongst the most disadvantaged groups of people in Australia today. That is because they face isolation and discrimination which comes from public ignorance and misunderstanding, and it is because there has been an acute reticence on the part of state and federal governments in this country to take the issues which affect them very seriously.

These revised impairment tables have more to do, I think, with the bottom line than with creating a better system for people with disabilities. As far as I am concerned, that is nothing less than deplorable. The tables contained in schedule 13 of the bill measure the impact of the person's impairments on their ability to work from a purely medical and, I believe, completely isolated perspective.

One of the major flaws with these new tables is that they do not take into account the wider factors which may exacerbate a disabled person's work related abilities. This is in stark contrast to the disability impairment tables introduced in the late 1980s which were based on the concept of a whole person approach. A person's eligibility for the pension was determined by adding together a number of factors which included their disability, their age, their previous work experience, their ability to speak English and the availability of the type of work a person with those characteristics might reasonably be able to perform. Unfortunately, this is no longer the case. Let me remind the Senate that the Democrats opposed the ALP when they moved to cut back on these additional factors as well.

We do not believe that the revised disability impairment tables are acceptable in their current form. Nor do we believe that in their current form they will do anything to improve the lives of people with disabilities. We believe the adoption of these tables would leave many people with disabilities a great deal worse off. As a consequence, we will be moving a series of amendments to this section of the bill which we think will go a long way towards rectifying some of the most glaring shortfalls of the bill.

The bill itself includes the artificially low impairment ratings designed to get as many people as possible off the DSP, the lack of recognition of the greater effects caused by multiple impairments, the absence of a table to assess chronic pain and fatigue based illness. Our amendments were put together with the help of people who are experienced in the disability area so that they would reflect the real needs and experiences of people with disabilities.

In conclusion, I would like to stress that the Democrats have very real concerns about the effect that these impairment tables will have on the lives of people with disabilities. I urge all those senators who share this concern about the plight of disabled people and the effect of the revised tables to support our amendments to this section of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Bill deals with mainly two issues. One is the government's decision to include superannuation entitlements for the purposes of social security income and assets tests where a person is between the ages of 55 and 65. This was dealt with quite extensively by Senator Sherry and I do not intend to deal with it any further. The second item that is contained in the bill is a reduction in the maximum rate of rent assistance payable to single people sharing accommodation. I would like to speak in detail about this matter as to date we have not dealt with it, except in a fairly minimal way.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 2 of the bill deals with the maximum rent assistance which is available for single people in shared accommodation. The bill reduces the rent assistance available for single people sharing accommodation by a third of the maximum rate that is normally applied. Within the proposed new subsection 5A(1), the definition of a person who is single is: someone who is not a couple, has no dependent children and who shares with one or more people at least one major accommodation area, for example, a bathroom, kitchen or bedroom.

There have been a number of exclusions made, in particular, those people who are residing in a boarding house and are therefore under licence. But this is limited to a situation where the person also includes the provision of food or meals with their accommodation. This sort of situation is quite unusual, quite rare, in the modern situation.

This bill, once again, demonstrates that this budget is a budget of deceit and a budget of broken promises. The repetition of this issue might seem tedious but the fact is that each of the budget bills that come before us illustrates that the basis upon which this government was elected is false in that they have no intention of keeping a large number of the commitments they made when they were actually seeking the support of the community during the last election campaign.
The coalition's social security policy A social security safety net that was issued in February 1996, not very long ago in time but a long way in terms of the intention of this government, stated:
The Coalition recognises the vital role of the payment [rent assistance] in reducing after housing poverty. A Coalition government is committed to maintaining the real value of rent assistance.

Nothing in there about reduction on any basis whether sharing or not. Despite the coalition's promise, this bill cuts rent assistance to about 80,000 single people who share accommodation. This will save the government $118 million over four years.

What is the government's reasoning behind this issue? The government believes its measure ensures greater equity in rent assistance between couples and single people sharing. It believes economies of scale means a person living in shared accommodation will have reduced costs and this should affect the amount of rent assistance a person receives. But this logic is inherently flawed. It misses the entire point of what rent assistance is about.

Rent assistance is not about buying food. It is not about assistance with school books or the general expenses of life. Rent assistance is what it clearly states: it is about assistance with paying rent. Existing arrangements already take into account economies of scale. Currently, eligibility criteria ensure that where enough people are sharing a house and the rent for each person drops below a designated level rent assistance is not payable.

The Tenants Union of Queensland said in its submission that single people sharing accommodation will still pay a minimum of 30 per cent of their income on rent before they receive any assistance. If rent payable drops below this level, then they no longer eligible for rent assistance. The concept of economies of scale where people will share additional costs is presumptuous about what share household living is about. The Tenants Union further noted that couples will share a range of household expenses but people in a share household who are not couples, who are not intimately involved, often cover their own individual expenses.

PARA.BREAK: The Housing Assistance Service also remarked in its submission that share house holds are not usually happily bonded environments, particularly when they live in adverse economic circumstances, where each of them is not very well off as they often rely only on social security.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Pensioners' and Superannuants Federation said in its submission to the committee that older renters are very serious about keeping their affairs private, and they will often not share expenses and therefore achieve any sort of economy of scale. The maximum rent assistance a couple can get is $70.40, and for a single person it is $74.60 a fortnight. A single person must pay $71.40 in rent before he or she is eligible for rent assistance, and a couple must pay a minimum of $116.20.

A couple occupies one bedroom and a single person occupies one bedroom. The amount of rent is therefore not reduced in proportion to the number of people sharing a household, as rents go up with the number of bedrooms within the house. Only the other living costs are reduced if they are reduced at all by sharing. A single person living alone and paying more than $68.90 a week can get more rent assistance than a person who pays the same amount but lives with other people. Is that fair? What this government is doing with the stated objective of resolving one inequity is creating another glaring inequity.

Who are the people most affected? The tragedy is that young people and pensioners are those people who are most affected by this mean‐spirited change to rent assistance. It is very hard to find single accommodation. There are very few one bedroom flats or similar accommodation in cities, particularly large cities such as Melbourne and Sydney. The rental market is simply not geared towards providing this sort of accommodation. Young people, as I have said, will be most hurt by this situation, as 65 per cent of 15‐ to 19‐year‐olds that live away from home live in shared accommodation. So this is another blow by this government to the young people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't get the same pensioner rates.
—As Senator West has pointed out, they are not only hit harder by this particular move but also receive lower benefits through social security anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: Young people are mostly likely to be on lower incomes, and they are also most likely to be newly arrived in the work force. They may be seeking employment in these difficult times or they may still be students. But the end result is that they are some of the poorest paid members of our community, and they are a group that certainly are at risk of suffering the most under these changes. As I have said, young people are most likely to live in share accommodation because of the difficulty with meeting rental costs with their very limited income, whether they are working or not.

The National Youth Coalition for Housing estimates that unemployed young people under the age of 18 sharing accommodation in Sydney will be left with just over $47 per week and those between 18 and 20 will be left with just under $60 to meet all their living costs once they have paid their rent. I do not think many people in this chamber would be very happy about paying for their food, clothing, toiletries, general groceries and maybe attempting to put something into their piggy bank so they can improve their circumstance in the future on $60 per week.

Rents in Sydney are so high that sharing accommodation is nearly always the only alternative available for young people. The National Youth Coalition for Housing points out that in Adelaide, where rents are lower, people will not be affected as much by this measure. So the bill has a double whammy for young people seeking work. It creates a situation where they may have to move from cheaper accommodation where they are sharing to an area outside the main centres of the city. They may have to move to areas where support mechanisms are fewer, where transport is less available, where services are fewer and where in most cases job opportunities are fewer.

As we all know, under the new activity test, if a young person were to move from the inner city where jobs are more available to the outer suburbs of Sydney, they would be hit by the new changes to the social security system in that it is a breach of activity test to move from a higher employment area to a lower employment area. So, in trying to escape the effects of rent assistance, they will be hit by the new penalties being imposed by this government as well. It is six weeks on the first occasion and 13 weeks for subsequent breaches under this government's new regime.

As I have said, the second group most affected are pensioners. A 1995 report by National Shelter into housing costs found that women over the age of 60 spend nearly 40 per cent of their income on rent. The Australian Council of Social Service says that this measure may provide an incentive for people such as the frail, the elderly or disabled to continue to live alone, particularly in circumstances where they really should not, where they would be better off sharing with others. So the end result is that hundreds of people currently sharing accommodation will suddenly face a one-third drop in their rent assistance.

The impact on many people's sharing will be dramatic. As I said, many will be forced to move into areas where there is less employment or where rents for individual homes are higher and infrastructure is poorer. The Department of Social Security will also have extensive paperwork and a nightmare in collecting detailed information. There will be more than they have ever had before. They will have to collect data not just on people's income and assets but on the more intimate details of their lives. They will need to know where people are living, what sort of homes they are in and exactly what portions of the house they share, be it bathrooms, kitchens or a different room. The department will need to ask these questions to comply with this new legislation. People will have to fill out quite a large number of new forms to make sure that recipients are entitled to the amount of rental assistance they are claiming. It means more forms and requests for personal information.

The department admitted in the hearing of the Senate Community Affairs Committee that it currently has very little information about sharers. They do not even know who shares and who does not. In light of that admission, I was a bit surprised to learn that such an accurate prediction has been made about the savings that will be achieved by this measure, and yet the department and this government are quite unaware of the extent of the impact of this change.

In conclusion, I am continuously surprised by this government's failure to appreciate the damage that they are doing to pensioners and young people in this community. When we were in government and this present government was in opposition, I was quite well aware of the difference in principle and policy between the two parties. However, I must confess that I was not aware of the extent of the harshness that would be visited on people in our community, especially those whom this government mouths platitudes about protecting, such as the elderly and the young. It is extraordinarily sad. I hope during the Christmas cheer which those opposite will experience overseas and here that they will examine their conscience and reconsider.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to address these two bills, particularly the rent assistance legislation. Before moving to it, I want to highlight two other items that are being included in this legislation. One is the abolition of the earnings credit scheme. This scheme was introduced not a great number of years ago to encourage people to take part-time work or casual work. It offered them a buffer to protect them from sudden changes of income that they would experience when finishing temporary and casual work, such as itinerant fruit picking. This is now gone and it will impact upon people.

SPEECH.PARA: The other item is amendments relating to debt recovery. People will now be forced to repay debts that they may owe the department even when it is the department's fault that overpayments have been made. People are going to be penalised not because they have made a mistake but because the department has made a mistake. It is one of the most cruel, callous, heartless and uncaring things that you could possibly think of.

One case that has just come to my attention involves a single income family with two children. After the birth of the first child and the taking up of a parenting allowance, there was the sale of a small amount of land. The department was notified by fax. The parents must have been in contact with the department to have had the name of the person to provide the information to and the fax number. But they made a mistake; they did not keep the slip from the fax machine confirming that the material had been sent. They are now up for quite significant arrears. I assure the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) that she will be shortly hearing about this case.

I want to deal with the rent assistance legislation. I dealt with this in a fair degree of detail in estimates, endeavouring, as Senator Neal pointed out, to get some facts and figures on the table. I wanted to find out the number of people who will be affected by this. I wanted a breakdown of the types of people, the situations in which they were living and how they would be affected. I am sorry, afraid and saddened that the department could not give me that information. They do not know how many people with disabilities in shared accommodation and in receipt of rent assistance will be affected. They do not know how many people in boarding and lodging places in the inner city, particularly in the city I am aware of, will be affected. It seems very sloppy that the government can bring in legislation and say in the budget and the estimates how much they think they will save, yet when you actually peel away the layers to find out why they think that, you do not discover it and it is not there.

I will quote one letter that appeared in the carers newspaper from the New South Wales division of the Carers' Association. It is a story of a mother and daughter. The daughter has worked for many years of her life and is now in receipt of a carers pension. The mother is an age pension recipient. They both get rent assistance because they are renting a two bedroom unit. You do not rent anywhere in Sydney and have much change left over on that income. Rents in Sydney are very high, despite what the national averages might be. The averages are distorted as far as the Sydney rents are concerned. You cannot say there are any similarities.

BREAK.PARA: This couple are in a two‐bedroom unit and they are both adults. Unless somewhere along the line the people involved, I and everybody else have been reading incorrectly, this mother and daughter—the daughter is on a carers pension to look after her mother—will have their rent assistance cut. Before anybody starts saying that they are not paying sufficient rent to get the maximum rate, let me say that they are paying sufficiently high rates of rent to be in receipt of the maximum amount of rent assistance. As the story goes, they are. I suggest that you look at these cases.

I also want to know what will happen to people who live in those grotty, awful boarding houses in inner city Sydney. They might be called boarding and lodging houses, but the tenants do not get any food there. The only things that move on the benches in these places are cockroaches. The tenants are each paying over $100 per week in rent. They are sharing the most squalid kitchens or kitchenettes and bathrooms.

From my understanding of this legislation, and from what I have been told previously, these people are affected as well because there is no meal component to the moneys they are paying out and they are sharing a kitchen or a bathroom. From my reading of this, that makes them subject to the cut to rent assistance. Many of these people are elderly, aged and frail. They may be people with disabilities, both physical and emotional or psychiatric. You cannot tell me the number of people involved in that. I ask you to talk to St Vincent de Paul, the Smith Family, the Brotherhood of St Laurence and other organisations to see what the numbers are and to see what their comments are, because they are servicing their needs, along with the community health centres in the area. I will bet nobody has been to have any consultations or discussions with them.

I also asked about the situation for people with disabilities living in shared accommodation. We have had this one shoved and pushed from pillar to post. We have had it dismissed because the states should be responsible for the accommodation needs of people with disabilities. Let me tell you that there are many people with disabilities out living in shared supported accommodation type arrangements who are in the private rental market. The department and minister should not tell me that they are boarding and lodging, and therefore they will be caught in the net because there is a boarding, a meal, component. When these people have supervision for 10 hours a week in their accommodation and they are on individual training programs and part of that program is to teach them how to be independent in their own home, to be able to cook their own meals, to be able to buy their own food, which is all part of their independent training program, do not tell me that is a board component. I have a lot more questions to ask about that, because I do not think the department and the minister have looked at the issues. I do not think they have identified the number of people who are going to be affected or where those people are.

These are people who cannot just take any accommodation. They have to take accommodation that may be able to cover and help them with their physical needs, if they have physical disability. In a country area that I am aware of, public transport services are inadequate, so they have to be living in accommodation that is in the central area of the town or the city. Because there is no public transport system, they have to be somewhere where they can walk to their employment. These are the sorts of issues and cases that should have been thought through before this legislation was introduced.

At estimates, I asked for and got a promise from the minister and the departmental secretary that there would be negotiations, discussions and consultations held with the organisations which provide assistance for people with disabilities. For the clients involved in this, it takes some time for their individual training programs to be amended, for their training schemes to be implemented and for them to start to learn to live on a lesser income.

I actually had a meeting with delegates from ACROD last week and I asked about this issue. The only reason ACROD has had any discussions with the department about this issue is because ACROD initiated it. I am still waiting for the minister to initiate discussions and consultations with these organisations. The organisations themselves have had to initiate the involvement and the search for information. These are just some of the issues that I think need to be taken into consideration.

The other issue that relates to accommodation is that people on low incomes do not have any discretionary funds. They do not have the ability or the wherewithal to save enough for the bonds if they want to move. That is why they are forced into these grotty flatettes. That is why they search for accommodation that is within their means and is cheap. With some of the changes to this legislation, you are actually going to be forcing these people to stay in higher costing accommodation, because the cheaper accommodation is probably where there are no jobs. They are really caught in a cleft stick. They can go hungry and stay there and get a benefit—maybe get a benefit—or they can move somewhere to accommodation that they have more chance of affording, but they will lose their benefit.

This is the most heartless, uncaring government that we have seen in some considerable time. This is blaming those people who cannot afford the basic essentials of life. This is discriminating. It is callous and cruel. This is a government that said they were for everybody. Let me tell you, they are not for a whole lot of people in this world. I think it is a shame upon them. I am totally opposed to this legislation and I fully support the amendments that we moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated into Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

Madam president, in the lead up to the March election, the now Prime Minister made a lot of noise about governing for all. We have now had nine months of seeing what this government means by governing for all.
These bills like so many before them, including the Workplace Relations Bill, do not represent government for all. They demonstrate the worst type of hypocrisy.
This government is not there for the old, the sick, young people, women, indigenous Australians, workers and it certainly isn't there for the unemployed of this country.
Of all the losers from the Howard budget, none have been more hard hit than recipients under the social security system.
The social security system, developed and continuously refined and focused, under Labor governments was not about welfare. It was no about handouts. It was about a social safety net.

This social safety net is being attacked and I don't think its an exaggeration to say that these bills, like others before them, are part of an ideological drive similar to that of Ronald Reagan in the United States of America and Margaret Thatcher in Britain.

With the dismantling of the Commonwealth Employment Service, thousands upon thousands of Australians will no longer have access to labour market assistance services. Thousands of other Australians will be adversely affected by the impact of these changes.
Take for example the abolition of the minimum rate of payment to under 18 year old sickness allowance, Newstart allowance and Youth Training allowance recipients

The youth training allowance is currently means tested on parent's income, with a minimum rate of payment of sixty-five dollars and seventy-five cents per fortnight if the parent earns over the cut-off.
The abolition will mean reduction or complete loss of this payment for 5,500 young people

This is clearly premature, given the government's planned introduction of a youth allowance by January 1998—a youth allowance which will merge all existing payments to young people aged sixteen to twenty years and students under 25 years abolishing the minimum rate to under 18 year olds at this point in time could simply be a lever to extend that abolition of minimum rates to all recipients of youth allowance.

Other changes include amendments to tighten activity test administration and simplify the penalty periods that apply to Newstart allowance and Youth Training allowance we have heard much from senator newman about her efforts-to stop rorting within the social security system.

The anti-fraud mechanisms she praises so highly are in fact those introduced by Labor. Any increase in sums recovered simply reflects the re-deployment of staff from service delivery to debt collection.
The Labor position has always been one of ensuring benefits go to the people who need them.
This has been accomplished by tight focussing of program delivery—not through throwing up hurdles to people making it more and more difficult for them to remain eligible for benefits.
The tightening of definition of `unsuitable work' will inevitably put jobseekers in an untenable position.
It is currently okay for a person to retain benefits after refusing a job which is considered `unsuitable'.
The new meaning of unsuitable work is an extreme one—it is much, much tighter

Someone can currently apply for a job but not have the appropriate training or qualifications. This then is considered, quite rightly, `unsuitable work'. The jobseeker can refuse the job and retain benefit.
Now they have to show that they have tried to negotiate appropriate training with the prospective employer.
Failure to do so will be defined as a breach and that person loses benefits for six weeks for the first `offence' (and I use the term deliberately) and 13 weeks for a second `offence'.
This puts the onus straight on to the jobseeker. They need knowledge about training and they need to be able to effectively negotiate with their prospective employer.
Up until now, people have been able to refuse work on occupational health and safety grounds.
Now they have to show they have tried to negotiate occupational health and safety changes with the prospective employer or else they lose their benefits.
May I remind Senators that the loss of benefit means the loss of family income. Saint Vincent de Paul will be very busy.
Once again this puts the onus on the jobseeker to have the skills and knowledge to negotiate occupational health and safety changes with the prospective employer or else they lose their benefits.
Up until now, people have been able to refuse work due to family and personal considerations.
For example a proffered job may require a person to work hours from 3.00am to 1.00pm and entail an hour of travel.
This is no longer valid—and is therefore seen as a refusal to accept a job—therefore a breach.
All the above has implications in light of the Workplace Relations Bill and the `sign before you start' considerations.
The `unsuitable work' provision changes also mean that a person could be expected to move if a job becomes available but it is at a distance and too far to commute.
The exceptions apply but they are very specific and many people would not qualify for an exemption. Refusal to move would constitute a breach.
Allow me to mention here the infamous dole diary. What an unmitigated failure this has been.

Dole diaries do not require legislative change and so do not rate a mention in the legislation. However, failure to complete the diary properly constitutes an activity test breach and is another example of this government's intention to balance the books by eroding the social safety net.
This is an added hurdle for a jobseeker to comply with and it is therefore easier for the jobseeker to breach and have the wrath of the department descend.

It is interesting to note that breaches as a result of dole diary errors are being recorded using the same computer codes as other compliance measures—DC, DE, and DP. There is no mechanism to tease out the effectiveness of the dole diary as a compliance measure.
I will be interested to see in future months how the government will try to show the effectiveness of this measure when the data is not being specifically collected.

The bill also changes the non-payment period for activity test breaches to 6 weeks for the first breach and 13 weeks for each subsequent breach. This will leave people with no means of support for 6 weeks and then 3 months if they breach again.
I wonder if we will see the springing up of charity bins in supermarkets around this country as has been the case in New Zealand.

Let there be no doubt that the huge increase in the number of people thrown off benefit that this Bill will precipitate cannot and will not be absorbed by existing charities. They simply do not have the resources.
Extension of the penalties for breaching will severely disadvantage and impoverish one of the most vulnerable groups in our community.
Then we have the amendments to the provisions relating to unemployment due to industrial action.

This is a deliberate attempt to frighten people off striking. Currently if a person is unemployed at the end of a period of industrial action, then that person is entitled to go on to unemployment benefits.
Now, that same person must wait 6 weeks before becoming eligible.
This bill tries to equate striking and not returning to work for whatever reason, with voluntarily quitting a job.
A strike by members of one union may result in full workplace closure. All workers thus effected cannot claim benefits for 6 weeks after the action is completed.
The employer may choose to use strike action as an excuse to close down the business. All the workers automatically become ineligible for benefits.

The savings anticipated from the above are huge. (Three hundred and seventy-seven point three million dollars over four years). So it is clear that many people will suffer with payments being cut or withheld.
There are certain measures in this bill that show that this government is not serious about getting people back to work.
One such measure is the intention to abolish the earnings credit scheme.
The earnings credit scheme actually encourages people to get back to work

It allows pensioners and other allowees to take up temporary or casual work without affecting their level of payment. Pensioners can accrue an earnings credit of up to $1,050 or $2,100 for couples combined to offset earnings from employment before their payments are cut.
The government said prior to the election:
People who are unemployed should be given every incentive to work if a person is not able to find fulltime work, he or she may be able to find part-time work."
The government also said:
"The earnings credit scheme will be retained by a Coalition government".
Yet another broken promise.
People may well be put off accepting casual or temporary employment as it becomes available.
This will have the effect of further distancing those people from the culture of work—a very negative outcome of a stupid decision.
This bill also seeks to abolish the employment entry payment and modify the education entry payment.
Let me remind the senate of the purpose of each of these measures.

When a social security recipient enters work or commences study, considerable expense is involved. Most people who have had a period of unemployment have depleted or no savings. The clothes needed to start work, the childcare arrangements necessary and the book, fees and other costs involved with commencing study impose a burden, a burden made considerably heavier by the planned changes to HECS and childcare.

These measures recognised those difficulties and gave some assistance. We in the Labor Party believe these and other measures go some way towards removing the barriers to employment and education experienced by social security recipients.
One of the most insensitive measures introduced by this bill is the limitation of the payment of child disability allowance to 3 months before a claim is made.

Basically this government is saying, if you have a child with a disability then you should know of your eligibility for assistance and apply for that assistance within 3 months. Through the Senate estimates process it was shown that over 75 percent of claims for child disability allowance involve arrears of over three months. This amounts to over 11,000 people in any one year.
Eleven-thousand people who have a disabled child, who have the expense and the worry of arranging appropriate care, modifying their homes and their lifestyles to care for their disabled child.
It may well be that months or even years could pass before the parents become aware of the existence of this payment.
What is the policy imperative for denying these people arrears on this payment—a small compensation and acknowledgment of the difficulties they face.

This measure is callous and completely lacking in compassion. Objections to the proposed amendment to the treatment of lump sum compensation payments are perhaps best expressed by the Australian Council of Social Service. The bill also proposes to change the divisor used to calculate the compensation preclusion period where a person receives a lump-sum compensation payment.
It can be assumed that the current devisor (all persons average weekly earnings—$564.60 a week) was chosen as it reflects average income and thus the average weekly loss a person has experienced.
There appears to be no rationale behind the decision to change to the single pension cut out point ($397.00 a week).

This will increase by around one third, the period of time a person who receives a lump-sum compensation payment is not entitled to social security and must therefore live off their lump-sum, a large part of which is intended to cover the additional costs associated with their injury.
This measure will hit injured workers and their families very severely.
And what will this mean-spirited change save?—Fifty eight and a half million over four years. And what of the amendment to the application of the below threshold deeming rate?
This amendment will affect around seven hundred and twenty-one thousand pensioners and sixty thousand allowees for the saving of about forty million over four years.
Currently bank accounts with balances below the. Threshold of two thousand dollars for singles and four thousand for couples are exempt from deeming.
We are not talking `share portfolios' here—just a little money in the bank.
This measure means all bank accounts, regardless of how low the balance is, will be deemed as having earned five percent interest.
Over half the financial institutions in this country do not even have access accounts which pay this rate.
As this measure is reliant on pensioners having access to this type of account, the measure shows itself to be unworkable.

There are serious difficulties associated with the changes to debt recovery. Basically the amendment increases overpayment raising and debt recovery, increases the recovery of debts from non-customer debtors and re-defines the meaning of recoverable debts.
It is the area of the redefinition of recoverable debts that the real difficulties arise.
Unrecoverable debts currently arise when a person is overpaid due to the fault of the Department of Social Security.
This applies whether or not the person realises they are being overpaid or whether or not they can afford to pay the money.
The Australian Council for Social Service also has expressed serious reservations about amendments to debt recovery, particularly debts caused by departmental error.
The overall effect of these changes is to make every over-payment a debt even if the customer did everything required and the Department of Social Security failed to act on the information provided.
This will effectively remove any accountability the department has to clients to ensure that it takes action on advice from customers quickly to prevent over-payments."
Labor considered introducing a similar measure in 1994. The then opposition opposed the legislation on the grounds of departmental efficiency.
I would like to read quite a lengthy quote from the then shadow minister Mr Ruddock, made on March 1, 1994

"It seems to me that the difficulty with this matter is that, if this backdating is allowed to the date at which the person was no longer qualified, a certain laxity is allowed to develop in the administration. It means that nobody has to be conscious that there is a penalty that the department suffers, the revenue suffers if somebody is not making the decision that the person is no longer payable. It means that people might even be encouraged in the view that they can let the matter go on and not draw it to attention in a situation in which there may be pressure to do other work, for instance."
Now the government wants to introduce measures that it considered unworkable in the recent past.
The hypocrisy is breath-taking.
The bill also introduces changes to the act which alter the social security entitlements advance payment scheme.

This scheme has been very successful in allowing social security recipients ride through periods of unexpected expense. A classic situation is the one in which someone needs to buy clothes to attend job interviews.
Senator Alston would have us believe otherwise, but I don't believe everyone has the money to buy shares let alone the necessities of life.
The bill wants to restrict the uses of advances, limit them to one per year, reduce the amount of advances and standardise recovery to six months.
Restricting the availability of advances further restricts the activities of social security recipients.
The money is repaid—so what is the problem?

One of the worse measures introduced in these bills, one which will have a profound impact on the lives of members of the community over the age of fifty‐five is the decision to include superannuation rollover assets tests for those aged between 55 and age pension age who have been unemployed for more than 9 months this measure in its current form will affect the lives of sixty-seven thousand Australians and would result in profound inequity.
Given the aging population the measure in its current form could potentially affect three hundred and sixty thousand people. Over a third of a million Australians will be adversely affected.
People are being asked to use up the funds they have saved throughout their working lives to supplement their old age before they can access social security assistance.
This will actively encourage people to withdraw from superannuation schemes and reduce the level of national savings.

Finally I wish to refer to a measure which will cause severe problems for many single people living in shared accommodation. That is the proposed cuts to the maximum rate of rent assistance by a third for single people sharing accommodation.
These are people who already experience high levels of poverty. Not a share between them. It will particularly affect those people living in high rent areas.

The current rules for determining rental assistance are based on the proportion of rent they pay. This is fair and reasonable. This bill seeks to further restrict access to rental assistance for some of the most needy in our community.

The combined effect of the measures involved in both of these social security legislation amendment bills is a massive erosion of the social safety net that Australia can rightly be proud. We believe in dignity and quality of life for all Australians, not just for a fortunate few.
These bills expose the mean‐spirited nature of the government of today. The battlers will not thank them and will remember this government at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated into Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
I rise to speak on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and other Measures) Bill 1996.

This bill is an attack on the social welfare system—It is predicated on the misconception that recipients of social security benefits are there to rip off the system. It presumes that people on benefit are fraudulent—are lazy and do not deserve to receive a benefit.
It completely ignores the fact that people are not on benefit because it is a good lurk. They are not there because they don't want to work.
They are there because they cannot find work or are too ill to support themselves and to support their families.
`If the price of progress is human misery, its not progress. If change makes people worse off, its not reform'
These are the words of The Prime Minister in an address to the Australian Council of Social Services in Sydney on 13 October 1995.
And yet what we see in this bill is an attack on recipients of welfare. There is no doubt that it will make people worse off. By the Prime Ministers own admission it is not reform.

The first area of this bill I wish to address is contained within SCHEDULE 5 PART 1 and it deals with the proposed `Employer Contact Certificate'. This certificate is designed to act as proof that a person has applied for a position. It is to be signed by the employer. These forms must be completed and submitted to the DSS before a first payment can be received.
If the jobseeker fails to have this form signed then they could be deemed to have failed the activity test and incur a penalty for such a breach

This obviously ignores the difficulty a jobseeker might have in getting prospective employers to sign forms. Some employers receive hundreds of applications for jobs—does the government think that employers will then sit back and complete these forms for every applicant? There is no requirement on them to do so. In fact for small business it would be deemed an unnecessary bureaucratic step which would impede rather than assist them.
I fail to see how the introduction of such certificates will actually assist a jobseeker to find employment?.

It appears that it will only lead to a far more complex paper trail which will discourage many jobseekers and see many people left incomeless whilst they are being penalised for failing a system that was designed to cause them to fail.
I now turn to SCHEDULE 5 PART 2.
This amendment deals with the ability of a job seeker to refuse to take up unsuitable work. The government intends to move the goal posts in terms of unsuitable work.
The onus will now be upon the jobseeker to prove that the offer of work was unsuitable and to establish that they tried to resolve issues that make the work unsuitable.
`That they tried to resolve issues that make the work unsuitable.'

What if the reason the work was unsuitable was because the work offered was unsafe? What possible chance has a person applying for a job got to resolve an issue that the employer has not resolved already?
And how do you expect that the jobseeker would be able to prove that?
Whose word will the government take?
An employer in breach of occupational health and safety legislation is hardly going to contact the DSS to support the jobseekers claim that that was the case.
"Oh sure the jobseeker turned down the job because I refuse to put safety guards up.'
What is the likelihood of employers admitting that they are breaching legislation?
The same case would apply if the employer refused to provide training.
What you will have is the jobseekers word against the employers.
What then constitutes a definition of proof?
It is an unreasonable expectation on jobseekers who may already have self esteem issues to resolve.
It works on the false premise that they are on an equal power relationship with the employer.
It negates the individuals rights to choice based on family or health reasons.
Individuals may be forced into taking positions which are dangerous or have unfair working conditions.

John Howard promised the people of Australia that no one would be forced to accept an individual contract that was unfair. By this measure he is giving people on benefits no option but to accept an unfair contract on the basis that his Social Security legislation will fine them if they do not.
Sure you do not have to take the job—but don't expect to remain on benefit if you don't.
I ask Senators opposite—what kind of a choice is that?
The proposed amendments in SCHEDULE 5 PART 3 seek to increase the penalties for breaches of activity tests.
The first breach of the activity test is liable to an on the spot fine of 6 weeks benefit.
The second and all subsequent breaches will incur on the spot fines of 3 months benefit.
These are excessive fines to impose upon people who are already severely disadvantaged.
I refer Senators to the ACTU document of 22 October 1996
`The imposition of penalties involving the withdrawal of essential income are not consistent with the values of a society committed to the eradication of extreme hardship and poverty'
Schedule 5 part 4 is similarly offensive.
Not content with being able to impose harsher penalties this government wants to expand its potential for revenue earning by broadening the definition of an activity test.
Now some events which are the result of an administrative error will be deemed an activity breach.
The activity test is designed to apply to the active seeking of work. Yet this change means that faults such as a failure to declare income will be liable for activity test penalties.
Declaration of income is not an activity that assists someone to find work.
Such a situation frequently occurs as a result of an error or a misunderstanding of the DSS forms.
An activity test fine for failing to declare income is completely inconsistent with the activity test onus on finding work.
It is simply a manner in which benefit can be with held and the government can save money.
Within part 5 of SCHEDULE 5 the proposal is that if a person moves to an area which has lower employment prospects then they will incur a fine of 26 weeks.

Obviously the government assumes that they would only make such a move because they do not want to find work. Once again this government proves itself to be totally out of touch with the reality of living on a low income.

A person may decide to move for many reasons—many quite valid reasons. It may be to access cheaper housing, a pressing domestic need, or to be closer to family and community support. These are legitimate reasons to consider moving.

And for this legitimate move—this move which may be required to achieve financial survival—a person could be fined for six months. For 26 weeks this person will receive no income, more than doubling the current penalty.
How does this government expect people to survive? To pay for rent and food?

What if it has already been decided that the unemployed person does not have the capacity to benefit for further employment assistance. Whilst it is decided that in effect they are unemployable they would still be penalised for moving to an area where they were equally unlikely to find employment—not less likely.
In this regard the provision is a nonsense.
I now seek to address the provisions outlined in SCHEDULE 6.
There can be no denying that the proposed amendments to the provisions relating access to unemployment benefit due to industrial action are an attack on union members.

Currently a person is not entitled to NEWSTART allowance Youth Training Allowance, Partner Allowance, Mature Age Allowance or special benefit while engaged in industrial action.. However if a person is unemployed when industrial action ceases, the current legislation allows payment. The only delay would be through normal waiting periods.
This clause is designed to penalise workers for being involved in industrial disputation.
A person who at the end of an involvement in industrial action finds themselves unemployed would not be able to access benefit for another 6 weeks.
This is totally unreasonable and totally transparent. It is an attack on union members rights to participate in industrial action.
The Explanatory Amendment states that the amendments are necessary because
`workers can make a voluntary decision to strike knowing that once they cease their action unemployment benefits are available'
Well how much more evidence do we need to demonstrate this governments complete lack of understanding about workers, industrial action and the problems in the workforce.
How distant are they from the needs of ordinary workers that they could so trivialise a workers decision to partake in industrial action.
In fact workers do not need to be actively participating in such action—they just need to be members of a union taking action.

Workers take industrial action because they want to maintain their jobs and their job security. This can take the form of a strike. It can also be the result of a lockout, it could also be a case of a termination over imminent redundancy.
This is a further attack on the bargaining power of employees consistent with the governments attack on employees rights and standard of living in the Workplace Relations Bill.
Employees don't take such action in an attempt to access unemployment benefits.
They take it because they have not been left with an option and they are fighting to maintain their jobs and the conditions that workers have fought for.
This is a discriminatory amendment—it is clearly an attack on union members. This provision is yet another example of the governments hatred of unionism and employees who stand up for their rights.
With regard to SCHEDULE 11 this schedule deals with amendments of the Social Security Act 1991 to abolish the employment entry payment and modify the education entry payment
This is the removal of the bonus that people receive when they find a job or enter education. The bonus is designed to deal with the recognised costs that this incurs.
The benefit is to assist people to get clothing, equipment, books etc .

It is based on the findings of `Getting to Work' May 1988 which found that when entering work social security recipients encounter considerable costs associated with the purchase of suitable clothing, transport etc. New students are required to purchase text books and stationery supplies. It is very difficult for people who live week to week to afford the additional cost of these items. Such costs were seen to provide significant barriers for people entering the work force or educational institutions.

This amendment is purely a cost cutting measure. There is no reason to believe that this payment is not achieving the ends it was designed to—that is to assist in the removal of the financial burden involved with entering the workforce.
It is in fact just a mean spirited attempt to save money.
When people commence new jobs they need assistance. it is important to have a sense that they fit in as self esteem issues are critical in the first few weeks of employment.
The cost of this benefit is not excessive. In fact the rates are as follows;
Youth training, newstart or jobsearch
(if unemployed for 12 months) $100.00
As above under 18 years old $50.00
Disability support pensioners
& disability wage support $100.00
Education Entry $200.00
These are hardly extravagant bonuses.
SAVINGS $59.386 million over 4 years.

This bill and the other bills relating to social security have one over riding aim and it is not the well being and assistance of people on benefit. This bill, predicated as it is on the false assumption that people on benefit are just ripping off the system, is only designed to save money without regard to fairness. The government does not care that it will mean that some people will be without income for as much as 6 months.
This government does not understand the problems facing recipients of benefits—and frankly I do not think they care.
These measures will shift the burden onto charities and welfare groups and inflict greater poverty on the lowest income groups in Australia.

Even worse when you consider the experience in the United States where welfare benefits are even less humane and about 2% of the population is in prison these provisions are likely to have a similar effect.

So in fact the likelihood is that these provisions will shift the cost burden onto the states by increasing their prison populations because of the desperation, alienation and anger that this atrocious legislation will cause.
I want to remind the Prime Minister of his own commitment made in an address to ACOSS on the 13 of October last year,
`We will not be eroding the safety net that underpins our social security system.'
Well I ask Senators opposite to remember that because that is exactly what this bill seeks to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated into Hansard .

BREAK.PARA: There are numerous measures contained in this Bill that we on this side of the Chamber find will cause untold hardship to those unfortunate to find themselves out of work.
I would like in my time to concentrate on a few of the measures contained in this Bill.
To start I would like to make some general remarks about Schedule 5 of this Bill before moving on and making brief comments about some of the other schedules of this Bill.

Increases in penalties for activity test and the change of penalty for administrative breaches would have to be one of the most heavy measures for young people since unemployment payments were introduced by the Commonwealth in 1945.
As I read in a letter from the President of ACOSS, Mr
Fitzgerald recently;
`Extension of the penalties along the lines proposed in this Bill will severely disadvantage and further impoverish one of the most vulnerable groups in our community.'
I abhor the provisions with regard to the amendments to tighten the activity test administration and Part 3 of Schedule 5 that extends the penalties for breaches to six weeks for a first breach.

When I read this Bill I became deeply saddened that a government could place itself in a position where it would be so wilfully and directly involved in causing poverty. To me this is one of the rawest or crudest of all the measures across all portfolios that came out of the budget.
It is crude because there is not one skerrick of reason that can be called upon by the Minister to demonstrate why this measure is warranted.
At least for example there was a rationale for penalties to be increased under One Nation—there was in that case a mixture as the Welfare Rights Network said of carrot and stick.

Increases introduced then, copped a lot of flack from emergency relief providers but its gone a lot further now under a Minister that I truly believe has never had an understanding of the hardship that is experienced by individuals and families because of poverty.
No evidence exists that the first breach penalty in failing the activity test, has led to unprecedented recidivism on the part of our young people who are the most targeted under this measure.
Rather the evidence is to the contrary that in losing benefit for 3 weeks it was enough for our unemployed young to experience real hardship and to never do it again.

I use the word recidivism deliberately because I fear that this Government in all its efforts to show how it is hardening up the system—that it will be doing a greater disfavour to our young. Many unemployed young people are going to feel even further outcasts in our society—as if they are criminals because of measures such as this.
As the National Welfare Rights Network pointed out in their
submission the penalties are already extremely harsh, more so in fact than penalties for summary offences under the criminal justice system.

I abhor this measure as I see them as a stunt by this government to ensure that they appease the many people out there who unfortunately still believe the balance of the unemployed are bludgers and are able to merrily claim the dole fortnight in—fortnight out.

Welfare cheats are not to be tolerated. That goes without saying. But in reading the recent Social Security Compliance Report tabled by Senator Campbell from the Minister for Social Security I sadly believe a perception is developing in society that there is some parallel between overpayments, debt recovery and payment cancellations and breaches of an activity or administrative test.
I find them abhorrent as the view that has been pedalled is
that there are many unemployed who are aren't making a

genuine effort to obtain employment. I have spoken now to 3 case managers on the North West Coast of Tasmania to gauge whether that is the case. I am talking about the long term unemployed that were dealt with under the old regime. I asked whether unemployed people are that bad in keeping appointments and the like. The view of all three was that yes there are one or two but on the whole the overwhelming majority wanted work, were not intentionally obstructionist but unfortunately some had substantial impediments to employment like illiteracy and physical or mental health problems.
I note that this is also raised by ACROD in their submission.

ACROD fears that many of those that will be reassessed as ineligible for disability support pension will find it difficult to understand the gravity of failing to do something required of them under the activities test.
I would be interested to know if this measure is adopted what the proportion of those breached were once in receipt of disability support.
This Federal Government have unfortunately decided to punish those already experiencing the hardship of poverty by bringing in a raft of changes that are clearly counterproductive.
It is hard to believe what will be the social ramifications when 91 thousand people under a tightening of the activity test are estimated will be affected.
I do not know how many of these people are going to survive.

Without being overly melodramatic and adopting too freely a flood gates type argument l just wonder whether the introduction of this measure taken in tandem with all the other measures introduced in this Bill will in time be seen as a pivotal point in the development of a true underclad in our society.
I now want to refer to Schedule 7 a Schedule that we believe should be withdrawn.

The amendments to waiting periods and the replacement with an income maintenance period is another attack like that of increasing penalty periods in that it will make it doubly difficult for people to return to the workforce.
People and particularly families will have their financial affairs compounded where a partner ends up becoming unemployed and will need to draw on their annual leave and the like.
I believe that with this measure there has been shown a lack of understanding as to how a family or individual live from day to day and as the National Welfare Rights Network points out:

"The Government's proposals that people should use savings to support themselves ignores the fact that many people on low to medium incomes have very little disposable income and have few opportunities to acquire savings to meet the unexpected events in life. The money that many people receive as unused annual or other leave often constitutes their only savings when they become unemployed. They provide a necessary buffer to help people pay outstanding debts and expenses at the time as well as all the additional costs that cannot be met from the low levels of Newstart allowance over a period of unemployment.
People should not as is stated in the minority report be punished for saving .

It is important to also note that with the change from an annual leave waiting period to an income maintenance period people will be precluded from obtaining special benefit which would currently assist people who are facing particular hardship.
I am also concerned that the extent of the proposed reduction in the threshold amount under the liquid assets test is over the top.
To decrease the threshold by 50% on the current amounts for singles and couples will as the National Welfare Rights Network states, reduce peoples' financial reserves to a dangerously low level.

To ameliorate these harsh provisions Schedule 7 the alternative proposal of Welfare Rights by replacing both the proposed liquid assets test and the income maintenance period with a new liquid assets test should be adopted.
Finally I would like to make some comments with regard to Disability Support Pension and the proposed amendments to the impairment tables.

In reading the submission from ACROD, the National Industry Association for Disability Services and in hearing their comments to the submission in the hearing on this Bill I am particularly concerned for those on the cusp of being eligible for disability pension now, and having to become under this measure reliant on labour market programs because they fall short of the 20% impairment rating.

Programs and access to programs I might add that are still up in the air. It was interesting to read the submission from ACROD to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs which raised in some detail, concerns about amongst other things the effect of the introduction of the `capacity to benefit' test and the capacity of those assessing individuals to understand fully the area of disability.
What struck out after reading the submission from ACROD on reforming employment assistance was just how uncertain the area remains for those who will be required to look for a job
and also have the disadvantage of a disability.
As was pointed out in the minority report clarification is still needed in this area and for that reason Schedule 13 of the bill should be withdrawn until those types of matters are resolved.
I fear that this group of people will not be adequately catered for as their support needs will not be met.
