There are many other matters that I could raise with regard to this bill as listed in the minority report but I will leave it there except to say that this bill flies in the face of achieving a more equitable society. And further I wish to address the issue of the maximum rate of rent assistance for single people who share accommodation.
If the Coalition had adhered to its election promise of remaining committed to maintaining the real value of rent assistance then this measure would never have come into being.
There is, in my mind, not one basis or rationale for the introduction of this change when 80 thousand of the poorest people in our society will be singled out to suffer.
On all the evidence these people will now need to review where they live and how they will survive. Why will they receive such a bad break when other options were available?

In fact, as was stated by the witnesses, in the hearing over this Bill, if, as the coalition state, the measure is designed to provide greater equity between single sharers and families in similar circumstances, why is it that this so called inequity is resolved downwards rather than upwards.
National Shelter said, and I quote:

We should be addressing the situation of couples rather than reducing the level of rent assistance to singles, I think, in effect, all this measure will achieve is hardship for singles and it will not resolve any inequity that couples face."
End of quote.
And from the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition when they said, and again I quote:
"If people living alone have higher unmet housing costs than those in shared accommodation, the solution should focus on improving their assistance and not penalising people in shared accommodation."
End of quote.
That is exactly what this measure will achieve.
As we and the Australian Democrats say in the minority report new inequities would be introduced under Schedule 2.

While the coalition woefully attempt to quantify the degree of inequity that currently exists with rent assistance—on the other side of the coin the effect of this measure on the poor has not been quantified.
Evidence suggests that this measure will be most felt by the young, disabled and older women.
The commonality for those people is that they will be in receipt of a low income.

Of the 80 thousand who are expected to be affected by this proposal many will live through an upheaval that will result not only in less disposable income but less self esteem as they realise that the government has dumped them.
It is a charade for this Government to rely on the equity argument.
The equity fallacy pedalled by the coalition to cover up their election falsehood on this matter is quite shameful.
There is no equity in this measure but rather quite the contrary.

Organisations on the cutting edge, dealing day in day out on housing such as National Shelter, National Youth Coalition for Housing, and the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition are united in their view that this proposed measure is harsh with, a resultant hardship to many low income renters struggling to meet higher housing costs.
An interesting aspect to this measure is the potential for harm to people with a disability who live in boarding and lodging houses.
I am not satisfied with the Coalition view that the impact of this measure on people with disabilities living in group houses is probably not as great as may have been expected.

My understanding was that many people with a disability live in group houses and cook their own meals as a team. They desire to be independent and so not receive meals on a regular basis because of that strong desire for independence.
In my view the reasoning provided by the Coalition that the measure would not impact that heavily on people with disabilities is a little tenuous to say the least.
The Coalition do not understand what will be the extent of the ramifications from this measure on people living in boarding houses.
Likewise this measure comes at a time when we find efforts are in train to fundamentally change the nature of housing for low income earners across the nation.
To fiddle at this crucial time when wider reforms are mooted is a dangerous option as the extent of the social consequences are unknown.
The measure also does not rest easily with other social security policies such as the proposed activity test requirements and breaches for moving to a more affordable area.
I would expect that many who would make up the 80 thousand affected will not be able to just pull up anchor and move into single accommodation.
Rather I expect, as has already been discussed in committee, they will just battle on with less money.
In the region in which I live, I am very concerned for the young people who currently live in shared accommodation and are in receipt of rental assistance.
With this proposal it is going to be difficult for those young people to search out options once they are hit with the reduction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 seek to implement an important part of the government's budget. These measures reflect the fairness and responsibility of the government in the budget as demonstrated by the overwhelming public support for the budget measures. These budget initiatives follow a number of key objectives of the government—keeping necessary commitments to the poor and needy, asking people with their own resources to rely more on those resources rather than seeking assistance from fellow citizens and taxpayers, introducing greater simplicity in our very complex social security system, treating those in like circumstances in a consistent manner, and stopping rorts.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1996 budget continues the proud coalition history of social policy. In this budget, we have provided extra assistance to around two million families, including sole parents, through the billion dollar family tax initiative; we have, for the first time, set aside money in the budget forward estimates so that we can keep our commitment to maintain pension payments at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings; and we have listened to the welfare sector and sought to introduce some of their suggestions for reform.

Despite what the opposition has claimed, the government has largely kept its commitments to the poor and needy. Major concerns were expressed by ACOSS before the budget about possible budget cuts; none of those have been introduced by this government. This is a caring government for the poor. We accept that there are a number of measures we may have preferred not to introduce if we had been in the situation of inheriting a balanced budget.

But we all know that the previous Labor government, of which Senator Faulkner was a senior cabinet minister, misled the Australian people before the last election. We had a need to pay off that Beazley bankcard. The social security recipients have been treated very fairly in this process, while we have had to make much more substantial cuts in other portfolios.

Over the last five years of the Labor government, social security outlays grew by 35 per cent in real terms. The social security budget measures in total will reduce social security outlays by less than one per cent. This compares with the reduction in social security of three per cent by the Labor government in 1987 on that rare occasion when they were reducing government expenditure. These measures put in place our election commitments to provide extra assistance for carers, enhance voluntary work for the unemployed, tighten the activity test for the unemployed and broaden the eligibility criteria for the widows allowance for those widowed, divorced or separated after the age of 40.

There are also many fair measures in these bills which were announced by the government in the budget. These include taking greater account of the leave payments received by people leaving a job and the savings that they have before they can access social security payments. Redundancy payments are not affected by these provisions. People will also be able to use their savings to pay off debts without disadvantage. The proposed compensation arrangements are fair. Age pensioners receiving delayed settlements should have these taken into account in working out their payment. They will be treated fairly according to the individual circumstances of economic loss which they are compensated for.

The proposed change in the devisor, away from $564.60 to the single pension cut‐out point of around $400, will introduce a devisor which is closer to the earnings of the average Australian worker receiving compensation. This is fair. The activity test tightening measures will fulfil our election pledge to tighten up arrangements in this area.

It is important to have activity test arrangements which are respected by and, more importantly, complied with by the unemployed. This is essential to having a system of unemployment payments respected by the public at large and by the taxpayer who funds the payments. Opposition parties sometimes forget about the taxpayer.

A critical element of the activity test system is penalties for non-compliance which act as a sufficient deterrent while at the same time being reasonable and simple. Unemployed people and DSS staff find it very difficult to understand the very complex system of penalties introduced by Labor several years ago. Labor should recognise that that mess they introduced needs changing—with sensible changes, as we are proposing. We have listened to the welfare rights campaigners, as they have acknowledged, so as to introduce a payment reduction rather than a complete loss of payment as at present for administrative breaches, which comprise 50 per cent of all breaches.

With respect to activity test penalties, we are proposing to standardise the first activity breach at six weeks for all, which is the same as the current breach period which Labor imposed on long-term unemployed. We have then constrained the second and subsequent breach at 13 weeks rather than the non-limited compounding arrangement recently put in place by Labor.

At this point, I will address the proposed second reading amendment from the Labor Party. I presume that they agree with the government that some tightening of the activity test provisions is warranted. It is quite different from what you put forward to the Australian people in the last election and even from comments from the shadow minister over recent months. If this does represent a recognition that the government was right all along in pointing out existing deficiencies with the activity test, I recognise your belated conversion.

The community should be aware that the previous Labor government never provided labour market assistance for all long-term unemployed or other disadvantaged jobseekers. They cannot use this as an excuse for the complex system of activity test penalties which they put in place. Further, they just do not have the courage to admit the failures of their very rigid system of assistance with low job success rates.

The coalition is continuing to provide substantial labour market program and training assistance to the unemployed with greater regard to achieving job outcomes for the unemployed rather than simply recycling them through programs, as many people who have been unemployed will testify. We reject the Labor Party approach to link activity test requirements to the overall funding of labour market program assistance. It is a nonsense.

We have also recognised the need to be compassionate about activity testing for those who face extreme difficulties in the labour market. We will be relaxing the activity test for those very disadvantaged people unable to participate in labour market assistance. People generally need to meet the activity test because they are receiving taxpayer funds in the form of unemployment payments—no more, no less. This is what the Australian people and the vast majority of unemployed themselves accept, and it is what the government is seeking to introduce.

The government has taken a fair and reasonable approach to the activity testing provisions, with staff of the Department of Social Security having significant discretion to ensure that it is implemented fairly and with existing review and appeal mechanisms in place as added protection. These provisions do not require unemployed people to negotiate changes to the occupational health and safety conditions or training for the prospective job. They are simply required to raise the issue with the prospective employer and seek to come to a suitable resolution.

The proposed abolition of the earnings credit, employment entry payments and education entry payments for allowees only still leaves social security recipients with significant work force incentives through the income test, particularly as a consequence of the July 1995 changes for allowance recipients. The $500 payment advance arrangements and assistance for new job starters available from the CES still enables social security recipients to meet equivalent employment and education entry costs, which they may face.

The Labor Party also needs to face up to the fact that, despite their extensive efforts to publicise these measures, the take‐up is very low and the intended impact on work force incentives has not eventuated. Where measures are not working, we believe it is appropriate to consider alternatives. These are already available in other forms, as I have explained.

The changes proposed for widows and partners are sensible, compassionate and would lead to a significant simplification of existing income support provisions for older women who face considerable difficulties getting a job. This also implements our election commitment to provide access to the widow allowance for those widowed, separated or divorced after age 40.

BREAK.PARA: We have sought to implement changes to the disability support payment impairment tables, picking up the results of the process of change started by Labor when they were in government. The previous Labor government recognised that there were some problems with the impairment tables which they introduced in 1991. In this bill we have merely sought to introduce the expert advice provided to the Labor government on the tables which they had not yet implemented before the last election.

I would caution the Senate about trying to go back to the pre-1991 arrangements, where disability payments were provided to many people who did not have medical impairments. The Labor Party was correct to move down that track. The changes in this bill simply propose some necessary refinements following the experience and some identified problems over the last five years, which the Labor government was moving to address.

Another measure which the government recognises as necessary is the proposed changes to debt recovery. At the moment DSS can recover overpayments in a number of circumstances, such as when people lose qualification, when people are pre-paid and when their income estimate is wrong. In these and other circumstances there may be no fault or blame on the part of the customer in terms of informing the DSS, and the debt is still recoverable according to their capacity to repay. We are seeking to extend this principle to all overpayments, with the recovery process still dependent on the capacity of the individual to repay the debt.

Such a change would increase the accountability of the Department of Social Security, as now they would be required for the first time to keep track of and report on all of these overpayments which are currently not recoverable. The reporting requirements would provide substantial incentive for the department to reduce these overpayments year by year, aside from the additional resources it costs DSS to raise and recover overpayments as opposed to getting the decision right in the first place. The government is willing to consider placing a reasonable time limit on the department to raise these debts.

As I have mentioned before, this bill includes measures which asked those with access to substantial financial resources to look after themselves. Key among this is the very sensible proposal to remove the means test exemption on superannuation assets in the social security means test for those who can access superannuation from age 55. This seeks to overturn a recent loophole introduced by Labor only in 1993, and treats superannuation like any other financial asset. This is reasonable in view of the tax favoured nature of superannuation compared to other financial assets.

Those with small superannuation savings, such as the $38,000 often touted by the Labor Party and referred to again by Senator Sherry earlier, will not be affected. Those with larger superannuation assets will not have to eat into their superannuation capital sum, but are being asked to use some of the income growth to support themselves. Those who cannot legitimately access the superannuation assets are protected from these provisions. The change to rent assistance proposed for sharers is a response to the ridiculous situation at the moment whereby two single people sharing accommodation can currently receive nearly $30 a fortnight more in rent assistance than a couple in the same accommodation. Can the opposition parties explain how that is fair? I do not think that they have succeeded today.

After these changes suggested by the government, two single people sharing accommodation can still receive $30 a fortnight more in rent assistance than a couple in the same accommodation. I was wrong before: two single people sharing accommodation currently receive nearly $80 a fortnight more in rent assistance than a couple in the same accommodation. With the way rent assistance is structured, many young people will not be affected by this measure because they are paying lower rent contributions and not receiving the maximum level of rent assistance, which is possible at the moment.

In summary, these bills represent a fair and balanced approach to Australia's very complex social security system. It provides greater fairness and treats people in the same circumstances in a like manner.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Faulkner's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.PARA: Original question, as amended, agreed to.
Bills read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1996INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 resumed from 25 November, and debate on Industry Research and Development Amendment Bill 1996 resumed from 19 September, on motions by Senator Campbell and Senator Kemp:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating in the second reading the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 and the Industry Research and Development Amendment Bill 1996 cognately. That is the first problem that we in the opposition have, because the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) has an arcane title. It does not convey anything to anybody, but it contains the very important measures of the collapsing of the tax incentive for research and development from 150 per cent to 125 per cent. It also contains the measures announced in a joint statement by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) on 23 July last that syndication—a way in which companies can group together and claim a tax advantage for research and development—is to be terminated.

SPEECH.PARA: These are matters of major national importance. These are matters that have occupied the business pages and the general reporting pages of most newspapers in the months since the announcement. There are matters of high controversy here. Industry hotly contest with the government the basis for chopping the 150 per cent to 125 per cent and certainly hotly contest the issues of removing syndication as well.

The report upon which the government's decision is allegedly based is a report which, I would contend, is flawed and is not a report that actually finds what the government claims it finds. In a press release of the joint ministers dated 23 July, the government attached four examples in which they alleged the tax system was being abused under syndication.

In the evidence that was adduced before the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, which inquired into this legislation, we had a whole raft of Australian companies that came along and together claimed to represent about 93 to 94 per cent of companies who had applications for syndication before the Industry Research and Development Board. All of them said that the four examples the government had offered were not typical, did not resemble any of those that the companies had lodged—and they had lodged 94 per cent of them—would not have been approved under the IR&D guidelines that were tightened by the former government in the innovation statement on 6 December last year and, therefore, would not apply currently; that is, the examples were fraudulent.

I acknowledge, for its part, the government has stuck by the examples. But someone here is not telling the truth. The voice of industry is so overwhelmingly compelling on this that it does raise the question: why, if the government wants to encourage research and development—as it alleges it does, although that allegation would be laughable in the face of the measures in this bill—would the government want to throw out the baby with the bathwater on syndication? Why wouldn't it, if it felt there were some abuse of the system, deal with that abuse and let the overwhelming number of very good cases that promote Australian industry go ahead?

The government has not answered that question adequately in any way, shape or form. It is simply after the tax gain; it is not interested in the type of advantage Australian industry can get by good research and development, which will create intelligent jobs in this country, which will enable Australian industry to be more competitive internationally, which will enable us to grow our exports by manufactured goods and services and redress the problems of the current account deficit.

These issues are so important and so compelling that they ought not be buried in a bill which deals with five other measures. We in the opposition want to vote against the government on this. But—because of the way in which tax bill No. 3 is presented—to do so, we would have to vote against the whole six measures proposed by the government in this bill. I contend that this is a fraudulent way of presenting this legislation to the chamber.

I foreshadow now that at the end of my remarks I will move an amendment to the second reading. If the amendment is carried, one of the effects will be to enable the Senate to vote on the research and development components of tax bill No. 3 on their own rather than as part of an omnibus bill. One of the other effects of this will be to propose a series of steps in which syndication can be tightened so that the objective of the syndication scheme is realised. Therefore, further abuse, if any, can then be hived off and prevented so that this measure can perform its intended role and not simply be abolished. I intend to move that amendment at the end of my remarks.

As I have said, this is a complicated set of bills. tax bill No. 3 has six separate measures—all of which are important. We are opposing three of them, and we are supporting three of them. But there is another bill that we are debating here today too, and that is the research and development bill. This is a bill that has been hanging around for a long time. It is a bill that, just over a year ago when I was on the other side of the chamber and the responsible minister, I proposed to enact in this parliament because it dealt with one of the abuses of research and development; it dealt with the grave digging abuse. We in the opposition support the principle of this bill entirely.

What the evidence before the Senate committee revealed, however, is that there is a significant problem here that needs to be addressed. That significant problem is that, given the tortuous way in which companies apply for concessions under the research and development bill, they need to lodge an application and have that application processed by the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism for it to be registered.

On 6 December 1995, when the changes to the grave digging elements of this bill were announced, there was a backlog of companies that had lodged applications but had not been registered, and they had not been registered for no fault of their own. They had not been registered because of the unavailability of sufficient staff within the department to deal with the applications that had accumulated.

This came out clearly in evidence before the inquiry. I understand this is a matter that the government itself proposes to redress as a consequence of the inquiry. I commend the government for moving its position to accommodate the reasonable concerns of industry here. We do not think they move far enough. I will have an amendment on that when we come to the committee stage. It will take the change the whole way and not just seven‐eighths of the way.

There are two other elements of this bill that need to be mentioned before I return in my substantive remarks to research and development. The first one is the amendment to the cooperative companies section of the bill. This is an amendment which cuts out an advantage that cooperative companies in this nation have had for 36 years. Cooperative companies have had that advantage because, for 36 years, the governments in Australia have wanted to encourage the cooperative movement to acquire its capital goods and make investments in a way in which they can be encouraged to develop and flourish. The cooperative companies in Australia are, I think, unique. They are something that governments of all colours and hues have supported over the last 36 years. But, alas, the Howard government will not. The Howard government proposes to close down this tax concession on the basis that the very small amounts of money it will save go to the so‐called bottom line argument for the budget, but without particular regard—and certainly without any investigation—of what the real effects on cooperatives will be. I think this is outrageous.

BREAK.PARA: The cooperative movement, which is mainly rural based cooperatives based on farmers, is outraged about it. I will not speak at great length on this matter now because I know my colleague Senator Sherry and my other colleagues in this debate will speak at considerable length on it. But what I want to say is that the cooperative movement represents the small end of business. These are small business people banding together to create a cooperative company in order to establish a market advantage for themselves in contradistinction to the big end of town. This is now virtually the only sector of the food industry in Australia that is Australian owned—and here is the government quashing them. We will be moving to reverse the government's intention in the bill on that

Lastly, before I go back to research and development, there is the mining rights issue. The mining rights issue is very important to my state of Western Australia because it applies primarily, but not exclusively, to goldmining. It is when small prospectors find gold or another designated mineral and wish to then develop their lease and on‐sell that lease to a company which can mine it. They make their income by doing so. This is a provision that was inquired into in 1985 by the Gutman inquiry, and was required to stand. The now government, then opposition, voted with us in government to support that measure. It is interesting that they are now voting to remove that measure—something that they said they would not do they are now about to do.

However, I understand the arguments on this issue. I think that all income in one form or another should be properly taxed, but there is a major issue here of retrospectivity. This is a major issue of retrospectivity which is complex and difficult to understand at first blush. This is because, in a way, it is retrospectivity that is dealt with prospectively. That sounds like a contradiction in terms. But one has to understand how the system works to understand that those people who currently hold mining leases or did so on budget night did so on the understanding that, when they did on‐sell them, they would not be taxed. We will be moving an amendment which will protect their rights. Anyone who has acquired or pegged a lease from budget night will have done so in the full knowledge that the government intended to close off that loophole and that, therefore, they should take their chances. There are 4,000 registered prospectors in Western Australia, 400 of whom are active at any one time. Those prospectors are not entitled to be dealt with retrospectively as the government intends. I know that my colleagues will speak further on this measure, in particular my colleague Senator Mark Bishop who is also from the state of Western Australia.

I now have left to me something like eight minutes to address the very complex issue of research and development. That is a joke. The reason why it is a joke is that the government has bracketed these bills to prevent, I think, a full discussion, although I must say there has been quite an extensive Senate inquiry. I therefore commend for the record the findings of that inquiry, particularly the minority report of the Australian Democrat representative on that inquiry, Senator Andrew Murray—I thought he found in quite an important way in that inquiry—but, more particularly, if I might say so, because I think our report goes further, the minority report of Senator Sherry and myself. That contains a very long discussion of these issues. Our minority report is 22 pages. It deals at length with all these matters in detail. Let me try to summarise them.

The reduction of the tax incentive of 150 per cent to 125 per cent should not pass; it should not pass in the national interest. What the government is doing here in syndication is applying a narrow cost‐cutting approach in taking a nominal saving which, if you take a whole of budget view, is in fact in all probability a nominal loss to the budget as well as a nominal loss to the economy of Australia. I say that with as much passion and force that I can summon for this reason: an index of a nation's future prosperity is the amount of private sector investment in research and development. It is axiomatic. Companies that commit to high levels of research and development are historically companies which succeed in the globalised competitive market of the future.

Australia is a laggard in this respect. On the most recent OECD figures, in the table on business expenditure on research and development, known as BERD, Australia ranks around 17th or 19th out of 24 OECD economies. We are down there with Turkey and Portugal and a few economies like that. That is not Australia's natural place in the world. The Labor government provided particular incentives—the 150 per cent incentive being the key one—to encourage Australian corporations and firms to spend more on research and development to become, therefore, more internationally competitive and to win in the international marketplace. What does this government do? Just as those companies are developing a research and development culture which is beginning to pay dividends for this nation—there is a whole raft of highly complex but very illuminating submissions here on the type of research and development that is going on in this nation—just as they are beginning to turn on to this, the Australian government chops them back and says that the incentives that it is providing will be competitive.

Those incentives are not competitive. In any case, if we are competitive, we would be competitive with the most successful economies in the OECD bloc, and we are not. We need to actually provide a better incentive in order to lift ourselves up to their level of investment in research and development. Might I also add that by chopping the 150 per cent to 125 per cent, the government explicitly, openly and blatantly breaks its own election commitments. Before the election, Minister Moore and Treasurer Costello made it clear to Australian industry that 150 per cent was to remain. It was a solemn core promise. What we found on budget night was that it was an expendable, disposable promise and it is now to go.

All of the literature on research and development points to the significance of investment in research and development and the future health of the economy. Might I say that the government obviously has a more immediate, narrow, cost cutting view than the importance of the economy overall, and that is what has happened here. Important measures for industry have been overridden in the pursuit of savings dollars, which are counterproductive in the longer term.

I return to syndication, because I think this is the most blatantly fraudulent myth that the government wishes to perpetrate on Australians. As I have said, in July, the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism announced pre‐emptively the termination of the syndication scheme. They did so on a report from the BIE—what they claim to be the BIE. In fact, if you look more closely, they were wrong. They were misleading. It was not the BIE; it was the department, with someone seconded from the BIE to help with that report.

That report is a theoretical model which does not go to what new evidence would have accumulated given the tightening of the guidelines on syndication that the previous government introduced on 6 December. There is insufficient time to get anything like a population of reasonable examples to know how that tightening would have operated. What we see in this so-called report is a theoretical modelling based on a series of assumptions rather than a case analysis of what actually is the case. The document on which this is based is flawed. As I said in my earlier remarks, no-one in industry recognises the samples that have been put forward to justify this change as so‐called rorting of the tax system by syndication. The ministers have put them forward in their press release, and they stand condemned on that.

I am convinced that there is always a need to be vigilant when you provide a tax mechanism like this, because those with disposable income and desire for tax avoidance will always find ways around regulations once they are proclaimed. So you have to keep a watching brief on these things and change the guidelines as ways of subverting the intention of the guidelines are found. That is not a criticism of those who are currently before us. Surveying the type of R&D that they want to do, I think they are all respectable companies and I think that those that have been listed on the A list have an entitlement to have their syndicates considered by the research and development board. These are companies who were in full expectation of that before they were cut off at the pass by the statement of the ministers on 23 July.

The syndication scheme has worked well. It is a cost‐plus scheme for Australia overall. It is not a cost‐negative scheme. In my motion, I have set down where further tightening can occur in order to keep this scheme focused on its objective and to prevent tax avoidance. I ask the government to not throw the baby out with the bathwater here. Accept these suggestions for further tightening, allow the scheme to go on and allow the nation to harvest the opportunities that are there on research and development.
I formally move my second reading amendment, which has been circulated in the chamber:
At the end of the motion, add ", but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(a) the proposed reduction in research and development (R & D) tax concession provisions from 150% to 125% should be rejected;

(b) the issue of compliance costs in accessing R & D entitlements should be referred to the Government's committee on cutting compliance costs so that ways can be found to reduce the paperwork burden;
(c) provisions of the Bill eliminating syndicated R & D should be removed;
(d) the Government should direct its efforts to finding ways of overcoming any potential abuses of R & D syndication rather than eliminating the scheme altogether;
(e) if the Government considers further tightening of the syndication finance scheme guidelines are necessary, this could be achieved along the lines set out below:

PARA.TAB: 1. Increasing `at‐risk' investment

TAB.TAB: The guidelines currently require at least 10% of the investment in a syndicate to be not subject to any form of guaranteed return. This could be progressively increased to 30% over 3 years.

PARA.TAB: 2. Further restrict transfers of core technology

TAB.TAB: The guidelines require that at least 50% of the total value of the core technology must have been either developed by the researcher or owned by the researcher for at least two years as at the date of proposal. The above could be further tightened to require at least 75% of the total value and ownership for at least four years, to ensure that offshore technology transfers cannot be used to create artificial cost bases for syndicates.

At the same time, provision should be made to allow for up to 50% of the core technology to be acquired from Registered Research Agencies. This will provide some level of encouragement for companies to commercialise technologies resident in public sector institutions, eg. CSIRO and universities.

PARA.TAB: 3. Researcher must be applicant

TAB.TAB: The guidelines could be clarified to ensure that the entity which proposes to carry out the research is the applicant and the following details are provided—Name of Researcher (must be an Australian domiciled taxpaying entity), Details of Incorporation (ACN, date and State of incorporation), Tax File Number, Name of Responsible Manager.

PARA.TAB: 4. Details of researcher and project, taxation deductions to investors and fees to be public

TAB.TAB: It could be a requirement of registration of a syndicate that details be published in the Commonwealth Gazette and/or the Annual Report of the Department or of the Industry Research and Development Board, including—Name of researcher, Brief description of project, Name of investor (s),Tax deductions to investor (s), Name of broker/financier, Fees paid to broker/financier.

PARA.TAB: 5. Ceiling limitation on taxation deductions

TAB.TAB: Cap the cost of the program at $200m per year. This cap would be set on a rolling three year basis and the approving authority would be able to allocate entitlements to deductions within this cap.
Hold three rounds of syndicate bids per year.

Among other criteria (quality of R&D, commercialisation plans and capabilities), the approving authority would allocate the deduction entitlements based on a value for money measure such as the amount of R&D to be funded relative to the tax deductions gained by the investors.

BREAK.PARA: (f) the 46 proposals in the syndication "A" List should be entitled to have their cases considered and determined by the Industry Research and Development (IR & D) Board forthwith;
(g) the Treasury should review its estimates of the tax savings the abolition of syndicated R&D will generate by including in its estimates the amount of claw‐back from dividend imputation;
(h) the Ministerial undertaking of 23 July 1996 to "grandfather" R&D syndication cases lodged with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) should be included explicitly in the legislation;
(i) firms with applications lodged with the AAT be given leeway for those applications to be heard and determined;
(j) the Cooperatives provision of the Bill should be rejected, or, failing this, the transitional arrangements should be improved to make them more fair;
(k) paragraph 120(1)(c) of the Income Tax Assessment Act should be amended to make it explicitly clear that eligibility of deductibility applies to both Government and non‐government asset purchases;
(l) the principle of the removal of tax exemption for sale of mining rights should be supported;
(m) the Government should consider a tax deduction to mining companies of their expenditure on buying rights to a mine; and

(n) any problem of the retrospective application of this provision be resolved by providing that the operation of this section commence for prospectors entering into claims after the Budget announcement.

My remarks in the second reading debate address the main points of the amendment. In the first place, the amendment splits the R&D part from the tax laws bill No. 3 so that we can vote on that separately, as we should. In the second part, it sets down a whole range of areas in which, I believe, there can be tightening of syndication.

At the end of the day, what the government is doing here is driving Australia down a low‐growth road. What the government is doing here is breaking a culture that was beginning to emerge in this nation for research and development. What the government is doing here is cutting off its nose to spite its face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on these two bills before us. It is the view of the Australian Democrats that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 is a fundamentally anti‐business bill, a fundamentally anti‐intellectual bill and a fundamentally anti‐competi tive bill. It goes against all the principles required to produce a clever country with high and ecologically sustainable living standards, and it will reduce our environmental capabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats will throw a lifeline to the Liberal and National Party senators and the House of Representatives members on this tax bill. I am well aware that this bill does not enjoy full support in the ranks of the coalition. The cabinet of the coalition is presiding over the worst conceived, most destructive, most short-sighted anti‐business package of cuts and changes possible.

Many senators and members are as appalled as I am by this package. You, the government, have deserted the small country businesses. You have deserted the dusty, hard‐living prospectors. You have deserted the dynamic rural cooperatives, and you have deserted the productive farmers who are their members. You have deserted the clever university and institutional researchers. You have deserted the innovators and technologists of small business. You have deserted the competitive and hardy medium size businesses of Australia. You have deserted those big Australians who take on the world companies on their own terms. You have done so because you have cobbled together a hasty package of bills whose sole purpose is to look at the revenue side of your ledger.

This bill has been repeatedly and devastatingly criticised by virtually every commentator, policy analyst and industry association that comes readily to mind. As with other industry bills that have been put before us, the evidence is conclusive that the broader impacts of these changes and budget cuts on productive R&D, on industrial innovation and technological advancement, on the business sectors affected, on economic growth and directions, on environmental protection, or on Australia's overall international and domestic competitiveness have not been adequately evaluated by this government. That is why I refer to you having deserted what is supposed to be your own constituency.

As stated in my November 1996 minority report on the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, the budget debates, the estimates process and Senate debates and questions all have combined to show that the government's principal motivation for the substantial cuts it sought in industry and export assistance programs has been to generate revenue savings.

Once again, with this bill it is evident that the government, the Treasury and the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism have not undertaken—nor have they been directed to do so—appropriate and current cost benefit analysis, or sensitivity analysis or modelling, to assess the quantifiable impacts on jobs, investment, growth and competitiveness resulting from the specific policy changes it proposes.

Under questioning by me during Senate estimates, a senior departmental official admitted not only that they were unable to confirm what the effect of winding down the 150 per cent tax concession to 125 per cent would be but also that it would be three years before the effects of these changes could properly be assessed. This means that, if the effects are profoundly negative, long lasting and detrimental—as numerous witnesses and industry representatives have claimed—important opportunities would be missed before remedial action can be taken.

The Australian Democrats question the wisdom of taking on faith a radical leap—and it is a radical leap—into new business policy, new tax policy and new R&D policy. How can we justify blindly trusting the judgment of those who hastily cobbled together a policy package whose sole and overriding objective is revenue and cost driven?

The Australian Democrats support a credible, responsible and timely budget deficit reduction strategy. I would remind government senators that last year they voted against a deficit reduction package that we put forward. We believe, however, that the government's assumptions overstate the speed and the extent of deficit reduction required. While Treasury forecasts of the size of the budget deficit are important and useful tools for underpinning policy objectives, it is important to recognise that it is impossible for them to be absolutely accurate—and they could be substantially inaccurate. We all in this chamber know it, and they know it.

For this reason, it is particularly important that cuts which undermine jobs, profits, industrial development and competitiveness be treated with real caution. When evaluating industry programs, it is most unwise to solely focus on just one side of the ledger—on cost and revenue savings—without focusing on the effects on jobs, growth, investment and competitiveness and without focusing on the revenue‐positive benefits that such programs are capable of generating.

The combination of a new and inexperienced government—I do not say that with any slander; it is just a fact—and the triumph of opportunistic ideological elements within the government and Treasury has been unhappy for business, industry, universities and R&D programs. The government has failed to give due consideration to the fundamental importance of maintaining a stable policy environment for business planning and investment and for university and institutional research. The government has failed to recognise the fundamental importance of maintaining confidence in the certainty and durability of Australia's policy mechanisms.

It is a matter of deep regret that, in the defence of some questionable decisions, some ministers—including within this chamber—have chosen the pejorative, unjustified and demonising route of referring to industry and export assistance programs as `business welfare' and `rorts' and the like. Such an approach does no justice to the serious policy concerns that need to be addressed and represents a disservice to Australia's reputation for objectivity and considered policy debate in this field.

The government has been widely criticised for the series of short‐sighted and damaging anti-business decisions it has undertaken since gaining office—for example, the imposition of a three‐per cent tax on imported business inputs, the abolition of the development import finance facility, cuts to business R&D programs, cuts to export assistance programs and cuts to labour market programs, such as the new enterprise incentive scheme. Of course, you have introduced new schemes, such as START, which are to be welcomed.

The government has also been strongly and rightly criticised for lacking an industry policy which provides a vision, plan, direction or aspiration for Australian industry, both domestically and internationally. The sole policy aim of the government has been to find cuts to existing programs rather than to genuinely seek to invigorate or enhance existing policies and programs.

Another area of criticism, which you are starting to react to, relates to Australia trying to lead its competitors on tariff reductions and free trade. Unilaterally adopting a leadership role versus our competitors, and thereby reducing Australian competitiveness, can be very harmful to specific industry sectors.

I apologise to the Senate in advance. We have had a short time, as you all know, in which to produce our amendments to this bill. We will be circulating them in the committee stage. The amendments will go to the substantive issues, which include the 150 per cent to 125 per cent R&D tax deduction, syndication provisions and the retrospectivity question. They will go to the co‐ops issue, the mining prospectors issue and a number of technical and other substantive issues.

I want to deal with the 150 per cent issue. In slashing this tax concession to 125 per cent, the government shows that it has lost sight of the central role of research and development in creating and fostering internationally competitive industries. The 150 per cent tax reduction concession for eligible research and development expenditure was established in 1986 and has actually deteriorated in terms of its applicability, due to changes in the company tax rates.

This concession is without doubt one of the major contributors to Australia's research and development successes and growth. I would suggest that, within the OECD and within the tiger economies, continued application of strong R&D effort is absolutely essential if we are to not see a future scenario of Australia's gentle decline.

A number of independent and thorough economic studies have singled out this 150 per cent concession as one of the key factors responsible for the dramatic growth in business expenditure on R&D which has occurred over the past decade. I was speaking to a senator earlier today and he said, `Oh, but it is going to cost the government such a lot of money if this does not go through.' I tell you: it will cost a lot more money if it does go through, and I would urge you to reconsider.

Despite the strong efforts of some firms in industrial sectors, Australia's overall private sector R&D performance remains by international standards very low and can be described in some ways as appalling, because we have one of the lowest ratios of business expenditure on R&D to GDP in the OECD. I would say to you, as someone with considerable international experience: that is a waste of the outstanding intellectual capital we have in this country. Even our growth rates in business input to R&D, which until recently were relatively high, have dwindled and are now mediocre in comparison with our international competitors.

So the government responds, led by a set of people who I do not think understand this field, by reducing the 150 per cent tax concession to a top rate of 125 per cent. It may be in their terms a good way of getting headline figures about ensuring short-term budget savings, but we do not believe this is a means of ensuring genuine, lasting, long-term economic development. We expect that the coalition will be in power for two terms and we think they will rue this policy if they allow it to go through.

If the government really wants Australian industry to prosper, if it is serious about making Australia a key centre for research and development in the Asia-Pacific region, then it will need to rethink its approach and not walk away from its commitments. If you pursue these kinds of policies, you will find your ability to pursue a second term much harder than it would otherwise be.

If this bill passes, it will simply ensure that ever increasing quantities of Australia's already inadequate investment in R&D head offshore. Critics do not want to listen, Treasury do not want to listen and industry people do not want to listen. I do not know what experience they have of business and management in the wide world, but I have a great deal and this is a wrong policy.

The government claims that this tax concession is very generous compared with other international measures. This criticism is not well founded. In an extremely competitive world environment, it is probable that Australia needs to increase and not decrease its business R&D incentives. The level of industry R&D in Australia has to be recognised as below the OECD average, and it has to be lifted up.

The Australian Democrats accept the evidence provided by industry and research specialists that the reduction in the value of the concession will cause a harmful reduction in R&D to the detriment of Australia's future economic growth, environmental protection, competitive strength and export performance and that it will encourage Australian R&D to move offshore.

The Australian carried a report on 13 November 1996 claiming that the Productivity Commission in unpublished statistics concluded that the decision to reduce the 150 per cent tax concession to 125 per cent will encourage less research and development. It stated:

Eighteen per cent of R&D activity and 12 per cent of R&D by foreign‐owned companies, had been induced by the 150 per cent tax concession. But the 125 per cent concession would induce only 10 per cent of R&D by Australian firms, and 8 per cent of foreign‐sponsored R&D investment.

That is a significant reduction of between 25 per cent and 50 per cent. Moreover, the report stated that the commission also found it is mostly smaller firms which were influenced by the concession. It stated:
One quarter of firms with fewer than 20 employees undertook R&D on the basis of a 150 per cent tax concession, falling to 20 per cent for a 125 per cent tax concession.

PARA.BREAK: I now turn to the matter of syndication. Syndication has been subject to a particularly nasty form of demonising by ministers of this government. I, too, have had people whispering in my ear about the rorts, but I have to rely on credible evidence. No credible evidence whatsoever has been provided in any parliamentary or public forum for the exist ence of rorts in approved R&D syndication schemes. Where previously there was some inefficient or inappropriate approval of syndication applications, the tightening of eligibility and screening criteria in December 1995 was effective in providing for tighter processing of applications, and that has been acknowledged by both the department and the government.

SPEECH.PARA: The real question is whether syndication is the most appropriate and efficient method of promoting R&D. That question has not, in my view, been adequately answered, either in evidence before the committee or in other forums. The government has made a case that syndication does not always produce optimal or cost effective results.

Despite obvious misgivings I have been expressing as to the government's motives and conclusions, the Australian Democrats will support the government on the abolition of syndication. But we would not have done so were it not for the government's introduction of the innovative new START scheme. However, you should recognise that we will not support you in abolishing syndication without a guarantee, which we would seek from the other side during the debate, that START will continue and without adequate provisions to eliminate unfair retrospectivity.

There are a couple of other areas which I will not go to in any length now, because I appreciate that this debate time is limited and I want to give my other Senate colleagues an opportunity to speak. We will be dealing with cooperative companies. We will be opposing your intention to remove section 120(1)(c). We will also be dealing with the matter of the mineral and prospectors' provision, 23PA. We will support you in that venture, but with an amendment to cater for unfair and retrospective conditions.

I hope—I think many in the government benches might hope also—that you will reconsider on some of these areas during the debate. I dearly wish that we will be able to defeat you, particularly on the measure affecting the 150 per cent tax concession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 is an omnibus bill of nine separate amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act. I do not propose to speak on each and every item but I wish particularly to focus my remarks on cooperatives; namely, the repeal of section 120(1)(c) of the tax act which would deny cooperatives one of their few effective sources of funds to enable capital expansion.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I do so, I would like to make a few short comments on one other provision in the bill. The new provision that provides for an income tax rebate for low income earners is welcomed and supported by the opposition. The only point I wish to make here is the increase in costs employers will incur in having to vary their payroll systems to cater for the rebate.

I do not raise this as a criticism of the initiative but when this increase is added to the costs employers will face in keeping a record of the background of employees who qualify for the family tax initiative, as well as the increased costs that employers will face from the administration of the new $1.5 billion superannuation tax, one must wonder when all of the coalition's rhetoric about reducing paperwork faced by small business will in fact become a reality. From this series of government initiatives it appears the government is more intent on increasing the paperwork burden than decreasing it.

Having made some comments in this area, I now want to address the removal of section 120(1)(c) of the tax act and the effect this will have on the many thousands of cooperatives—I was surprised it is over 2,500 cooperatives—which mainly operate in rural and regional Australia. This section of the act dates back to 1930 when it was introduced to recognise the unique nature of cooperatives by virtue of their status of being owned by their members. As the evidence tendered to the Economics Legislation Committee demonstrated, cooperatives face disadvantages not faced by other trading enterprises in their efforts to raise capital to fund capital expansions.

Cooperatives are precluded from raising equity capital through public share floats. As such their only source of funds is from capital raised from their own members, who have limited funds, particularly in times of a rural downturn, internal funds generated by the use of section 120(1)(c) or external borrowings. Evidence tendered to the committee suggested that banks view cooperatives as an inherently riskier investment due to their unique status as a cooperative. Consequently, cooperatives have to pay a risk premium in the form of higher interest rates on external borrowings than that enjoyed by public companies.

This discrimination would appear to be totally unfounded and one must wonder how banks will view cooperatives in the future when assessing an application for borrowings, given that the repeal of this section will only decrease the amount of internal funds generated and therefore available for the repayment of loan borrowings. Given this scenario, I can only see banks seeking to charge a higher rate of interest to compensate them for the increased risk due to the decrease in available cashflow that cooperatives will have to repay external loans if this section of the bill is passed.

It interesting to note that no supporting evidence was given to support the view that cooperatives were inherently riskier investments than other trading enterprises. Nonetheless, this would appear to be a real barrier to cooperatives securing external funds on terms as equal as other business borrowers. This highlights the importance of the continued maintenance of section 120(1)(c) of the Income Tax Assessment Act and how it provides one of the few avenues for cooperatives to access funds for capital expansion.

But as is quickly becoming the hallmark of this government the repeal of the cooperatives provision is yet another bash the bush exercise by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and the Treasurer, Mr Costello, on top of the slashing of funds to rural and regional Australia and the one-third sale of Telstra that will see higher costs for local calls and most probably restricted access to new technology for rural subscribers. I note the laugh from the other side but I believe in a few years you will live to regret these anti-bush, anti-rural and regional, measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you know about it?

—I would know about it. I was an assistant to Bob Collins when he was the parliamentary secretary to the minister for primary industries. I lived in rural and regional Australia as well. I grew up in a small country town.

BREAK.PARA: What is most surprising is the avid and unwavering support given by the National Party as they help the economic dries led by the Prime Minister and his Treasurer to sell out the interests of rural and regional Australia on the alter of economic rationalism. Black Jack McEwen, as he was known, must be turning in his grave as he watches the supposed leadership of the National Party sell its soul to the Liberal Party for little or no gain.

What has become of the National Party? I always thought that a coalition implied equal standing, equal say and equal respect among the parties involved. But here we have a coalition where one partner, the National Party, has been gagged, bullied and berated to the point where it is no more than a poor cousin to the Liberal wets. The National Party struggles for relevancy and is slowly fading away to the point where it will no longer even be considered relevant unless they take a stand on the sorts of issues that we are considering in this legislation today.

I therefore ask: where is the National Party? When will the National Party stand up for their constituency and say that enough is enough? When are they going to cease being the doormat of the Liberal Party? When are they going to stand firm in their beliefs and stand up against the attacks on the bush and rural and regional Australia?

This bill does present an opportunity for the National Party. It is their opportunity to draw a line in the sand and say no to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. The National Party needs to be honest to themselves and realise they got conned on Telstra—and there is growing public evidence from National Party members about that each day—they got duped on funding to rural and regional Australia in the budget, they got done on imported chicken meat, despite their protestations prior to the last election, and they are slowly getting done on competition policy. Will they get done on the issue of cooperatives? I sincerely hope not. But unless they take a stand on this issue they inevitably will.

What I would like to know is why it is so hard for the National Party to say, `We are going to stand up for rural and regional Australia?' I particularly say to two senators in this place, Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee: come down and stand up for rural and regional Australia, stand up for the interests of cooperatives which you tell them privately you are going to do but publicly we will wait and see what you do.

I suspect that they will do nothing. I hope that Senators Boswell and O'Chee have read the remarks made by their own National Party colleagues in the other place. But, if they have not, I would like to remind them and remind the Senate about the comments made by some National Party members in the other place. The member for Dawson (Mrs De‐Anne Kelly) said: The benefit of cooperatives is easily seen . . .
She later went on to say:
A cooperative has considerable disadvantages compared to a company. They are not in a level playing field situation.
Mr Anthony, the son of the former Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party, said that cooperatives are:
. . . extremely important for Australia's rural constituency.
He further said:
The great benefit of cooperatives is that they are always run and owned by Australian businesses . . .

But the statement which sums up the importance of cooperatives to the National Party and the statement which I draw to their attention, in particular, Senators Boswell and O'Chee, is the statement by Mr Anthony, which said:
The third part I would like to highlight, which is part of the heart and soul of the National Party, is in relation to cooperatives.

Mr Anthony, the member for Richmond, could not have put it more succinctly. `Cooperatives are part of the heart and soul of the National Party.' Yet here we have before us a bill which will drive a stake through the heart of the National Party, according to Mr Anthony; a bill designed to destroy one of the main underpinnings of rural business enterprises in Australia.

So I say to Senators Boswell and O'Chee, who have been furiously trying to reassure cooperatives, particularly in Queensland, to come down and stand up for rural and regional Australia. Stand up for farmers. Stand up for what you represent. Stop being a doormat, and start saying no to the destruction of rural cooperatives in this country.

If Senators Boswell and O'Chee are not convinced by their own colleagues in the other place, then I would ask them to look closely at the evidence presented by the cooperatives themselves to the Economics Legislation Committee. Let me quote from the report. The Mackay Sugar Cooperative Association said:
. . . the major motivation for the operation and formation of cooperatives is the desire for primary producer members to control the processing and marketing of their produce.
The submission then went on to state:
They should therefore continue to be taxed on the same basis.
Golden Circle, another Queensland company, said:

The government's principle of competitive neutrality is focused on domestic competitiveness within specific industries and ignores the fact that cooperatives compete in export markets where foreign primary producers are often subsidised and multinational companies have access to cheap finance.

These are two major Queensland cooperatives that have put forward the case for the retention of section 120(1)(c). The question is: are Senators Boswell and O'Chee going to support the cooperatives of Queensland and their members, or are they going to sell them out for a relatively modest total gain against the total budget of $12 million over three years? Is that what the heart and soul of the National Party is worth—a lousy $4 million a year?

PARA.BREAK: It is my honest belief that Senator Boswell is a man with both a heart and a soul, particularly when it comes to representing the interests of his National Party constituency. I am sure that Senator Boswell will not sell out the cooperatives of Queensland for $4 million a year. It is a shame that his colleagues in the House did, though. And I have drawn atten tion to a number of comments they made about this matter. At the end of the day they were quite happy to remain a doormat of the Liberal Party and support this attack on rural cooperatives.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Boswell has become a strident critic of competition policy reform and its impact on rural and regional Australia. Only recently Senator Boswell said in this place:
Not enough time has been devoted to the ramifications of Hilmer on the fortunes of small business.

I therefore ask: what assurances have the National Party got on the ramifications that the repeal of section 120(1)(c) will have on the future of cooperatives, which are in the main small business enterprises? My guess is they have none and that the transitional provisions in the bill are no more than a few crumbs the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has thrown the National Party in the hope that they will go away.

There is no doubt that this worked in the House because the National Party members en bloc voted for this measure, but I certainly hope that Senator Boswell will not be so easily conned. Just in case Senator Boswell has any doubts as to the motivation for the repeal of this section, I refer him to the remarks made by Mr Miles, the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister, when he introduced this bill in the House. He said:

The measures will prevent the effective 200 per cent tax deduction which was previously available for the cost of certain assets and which provided cooperatives and government lending institutions with commercial and taxation advantages over other companies. These advantages are not justifiable and are inconsistent with competitive neutrality principles.

This assault on the many thousands of rural and regional cooperatives is driven by the fact that the Liberals consider section 120(1)(c) to be inconsistent with competitive neutrality principles. Once again, the economic rationalists of the Liberal Party want to deny cooperatives one of their main sources of funding, because it does not comply with the objectives of competition policy.

I now turn specifically to Mr Miles and his comments. Mr Miles and his avid support for this bill paid no regard for his own electorate of Braddon, in north‐west Tasmania, and in particular the expansion plans of UMT, a cooperative that employs 346 people and generated sales of $171 million in 1995-96. If Mr Miles had any concern for UMT, which is based in his electorate of Braddon, he would be aware that his government and the Australian Taxation Office are now trying to reinterpret section 120(1)(c) of the tax act, which would be to the detriment of UMT's $45 million expansion at Spreyton.

The Spreyton project was predicated on the interpretation of section 120(1)(c)—an interpretation which has been relied upon for the last 60 years—that cooperatives which borrow funds from a government or government instrumentality and subsequently use those funds to purchase an asset will be entitled to the full deduction under section 120(1)(c).

The government, through the Australian Taxation Office, is trying to reinterpret this section so that only assets purchased from a government will be eligible for the deduction. This is a blatant attempt to deny legitimate deductibility to cooperatives that have entered into contracts in good faith. I will read a letter to UMT signed by the acting assistant commissioner of the legislative services branch of the Hobart division of the Australian Taxation Office. It is pleasing to see a member of the National Party in here at last listening to these comments about cooperatives.
Senator Herron interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The relevant part reads as follows:

BREAK.PARA: I would like to bring to your attention the ATO view that, having regard to the extrinsic material which accompanied the relevant legislation in 1930, the correct interpretation of paragraph 120(1)(c) is that the asset for which the loan is taken must be obtained from the government that is providing the loan.

I take Senator Herron's interjection that the National Party member who has just entered the chamber is an urban member of the National Party. Perhaps that reflects the tragedy of the National Party today in their lack of representation of rural and regional Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—I am taking the interjection by Senator Herron, your own colleague. Senator McGauran has a Collins Street office.

BREAK.PARA: While this interpretation is non-binding, it is also an implicit threat that the Australian Taxation Office will seek to deny tax deductibility for a loan where that loan is used for non-government asset purchases. Besides the fact that this attempts to overturn over 60 years of accepted tax practice, we see the government now trying to deny legitimate tax deductions to the rural sector. What is the National Party doing about this?

TALK.START.PARA: —We negotiated transition arrangements.

—Where is Mr Miles on this? Of course, he is 100 per cent behind the government and the Australian Taxation Office. Mr Miles is effectively attempting to deny UMT a deduction that it is legitimately entitled to and which it in good faith embarked upon on in its Spreyton development on the understanding that it would be entitled to this deduction. Mr Miles, regrettably, is inhibiting much needed investment on the north-west coast of Tasmania and in Tasmania in general. The north-west coast has one of the highest unemployment rates of any region in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The honourable member for Braddon fully supports the Australian Taxation Office in the attempt to deny the UMT cooperative a tax break that it is legitimately entitled to. From his comments in the House, Mr Miles appears to support the Taxation Office. Mr Miles should let it be known that he should be supporting the expansion plans of UMT or any other Tasmanian cooperative. But, regrettably, the provisions of this act and the attempt to reinterpret section 120(1)(c) may scuttle these developments.

The opposition will not be supporting the repeal of section 120(1)(c) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Furthermore, the opposition will be seeking an unequivocal statement from the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp)—I hope that it is unequivocal, unlike his answers to questions in this place—that section 120(1)(c) of the Income Tax Amendment Act allows for full deductibility for assets purchased from both government and non-government sources and that this statement supersedes any other statement to any contrary effect. In the absence of such a statement from the Assistant Treasurer, I foreshadow on behalf of the opposition an amendment that will state explicitly that section 120(1)(c) is to be interpreted so as to apply to the purchase of both government and non-government assets.

In conclusion, I note with deep regret that there are no National Party senators speaking on this piece of legislation. I hope that it does not reflect in their vote. I urge them to cross the floor and help prevent this attack on rural and regional cooperatives and rural and regional workers and farmers and their employment opportunities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Cook. Australian business must really be questioning their vote in the last election, believing that they would be voting for an environment of growth. All they have received from this government in the area of industry policy has been negative. Funding to Austrade and AusIndustry has been cut by $134 million. The computer bounty will be abandoned, while changes to syndication and tax concessions will reap no less than $2.2 billion out of industry research and development over the next four years.

SPEECH.PARA: The comparison is that carefully managed government intervention under Labor through targeted programs encouraged more investment in research and development and provided essential support to new and expanding exporters. This Liberal government's policies will inhibit growth in commercial investment in research and development that Australia has enjoyed over the last decade.

PARA.BREAK: Ten years ago, Australia was trailing the world in research investment. We were destined to a lower standard of living if our industrial base did not become more sophisticated. This was recognised. The Labor government sought, through a variety of assistance and incentive schemes, to turn around this nation's investment in research and development. In 1983, commercial invest ment was at 0.23 per cent of GDP. Through government intervention, it grew to 1.61 per cent in 1994-95. If that growth continued for another 10 years, it would have seen Australia move from an economy of assets to an economy of knowledge.

SPEECH.PARA: This government's policies place this development in jeopardy. All respected commentators have claimed that this government's changes to what has been described as one of our most successful industry policies will result in a stifling of the expansion and momentum that has been gained in research investment. A major plank of this policy is the 150 per cent tax concession on research and development expenditure. This government's intention to reduce that to 125 per cent constitutes nothing less than a halving of the incentive, because its value is in the percentage beyond the 100 per cent that would be available if the expenditure is written off as a normal expense. So this government has effectively halved the incentive to business to invest in this area.

The government intends to also abandon the successful syndication scheme that has brought researchers together with financial backers to produce not only some of the strategies and programs outlined by Senator Sherry but also leading edge technology which we need to take our economy into the future. As Senator Cook and Senator Sherry both outlined, the syndication scheme is the embodiment of the cooperative and an attack on the provisions can be interpreted in no other way than a fundamental handicapping of small business, particularly in rural and regional Australia.

Even if this government recognises the value of research and development to our economy, it is taking a complete gamble that there will still be businesses willing to invest in research, regardless of the level of government incentives. I am sure there will be some, but all predictions are that many investments will just not go ahead, or they will go overseas where the incentives are far more attractive. Recent surveys of companies already investing in this area have indicated that up to a quarter of respondents would be considering moving their research overseas.

BREAK.PARA: According to the Bureau of Industry Economics, the small business sector contributed almost $500 million to Australian research and development in 1993‐94 and spending in this area by small business has had a faster average annual growth rate than expenditure by big business. Indeed, the sector expenditure on research and development trebled in the decade from 1984. If syndication becomes a scheme of the past, then many small to medium sized enterprises will cease investment in research because they cannot share the financial risk by taking on a partner. The government's alternative Start program does not offer small to medium sized enterprises any capacity to advance through research and development. It is, therefore, a bill that I believe exposes the muddled, mixed up and scatter‐gun approach by this government to fostering small business growth and expansion. It will not assist anybody in the corporate sector unless they sit at the bigger end of town.

For a government which publicly commits the success of the national economy on the backs of small business, their policies are quite incredible.
