We are not talking about small enterprises like the local corner store whose investment in research probably would not get past a bit of community market research. There are a multitude of small enterprises who are technology and research driven in their quest to be nationally and internationally competitive. The information technology sector is one quite classic example of this.

Information technology, I believe, will be the major industry of the future. Australia really could be at the crest of the wave of this development—I have spoken about this in this place before. Revenue to Australia from information technology grew from less than $20 billion in 1990 to over $33 billion last year. Significantly, this is also an industry centred on dynamic, small enterprises.

The Australian Capital Territory and region is home to quite a vibrant information technology industry, dominated by small operators. Nationally, it is important to remember that 95 per cent of these businesses employ fewer than 20 people. Government incentive schemes meant that high risk ventures for small firms would be rewarded in some way, if not in product development. This government's industry policy will not severely hamper the development of this one sector that they are relying on so heavily to create jobs, from the micro to small and medium enterprises.

The minister for industry's recent attempts to secure further incentives for small business is another example of this government's patronising and narrow understanding. Yet we again see Mr Costello's juggernaut of fiscal contraction flatten Mr Moore's attempt to secure cabinet support for a Commonwealth procurement scheme that was promised by the coalition prior to the last election. According to press reports, this policy would have guaranteed at least 10 per cent of the Commonwealth procurement budget for small to medium enterprises and link the procurement process with local industry development. This would have been a sound policy that would have been applauded, certainly in my own region, the Canberra region, particularly having been starved of funds, with cuts to the public sector and a lack of innovative and forward looking policy for the national capital region.

This type of initiative could have alleviated some of the pain that is being felt by residents of the Australian Capital Territory and surrounding area, pain that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) publicly acknowledged yesterday. But again, the anti‐interventionist stance of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has won through and steered the government away from a policy that would have embodied sound industry development. A smart government would be encouraging the nation's intellectual capacity. This government is putting it to sleep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of what I would like to say has already been covered by my colleague Senator Sherry on cooperatives. So I am not going to take up a great deal of the Senate's time this evening, other than to share the outrage that has been raised by my colleague Senator Cook and note loudly and clearly that agrar ian socialism today has taken a giant step backwards—
—Did he say that?

—Yes—with the leading agrarian socialist not here to defend the cause of rural and regional Australia. Under those circumstances, with the absence of Senator Boswell, I will set down the path of doing so. What we have here—as I said yesterday in a question to the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp)—is a mean spirited affair where the government is whisking away minimal amounts of money from cooperatives which are the heart and the backbone of places such as Queensland and other states in Australia. Rural people are being exposed to the ravages of this government.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at what has brought this on one will see that it is the paranoia of the government to have a level playing field mentality in everything. Quite contrary to what I was told yesterday, there was no consultation in the process—and I will come to that later on. This is clearly borne out in the submissions that I will refer to later on.

But it is interesting to note that the amendment to section 120(1)(c) will affect some 17 major cooperatives throughout Queensland—including Golden Circle, Tully Sugar, Proserpine Sugar, Dairy Farmers Cooperative, Isis Sugar, Mossman Sugar, Dairyfields, Suncoast, Gold Macadamias, Darling Downs Bacon, Capilano Honey and so on. As one can see, the list covers rural and regional organisations in Queensland that will be hit by the changes to this very section. Of course, there are similar organisations in other parts of Australia that will also be hit by the changes.

As I said, Senator Sherry traversed a lot of the area before. I basically want to focus on the Queensland situation. It is interesting to note that these cooperatives are unique in their structures. They are invariably and totally owned by primary producers. The profit is turned back into the enterprise and also back into the community. It is not profit which is going into corporate profits, which will find its way into the pockets of those already well heeled or overseas; it is going back into the regional and rural communities in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: I want to refer to one thing in the report from the Senate Economics Legislation Committee—the suddenness of this decision by the government. At page 24, the second dot point on that page, which came from evidence deduced in the hearings, says:
The change is abrupt, particularly in light of the long history of the concession.
Then it goes into a section of quotes. It further says:

`The government has had the company and taxation laws in place over decades which have served to entrench the legal and cultural restrictions under which we operate and promoted the present cooperative structure. Section 120(1)(c) was introduced over 65 years ago and co‐operatives have based, in part, their company structures around the availability of this section and need time to efficiently and effectively reorganise to meet any changes required.'
So this came abruptly and is not out of character with what this government has done. Of course, what they have done is affect their business mates—quite callously in my view.

As I said, I do not want to take up a great deal of time. But I want to look at some of the problems and some of the situations in my state of Queensland. Since Australia's self-proclaimed leading agrarian socialist is not here, I will refer the Senate to a number of these submissions. It is worth while noting the submission of Capilano Honey Ltd to the Senate inquiry. They said:
Overnight and without prior warning the government signalled its intention to repeal the Section 120(1)(c) of the Tax Act with immediate effect.
So much for consultation! So much for going to their constituency to find out what they thought! They went on to say:

The government has failed to take into account the forward planning of businesses including present contractual commitments to both banks and suppliers. It has failed to realise the impossibility of changing a corporate structure overnight in order to access equity by other means.
The government will counter that by saying that there are transitional provisions. They, by my reckoning, do not go anywhere near far enough. The Capilano Honey submission goes on:
Our present plans of $7.5 million investment expenditure will reduce to approximately $4.5 million over a three year period.
This is as a result of these changes and shows the nature of these organisations. It goes on:
Capilano Honey Limited is a co-operative with more than 90% of its shareholders as beekeeper/suppliers. It is a medium sized business of $50 million turnover, of which half is export business.
So it is not just domestic business that is being affected by this government's decision; we are dealing with export business as well. The submission further states:
It is in the top 500 of Australia's private companies. It has around 100 direct employees and supports the beekeeping (apiarist) industry which employs many more.
Then we turn to Golden Circle. Golden Circle, in its submission to the same inquiry, noted that it:
. . . is a grower owned—
again grower owned—

unlisted public company which has operated the largest fruit and vegetable cannery in Australia since 1947. Employment at the Northgate operation varies from 750 to 1700 depending upon seasonal requirements.

The 750 shareholders are predominantly located in regional areas of south east Queensland, and as the only significant processor of pineapple in Australia, Golden Circle accounts for over 80% of total pineapple output.
These people have been completely deserted by the National Party. We then go on to have a look at what the Mossman Central Sugar Mill from North Queensland says:
The repeal of Section 120(1)(c) will mean a deferral of part of our program—
that is, their program of expansion—
Because of our structure traditional capital raising alternatives are not feasible.
Deferral will affect the Mill, cane growers, work force and others in the district.
The Section 120(1)(c) concession results in cost savings which become income which is distributed as cane bonuses to cane growers who pay tax at a higher rate than the Mill does on retained earnings.
So there is more of the constituency of the National Party left absolutely high and dry.
Then we go to the submission of the ISIS Central Sugar Mill. Again, its submission is an interesting indictment of this government. It says:
Section 120(1)(c) has been in place for over 60 years. ISIS Mill's forward planning and forward commitments assumed its retention. There has been no consultation—
I emphasise that—

on its repeal and I question the bureaucrats' and Government's understanding of the issues. The potential damage to ICIS Central Sugar Mill and the Australian economy by its repeal far outweighs the projected benefits contained in the budget.
As I said, it is mean-spirited. We are looking at $2 million in the first year, $4 million in the second year and $6 million in the third year.

Last but not least, it is worth looking at the Co‐operative Federation of Queensland. This organisation represents cooperative organisations. It is worth looking at what they had to say in their submission to the same inquiry. They said:

The rural communities in Queensland and Australia will see significant employment opportunities lost, business houses will suffer considerably with the reduced expenditure and the primary producers will suffer as a result of the decline in manufacturing capacity of the relevant processing plants.

The Co‐operative Federation of Queensland is most concerned that the Federal Government under the auspices of the competitive neutrality principles has taken a change in legislation without the knowledge of the damage it will be causing in rural communities or to the export income of Australia.
That to me is an indictment on this government and an indictment on the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you ever done for the bush?
—More than you. That submission shows a lack of consideration for the people in the bush—the real Australians, as they like to claim.

PARA.BREAK: I want to conclude by saying that, by removing the tax deduction, the government is significantly hampering the capacity for regional cooperatives to expand, value add and create jobs. The measure amounts to a new tax, in effect, on debt for primary production cooperatives. This is another kick in the teeth for regional Australia and National Party members who have stood by and allowed it to happen. As a result of the meas ure, many cooperatives, which are 100 per cent Australian owned, will have little option but to accept takeover offers from multinational companies which they have until now resisted. Australian jobs, investment in regional communities and export potential will all head offshore.

BREAK.PARA: It would be nice to see my colleagues from Queensland in here to defend the stance that they have taken on this issue. It is a sad day for Queensland when we see this action being foisted upon them by this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 is an omnibus bill. Like most omnibus bills, it has good measures and bad. There are several measures that we are happy to support and others we oppose. There are a number of amendments to this bill which have our support. On balance, we cannot support this bill. For the sake of several measures we consider important, including some of the tightening on research and development, I hope it can be amended in such a way as we can support it.

SPEECH.PARA: We can support the tax rebate for low income people, the rebatable annuities and several of the research and development measures. We are happy with the changes to infrastructure borrowing and the changes to cover tax exempt entities which become taxable. We are opposed to the change to the research and development deduction from 150 per cent to 125 per cent. We are opposed to the elimination of research syndication. We are opposed to the changes to cooperatives and the changes to the medical rebate. We are not happy with the treatment of prospectors.

I will try to cover the major issues in this bill now and our basic stance on some of the amendments in the hope that this will speed treatment in the committee stage. The area that has attracted by far the greatest attention is the treatment of research and development. I regret that the government did not heed the recommendation to cover this contentious and involved issue in a separate bill. I think it would have allowed the other measures to be dealt with far more easily and quickly.

PARA.BREAK: Before I go into this contentious area, I note that Senator Brown has circulated an amend ment to ask for a report on which companies receive research and development benefits, how much, for what and under which provisions. Such information would have proved useful at an earlier stage and could prove invaluable in the future. I will be interested to see the comments from the government in relation to this, but it certainly highlights a problem, which is that the Commonwealth is basically generating an expenditure through loss of revenue from a program specifically targeting commercial industry. Such a thing should be considered an expenditure and be as accountable as, for example, the diesel fuel rebate. We can get information on the rebate—who gets it and to what extent—but we cannot get similar exact information in relation to research and development programs. As a consequence, we get Treasury and the ministry coming to us and saying, `This is a rort; we can't tell you who, but it's happening.' Given the government's record on using hypothetical examples, I think we still have cause for suspicion.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the 150 per cent rebate, we have a number of problems with the 150 per cent research and development measures. What needs to happen is targeting rather than simply cutting the rate as a budgetary measure. They did not have the backbone to make the diesel fuel rebate cuts. We would rather see this tightened than the rate cut while maintaining the same loopholes.

We will support the opposition amendments on this. We will support the second reading amendment intended to demonstrate how the scheme could be tightened up. The answer to stop a scheme from being abused is not to making the abuse less expensive through decreasing the benefit; it is to tighten the definitions of eligibility for the scheme.

We will also support the opposition's committee stage amendment to oppose changing this scheme from 150 per cent to 125 per cent. Research and development is important. The government uses the rhetoric of the clever country when it suits it. Senator Alston did so yesterday in relation to an amendment to the Telstra sale bill. It was an amendment to end the exemption of commercial companies from state and territory law.

BREAK.PARA: The 150 per cent tax deduction is intended for use by companies that are doing their own research and development and are making enough income in their primary activity that a tax concession has meaning. Research and development is a real expense and a deduction is really effective only when there is income to offset it. If there are problems, such as companies buying other companies for their losses and tax credits in relation to R&D so that they gain a tax benefit without actually doing any R&D, they should be addressed directly. Changing the rate of the tax concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent does not address this problem.

I understand that the syndication provision was intended to provide venture capital for R&D in smaller start‐up companies. Venture capital is always a difficult thing to obtain. Various means have been tried. For several years, the government went into the business of picking winners and providing grants to those businesses with ideas that the government believed had high commercial promise and, later, had high commercial promise and an export orientation.

The government is not particularly good at picking what applications in industries will be successful. It is a tricky thing. Simply having a good idea or even a good product is not always enough. Venture capital is risk capital and a lot of these risks bear little fruit. The thing with venture capital is, where an investment does bear fruit, it might bear very good fruit in terms of successful businesses which involve a high level of value adding and substantially add to the breadth and depth of the economy as well as to the bottom line.

I have said that governments are not good at picking winners, but never is the private sector necessarily. However, both may be reasonably good at picking potential winners. The problem with venture capital is that, whenever the economic bean counters look at an entity, public or private, that provides venture capital, they come to the inevitable conclusion that such investment is risky. The result is almost always to eliminate venture capital or to try to make it a no-lose proposition by increasing its cost.

An example is the now dead managed investment companies, or MICs, which got government support to provide venture capital. After a while, the conservative accounting principle took over and most of the investment funding was put, if I recall correctly, into land speculation—not exactly what was meant by `venture capital'. Another example of a venture capital scheme was the Perth Stock Exchange's second board. This was also heavily abused and used speculatively on a principle similar to junk bonds with far less scrutiny over the quality of projects.

The syndication scheme gives an incentive to private sector companies to support research and development where the results of that research and development are not of direct productive benefit to the investors. This is almost the definition of a private sector venture capital scheme. Certainly, many of the people doing the research and development are doing projects that appear worth while. They fit the definition of potential winners.

Partners must register with the research and development board. It is not a case of simply making a tax claim. There is obviously scope for scrutiny over whether an R&D project is actually doing research and development. If the scope for abuse is too broad, it can be tightened. We would support such tightening and, indeed, will do so in respect of several areas such as the feedstock provisions.

Venture capital schemes to provide investment from the private sector are worth while. They are important to a clever country. If the government wants to change the way it supports the provision of venture capital, it should put forward its proposal legislatively rather than simply asking us to scrap what we have. I know the government wants to shift to a system of government grants and a kind of second board, but I would like to see details before I would be willing to axe the current system.

I now move to part 6 of schedule 1 dealing with cooperatives. Agricultural cooperatives—defined as those whose primary business relates to the acquisition of animals or commodities—are currently given some special deductions in relation to income used in the repayment of loans from government. These loans are provided to carry on its business or to acquire an asset. The special deduction is on top of the normal business deductions for expenses, which include the purchase of assets necessary for that business. This is, therefore, a double deduction in relation to such expenses.

The basis of the original policy is a recognition of the fact that agri‐pastoral cooperatives usually have a harder time getting funding from regular financial institutions and pay higher interest rates as they are at higher risk of default. I also think that there was some recognition that frequently the only way small farmers can effectively get a fair price in a market is to pool their products and sell them as a unit. To do so does not create massive advantages to small farmers, nor does it eliminate the risks and difficulties involved in farming. It just puts smaller farmers on a level with the larger and sometimes corporately owned farms.

There are a lot of reasons for supporting cooperatives. A small farmer has difficulty getting the same level of discount on agricultural inputs available to large farms. Larger buyers, such as supermarket chains, will often overlook small producers as not worth the trouble, preferring to deal with someone capable of providing produce at a higher volume. Cooperatives allow smaller farmers to act collectively like a big farm. Cooperatives in supporting smaller farmers generally assure that a lot more money goes into the local economy. Money made by cooperative members is generally spent locally.

Support of cooperatives is certainly in line with the Greens (WA) policies for support of more decentralised regional development, higher levels of self‐reliance, and small and medium sized locally owned businesses. That goes along with our ideas in terms of agri‐forestry and the ability to work that into better value adding in the future.

Of course some cooperatives engage in activities the Greens have problems with. For instance, cooperatives for growing cotton may use large quantities of pesticide and build weirs and dams that cause negative environmental effects. One could say the same of examples of some small business or some large businesses—this is not the way to deal with these issues.

Many farmers are, of course, concerned about land care. This is often specifically the case for many small family farms. One of the things that works most strongly against small farmers is the onerous nature of debt, which is perhaps the greatest single cause of unsustainable agricultural practice. Where it is a choice of trying to wring every dollar from the land to service a loan or farming sustainably and losing the farm, most farmers will farm intensively, even when they would rather not and know it is not in their long-term interest. For this reason alone, we would do what we could to support cooperatives, which improve profits and specifically those measures in relation to the repayment of loans. We do not propose to punish all cooperatives simply because some farmers may farm unsustainably.

We also note that recently the Taxation Office has been trying on a new interpretation of the act—to read 120(1)(c) as if the treatment were an `or'—to try to end the double deductions. Senator Sherry has amendments to clarify that the interpretation used so far—that is, that a double deduction applies—is the intended one. We will support Senator Sherry's amendments in this regard.

In relation to medical rebates, we have an amendment to oppose the changes to medical rebates. Currently, cumulative annual qualifying medical expenses which are above $1,000 attract a rebate. Qualifying expenses are those above expenses covered by Medicare. So if a treatment costs $200, and Medicare will pay $190 of that, the qualifying expense for the rebate is only $10. Given that Medicare covers much of most expenses, one needs to be getting considerable levels of treatment before one qualifies for the rebate.

The government now wants to increase the cumulative level before qualifying for a rebate to $1,500. This seems to be another cynical revenue earner, especially since government is also limiting increases in Medicare payments for medical services, which will push doctors away from bulk-billing and into partial fees above the Medicare component. The partial fees approach has the additional disadvantage that patients must pay up-front and then go to the Medicare office to get a partial refund. Bulk-billing allows the doctor to directly bill Medicare, and the patient does not have to pay.

This whole process simply makes medical treatment more expensive. As with tertiary education, we are increasingly going to a system where free universal services are being replaced with increasing levels of partial user-pays—a base coverage topped up with fees. This disadvantages the poorest while assuring that those better off get a substantial subsidy for their expenses. As fee components of cost increase, the income level for which a service is accessible increases. Ultimately, as with the current HECS regime, we start seeing a system of partial subsidy for a service that only the middle and upper income earners can easily afford and where the poorest are often entirely excluded. This should not be allowed to occur with health.
In relation to prospectors, we will support the Democrat amendments. This would recognise the retrospective aspects of this measure. I will speak more on this during the committee stage of the bill.

The opposition amendments are measures we support and believe address our concerns on research and development. I will leave further discussion to the committee stage, except to say that there is a very important role for the Senate to play in this regard. I hope that all senators are looking at how they can improve the bill. That is the role of the Senate. It is not being obstructive; it is enabling a bill which has some good measures to go through with those measures intact to allow the community concerns to be addressed. I certainly hope that happens with the support of all senators looking carefully at their responsibilities in this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief remarks in respect of the sale of mining rights provisions in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 and the Industry Research and Development Amendment Bill 1996. I will then make a few comments on the titanium industry as it affects my state.

BREAK.PARA: In my home state of Western Australia, the issue of mining, particularly in relation to the gold sector, is of substantial importance. I must initially state that changes to the current taxation arrangements for the gold sector do not surprise me, considering recent comments by the Western Australian Premier, Mr Court, that he would be happy to look at the issue of a gold tax.

The reasons for the change here, though, are somewhat incomprehensible. The main thrust of the argument is that the law regarding exemption was relevant to the 1940s and the 1950s, when minimal reserves were not considered adequate and there was a need to provide incentive for small prospectors to search for these particular minerals, as identified in the report. Apparently, the government now considers the level of mineral reserves in Australia to be adequate and, therefore, there is no need for the tax exemption as an incentive any longer.

This argument ignores two fundamental points. Firstly, the mining industry is just as ever an integral and essential part of the Australian economy. We as a nation cannot take this sector for granted. History illustrates that taking it for granted results in the low level of reserves that were the reason the tax exemption was introduced in the first place. Secondly, this change has the potential to destroy or, if not destroy, harm many communities and mining sectors in Western Australia. In Western Australia there are mining towns full of small prospectors and leaseholders, searching for minerals which can then be mined by major companies.

These changes will mean a number of consequences for small prospectors. They will be at a disadvantage when compared with big mining companies. The small prospectors will be taxed under the proposals for selling the mining rights, but the mining companies will not be able to claim a deduction for buying those rights. In the area of gold, most discoveries are made by small prospectors. The figures suggest that it is something in the order of over 95 per cent. These prospectors and their eventual success keep towns like Kalgoorlie and the eastern goldfields alive. These people should be encouraged rather than have their livelihood taken away from them.

The report by the committee also highlights several transitional problems. The changes are retrospective and will have the impact of placing upon small prospectors large tax bills for income accrued over a period of time through the increased value of a lease.

The government's responses are a few tax deductions. However, when compared to the new tax on income received from selling mining rights, any tax concessions will now be wiped out. Overall, many of the changes in the bill are supportable. However, that particular issue I have mentioned today and those mentioned by my colleagues will do much to destroy investment in our industries, research to improve our competitiveness, and incentive for small investors and prospectors to continue adding to the economy through mineral exploration. These changes will have both a national effect and a local effect in areas like regional Western Australia.

Finally, I turn to some correspondence I have received from the Australian titanium minerals industry. I presume it was received by other senators in this place. I normally would not have much regard for such a submission because they are usually self‐seeking. However, I was caught by the comments in this document to the effect that, during the past 10 years, Australia's titanium minerals industry has grown to be a $1.2 billion a year export earner on the strength of the extensive investment in downstream processing.

The investment has depended heavily on technology advances in processing titanium minerals to synthetic rutile and titanium dioxide pigment. Some of the research which that industry has engaged in is: improved efficiencies in synthetic rutile production, enhancement of synthetic rutile products, processing and reuse of synthetic rutile waste, energy efficiency and recycling in titanium dioxide production, reduction of titanium dioxide solid waste, reuse of titanium dioxide waste, and new extraction and process technology for waste zircon. All this work has had a major impact on the competitive position of the Australian titanium minerals industry. In fact, some of that research will be critical to the industry's future.

In that context, they make three comments which are particularly pertinent and should be put on the record. Firstly, they say that the proposed tax allowance cut from 150 per cent to 125 per cent effectively reduces the level of government support for individual projects by 50 per cent. It is pertinent to point out that most of the industry's projects have qualified for tax exemptions in the past or would be expected to qualify in the future. Removing government support for research will lead inevitably to the shelving or cancellation of sections of this work. It is worth noting also that some of the programs most at risk are those aimed at improving environmental management. Because these projects may not contribute to the industry's bottom line, they will be harder to justify from a commercial viewpoint.

The second complaint that should be placed on the record is the classification of some essential research investment as capital expenditure, ruling out any form of deductibility other than depreciation. This change is potentially crippling to research programs based on pilot plans or test facilities. The third complaint that needs to be addressed is that the new definitions of research possibly eliminate much of the work undertaken by mining and mineral processing companies. Their complaint is that the apparent emphasis in their report on experimental activities and high level risk does not favour the practical research and development programs needed for successful mineral processing.

It is useful to place those complaints on the record as they are affected by the government's proposals to amend the R&D concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent. In the interest of time, I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
Firstly I must point out that there are many aspects of this Bill which are supportable. By and large they will tighten up the processes and encourage more scrutiny in our industry policy.
However there are some significant proposals that will be disastrous for Australian industry and the mining sector.

Clearly from the outset it must be understood that this Bill is not what it should be about. As far as the Government is concerned it is a revenue raising Bill rather than a Bill dealing with research and development and our nation's industry policy

This Bill by the Government affects industry policy in this country through the main avenue of research and development. It also has harmful impact on the cooperative company provisions and the sale of mining rights provisions.
All of these areas will be affected by this Bill and will have a resulting impact on industry policy in Australia and our level of company investment.
This Government Bill is reflective of a broader Government approach to policy since it has taken Government.
The Howard government views the Research and Development incentives as a simple tax measure which can be reduced to help with what the government perceives as an outlay problem.
Of course this is typical of what is wrong with industry policy in Australia today. Rather than a tax measure the R&D tax rebate is an essential tool in industry policy.

To ignore this point, as the Government has done, is to place a lesser rating on industry policy and deter investment in Australia instead encouraging valuable investment dollars to be spent overseas.

There are a number of reasons the Government puts forward for the slashing of the R&D concession. None of them are based on a strategic view of industry policy, instead they are a result of the Government believing its own press in relation to Government outlays.

The first of the reasons for the need for the cut is that there has been an increasing usage of the concession, particularly by syndications. Rather than seeing this as companies investing in Australia and improving its efficiency and production through R&D, the Government sees it as a burden on its own fiscal position.

It appears unable to realise that the result of current work which results in R&D support will create greater opportunities for investment and jobs in Australia, far offsetting any outlays initially by the tax concession.

If we are to accept from the Government for example that the tiger nations of Asia have a much lower rate for R&D and therefore this is justification enough, we must be sure to examine fully how their system works.

In Malaysia for example, while it is true that the R&D concession is much lower than Australia, even with a shift to 125% rather than 150%, it is also true that it is part of a comprehensive industry policy, designed and targeted to have impact on certain areas

The proposal by this Government is not part of an overall industry plan. Rather it is a taxation measure designed to reduce Government outputs without any real thought or focus on its impact on industry.

The result of this change will be evident in the planning of industry in this country. Rather than current investors developing new initiatives here, they will now look to other nations which more actively and in a greater targeted way, increase research and development and the industry production spin offs which stem from that
It shows a lack of understanding in international industry policy to say that because these other nations have a reduced R&D tax concession, this is reason enough for Australia to do the same thing.
Rather though than just being based in poor theory there are also other structural problems with the Bill.
For example the issues of syndications, co-operatives and mining rights are all controversial and have resulted in much national attention.

This highlights a need to ensure that the issues are examined fully in the national interest rather than just being rammed through in the one Bill. Failure to do will result in supported measures being rejected with the aforementioned parts thus interfering with tax reform in areas where there is no disagreement.

If this were the only example of Government failure in industry policy it may be passed off as inexperience. However when one remembers the fiasco with the Ships and Book Bounty's, we see a pattern of no commitment to industry and a large comment to revenue raising by this Government.
I will now look at the impact of the changes in relation to each issue.
Firstly they are in blatant contrast to the election commitments of the Coalition. In the election documents they stated that they would,

"Maintain support for R&D through me 150% tax concession. We will re‐examine the impact of proposed changes to the definition of eligible R&D to the operation of the tax concession as an effective incentive for innovation."
This is a clear indication that the Coalition promised to maintain the 150% R&D tax concession There is also no mention of change to the rules affecting syndication.

The Majority Report of the committee argues that a 125% tax concession is a more effective level that 150%. In the same breath it admits that the reduction of 25% will result in less R&D. The two arguments can only be compatible if one accepts the premise of the Government's argument that a more effective R&D rate is one which results in less Government outlays.

However it does nothing for the effectiveness of industry policy and future investment. This is supported by the Industry Commission which heard all the arguments on why the R&D rate should be reduced.
After its hearing it rejected the arguments and itself argued for the retention of the 150% level.

These points I have just mentioned provide argument for the Opposition view that the Government has no mandate for these changes. There have been either no alternate views put forward since the Industry Commission to discredit these views and clear indication by the Government that they would keep the 150% level are reasons that they have no mandate to change the 150% level.

Senator Cook has previously used as a very good example of the effect of the changes, the case of Intact Tasmania. The result of the change on a company which has 30% of the world market in the held of aluminium speed ferry's will be to increase their costs by some 20%.
In my own state of Western Australia Ship Building companies are now receiving a double whammy by this Government. They are

being attacked through changes to the Ships Bounty and now they are being attacked through the R&D changes. Austel Ships which operates out of Fremantle must be wondering what it ever did to John Howard to deserve this kind of treatment.

Finally, in regard to the tax concession, it is worth making further note of the comments by Associate Professor Chris Peterson who is a past member of the Industry Research and Development board and chairman of the Tax Concession Committee on the Board.
He argued that the significance of the concession is two fold.

Firstly it plays a role in the strategic planning of our industries. The concession and its size is something which must now be factored into their thinking, whereas in the past these decisions were made by line managers on a case by case basis rather than with a strategic view.

Secondly the R&D concession contributes more to the national economy than it takes out through outlays. The strategic role of Australian industry in regard to research and development will become a financial burden for individual companies rather than an opportunity for Australia.

Of course some of the reasons behind the changes are even further cynical. In many ways the change to R&D is an excellent case study of the influence the National Party is able to exert over the Govern ment. In response to criticism in the `West Australian' newspaper about the cut in R&D assistance, the Science Minister made the following comment,
"It had to be reduced to 12% in the budget to enable retention of the diesel fuel rebate."

While we support the retention of the diesel fuel rebate, surely it is not something that should be used as an excuse for stopping research and development in our Industries. Unfortunate as the decision is, I accept that it was an excellent face saving exercise for the Deputy Prime Minister who was under considerable internal pressure at the time.
I will now turn to Syndications.
The Government has dealt poorly with this issue generally and disgracefully with regard to the individual companies concerned.

It would be naive of me to suggest that there is no one who tries to manipulate the syndication system for their own personal advantage. I am sure it goes on. However this is a problem with the checks and balances of the process rather than with the whole issue.

Indeed, many companies themselves have argued for tightening of the procedures to ensure `rorts' are stopped. We are not opposed to the prevention of rorting of the system. We are however opposed to the notion that all companies should pay and be disadvantaged by this.
Once again I will refer the Senate to the comments made by Associate Professor Chris Peterson. In his submission to the inquiry, he made the following point.

"It has been repeatedly stated that Syndication has not achieved ifs objective of stimulating R&D with a high prospect of commercialisation. This is false. Two professional economic studies have shown that Syndicated R&D is a unique and highly effective instrument for cheaply stimulating new R&D. The net benefit fo revenue foregone is over 50%."
The essential point being that the Government is destroying a valuable investment in our industry instead of working to tighten up the procedures through which this assistance is given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to endorse the points made by Senator Margetts. She has covered the field extremely well. The Australian Greens take the same point of view. She foreshadowed for me—and I thank her for that—the amendment to the motion that the report of the committee be adopted at the end of the day. The amendment would lead to information about the huge amount of money—currently $680 million per annum if you do not include the so‐called gravedigging provisions—that goes to the corporate sector as a result of the research and development tax concessions. It is effectively money which is given to the corporations. It is a benefit they get that other corporations do not. It is analogous to the diesel fuel rebate. It ought to be seen as government expenditure. But I know there is very great concern in the government about the amount of money that is being spent in this way and about the way in which it is being spent. That is why this part of the legislation is before the Senate tonight. I will be moving a return to order which would provide the Senate with information about the concessions: the name of each company, its registered address, a brief description of each research activity for which a concession is given, the total cost to government revenue of the concession for each research activity, and the cost of the components of the research activity, for example, the feedstock and the core technology.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope the Senate will support that amendment because whatever the outcome of the debate tonight, it would mean that we are much better informed when this issue comes up next time around—and it is going to. I expect we might even have the government considering whether or not it should support this amendment. I hope the government is looking closely at it. I do not know whether the government has got a crystal ball so that it knows whether this legislation will go through tonight. I think the government would be in a much stronger position to argue its case next time round if it had this information. After all, information is the currency of democracy. If we were enlightened, we would be in a much richer position to make a more democratic decision on this matter next time round.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not sure whether Senator Harradine wanted to speak or not. I understand he cannot be contacted at the moment, so I will proceed. Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 delivers on two more of the government's election promises: to provide a tax rebate for low income aged persons, and to allow equity investments in SMEs to be taxed under the CGT provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill also implements a number of 1996-97 budget announcements relating to the medical expenses rebate, the sale of mining rights, cooperatives and research and development. I understand that the opposition has a second reading amendment regarding research and development. The government will not be supporting that second reading amendment. That is not a surprise, I suspect, to this chamber.

We have announced a series of changes to the operation of R&D provisions in July and in the budget context. I also understand that the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens have amendments that they will move. I propose to make appropriate comments on the amendments at the relevant stages of the committee process. I am not even sure, at this stage, whether we have all the amendments on hand.

We will do a rapid stocktake but, as of three minutes ago, some amendments were still coming through. Of course, we will closely examine those amendments. Any cooperation that we can receive from senators around the chamber to make sure that we have a complete set of amendments, before we break for dinner, would be a great help so that we can order the process in a sensible way after the dinner break.

A number of speakers got up to speak on the issue of cooperatives. The government would like them to reconsider the views that they put forward. The paragraph in the tax act is an anomaly. It allows double deductions for capital expenditures. It is not available to all cooperatives. It is not available for borrowings other than from government. The paragraph is also an anachronism introduced in 1930—and that was referred to by some of the speakers—to facilitate the transfer of government infrastructure to relevant marketing cooperatives. That purpose is not relevant today.
The government recognises the importance of cooperatives and their important contribution to the primary production sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's why you are going to dud them.

—It is in recognition of that that the government has announced generous transitional arrangements, Senator, designed to ensure that the cooperatives make a smooth transition to the new tax arrangement.

BREAK.PARA: I understand that there may be some opposition to the increase in the medical expenses rebate. The budget announcement must be seen, I believe, as part of a package of measures made in the budget which encourages people to take out private health insurance. Both the private health insurance incentive and the Medicare surcharge are designed to encourage people to retain or take out private health insurance.

Senator Cook and other speakers spent a lot of time in their remarks talking about research and development. Let me reassure the Senate that the coalition government is maintaining a strong commitment to research and development—and that would not have been apparent, I would have to say, from the hyperbole that Senator Cook shared with the chamber. We have announced a reduction in the headline rate from 150 per cent to 125 per cent for R&D and for the abolition of syndication.

However, many overlook that total Commonwealth government support for R&D will remain in excess of $3.5 billion in 1996‐97. I have a few brief remarks on the R&D premium rate reduction from 150 per cent to 125 per cent. The benefit of the R&D tax concession comes mainly from the immediate or accelerated deduction of expenses, which would otherwise be allowed only over a longer period. By reducing the premium rates of deduction from the maximum of 150 per cent to a maximum of 125 per cent, this parliament will save revenue while keeping the same, or perhaps slightly greater, net economic benefits from the concession.

Moreover, at 125 per cent, the overall net economic gains from the concession are more likely to add something—true—even if there are errors in the data used and even if the economic conditions vary from those assumed in the established economic model. The detailed analytic results of this modelling were attached to the report of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee.

The government announced a new support for R&D, establishing the Start program. Under the Start program, the government will provide a flexible package of assistance totalling $340 million over the next four years to encourage large projects containing highly innovative or technically risky R&D. That has strong support for commercialisation from the private sector.

In addition, the government has maintained funding for CSIRO cooperative research centres and the technology support centre program. The election commitment to increase CSIRO's funding base by an additional $115 million over the next four years has been honoured. The government will fund CRCs at about $145 million in 1996, rising to $148 million in 1998‐99. To increase the effectiveness of R&D assistance, the government is focusing that assistance towards increased outlays on R&D and away from tax expenditures. I think that development received no recognition in many of the remarks which were made in the chamber.

Our decision to end syndication is a sound one. Syndicated R&D arrangements had become focused on tax minimisation rather than on the provision of genuine R&D. Technically, syndication arrangements provided significant taxation benefits for investors but limited direct assistance to researchers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 7.00 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will conclude my remarks. As I was saying, the tax benefits of syndicated R&D arrangements commonly exceeded the cost of R&D work still to be done. The main focus of syndicated arrangements was to provide payment to researchers for R&D already completed rather than for R&D still to be done.

BREAK.PARA: Syndicated R&D has been characterised by poor targeting. The government considers the best way to encourage genuine R&D is to provide assistance directly to researchers rather than to wealthy investors. In all R&D syndication, the cost to revenue is greater than the cost of any further R&D work carried out by the syndicate. In this sense, there is no `good' syndication to protect. This is no reflection on the quality of the R&D projects that might seek some of the spill‐over from the large tax benefits obtained by investors.

There will be an extensive committee debate on this. Apart from the amendments to be moved by the government, at this stage I understand there are 11 groups of amendments to be moved by the other parties in the chamber. I hope that we now have all those amendments on hand so that we can conduct an ordered process in the committee stage. Of course, we will be opposing the second reading amendment moved by Senator Cook.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Cook 's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

BREAK.PARA: Original question agreed to.
Bills read a second time.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens WA are opposed to schedule 1, part 3, page 7, lines 2 to 11. As we covered in our speech on the second reading, we are opposed to this measure. I will not repeat my argument other than to say that I do not believe it is appropriate to be increasing the cost of medical services. It is simply a revenue grabbing measure in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, am opposed to part 3 of schedule 1, as are the opposition and the Australian Democrats. I want to make a point here. Under part 3 of schedule 1, the government is attempting to require people to have spent $1,500 instead of $1,000 of non‐reimbursed medical expenses before getting a 20 per cent rebate on the excess.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that the government has put forward is that since people are now getting the benefit of the $100 single health insurance rebate it is all right to cut the value of the medical expenses rebate by $100. It sounds reasonable on the face of it. But, and it is a big but, families tend to have higher medical expenses and would be hit harder. Secondly, the medical expenses rebate covers uninsured expense. To that extent, taxpayers have not benefited from private health insurance.

The health funds have been putting up premiums. Self‐insurance needs to be treated no less generously than insurance premiums to ensure that the health funds are subjected to competitive pressures not to raise their premiums. I would have thought the government would have accepted that argument and would have rejected the argument of Treasury. Indeed, the first argument goes against the government's view of supporting families. This is anti-family or discriminatory against families.

A further reason is that the health insurance rebate will only be available to those in registered health funds. What about competitiveness that you are talking about all the time? Persons covered by commercial insurance arrangements—and here again is the heart of the government—including trauma benefits attached to life policies will get no benefit from the new health insurance rebate yet are denied recognition for a further $500 of medical expenses. It just does not make sense. I am using principles of the government's own policies.

In point of principle, all medical expenses in my view should be outright deductible in any case. Taxation is supposed to be based upon the ability to pay and a person who has to outlay money to achieve normal good health does not have the same ability to pay tax as a normal healthy taxpayer. That has been my view all along. It has also, incidentally, been my view on accumulated sick leave in respect of whether or not that ought to be cashed out.

My view has always been that you are either blessed with good health or you are not. In this particular case it seems to me that the principle that I have just espoused should apply. That might be too much for the government, but I do suggest to the government that it ought to have a very good look at this issue as to the question of the family, as to the question of competitiveness and as to the question of discrimination against those people who are not insured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to make a few notes before we finish on this particular item regarding medical expenses rebate. We will be opposing this part of the bill. We find that this is one of those nasty little pseudo savings items that are tucked away in the budget. At the moment the threshold is $1,000. This schedule increases it to $1,430 for 1996‐97 and then again to $1,500. This government has prided itself on this budget calling it family friendly. I would argue that this is a long way from that.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the people who are going to be worst affected by this measure we see that they are largely going to be people with chronic illnesses and people with disabilities. Even if people do have private insurance, where there is chronic illness in the family the expenses build up. I call again on the government to reconsider this measure. It is a saving of $25 million, yes, but look at whose pockets it is coming out of. It is coming out of the pockets of those who can least afford it.

We are not just talking about people who are in the situation where they are able to put their hand in their pocket for medical expenses. We are talking about families who fork out regularly for everything from pharmaceuticals to additional X‐rays. As you know, even if you are insured you cannot get the gap payment back between what many doctors charge and what is the official rebate. For these reasons, the Democrats oppose the increase in the threshold.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I should say that this was not a matter that the Senate Economics Legislation Committee inquired into. That committee inquired into research and development, cooperative companies and the sale of mining rights. This was not one of the issues on which we had a hearing. However, the position of the opposition is to support the amendment that has been moved. I do so by endorsing the remarks that senators in support of that amendment have already made. It does not require me to go back over the same ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We have listened to the arguments from Senator Harradine, Senator Lees and Senator Cook, and the general argument related to the family. I do not think one can doubt that this government is hugely committed to the family and assisting the family. In the generality of our policies, so much of our policies are devoted to assisting the family.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lees interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —One which you might like to take note of, Senator Lees, is the huge benefit to families which is now flowing through from the interest rate cuts. They have been variously calculated. At $100,000 per average mortgage, the assistance to the family is in the order of $188 a month. That is an enormous assistance to many Australian families. The family tax initiative is another huge benefit to families. Two million families will benefit and $1 billion will be expended in that particular policy, which will be effective from 1 January next year.

SPEECH.PARA: So, in the generality, I do not think there can be any doubt of the huge commitment of this government to the family and to the measures which are already assisting families. In relation to the announcement that we have made on the medical rebate, the budget must be seen as part of a package of measures which encourage people to take out private health insurance. Both the private health insurance incentive and the Medicare surcharge are designed to encourage people to retain and take out private health insurance.

The rebate is being retained at the rate of 20c in the dollar. Only medical expenses net of reimbursements from health funds qualify for the rebate. The increase in the threshold is consistent with other incentives announced in the budget for people to take out private health insurance.

We understand the great sympathy and support that senators have expressed for the family. I point out that we are already delivering great benefits to families, and that should be seen in the generality of the budget. This is a measure which we feel in that context is appropriate. Therefore, we will not be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Margetts.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That Schedule 1, part 3 stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Cook.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. My amendment under item 4 is a larger one and involves more time than Senator Cook's. It may be less messy if mine is moved first.
—I am quite happy to yield to Senator Murray.
—We are happy for the Democrat amendment to be brought forward. We understand that there has been some wording change in that amendment. Perhaps Senator Murray can indicate what that change is.
—The committee will now be deciding the amendment under item 4, which is Democrat amendment No. 2 on sheet 328.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 13, page 8 (lines 3 to 5), omit the item, substitute:

PARA.TAB: After "mineral" (first occurring), omit "being a person who is a bona fide prospector, that is to say—", insert:
Where:
(ia) those rights to mine were acquired by the person before 7.30 p.m., by legal time in the Australian Capital Territory, on 20 August 1996; and

(ib) the income was derived prior to 20 August 2001 and is less than or equal to the market value of those rights at 7.30 p.m., by legal time in the Australian Capital Territory, on 20 August 1996; and
(ic) the person, on or prior to 20 August 1996 and at the time the income was derived, was a bona fide prospector, that is to say—

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate the courtesy of both the chair and Senator Cook. I was not aware that we had changed our amendment. What I have before me is sheet 320, Nos 1 and 2.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a sheet which is headed 328.

—I now have it before me. Thank you for your discretion in the matter. I do not want to take up much time of the committee. I made some remarks on this matter in the second reading debate. We believe that this amendment is probably less retrospective and hurtful than Labor's. We seek to ensure that prospectors who work their claim and who now have an asset of value because of a find are not retrospectively made subject to tax.

SPEECH.PARA: It has three elements: that the right to mine was purchased before August 20; that the exempt income was derived in the next five years and was not more than the current market value of the mine; and that the person is a bona fide prospector. We say these are tight criteria, but they seek to ensure that prospectors who work their claim preserve the value of their asset as it is now an exempt income. I commend this amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This measure proposes an end to tax exemptions relating to the sale of mining leases by legitimate small prospectors. In their minority report of the committee looking into the issue, the opposition also supported this principle, as did the Democrats. They both noted that there were problems with the retrospective aspects under which the income is seen to have accrued and been effectively earned during the several years of exploration discovery, and ultimately finding a buyer and negotiating a sale. During that time, real expenses were generated, while the notional income was deferred—that income is only made at the time when the sale goes through.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Murray's amendment on behalf of Senator Kernot attempts to deal with the level of retrospectivity over which those expenses have occurred. We will support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats amendment has been fully explained. Let me say, though, that the way I read the Democrats amendment, it is not as all embracing as the amendment that I have put down on behalf of the opposition. That means that, while I will vote for the Democrats amendment, I will still seek leave to improve on it by moving mine at a later moment. This is a very important issue for this chamber. In particular, there are four Liberal Party senators who ought to focus on this debate very closely. They are Senator Campbell, Senator Panizza, Senator Eggleston and Senator Ellison. The reason they should focus on the debate is that they are all West ern Australian senators. This amendment relates basically to gold prospectors and prospectors for other designated minerals set out in the schedule to the act.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the gold prospecting in Australia goes on in Western Australia where there are some 4,000 registered prospectors. I am not sure to what extent there are registered prospectors elsewhere in Australia but, wherever they are, they will be affected.

This provision of the government seeks to deny those who are currently in possession of a prospect, disposing of that prospect after 31 December and realising the conditions on which they entered into the prospect in the first place. This is a complex case of retrospectivity.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that government senators are interjecting that it is not a case of retrospectivity. For the record, I say go to the record of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee hearing in which the prospectors association, an accountant on their behalf, and, indeed, a former Liberal Party senator in this chamber, former Senator Crichton‐Browne, gave evidence to the inquiry—and argued to the inquiry and through the inquiry to this Senate—that this is a retrospective taxing arrangement and should be chopped out.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me explain why it is retrospective in terms of its taxation and why Senators Campbell, Panizza, Eggleston and Ellison should cross the floor on this vote—they are senators elected by the State of Western Australia to this states house to represent the interests of that state. There is no interest group in Western Australia that commands more bipartisan support, I would contend, than the small prospector association. Indeed, the mining industry depends on the activity of the small prospectors to discover mineral deposits which would not otherwise be discovered. The reasoning that the government has put up—that this was appropriate in the 1940s and 1950s but is not appropriate any longer—is specious in the extreme. Why those four Liberal Party senators should cross the floor and vote for this amendment is, quite clearly, that they represent the constituents most affected here. Those constituents are wanting to see from their state senators a vote of support for their industry.

The mining industry is carried on the back of prospectors. Without the type of work that these people do, you would not discover the minerals in the first place. These are small people in terms of their business interests. There is an idea that a prospector is someone who will strike it lucky and make a fortune overnight. The truth is that most of these people are very moderately rewarded. They are not excessively wealthy. They are people who work in arduous circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where were you on the native title debate?

—I take your interjection, Senator Campbell, because you are one of the Western Australian senators who should cross the floor on this matter. If you are concerned about the plight of these prospectors, you should interject now that you will.
—Where were you talking to the prospectors during the native title debate?
—I notice that you do not interject that you will cross the floor. Therefore, I assume that you will not take an interest in this issue for these prospectors.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure was announced by the government in the budget on budget night. Up until then, the provision had stood the test of time over many years. In 1984, the Gutman inquiry came down with the recommendation that this provision stand, not be deleted. That was accepted by the then Treasurer, Paul Keating, and was then proposed to the Senate and supported by the Liberal and National parties.

There are good reasons in income tax principles why we should not allow any person to have an income which is untaxed. But there are no good reasons, in any principles to do with taxation, that the operation of those provisions should be retrospective. It should not be retrospective for this reason. When those small guys got out there and found these deposits, pegged and registered them, they did so against the present law. They had an expectation of remuneration or return in the present legal terms. They improved on their leases in order to try to sell them and make a return but, for whatever reason, on budget night they did not expect that this law would change and they were caught short.

The only sensible way the government can introduce this principle is by grandfathering in all of the existing leaseholders. A way of doing that is by the Democrat amendment that is before the chamber. I frankly think a better way of doing it is by the amendment that I have. But I am prepared to vote for the Democrat amendment. If that fails, obviously, mine would fail. But if it succeeds, I will move mine and test to see whether we can take this the full distance. But it is a retrospective measure. This is a question of putting the Western Australian Liberal senators in this chamber on trial. Are they going to stand up for their state or are they not?

TALK.START.PARA: —By leave of the Chair, I have now discovered what those missing words are. I would like to advise the Senate, if I may.
—You are about to indicate where there is a slight change.
—Yes. There is a change to sheet 328, item 2. There is a small change to subsection 13(ib) in the second line. Remove the words `any right' and substitute the words `those rights'.
—We will take it that it has been moved that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always trying to assist on these matters. My understanding is—if you could just turn to those lines—that your intention is for that part of the amendment to read:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the income was derived prior to 20 August 2001 and is less than or equal to the market value of those rights at 7.30 pm, by legal time . . .
I think that is the drafting. Are you happy with that drafting?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—He took out `any right'—
—Yes, but you have taken out more, Senator Kemp.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —What I have at the moment—and we will see whether Senator Murray agrees with this—is that (ib) should read:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . the income was derived prior to 20 August 2001 and is less than or equal to the market value of those rights at 7.30 pm, by legal time in the Australian Capital Territory. . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't it have to be held by the person?
—Yes, that is in a previous clause.
—I see.
—Senator Murray, is that correct?

—The amendment, I had agreed, was `those rights'. What the parliamentary secretary has done is taken out a double reference, as I understand it, because (ia) already states that the rights are those acquired by the person. Is that correct?
—Yes.
—Is the opposition happy to accept that?
—Yes.
—We will accept that you have moved it that way.
—Yes, I move it that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We suggested the removal of that because it could have created an ambiguity, I understand. The intention that you were seeking is now better expressed. For clarity's sake, we will support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a pity that the Western Australian election is on. We are going to be subjected, I think, during this evening to relentless attacks as people seek—particularly the Labor Party, I suspect; Senator Murray, I hope, will be more restrained—to gain any vote in a situation which does not look too good for them.

PARA.BREAK: But, Senator Cook, I do not plan to take up too much time on this amendment. This whole issue of retrospectivity was very well covered in the report of the Economics Legis lation Committee, chaired by my colleague Senator Ferguson.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very well chaired.
—Very well chaired; I will take that interjection. I suggest to those who wish to explore this issue and the responses further that they look at pages 28 and 29 of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I make, Senator Cook, is that you should send your speech off to mining interests to show that after 13 years of government—of really damaging the mining industries—you have at last decided to stand up and support them.
Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You attempt to score a political point. I will just respond by saying that the mining industry well knows what the Labor Party did to them over 13 years. They would treat your comments with the cynicism they so richly deserve. I wish to say that in relation to the amendment that has now been moved by Senator Murray, we will accept the changes and we will support that amendment.
—I just rise, as the mover of the amendment, to make absolutely sure on the record that it is understood that the rights referred to in (ib) follow from the rights expressed in (ia).
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the changed position of the government, although I do not necessarily welcome the poor way in which it was presented, with the greatest of respect.
—Great grace.

—I do not know about that, because I was the subject of an attack. But I am thick‐skinned enough not to worry about that because I am secure in the knowledge that my reputation as a former resource minister is high in the resource industry area. So whatever you might say does not affect me.

SPEECH.PARA: I do think this is a clear case of where the government has been forced to recognise the error of its ways and to remedy it. The holding of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee inquiry—and, indeed, the special one-hour hearing we had on this matter—may have been instrumental in forcing the government into that position. If it has been, that is a tick of approval to the Senate committee, the Senate committee system and the scrutiny that that system can deliver on complex issues like this. I actually suspect, however, that the real truth here is that the political circumstances conspired to force the government. But I will take the gain, whichever way it occurred.
Amendment agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Cook) negatived:
(1) Schedule 1, item 13, page 8 (lines 3 to 5), omit the item, substitute:
After "mineral" (first occurring), insert ", where those rights to mine were acquired by the person before 7.30 p.m., by legal time in the Australian Capital Territory, on 20 August 1996".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) oppose schedule 1, part 6. I have already spoken to this inadvertently. I am sure that there is obviously a great deal of support in the chamber in relation to cooperatives. I am happy to see whether we get majority support in the Senate on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not speak on the second reading debate because I wanted to save the time of the Senate. But I do want to make a few remarks on this particular issue. It is clear that it has a lot of support, because there are a number of amendments which are exactly the same. The proposal in a sense is simply that we will delete part 6 of schedule 1.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Democrat spokesperson on rural Australia, I absolutely relish the opportunity to speak to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). There is a section of this bill which clearly demonstrates this government's absolute stubbornness and lack of understanding of issues affecting the rural sector. This bill seeks to knock out a 200 per cent tax deduction for eligible farming cooperatives who take out government loans for capital expansion. The revenue involved in this measure is negligible in comparison to the total revenue of about $130 billion involved in all of the budget measures. This is a measure of about $6 million a year maximum.

The assistance that this measure gives to farmer owned companies in marketing and controlling the sale of their own products is immeasurable. Anyone with any knowledge of the rural sector knows the value of the cooperative movement to country Australia except, it would seem, the Howard government. I think I am probably prepared tonight—we will see how the vote goes—to exempt at least part of that government. It remains to be seen yet whether I can make that statement.

Some of Australia's most successful rural industries are cooperatives, particularly in Queensland, where the cooperative movement is one of the proud parts of the history of the National Party in Queensland, which as a government over many years has supported rural cooperatives. That is to their great credit. For many years I have strongly supported the cooperative movement because of the great benefits it brings.

Some of Australia's most successful rural industries are cooperatives, especially in Queensland. I will just name a couple: Mackay Sugar Co‐operative Association Ltd, Golden Circle, Capilano Honey Ltd and KR Darling Downs. If there are some Australian icons which we have seen disappear in recent years, there is certainly a Queensland icon that I do not want to see disappear—that is, Golden Circle pineapple juice. It is an absolute icon in Queensland. I am sure Senator Boswell would agree with me.

The tax deduction which this government seeks to remove allows farming cooperatives to engage in capital expansion and to contribute to regional development projects such as dams and bridges with other proven provincial bodies. It is not much but it indicates a commitment to supporting Australian farmers over huge corporate multinationals, which would be more likely to take over small farming cooperatives without this little bit of support from the taxpayer.

I have spoken to many of those cooperatives. I should perhaps name a few who came to see me, including the Queensland Farmers' Federation, David Woolrych from the South Burnett Meat Works Co‐operative Association Ltd, Tony Wagstaff from Golden Circle, Bryan Smith from the Dairyfields Co‐operative Association Ltd, Brian Raphael from the Macadamia Processing Co‐operative Ltd, and John Cameron, the executive officer of Australian Sugar Milling Co‐operatives. There is a lot of support for this particular measure and a lot of support to stop the government from removing the support for farming cooperatives.

The fact that this government wants to place small farmer cooperatives on the same so-called level playing field as the multinational agribusiness companies puts the lie to the claim that it cares about rural Australia. Any Australian living in a struggling country or provincial town has to be sceptical about a government that does not understand farmer cooperatives. Clearly, traditionally conservative voters are becoming sceptical, as Lex Buchanan of the Queensland Farmers' Federation said in a press statement this week. He said:

. . . the primary industries sector felt it had been neglected by the Coalition since it came to power in March . . . the conservative parties could not accept that they would always be the "natural" party for the bush.
There is a great deal of disillusionment, where the farmers are concerned, with the Coalition government.
I can't predict where people will vote in the future, but that disillusionment is becoming more and more apparent.

The Democrats, however, do understand the huge value of the farmers cooperative movement in Australia. That is why we move amendments and support others in moving this amendment to restore the tax deduction and why I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief remarks.
—Farmers' friend.
