—Yes, the farmers' friend. Thank you very much, Senator Campbell. I grew up on a dairy farm and my family sent their milk to the local cooperative, which ultimately became one of the biggest coopera tives in Victoria from merges with other cooperatives.

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone has understood—Senator Woodley has more than adequately explained this—the role of rural cooperatives. If we had proposed this change in the last 13 years of the Labor government, imagine what the cocky corner over there would have been doing—the National Party and rural members like Senator Panizza. They would have been screaming their heads off and saying that this was typical of a Labor government with no understanding of the bush.
Where are their voices now? They look very embarrassed. What is this measure doing? I understand it is saving about $6 million all up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Equity and fairness.

—A cooperative is about equity and sharing so that ordinary small farmers can have an advantage by having a chance to be in control of their own marketing operation. That is what it is about, Senator Short. That is equity and fairness.

SPEECH.PARA: Again this government, particularly this Treasurer (Mr Costello), is all about helping the big end of town—the big manufacturers, the big companies, the Nestle company. That is what he is on about. He will give them an infrastructure bond, but he will not give $6 million to rural cooperatives around Australia.

As I say, this is an astonishing move and there is embarrassed silence from the National Party. The old style Country Party under John McEwen would have burnt parliament down first, Ronnie, before he would have copped this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good old Black Jack!

—The old Black Jack would have been in here, threatening the coalition and pulling it apart if he saw his constituency being treated in this way by a city‐based slick lawyer who happens to be the Treasurer of Australia and who could not give a damn about anybody west of Kew in Melbourne. That is what is at odds on here.

SPEECH.PARA: Some slick adviser in the Treasury department said to him, `Here is a way we can sort out something. We will have a go at this.' If Treasury, who would not know a farm unless it fell on top of them, had put this idea up to us, we would have chucked it in the bin. The new naive Treasurer turns up and they sucker him in.

The former Assistant Treasurer shouted out to me before that this is an equity measure. That is how Treasury convinced them—the former Assistant Treasurer. He said that to take $6 million off rural cooperatives around Australia is an equity measure. I tell Senator Short that we are going to have a great old time around the bush in the next few months saying that the former Assistant Treasurer, who was at the ERC table when this measure was decided, believes that taking $6 million off rural cooperatives is equity. They might say that he got his comeuppance, he is no longer Assistant Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —You got yours. You are over there now, instead of here.

—Senator Ferguson, you come from the bush. Why are you not standing up defending rural cooperatives here for a measly $6 million? We will have a great old time on you, too, Senator Ferguson. I will see what they say in the Goodenia paper about you taking $6 million off the local rural cooperative.
—It would be a long time since you read it.

—I read it regularly, because it happens to be where my in‐laws come from. So I will be making more of this wonderful opportunity. I cannot believe this. If we had tried this little stunt, you would have been screaming your heads off to stop this. But, no, this new slick Treasurer, who has fallen for the three-card trick from his Treasury advisers, believes you can take $6 million off rural cooperatives.

SPEECH.PARA: We look forward to the vote. We look forward to seeing the National Party—this is your big chance, Senator Boswell—stand up and vote for their constituencies. Are you going to again be trampled on by this city slick Treasurer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I, Senator Sherry in particular, Senator Hogg, Senator Lundy and Senator Bishop spoke for the Labor Party in the second reading debate at some length on this tax bill. Senator Sherry dwelt at some length in his remarks on what the National Party Queensland senators—Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee—might do on this bill and called upon them to stand up for their state. I certainly hope that his call has not fallen on deaf ears.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not, therefore, intend to speak at length on the merit of this, because I have set that out in some detail on pages 48, 49 and 50 of my minority report in the Senate Economics Legislation Committee report. A couple of things are worth mentioning, though.

I understand that, if this amendment goes through, expansion plans by the Golden Circle Cannery in Brisbane will be put on hold and a number of workers whose jobs are there if the expansion goes ahead would face employment difficulties. I also understand that the same is true with United Milk in Tasmania. That is the largest cooperative in the state of Tasmania. It employs over 400 people and its sales last year were $170 million.

This measure is an important measure. In the evidence given to the inquiry, two things were said by the cooperatives themselves that bear repeating at this point. They said that the deduction, which the government is by this bill trying to close off, helps to compensate cooperatives for the disadvantages they face in raising capital for investment. They are not allowed to raise equity through the public share float. Their ability to raise capital for members is limited to the members, which means their ability to raise capital is limited to the fortunes of rural Australia. If rural Australia is doing it hard, their ability to raise capital is circumscribed, to a considerable extent, by virtue of that.

As well, they said that another disadvantage of the cooperative structure is that the members do not have access to dividend imputation. Thus, the concession is not a fair advantage for cooperatives, as the government says. It acts as compensation for other disadvantages. I am aware in the majority report, the report from government members, they did not accept those submissions.

BREAK.PARA: I wonder whether the minister might answer those two specific points that have been raised, because they are points on which a fair bit of this turns. The argument here is about a laudable form of cooperative enterprise in the area of rural cooperatives, particularly cooperatives that are marketing rural products—one of the few areas of the Australian food industry that is owned by Australians. I wonder whether the minister might comment directly on those two points raised by the cooperatives themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I just stress what a pity it is that we have an election next Saturday, because we have to put up with all this nonsense from the other side of the chamber, especially Senator Schacht and Senator Cook. Now they are pretending to be the farmers' friends. A moment ago Senator Schacht and Senator Cook were the miners' friends; now they are the farmers' friends. If you are the farmers' friends, why do you hold so few seats in rural and regional Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: Look at what you have just done in the last day. The Natural Heritage Trust Fund, which will be established as a result of the sale of Telstra, will deliver massive benefits to rural and regional Australia. The old farmers' friends over there—Senator Schacht and Senator Cook—utterly opposed it.

As the revegetation programs get going and as the river care programs get going, the farmers will remember how short lived were the farmers' friends on the other side of the chamber. The reason, Senator Schacht and Senator Cook, that you hold so few seats in rural and regional Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —We'll be holding a lot more after the next election.
—Order! I remind the chamber that the question before the chair is that part 6 stand as printed.
—They will remember what miserable friends you were when the crunch came. They will remember your high interest rates and your high taxes. So do not stand up here and pretend to be farmers' friends.

SPEECH.PARA: I announced the government's reasons for this initiative in my second reading speech. The effect of paragraph 120(1)(c) is that the marketing cooperative can claim an effective 200 per cent tax deduction for capital expenditure, full depreciation for the cost of the asset and deductions for capital repayments if the asset and the loan came from government.

The paragraph is an anomaly. It allows double deductions for capital expenditures. Double deductions can distort investment decisions by cooperatives as well as providing them with a competitive advantage in the marketplace. However, in recognising the important contribution, this touches on a point that Senator Cook raised. Having recognised the important contribution of cooperatives in the primary production sector, the government has announced transitional arrangements designed to ensure that cooperatives make a smooth transition to the new tax arrangement.

Senator Schacht got up to speak. I have to say that—and this is pretty hard to say, Senator—that was really one of your least effective contributions, even by your standards. Senator, do not tell me now, because we do not want you to take up any more time, but I wonder whether the cooperative that the senator's family sent its milk to could still use this double tax deduction. It would be interesting to see whether that is the case.

Only some tax cooperatives can access the double deduction. Senator Schacht, the advice that I have is that some of the largest area cooperatives in Victoria have not qualified for this double deduction for years. So the one that you got started may well not qualify, but it has not stopped their development, as you reminded us, nor their export drive. So I put it to you that the government believes this is an important measure and urges the chamber to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to add to the general jollity and excitement of this measure, but I do want to commend the chamber to my minority report on pages 61 and 62 of the report. There was something important which emerged from the hearings. The first was the nature of the evidence from the cooperatives concerned who appeared before the Senate Economics Legislation Committee hearing. They did feel a sense of betrayal and shock. They also indicated that it was a lesson to them to upgrade their lobbying and campaigning skills, because they had somewhat taken it for granted that the cooperative movement was not under the same kinds of rationalist pressures as the rest of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Arising out of that, I have a made a recommendation that the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee considers the examination of methods to develop and enhance the cooperative movement. I hope, Senator Boswell, that you will assist me in motivating that to the committee because, quite frankly, the cooperative movement does need a leg up in modern competitive Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to enter the debate at this stage and indicate that I will be opposing the government on this matter. I believe that I am also speaking for a large number of people who do support the government, as well as many other people who believe in the principle of cooperatives. One of my first encounters with cooperatives was in the mid‐1950s. Indeed, I spent a considerable amount of time in the mid‐1960s on committees inquiring into the role of cooperatives in the development of developing countries. Unfortunately, some of those went astray. But, in Australia, the principle which binds a lot of people together, including a lot of small farmers, is the cooperative movement. In fact, probably a number of the members of cooperatives often think of themselves as being the managing directors. They have that deep—
—A sense of ownership.

—Yes, that sense of ownership—exactly, Senator Woodley. That sense of ownership is very important for self‐esteem and also productivity. Taxation and cooperatives come together. This is because, for the past 66 years, cooperative companies which met the strict requirements of 90 per cent of their business being done with 90 per cent or more of their shareholders were eligible for deductions for principal repayments on borrowings from a government to acquire assets used in their business. In the August budget it was announced, of course, that deductions under 120(1)c would be removed from 7.30 on that night. This bill attempts to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Outside rural and regional Australia cooperatives are not well‐known. But they have an enormous effect on the economy of this country, particularly the economy of rural and regional Australia. Their importance is vital to the future of this country. Their major role is in Australian ownership of food processing companies and their integrated path from the primary producer to the processor, on to the domestic and international marketplace where they have played an enormous and successful part in export growth. Their massive infrastructure development plans for the future to ensure that Australian primary produce is processed for the international export market by Australian owned processors. The future plans of food processing cooperatives far exceed the plan of multinational companies which, unfortunately, now control 80 per cent of Australia's food processing industry.

Multinational food processors make great headlines when they are to invest millions a year in their Australian food processing companies. But cooperatives are the modest unsung achievers with definite plans for at least $½ billion of capital investment over the next five years. The necessary tool in this regard is this section which the government is seeking to excise from the tax legislation.

Cooperatives cover a diverse range of industries. This information is absolutely vital for consideration of this matter. I know Senator Boswell is very much involved in this. I am grateful for some of the information that he has given me on this particular matter. The cooperatives cover such diverse industries as sugar. There are not too many sugar plantations in Tasmania. I think most of them are up in Queensland. Forty two per cent of all sugar milling is done in cooperative mills. Of course, there is dairying, which is a very important industry in my state. UMT, as I think Senator Cook mentioned, is the biggest cooperative in my state. It is located largely on the north‐west coast. That is a success story in Australian primary industry. Rationalisation has resulted in a successful industry with massive export sales and a rapidly growing export market. There is the fruit industry with, as has been indicated, Golden Circle and Ardmona. Although there is important Australian processing ownership through meat cooperatives in the beef industry, it is increasingly being taken over by foreign countries.

I do not want to see advantages being given. The minister has indicated that there is double taxation. But let me say that cooperatives have not got access to capital from where multinationals get capital. Indeed, there is an imputation question; that is a very important matter. I would also like to ask the minister about the imputation that has been referred to by Senator Cook. I think Senator Cook asked the minister a question about that matter. I would be very interested to hear the response from the minister. As I understand it, franking does not apply to cooperatives—unlike companies. Franking credits that would normally go to companies go as a direct benefit to Treasury. They are calculated by accountants as literally millions of dollars.

It needs to be understood by all concerned that cooperatives are not like corporations. They are prevented by law from raising capital because of the restrictions on the numbers of shares members can hold. They often must keep costly inventories of their members' seasonal produce. Treasury can cook up these particular ideas, but they have lost the plot, frankly. They have lost contact with the real world if they are putting this to ministers. I believe, frankly, the committee should reject this proposition.

I know there is a subsequent measure. Finally, I ask the minister one point, if he would not mind responding to this. Is it a fact that there is nothing to stop a state government and a cooperative achieving the same result—if you are successful in this area—by entering into an agreement to share gross revenues until the amount subscribed by the government is recovered? This income would be tax exempt as the state government is tax exempt, and would achieve the same result as a deduction. Is that or is that not the case? Or are you thinking of levying taxation on state governments?

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope this will assist in the conclusion of this particular section. The question was asked about franking. A cooperative cannot attach franking credits that are deductible to distributions to members. That does not limit the franking of distributions that are not deductible. That is the advice I have received on the franking issue, Senator. I am not sure that I can add too much in relation to that last question.
—I would like you to take that on notice and, as a matter of interest, at some time give me a response to it.
—We are always happy to take those things on notice from you, Senator Harradine.
—The question is that schedule 1, part 6 stand as printed.

PARA.TAB: Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 15 (after line 9), at the end of the Schedule, add:
Add:
(3) It is hereby declared to be the intention of the Parliament that paragraph (1)(c) applies to loans taken out for the purpose of acquiring assets from:

PARA.TAB: (a) government sources; or
(b) non‐government sources.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an amendment to part 6A, relating to deductions allowable to cooperative companies. It seeks to clarify the meaning of the act. We have just defeated the government's amendment to the bill relating to cooperative companies. Mr Howard, representing the Co‐operative Council of Australia and the Cooperative Federation of Queensland, in his opening summation to the hearing referred to the interpretation that is being placed on the act and sought clarification of that interpretation. His words were:
As a point of clarification, I draw attention to the section of the act that refers to acquisition of assets, which quite clearly says `or'—it can be from the government `or' somewhere else.
The point is clear enough. It is a question of making explicit the meaning of the act, because it seems that the act is being interpreted differently.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate, we are happy to support this clarification.
—The Australian Democrats advise that they will be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —It should not be necessary for the parliament to have this virtual declaration in the legislation. But I acknowledge that Senator Cook has considered it desirable and that the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Greens have considered it desirable that this go into the act. I will be supporting it.

SPEECH.PARA: All I say is that it should not be necessary. It is necessary only because the Australian tax office has put forward outrageous interpretations of paragraph 120(1)(c), which says that a cooperative must acquire assets from a government in order to write off a loan from the government. That is what ATO says paragraph 120(1)(c) means. But that view clearly is wrong.

Senator Cook wants to have this declaratory statement of the law to bind the Australian Taxation Office. We should not have to do this but, in view of the history of this, we perhaps need to in this case. It is a shot across the bow, might I say, of those responsible for the sorts of interpretations that cooperatives have been faced with. I support the amendment that has been moved by Senator Cook. I trust that it will be carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support the opposition's amendment. The second reading speech shows that the parliament intended that the deduction be allowed only where assets were being acquired from the government. The speech stated that the concession was to be provided to certain cooperatives `which have acquired assets from a Commonwealth or state government either by direct loan of funds from that government or by taking over assets created by it'.

PARA.BREAK: In a sense, the amendment moved by Senator Cook seeks to retrospectively amend the section. The interpretation and the admin istration of tax law, including paragraph 120(1)(c), is a matter for the tax office. Nothing the government has proposed in the bill affects the interpretation of paragraph 120(1)(c), and we do not support the opposition's attempts to amend it.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Cook's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 15 (after line 12), at the end of the Schedule, add:
Omit "(other than the amounts specified in column 3 of the table in subsection 159J(2) in respect of a dependant included in class 3 or 4)".
Omit "or class 4".
Omit "Where, but for subsection (1A), a taxpayer would be", substitute "Where a taxpayer is or, but for subsection 1A, would be".
Repeal the Table, substitute:

ROW.ENTRY: Child less than 18 years of age(not being a student)
In respect of one such child$376In respect of each other such child$282
Parent of the taxpayer or of the taxpayer's spouse

BREAK.PARA: This amendment is in the context of what occurred this morning when the disallowance motion on the Austudy regulations was not adopted. There is an argument, I suppose, that the government made a budget decision and the Senate decided to consider a motion put forward to disallow the regulations to increase the age for independent status under Austudy from 22 to 25 years.

It can be argued that that was a budget measure and perhaps it should not have been overturned by a disallowance motion. However, I voted for the disallowance motion because I was of the view that the regulations increasing the age for independent status under Austudy from 22 to 25 presupposed that the parents of the student would be footing the bill. That was the government's assumption, but it is not the taxation department's assumption. The taxation department gives absolutely no recognition at all for the expenditure that is made for students who would thus have lost out their entitlement to independent Austudy.

Following the government's therefore successful raising of the age for independent status under Austudy from 22 to 25, students between those ages and indeed between 18 and 25 are now means tested for Austudy on the basis of parental income. Given that the government expects parents to support students from the age of 18 to 25, I believe it is time to restore the student tax rebate in the tax system.

You will recall, Mr Chairman, that I moved a motion at the end of the debate on the increase of HECS that there should be a recognition in the taxation system that self-education expenses by way of HECS payments should attract a tax deduction. You and I, Mr Chairman, voted for that. Unfortunately, on that occasion we were not successful in that particular effort.

There may be a statement emanating from Treasury that the amendment to restore the student tax rebate involves double dipping, but it does not. If a student does get Austudy the available dependent rebate for parents is reduced by $1 for every $4 of income over $282 including Austudy received by students.

If a student were on full Austudy, the parents would have little or no entitlement to the rebate. It may be noted that the wording of the rebate provisions dates back many years, and the separate net income test goes back further. It was applied to the dependent deductions under the pre‐1970s Liberal governments. I say that quite deliberately to the government, if it is holding itself out as a family positive government.

The government's family tax initiatives, though touted as $1,000 per child, amount to a $200 tax rebate. In any event, it is limited to children under the age of 16 and students up to 18 years of age only. So there is this area between 18 and 25—which was 22—which needs to be filled. When questioned on the issue of the family tax initiative in the Senate, the government admitted that the family tax threshold is not available for students over 18 years. The rebate for a student aged 18 to 25 is set at $1,000 and indexed to be equal, in my proposal before the chamber, to the without child level of the spouse rebate. This is considered appropriate as both classes of persons are adult dependents. They are over 18 years of age.

I believe that this proposition is a matter of clear equity. I believe that fairness should apply. It would be a proper acknowledgment of the fact that the government is saying that the parents of those students whose Austudy payments are virtually cut out or minimised can pick up the tab. That can be quite expensive, particularly in the case of families with a number of dependent children who are students. I mean students who are 18 years of age and over.

I would like to explain to honourable senators that paragraph 159HA(7)(a) is intended to omit other than the amount specified in column 3 of the table and, in subsection 159J(2) in respect of a dependent included in class 3 or 4, it deals with the indexation of the rebate.

The amendment to subsection 159J(1A), which states `omit or class 4', is the operative provision in this amendment that restores the rebate for students aged 18 to 25 years. Subsection 159A(1B) omits the words `where but for subsection 1A' and substitutes `where a taxpayer is or but for subsection 1A would be' and protects the higher with child spouse rebate for those with students aged 18 to 25. That is quite natural, because they are in fact adults. The amendments to subsection 159J(2) set the actual rebate at $1,000 for students aged 18 to 25 years of age. The other measures in that particular clause are self‐explanatory. So I commend to the committee the adoption of this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —For those of us who are concerned about the overall impact of government legislation at the moment, there is a little saving grace in what Senator Harradine puts forward. But I cannot allow the opportunity to go past without saying that it is very disappointing to have this amendment put forward this afternoon when this morning the vote in the place was to cut children who are not in the family, who are outside very often because they have been excluded through circumstances beyond their own control, by $300 million in students incidentals allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that Senator Harradine has a constant pattern of giving some break to those people who are lucky enough to be within the family fold, as we are seeing now, and, on the other hand, of cutting out assistance from those who are unfortunate enough not to have that circumstance. I do not know what the motivation is. I do not know whether it is to subtly say that we might force them back into circumstances out of which they have come. It seems to be a very limited magnanimity towards people who are struggling to get an education.

I know that Senator Harradine voted for the government's overall cuts in education and the increase in HECS fees. The disincentive that we argued at the time involved poorer people in our community being able to go on and get a tertiary education. He gave some ameliorating amendment for those people lucky enough to be within the home as a salve to the wider wound of those cuts. Tonight we are getting a bit of the same.

It would be good for Senator Harradine to reconsider the circumstances of those people who are not lucky enough to be in a traditional home with the support of traditionally caring parents in what has become a very lucky circumstance and is being loaded in that direction by this sort of amendment. It does play on the good nature of people who are trying to consider the wider community and not the narrow view that Senator Harradine has.

I just cannot understand why in the morning Senator Harradine would vote against a $300 allowance to school kids who do not have family backup to try to help them get back into a secondary education, go on to a tertiary education and get through against all the odds of the education stream into a career and fulfilment while in the evening he puts forward an amendment like this, which most of the good natured people on this side of the parliament will at least be attracted to support. It is inconsistent and unfair to those people who are down on their luck in our community. I fail to see the magnanimity, to put the most modest word I can on it, that is in it for those people trying to get an education who are in harder circumstances than many of us in this place might have faced in our time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support this amendment. It is a logical extension of what we regard as the illogical decision of this government to treat intelligent 25-year-old adults still at university as children. If it is good enough for Austudy to say that a 25-year-old in the top 10 per cent of intellectual achievement is a child and a dependant, obviously the tax act should reflect it.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment will give families a maximum of $19 per week in tax rebates paid to the parents, not the children, because this government views a 25-year-old adult as not capable of running their own financial affairs. That $19 per week is roughly equivalent to the basic family allowance payable to students up to the age of 18 at school and the government's new family tax payment. For consistency of policy, the government should support this.

If we also sought to pick up the parenting allowance as well, the payment should rise to $1,700 per year. But $1,000 has a logic to it, so we will support it. It is well short of the $128 per week which a student would get on full Austudy. It is well short of a decent social policy that recognises that a 25-year-old adult smart enough to win a place at a university should no longer be treated like a child. But this government has chosen to put in place an illogical and discriminatory policy on Austudy. They should complete the circle by ensuring that the tax system reflects the policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There is obviously some logic in this amendment if you follow the fact that this morning there was a vote related to what I call compulsory families. It made sure that students cannot get independent allowances until they are 25. I was pleased to see the pressure put on by various members of the Senate, including the Greens and the Democrats. It helped to get some change in the government's legislation. It was very unclear until this morning that that change had occurred to make sure that it did not go up to the age of 31, which was the original decision.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of these compulsory families, we are left with very few alternatives but to support measures such as these, which give some recognition of the cost to families who may have to support an adult student up to the age of 25 who has no means of getting independent Austudy. It is very regrettable that we need to support such an amendment. A fairer go for students would have been much better from the government. It is a pity that this morning's vote was not supported by the majority of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the principle of what Senator Harradine is trying to do, although my advice is that we do not find the words necessarily precise to meet that objective. However, we will vote for the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a brief chance to look at the amendment. As Senator Cook said, the initial advice is that there are some drafting difficulties. One view put to me—we are having this checked out—is that the second part, subsection 159J(1A), which omits `or class 4', could have the effect of retrospectively reinstating student rebates back to 30 June 1976. It is very dangerous.
—That's okay for me.

—All these things, as the senators know, do have cost effects and implications. I think I am correct in saying that it is not possible to give an accurate costing on this. Certainly we would need time to properly assess those aspects, but I think over time the costs may well be quite substantial. We note Senator Harradine's views relating to the appropriateness of tax rebates for students but, given some of the problems I have just raised with the chamber, the government does not consider this the appropriate place to move these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I will certainly draw the senator's comments to the attention of the Treasurer. We do think that these amendments do not directly relate to the provisions in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996. However, we note your comments. We consider this amendment would be best considered in the context of other measures provided by the government to assist families. You mentioned in your remarks the substantial assistance that the government is giving to families through the family tax initiative.

We appreciate your bringing this issue to our attention. We would need far more time to carefully assess this, particularly the implications to the revenue and also, of course, the issue of drafting the matters that you have raised. In the context of what I have said, the government will not be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine is probably going to suggest this. It might well be possible for the government to use their amazing talents, or for other people to use their amazing talents, to deal with those wording problems, so that we will not inadvertently create a problem with retrospectivity back until 1976. I think it is possible, with the combined intellect available in this building, to do that. Perhaps we can adjourn this vote until someone has a chance to look at it.

—I thank the committee. Could I thank also the minister for indicating that it could be drawn to the attention of the Treasurer. It would probably concentrate everybody's minds and it would certainly be drawn to the Treasurer's attention were the amendments adopted by the Senate. Because of amendments to the legislation, the legislation will need to go back to the House of Representatives. No doubt the Treasurer would take some passing interest in what the Senate has done in respect of this measure—not only this one but other measures. If there were a problem, as envisaged by you, or if there were other problems, no doubt our attention would be drawn to them by the House of Representatives in pretty quick order tomorrow.
—Senator Harradine, would you like the issue to be postponed to a later hour tonight or tomorrow?

—No, that is not what I was saying. Clearly, in plain English, I would have thought that it might be desirable for the matter to be voted upon, adopted and, if there were some difficulties along the way, no doubt the Treasurer would draw the attention of the House of Representatives to those difficulties and we would receive the message.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Harradine's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Kernot, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Schedule 3, page 41 (after line 35), after item 6, insert:
After "DAA", insert "up to 8.30 p.m., by legal time in the Australian Capital Territory, on 30 December 1996".

This is a small amendment with a large effect. It seeks to close down the infrastructure borrowing tax concession from the end of this year. While we will support the tightening measures which the government proposes in item 6, they really are tinkering around the edges of the fundamental issue. The fundamental issue is that the infrastructure borrowing tax concession is, to use the government's terminology, a rort. It is poorly targeted, open to abuse, excessively generous and completely unnecessary.

The Australian Council for Infrastructure Development told the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation that there is no shortage of funds for infrastructure investment and there just are not enough projects. So why prop it up with a $200 million a year gift to the financiers and bankers who set up these finance schemes? Why indeed.

The government has received three reports in the last 18 months telling them that the infrastructure borrowing tax concession is a waste of money. The Economic Planning Advisory Commission private sector infrastructure task force said that the scheme was not needed and there was no tax disincentive for investment in infrastructure.

In June the government's own National Commission of Audit recommended that the scheme needed to be reviewed because it did not seem to be necessary. Earlier this week the Senate superannuation committee, in a unanimous report, called on the government to review the purpose and operation of the concessions.

It is a waste of money. Treasurer Costello has vowed as recently as question time today to work to stop the tax system being riddled and rorted. Well, here is one of his riddles and rorts. Let's get rid of it and let's save $200 million next financial year. I urge the Senate to support Senator Kernot's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot's amendment No. 4 seeks to abolish the taxation infrastructure borrowings concession provisions in this bill. I remind the Senate that the provisions seek to tighten the infrastructure concession in relation to certain tax aggressive schemes that seek a double benefit from the concession. This represents the government's position to keep its integrity intact by moving against the misuse of this concession. The government does not support Senator Kernot's amendment for that reason.

—I was doing something else at the time, so perhaps Senator Kemp should explain something. There was a potential problem with retrospectivity here. Was that what you were just explaining? Did I miss that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not mention the retrospectivity issue. I said that this amendment that was moved on behalf of Senator Kernot seeks to abolish the taxation infrastructure borrowings concessions. I pointed out to the Senate that the provisions in the bill seek to tighten the infrastructure concession in relation to certain aggressive schemes that seek a double benefit from the concession.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, we are seeking to maintain the integrity of the concession by moving against what we see as misuse of the concession. The government will not be supporting Senator Kernot's amendment. I urge other senators to oppose it as well.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition intends to oppose division 1, part 1 of schedule 4—one of the key features of this bill. This is the proposal that deals with the reduction of the 150 per cent tax incentive for research and development to 125 per cent. In my speech on the second reading debate I provided a great deal of detail about this amendment. I do not need to traverse that ground now. What I do need to say is that this was clearly spelt out in the government's election policy as a commitment by the then opposition, were it to be elected as government, to retain the 150 per cent tax incentive. What we have here is an explicit and blatant breach of that election undertaking.

SPEECH.PARA: If opposition in this chamber were to be in the majority against this change that the government seeks, this chamber would be enforcing the mandate that the government sought from the electorate. There is a certain justification in that when we find that the government has claimed a mandate for a number of things in this chamber, most recently the Telstra bill, earlier the industrial relations bill, and so on. They have a mandate for 150 per cent. That is what they sought and that is what they got, but they are now wanting to break that.

The second point I make is that Australia, in terms of the OECD nations of the world—there are 24 of them—is ranked 17th or 19th in the amount of private sector expenditure on research and development. This provision is in the act in order to encourage more research and development in Australia. Commonly, it is understood that countries with a high commitment to research and development have greater prospects for employment and economic growth in the future than countries with less commitment to research and development.

We would be voting, if we voted in opposition to this government measure, to improve the economic prospects for young Australians looking for employment in intelligent and skilled work, as well as to back companies to do more R&D and help grow the economy and enable it to become more competitive, given that the economy is now mostly a globalised economy.

This is one of the absolute cornerstones of this bill and it is one of the areas in which the Senate inquiry received a lot of submissions. Perhaps I should turn to one of them that may, Mr Temporary Chairman—interestingly, since you are in the chair—be of some interest directly to you because you are a Tasmanian.

During the inquiry, Incat, the Tasmanian manufacturers of fast aluminium ferries, made a quite comprehensive submission as to why they have achieved world-class manufacture in ferries, how they have stolen a march on more developed manufacturers in the world and why winning that lead and maintaining it requires them to spend a lot of money on research and development.

Incat is a research and development intensive company. It has succeeded in growing from quite a small concern to now a very large one because of the amount of money that it spends on research and development. What did it say to the inquiry? Let me quote its very words:

The decrease in the taxation concession from 150% to 125% means that each dollar incurred on R&D will now cost the company 55 cents where it previously cost 46 cents. This represents a 20% increase in costs. Taking into account the eligible expenditure incurred for 1996 the nett cost to the company will rise by $72,000 to $440,000. This increase equates to the salary of one of our R&D personnel and has a severe impact on future R&D programs.
That is a leading Australian company, a company that has helped penetrate the world ferry market so that now Australian fast ferries command 30 per cent of that market—

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty-three per cent.

—I will stand corrected. The exports of this commodity, fast ferries, is valued at half a billion dollars per annum. It is on the same level of export value as the entire wine exports from Australia is, but this industry does not receive the same international recognition for the reason that its market is entirely overseas. You do not have consumers of its product in Australia like you do of the wine industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, it is the only area of complex sophisticated technology where Australia has a world marketing lead. Why do we have it? We have it because this is a company that has done the hard yards and spent funds on research and development. It says that, by making this change, its costs will increase. It will be able to do less R&D than it would have done before and, under another bill due to come up next year, we know it will have a nine per cent increase in costs imposed on it by the abolition of the ships bounty. We also know that there are other changes to things on which it depends—Ausindustry, Austrade, a number of other market development grant schemes, like the EMDG scheme, and so on.

That is one example. It is a pertinent one for this debate. This example can be replicated across industry. If Australia is to maintain a foothold in the area of pharmaceuticals and in the area of telecommunications and information technology, the fastest growing industry in the world, it has to have an R&D rich investment, otherwise the majors will outrun us, they will create the technology which will dominate the market and we will have to conform our technology to their needs.

BREAK.PARA: If Australia does not hold its head up in that international technology race, then we will import foreign product from overseas and, if we do, the current account will blow sky‐high through the roof and the problems for the budget will be exacerbated beyond all belief. This is one of the few measures that you can say, in a post-protectionist society—Australia having phased down its tariffs to globalise its economy and be competitive in the world—is World Trade Organisation consistent.

One of the reasons why the ferry industry is upset is that the OECD agreement, which would phase down subsidies to this industry sector worldwide, has been blocked in the US Senate. It has now been thrown out and it is unlikely to be approved by the United States, which means that the other countries in the world—the Scandinavians and the north Asians, the Japanese and Koreans—will not sign it either. So this area of ship manufacture is going to become one of intense trade conflict in the world.

All other nations provide assistance of considerable value to their industries for research and development. We have a world lead in this particular industry. I can do nothing more than refer again to the words of Bob Clifford, the Chief Executive of Incat, when he said that his company would be put at a severe disadvantage if the R&D concession was cut back.

As I say, that is a visible and better known example. There are equally convincing examples elsewhere in all other industry sectors, too. The committee was inundated with examples of fine research and development, which will now not be as likely to be conducted in Australia. Some of it will be conducted overseas. We will lose our marketing edge. I implore the Senate to vote against this measure of the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have covered this issue at length in my speech on the second reading debate. In the interest of time, I will not repeat that argument. I support the opposition amendment and oppose this government measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak at length. I spoke extensively in the second reading debate. I merely wish to say to the government that, in my opinion, this measure is as large a betrayal to Australia as the cooperative cuts were to the farmers. If there is any one measure in this bill that you should not allow through, this would be it.

SPEECH.PARA: I use the word `betrayal' rightly. The condemnation of this measure has been almost universal. As I have said in the second reading debate, I am quite convinced that it is a minority within the government ranks which supports this, albeit a majority in the cabinet. That is what holds sway in my opinion. It is not an informed opinion; it is a judgment. That is where I stand on that.

The Democrats will be strongly opposing reducing this tax concession to 125 per cent. I wish to publicly and on the record commend the fierceness with which Senator Cook has joined me in estimates hearings and in committee hearings in opposing this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —This measure of the government to reduce the tax concession for R&D from 150 per cent to 125 per cent is a clear and unequivocal victory for Treasury and its advice to their new minister—a minister who has no experience in industry, a minister who has no connection or advice, a Melbourne establishment lawyer who just would not know.

SPEECH.PARA: Why I say Treasury is that, since this was introduced by the Labor government in the mid-1980s with the strong support of then industry minister Senator Button, it has been opposed by Treasury year in, year out. It goes without saying that in every budget one of the measures Finance and Treasury would front up with, on advice to the government, to make savings was to abolish the tax concession for R&D. They saw it as a rort.

TALK.START.PARA: —They sought to reduce it.

—At least, Senator Ferguson, we had the courage to tell Treasury to go jump. Unfortunately, your new, inexperienced city slicker lawyer-Treasurer fell for the three-card trick and accepted their advice. As a result, industry was taking advantage—and as a former small business minister, I saw many small businesses starting to get the culture of innovation in this country—
—How many small businesses did you run?

—You did not have to run them, Senator. You just had to visit them to find out. Over that period, Senator Ferguson, I think my staff counted that I visited over 500 small businesses around Australia. I can tell you about the Technology Industry Exporters Group, which is a group of 70-odd high-tech Australian companies. When I met their executive and visited some of their firms, they all said that they had accepted the encouragement and policy advice of the government to become exporters, to deal with our current account deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: The 150 per cent tax deduction was absolutely critical for those scores of small developing SMEs to become exporters. They could take their innovative idea, take it through the prototype, develop a commercial product and then export it. The R&D tax concession was critical at 150 per cent.

Of course Treasury would claim that they were tax rorters. That has been the consistent advice. Tonight we have seen a number of examples of this Treasurer taking advice from the department. The attack on the cooperatives is one of the most astonishingly stupid decisions—all for a $6 million saving. Then we have the former Assistant Treasurer interjecting and saying that it was a measure of equity. No wonder we saw such dreadful measures in this budget when Treasury advised the Assistant Treasurer that that was a measure of equity.

We also saw Mr Peter McGauran, the Minister for Science and Technology, on the public record on a couple of occasions, spilling the beans. The reason this concession had to be cut from 150 to 125 per cent to save several hundred million dollars was that it was going to pay for the fact that the government left the diesel fuel rebate untouched. He said in conversations which have been reported that that was the reason this tax concession had to be cut. It had to pay for the political decision to preserve the diesel fuel rebate for the mining industry, the farming industry, the forestry industry and the fisheries industry.

That is what this Treasurer is about. One part of industry has to be punished to support another. There is no comprehensive industry policy, and there is no broader view about a manufacturing policy for Australia or about value adding. One of the reasons we have a current account deficit in this country is that we do not value add enough. We do not turn our intellectual capacity into high value added products. That is something that Treasury and this new Treasurer would not understand, because a city based Melbourne establishment lawyer would not know a factory, a farmer or a cooperative if it fell on top of him. That is going to be one of the great problems for this government over the years ahead, unless members of the coalition government stand him up and demand a broad industry policy that has a strategic thrust about it.

My colleague Senator Cook mentioned the fast ferry export industry. When I was the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, I had responsibility for that industry for a couple of years. I have to say that it was a great pleasure to be associated with an industry developed from scratch by Australians over a 20‐year period. When you went and visited Incat's factories—whether they were in Tasmania; Henderson, which is south of Fremantle; and New South Wales—you saw an industry that had been developed. They all said that one of the things that really gave them the spurt from the mid-1980s was to be able to claim the 150 per cent tax deduction.

Senator Cook said they now export half a billion dollars worth of product. They are the best in the world. The reason: they have the best innovation, the best design, the best skill workers, the best management skills and are able to beat anyone in the world. When you go overseas, these are the ferries the rest of the world wants to buy. They are the best design at the best price, and they work very well. We lead the world. We now have that industry looking at converting that design into fast cargo ships.

BREAK.PARA: That would not happen with this mob in government taking away the R&D. In one fell swoop in this budget, the ability to develop a fast ferry into a fast cargo ship that can take our high value added products from Australia into the expanding markets of Asia—instead of doing that in 21 to 28 days; doing it in seven days and, therefore, giving an advantage to our high quality manufacturers, whether they are in products or food processing—has gone down the drain. They cannot do it. When you put this on top of the fact that they have removed the ship bounty without waiting to see what the rest of the world would do, it is a double jeopardy to an industry that ought to be used as an example to the rest of manufacturing. It is an astonishing decision.

If you have talked to the ship builders since this government came in, their view is very blunt. This minister, this Treasurer and this minister for industry do not care. They would make the comment that, if you were trying to get in to see the minister or the Treasurer, you would have a better chance of breaking into Fort Knox than getting a chance to speak and put the view on an industry that already employs several thousand workers. They are workers who are paid, on average, $1,000 a week for their high quality work. These are high quality, high value jobs, developed from an industry that has the innovation and the flexibility to be the best in the world. It is astonishing.

I know every government claims they always have budget problems. But we keep knocking off the industries that are actually changing our current account deficit and have a chance to improve it. What does this new Treasurer say? He says the current account deficit in the long term is the number one problem. He has introduced in this budget decisions that are going to completely exacerbate it. I know he is a new Treasurer and that he is enthusiastic, but essentially he is naive. When all those documents came in to the Treasurer and the finance minister, the old Treasury bureaucrats had had them in the bottom drawer. They got them out and said, `Here we are, Minister.' They take off Ralph Willis's name or John Dawkins's name and give the brief. They put on Mr Costello's name and say, `Here's a saving for you. Knock off the 150 per cent tax deduction for R&D.' They did not tell him, of course, that they had put it up to every Labor Treasurer since 1985, when it came in, and that it had been knocked back. They had a try every year in the ERC. It was always on their savings list, as were bounties.

Treasury and the Department of Finance were against any area that provided strategic assistance in developing industry. And so it goes. We will never get a strategic industry policy in this country to get value adding into manufacturing and exports while the dead hand of Treasury is there all the time undermining it. I made a similar point in one of the recent estimates committee hearings. Senate Winston Crane said, `You made a decision about this some time ago.' I said to him, Senator Crane, you're going to have to learn pretty soon that governments come and go, but Treasury's always there giving the same advice.' That advice is to flatten any strategic plan for industry in this country. It will go on and on. I have to say that at least on many occasions our government had the wit to tell Treasury to put them back into the drawer. We said, `This is not on.'

I remember that, leading up to the budget, there was a clear leak from the Treasurer's office that he was not going to put up with any more `business welfare'. That was the phrase he used. That was put out in his name. I just about fell over. A year ago Treasury was giving the same advice to the Labor government. They were saying, `We've got to close down business welfare.' When we were putting together the innovation statement, Treasury's advice was that it was all business welfare. It was as though it was some gigantic rort. We chucked that in the bin too. It is at this level that this innocent, naive city slicker Treasurer has been taken for a ride by these Treasury officials. The Treasury advice will not change. That is not their culture.

I will finish on a comment John Button once made to me. Of course, he had more than his fair share of battles with Treasury and Finance over industry policy. He said, `What you've got to understand, Schachtie, is that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Schachtie—that's very familiar.

—Yes, that is very familiar. He said, `The problem with the senior bureaucrats in the central agencies,'—Treasury, Finance and PM&C—`is that they're really dysfunctional to Australian industry. When we were putting together the One Nation statement expenditure, it was agreed that we senior cabinet ministers would go around to meet business and other people in Melbourne, Sydney, Perth, and so on, to get their views on getting expenditure into infrastructure.' . Everybody now says that the western ring road in Melbourne is a major improvement to the efficiency of business. He said, `When we went down to Melbourne, the senior officials in those departments came along. When we got down there and met the heads of Melbourne business, all the ministers knew everybody by their first names. The officials did not know any of the heads of business. They had never met them. They had to be introduced.' That gives you an idea about the dysfunctional nature of Treasury, Finance and PM&C. They're just not connected.

BREAK.PARA: When I raised this in estimates, I was told there was some sort of advisory committee—a group of people who run around and take soundings from business. Whatever soundings they take, it does not change their advice one iota. Labor and Liberal governments come and go, but the advice will always be the same. The advice you have fallen for is to knock off and reduce this concession. It is a horrible decision. If you leave it there, in the long term this country is going to pay a very big penalty. This is one of the worst long‐term decisions—if not the worst—in this budget. It is about time the Senate made sure we voted this one down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat reluctant to enter this debate. I have sat and listened to the contribution by Senator Schacht for some quarter of an hour now. It was a pretty extraordinary contribution, I must tell you.
—Do you know that Treasury call him `Mr Big Interest Rates?

—Thanks for the big interest rates! Let me tell you, Senator Schacht, that that is one of the most extraordinary contributions I have ever heard. As chairman of the legislation committee, I listened to the submissions of the people who wanted to make submissions to the committee. I never saw you there on any occasion. I doubt whether you have ever read the report that was put down, because you did not quote from the majority report at all. You may have used the little bits that suited you in the minority report. Let me tell you, Senator Schacht, that you have talked about just about everything except the things that are involved in this part of the bill and the reduction of the concession. You talked about former Senator Button. You have gone back over history for some time, and a lot of things that are quite irrelevant.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course there were differing points of view in the evidence in this particular inquiry. When the government decides that it wants to make some changes, the people who generally come along to give evidence are those who do not like what the government is doing. You picked up every single issue that they raised, but you did not ever listen to the other sides of the argument. There are a couple of things in the report that I think you ought to be reminded of. It is a comprehensive report. I think it is one of the best reports that the legislation committee has put out for a long time.

I understand that there is a substantial minority report. There is also another minority report from the Democrats. The important part of what the majority report of that committee had to say—and I think you need reminding—is that it accepts that the reduction in the generosity of the concession will lead to a marginal reduction in the amount of concession claiming R&D. The committee notes also that the government affirms the importance of R&D to economic strength and intends to compensate for this through the newstart program of direct grants.

The important question in the design of the concession is not the absolute amount of R&D in the economy but rather what is the most cost effective rate of concession in gaining social benefits in exchange for public subsidies. Not once did you look at that and quote that in what your were saying, because this is the alternative point of view, which you have obviously taken no notice of. A subsidy, or a subsidy at a certain rate, which does not change recipients' behaviour when compared with no subsidy or some lower rate respectively, is simply a windfall gain to the recipients and not a cost effective use of public money. It is just not a cost effective use. You have chosen to totally ignore that opinion in putting your opinion before this house.

As well as that, at the margin, giving a high subsidy to an increasing amount of increasingly less valuable R&D may increase the total amount of R&D but it does not increase the net social benefits. If the R&D uses resources which, even after accounting for spillover benefits, could be more profitably employed elsewhere in the economy, the same applies to any activity. Statements to the effect that the R&D concession is relatively generous, whether compared with other industry assistance, or by international standards, imply a judgment that the concession rate is set higher than that which is most cost effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had prime interest rates at 22 per cent.

—Senator Schacht, it would help you to listen, because you have had your say, and what you had to say was not very effective, let me tell you, because all you did was quote some old history and that was that. How much at the margin will a certain reduction in the generosity of the concession reduce an R&D, and what is the most cost effective rate? And what is the most cost effective rate, Senator Schacht, is what we are really talking about here tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The contribution that you made to this debate did absolutely nothing to convince me or anybody else on this side of the chamber that we should support your point of view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth pointing out that the R&D tax concession is being retained at a very concessional rate of 125 per cent. Most R&D is of a capital nature and, under ordinary provisions, it would of course be deductible over a longer period, if at all.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a major part of the budget. Make no mistake: this is a major part of the budget. It is worth, to the budget, approximately $1.2 billion to the year 1999‐2000. The government believes, as a central part of the budget, the Senate should be prepared to give us the support for the changes we have made to the tax concession for R&D. I urge the Senate to support the government's position.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the Senate is that division 1, which reduces the R&D concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent, stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition opposes division 2, part 1, schedule 4. This section of the schedule deals with amendments relating to deductions for expenditure incurred by partnerships. If the government succeeds with this part of the bill, then it will prevent more than one firm combining in a partnership to apply for a research and development grant.

SPEECH.PARA: Some would say that this is backdoor syndication, and the government has announced its intention to end syndication. I do not believe it can be fairly characterised that way. Even if it were characterised that way, it may well be instructive for the Senate to hear what the government said about syndication prior to the election. The government's policy statement on science and technology, in reference to syndication, said:

Furthermore, changes to the syndicated research and development tax concession scheme guidelines may well result in the drying up of one of the few effective forms of venture capital available in Australia to fund research and development.

What they were referring to are the guidelines that the Labor government introduced in the Innovation Statement on 6 December 1995. These were guidelines aimed at cutting out any abuse of the syndication system. I believe—all the evidence that the committee received when it inquired into this consolidates this belief—that those guidelines are effective in doing so. However, the government, then the opposition, was saying that they may be too tight, that they may in fact have gone too far and that therefore syndicated research may dry up. So they were making it clear by saying that they were strongly supporting syndication. But that is not all they said. They said:
While the Coalition is not planning specific changes to existing programs of industry support for research and development—
we know that to be hollow from tonight's performance—
and has just accepted the extension of the computer bounty—
we know that is hollow from their intention to abolish the computer bounty—
the Coalition as an early priority will review these programs to determine whether they might be improved.

The way in which the government is intending to give effect to that election undertaking is to abolish the program. It can hardly be said that you are improving it by abolishing it. Nonetheless, what they are seeking to implement here tonight is the repudiation of their own electoral mandate. They say further in the same policy:
In making that assessment the Coalition particularly will take into account the following factors . . .

And there is a whole range of factors, as one might imagine. One of the pertinent ones is whether the government's revised syndicated research and development scheme guidelines will be much less attractive to investors. The signal here is that they were looking to improve it rather than abolish it. And so it goes.

The interesting thing about this is that this is the industrial research and innovation policy produced by the government when it was the opposition. Who was the responsible shadow minister at the time? The responsible shadow minister was none other than the now Leader in the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. I notice that he has had the good grace to head for the door of the chamber and leave, as the perfidy that has been entered into by his government is being exposed. I think it is absolutely essential that this provision be retained in the bill. That is why I oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook's amendment mirrors ours; therefore, the Democrats will support it. We concur with most of the remarks of Senator Cook. The government proposes to make eligibility under this section applicable to companies and not partners. This restriction unnecessarily limits the opportunities for jointly funded R&D projects and the scope for the commercialisation of these ventures. Non-syndicate collaborative research must be given maximum assistance. We support the Labor amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —As I noted in my speech during the second reading stage, the Greens support the retention of the syndication provisions, so we will be opposing this amendment. We believe the support for private sector venture capital is important. We also believe that it is necessary to address the issue of rorts, but this is best done with syndication in place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a pity, therefore, that the government did not support the second reading amendment of Senator Cook in relation to looking into these issues. I guess it is still open for them to do so in other ways. I am sure there are ways the Senate would support looking into any rorts that exist. I am sure the government can do that themselves in their own time as well. In this case, we will be supporting the continuation of the ability for smaller players in industry to have access to research syndication.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, we will not be supporting the views that were put forward to the chamber by Senator Cook. The justification for removing syndicates lies in their misuse by finance arrangers to lever up tax benefits to investors well beyond the level of real R&D spending. Most syndicates are arranged so that investors are not at risk, whether the R&D project is successful or not. In the majority of those syndicates, the tax benefits are in the range of 1.4 to 2.4 times the amount spent on R&D.

SPEECH.PARA: The government considers that the best way to encourage genuine R&D is to provide assistance directly to researchers rather than to wealthy investors. To increase the effectiveness of R&D assistance, the government is focusing that assistance towards increased outlays on R&D and away from non-transparent costs and ineffective tax concessions.

BREAK.PARA: The government has announced a new program of direct assistance for researchers for genuine R&D, establishing strategic assistance for research and development, the so-called START program. Under the program, the government will provide a flexible package of assistance totalling $340 million over the next four years to encourage large projects containing highly innovative or technically risky R&D that has strong support for commercialisation from the private sector.

I am not sure whether at this stage Senator Murray wants to make further comments, but I repeat that, under the program, the government will provide a flexible package of assistance totalling $340 million over the next four years to encourage large projects containing highly innovative or technically risky R&D that has strong support for commercialisation from the private sector. We would urge all senators to recognise the importance of the government's position on this, the significance that it has to the government's program and the importance of the START program. I urge senators to support our position.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the minister introducing the question of the START program, which is something the industry has expressed a great deal of disapproval of as a substitute for syndication, perhaps the minister can tell us why a condition of eligibility for a grant under the START program is that any company that has legal action to enforce its rights for syndication as the law stands is required to withdraw its legal action. Can you tell us the answer to that question?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I always seek to respond directly to the question you have. My advisers are currently preparing some notes for me which will allow me to respond. In the meantime, I can indicate that the government announced the funding of the START program in the budget. The government did provide in the budget $40 million in 1996-97 and $100 million over the following three years. That funding was announced in the budget.
—We know all about that.

—Good. I think some senators are very interested in this. That is why I am spelling this out. The government will ensure that the funding is provided in full if the measures to abolish syndication are passed. The funding of $40 million in 1996-97 has already been provided. The further $300 million will be provided with the abolition of syndication. I think Senator Murray has shown considerable interest in the START program and we welcome that interest. I hope that addresses some of the concerns you had for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the question that Senator Cook raised with me, I am advised that it is not a condition that an applicant has to give up rights to qualify. They do, however, have to forgo claims to syndication before the Commonwealth provides a grant of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —So they have to give up rights.
—Don't jump the gun. This is consistent to prevent double dipping of benefits. I think you, Senator Cook, would be equally opposed to double dipping of benefits, as would the government.

—Minister, I thank you for your intervention. The Democrats very much appreciate your approach on START. Your advisers and you yourself would know that we have a distinguishing view between this particular section on partnerships and the overall abolition of syndication itself. It does not change our view. We will support Senator Cook on the partnerships issue. When we come to the major abolition of syndication we will express our view then.

—Senator, we always hope that we can change your mind. We thought that if we moved forward rapidly you would see what good things were in store. We thought that if you were prepared to go on record maybe in this earlier section, for which you flagged you will not be giving us support, you may be persuaded by the good faith that we have shown and the arguments that we have put.

BREAK.PARA: While my advisers provide some further worthwhile thoughts which may persuade you, let me say that the government remains committed to the encouragement of innovative R&D in the private sector but of course has every right to be concerned at the very generous and open ended nature of tax concession made risk free by R&D investment possible without a commensurate increase in genuine R&D activities. I think that point has been well made.

The partnership provision is an essential part of the government's action on syndication. It cannot be omitted, we believe—and I urge senators to reflect on this—without allowing the intolerable features of syndication which have been very well expressed at least by some senators early in this debate and expressed before the committee chaired by Senator Ferguson.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to that, you would be aware, Minister, that the Democrats have not had proven to them either in public or in parliamentary forums the undesirable consequences, as you refer to them, of syndication. We have, however, accepted the government's view, giving you the benefit of the doubt, as expressed in my minority report, that syndication does lead to a less than optimal result as presently formulated. However, we regard this partnership exercise as discriminatory against forms of joint venture companies which we think contribute to good R&D opportunities. It is for that reason we are supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure how open to persuasion you are. I hope you are open to persuasion as my advisers continue to provide me with some interesting observations on the matters that you raise. As I said earlier, the partnership provision is an essential part of the government's action in relation to syndication. We believe very strongly that it simply cannot be omitted without allowing the intolerable features of syndication.

SPEECH.PARA: The established taxation rulings on the R&D provisions which preceded the addition of partnership allowed a wide range of joint expenditure on R&D. That joint R&D will continue to be possible on the same familiar terms. I do not know whether I can add much more to it, but it is all part of that wider picture and the wider arguments which have been put to the chamber. Although you have stated a position, Senator, we know that you are a man open to reason and we ask you to reflect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of opposition to division 2, the question before the chair is that schedule 4, part 1, division 2 stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats oppose divisions 4 to 7 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 4, Part 1, Division 4, page 49 (line 26) to page 50 (line 21), Omit the items.
(4) Schedule 4, Part 1, Division 5, page 50 (line 22) to page 53 (line 8), Omit the items.
(5) Schedule 4, Part 1, Division 6, page 53 (line 9) to page 55 (line 31), Omit the items.
(6) Schedule 4, Part 1, Division 7, page 56 (line 1) to page 60 (line 30), Omit the items.

The government has proposed modifying the deduction rules for interest expenditure used to finance R&D, for R&D feedstock, for core technology expenditure, and for pilot plant expenditure. These changes do nothing to advance the cause of greater efficiency or administrative simplicity. They do not contribute to greater or more focused R&D expenditure. At present, interest paid on debt used to finance R&D is deductible at 150 per cent. We see no reason to distinguish interest from other R&D costs or to move away from the 150 per cent principle. We have heard the arguments of government. If they want to replace those sorts of principles, they have to provide some other form of incentive financing.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are happy to support the feedstock moves by the government, since the particular rorts that arise from that section are not only bad in themselves but are also often used in a way that damages the environment. An example of this is the claim that a pulp mill or coal processor is an innovative piece of development and that the trees or coal are feedstock and hence tax deductible at 150 per cent. The feedstock amendment would see the value of the product deducted from the value of the feedstock so that the net cost of feedstock is all that is deductible. Pulp mills and coal producers may be some of the people rorting this measure. In this case, I will not be supporting the call to oppose the sections in the bill. I believe they should be supported.

—We will be supporting the amendments. Normally, we would support the government on this, because it narrows the definition and there is some justification for doing so. However, what the government did tonight was reduce the 150 per cent tax concession to 125 per cent. That is a major blow to research and development in Australia. The very least that can be done to try to even it up a little and be fair is to support this Democrat amendment. We will do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
