TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. I was pleased to hear from Senator Cook that normally the opposition would support the government on this matter. However, they will not be doing it this time. There has not been much sign of support from them in the debate on this bill.
—Well, it's a crook bill.
—I was quoting Senator Cook. He said, `Normally, we would support the government.'

SPEECH.PARA: The treatment of feedstock was one issue raised. It should be remembered that the detail of this proposed amendment is the result of consultation with industry in Melbourne in September this year. Industry indicated that they were not entirely comfortable with the changes to feedstock. However, the industry accepted that a change was required and that the treatment of the expense item was satisfactory. Increasingly, it became apparent that the manufacturing process said to be R&D would claim inputs at the premium rate while the output would be assessed at only 100 per cent. The bill seeks to allow deductions for only that part of the output that is consumed in the process to receive the premium rate.

In relation to the pilot plant, it should be remembered that that occurred as a result of consultations with industry in September. Industry indicated that they were comfortable with the proposed changes to pilot plant. Core technology has been modified. Again, the detail of this amendment was discussed with industry. Industry did not, I am advised, appear unhappy with the decision to modify the treatment of core technology. Core technology expenditure was found increasingly to be a vehicle for structuring finance. It would deliver a claimant company a substantial tax benefit for R&D previously conducted rather than new R&D. I urge the Senate to support the government's position.

The final part relates to the treatment of interest on debt, which has been limited to 100 per cent deductibility. Again, I am advised that industry did not appear unhappy with the decision to limit the level of concession to 100 per cent on interest expenses. Interest on debt was limited to 100 per cent to discourage the practice of funding R&D entirely out of debt while using equity in other areas of the company. For example, assume you had a company with $100 of business expenditure, including R&D expenditure of $20. The smart thing to do would be to fund the R&D out of the debt so that the interest expense is at 125 per cent rather than the normal 100 per cent.

The government rejects the amendments that the Australian Democrats have put forward. As I said, we have consulted with industry. They are well aware of the position. I have stated the advice we have received from industry in relation to each area. I urge the Senate not to support the amendments that have been moved by the Democrats.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that divisions 4 to 7 stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Divisions 4 to 7 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose items 57 and 59 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Schedule 4, item 57, page 61 (lines 3 to 8), Omit the items.
(8) Schedule 4, item 59, page 61 (lines 11 to 13), Omit the items.

These measures ensure that the existing definition of eligible R&D is retained. The government has sought to curtail what qualifies eligible R&D by changing the definition from `systemic, investigative or experimental activities that involve innovation or technical risk' to `systemic, investigative and experimental activities that involve innovation or a high level of technical risk'. I have been persuaded by arguments from industry that changing the definition in the manner suggested would be counterproductive to effective and well‐understood R&D activities. This would simply exclude a tremendous amount of legitimate and vitally important R&D. It will exclude R&D of the sort that should be encouraged and motivated. It is a measure whose sole purpose is budget savings. It is just another way the government can pull out research funding.

Moreover, I am concerned that by the use of the term `high level of technical risk' the government will be able to exercise a significant degree of restrictive discretion which will enable it to deny assistance to research projects on a pretty arbitrary basis. I stress, however, that I recognise the need to clarify definition of eligible research and development in order to enable more efficient processing. My amendment still enables us, as it retains all the clarification proposed but not the words `high level of technical risk' or the word `and' in place of the word `or'.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the matters raised by Senator Murray, there is really no substantive change to the definition of R&D. Really, all that has happened in the amendments proposed is that the current definition is clarified by bringing in the terminology of the original explanatory material. The definition is in keeping with the Frascati manual—an OECD manual for the measurement of scientific and technical activities—international definition of R&D. So I urge the Senate to support the government's position on this.

—We will be supporting the Democrat amendment on the same basis that I explained on the last occasion, although I must say that I do not think it is true to say that this is not a tightening of the definition of research and development—I think it is. The international measure is the Frascati measurement that the OECD applies, but Australia has had a more liberal interpretation of research and development. The reason why it has is that, of the 26 OECD countries, we are about 19th in private sector R&D and there needs to be a more positive incentive for the private sector to get into R&D. So we have allowed a broader definition, is my understanding. I do not know that I can agree with that last comment, but we will be supporting the Democrats on this.
—I need some clarification here, perhaps from the government. What would be the implication of the wider definition and how does that relate to what exists now?

—I think I have answered that in my earlier comments. I made it very clear that there is no substantive change to the definition of R&D and all that has happened in the amendments proposed is that the current definition is clarified by bringing in the terminology of the original explanatory material.
—If you reckon it hasn't changed, why is it necessary?

—Senator Cook, you have said that you normally support the government on these matters. This would be an easy one to support us on. See whether you are able to deliver on that statement for once in this bill.
—I don't agree with you; that is the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I sat through the hearings and have had a number of submissions from a number of people. My understanding—if I may assist the minister to Senator Margetts—is as follows: that when you add the word `and' you are grouping the three categories together and all three must be satisfied. When you use the word `or', it is either/or and that is a very substantial difference. Far be it from me to claim the minister has misrepresented or misled you, but I think he has not fully grasped the consequences of that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The second area is, by adding the words `a high level of', you make it a very high bar to jump. It is a very restrictive requirement and the whole purpose of this measure is to restrict the amount of R&D which can be done and which is available to persons who might otherwise apply. It is a device by the tax office and by Treasury to limit the amount of R&D that can be claimed. Therefore, it is not a minor, a tidying up or a housekeeping amendment. This is an extremely restrictive and defining amendment and I think you should look at it very carefully in terms of your views.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am always happy to hear arguments from you, as you well know. Sometimes I think I need your assistance and other times I do not. I am not sure I did on that occasion. Let me put some background on the table which may even persuade Senator Cook. The IR&D board has been challenged in the AAT over matters relating to the definition of R&D. That makes a legislative clarification really essential.
—So they can win the AAT case?

—No. The clarification, Senator Cook—this is an easy one for you to deliver on your statement—allows the general intent of the original legislation to be effected. That is the advice I have received. Senator Murray and I may well have to differ on this, but I think we have both stated our views. I have sought advice on the matters raised by Senator Murray. I urge the chamber to support the government's position so we can move on.

—There was part of my question—it was a serious question—which has not been answered. I wanted to know what the likely financial implication of the tightening or clarification of the definition will be compared with the wider definition. I think it is quite important for us to understand what the potential implications are.
—I think the short answer is that it protects revenue rather than picking up additional revenue.
—This I worked out, but I am just trying to get some idea.

—I am not trying to be unpleasant; I am just trying to answer the question. You have raised a fair question. We have very eminent advisers here from Treasury. You asked what the financial implications were. The answer to that I thought was a fair answer. The aim is to protect revenue. My advisers inform me that we cannot give you any sort of figure, but I think I have outlined the philosophy which underlies the move that we have made.

—What you have given us is the best argument possible for Senator Brown's foreshadowed amendments in terms of gaining information about this whole syndication business. It is not a particularly clear-cut issue, but I feel on balance that it probably is worth tightening these definitions. I think people do deserve to have the situation clarified. On balance, I will be supporting the government on this issue.

—I do not accept the explanation that this simply clarifies an existing meaning of the act—and I think the minister has given lie to that explanation anyway by telling us that it is necessary for the government to win an AAT case. If this is the meaning of the act, then that is how the AAT will find. But you know the AAT is not likely to find that way and, therefore, you want to get to the law and fix the case before it goes to the AAT. That is the plain fact of the matter here. The Democrats' amendment should go through.

—It is not dreadfully important at this point, but it is important, generally speaking, to understand that material like explanatory memoranda aid the interpretation of the law. If there was some problem about examining the words of the legislation on the face of it, then all they need to do is turn to the explanatory memorandum.

PARA.BREAK: The minister has indicated that what the government are doing is simply using a definition and including those words that are contained in the explanatory memorandum. I really cannot see, therefore, why they needed to change the definition. Explanatory memoranda can be used by the AAT for the pur pose of interpreting the law. Anyhow, I am not going to continue with that except to ask the minister to advise the committee: on how many occasions has the AAT been involved in hearing appeals on this particular matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that we have 15 current cases and that we have had four in the past.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Childs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that items 57 and 59 stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 4, item 72, page 65 (after line 13), after subsection (2), insert:
(2A) If:

PARA.TAB: (a) before the commencement time, an application was made under section 39P to register 2 or more eligible companies jointly in relation to a proposed project in respect of a year of income or years of income; and
(b) by the commencement time, the Board had not, in respect of the application, registered or refused to register the companies jointly;
subsection (1) does not prohibit the Board, in respect of the application, from registering the companies jointly.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 4, item 73, page 66 (line 20), after "39PA(2)", insert ", (2A)".
I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments I have just moved to this bill. The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 12 December 1996.

The government amendments provide for syndicates that had lodged an application for joint registration under section 39P before 5 p.m. on 23 July 1996. These syndicates had to complete applications lodged and had investors committed to the carrying out of the R&D. They represent the most advanced proposals on hand and those that may have reasonably incurred expenditure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —We will vote for this amendment, though not because it is perfect. It is far from perfect; in fact, it is a slap in the face for the vast majority of applicants who have not been properly dealt with by the IR&D board. We will vote for it and we will vote for our own amendment, which follows this, to restore justice across the board to all of the applicants before the IR&D board.

SPEECH.PARA: These government amendments recognise the justice of the case, however—that is, that a number of applications, 46 in number, were put on the so-called `A' list by the government. These were applicants who would have been dealt with by the IR&D board on 24 July at its scheduled meeting. But on 23 July the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) announced an end to syndication. Those applicants who were fully in anticipation of being dealt with were denied access to the board.

This was legislation by press release. The government announced it by press release, so the board did not deal with them. They have sat there—properly constituted applications—being unable to be dealt with. I understand that some of them are so frustrated by the government in this that they want to take legal action against the government.

My understanding is that the government claims that of the 46 applications before the IR&D board, this will mean that 16 of them will have the opportunity of going forward and having their applications dealt with by the IR&D board. That does not mean they will pass. They still have to win on their merits that this is justifiable R&D within the tenets of that board, but at least they will have the chance to be dealt with. That is 16 out of 46—what the government claims.

What we say, looking at the effect of this clause, is that only seven of 46 will be able to go ahead and be dealt with. There is an injustice here to 39 other applicants. I repeat: going to the board does not mean you will be granted. Going to the board only means that you will have to establish your bona fides under the provisions of the board as it existed and then be entitled to have your syndicate approved or not.

What we have here by the government is a last minute effort to try to head off some of the justifiable frustration and rebellion that is in the ranks of industry by the heavy-handed, high-handed attitude of the Treasurer and the industry minister by trying to legislate by press release.

I could speak on this subject for a lot longer but, in view of the hour, I will not in the hope that we can at least get these amendments through the Senate tonight and clear the way for tomorrow morning, when I will move my amendment, which will do justice to the whole 46.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of time, I seek leave to incorporate my remarks on this in Hansard . The Democrats will be supporting the government.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Democrats will be supporting the Government amendment and we are very pleased that the Government has moved it. In our discussions with the Government today, the Democrats indicated that our primary concern with respect to the cut-off for applications for the R&D concession is to ensure that those syndicates who are quite advanced in the approval process are allowed to proceed.
Much expense is involved in getting to an approval, with each stage of the IR&D Board process requiring a great deal of work.

The approach which we discussed with the Government today and which is picked up in this motion is consistent with the approach the Democrats took with the previous Government last year when it moved to cut off access to the R&D concession for tax‐exempt researchers. Again, our concern there was that applicants well advanced in the approval process should be allowed to proceed, but those who had barely applied should be excluded.

It has to be remembered that there is no "right" which is being taken away here. The Parliament has decided that it is no longer appropriate policy that syndicates have access to this concession. This transitional arrangement is only about at what point the gate should be shut.

We believe that the amendment moved by Senator Cook cuts it off too late. The Government has advised us that the vast bulk of the 120 outstanding applicants would proceed under that process. The ALP disputes this, arguing that the application of the new finance guidelines will cut this figure by more than half. I am quite concerned about the uncertainty about this.

I have been advised by the Government that about 16 or so applications are at the advanced stage of having applied for registration. Those 16 companies have been through the hoops and should not be disadvantaged. But, that is where the door should shut.

Even this amendment will cost $160 million over 4 years, and to open up the door further will add significantly to the cost of closing down what we believe has been shown to be a concession not working properly in relation to syndicates.

As I said, the approach in the amendment which we have developed with the Government is entirely consistent with the Democrats approach last year when the previous Government moved to cut off access to the concession for tax exempt research and I commend this amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am taking the same line on this issue as the ALP. We will be supporting the government's amendments, but also supporting the ALP's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Likewise, this is a matter of great concern to me because of the inferred retrospectivity that was involved—changing the rules in midstream whilst people were entitled to expect treatment and they were denied. I will be supporting the motion that is currently before the chair.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose items 71 to 73 of schedule 4. These are the substantial provisions by which the government gives effect to its attempt to legislate by press release by outlawing syndication. Much has been said about this in the debate. There is a shonky report on which the government claims to justify its actions. There is a press release that industry does not recognise as being typical. Industry represented 94 per cent of all the applications that were before the IR&D board. In any case, they would not have got through the tightened guidelines that we introduced in the innovation statement on 6 December last year.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have here is a press release by the two ministers with four examples of the truth—which no-one other than the government recognises—of what has happened since the guidelines were tightened on 6 December. It is on that basis and on the basis of this report that the government claims is from the BIE, but is not—we now know it is from the department, not from the scientifically based analysis of the BIE—and a report which is not about examining the evidence but is about running a few computer models to see what assumptions come out at the end, that there is an allegation of widespread rorting. There is large‐scale rebellion out there in industry that they are being totally misrepresented by the government on this. I do not have any time to develop my remarks further, but I certainly want to indicate that we believe that these items should be opposed. I oppose them.
Progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being midnight, I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am as fresh as a daisy, but I should not think anyone else is. I wonder if it would be convenient for the Senate to have my adjournment speech incorporated.
—I think you should give the speech, Senator.
—I am happy to look at it while someone else gives a speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to take the same opportunity but, unfortunately, I am not quite as prepared as Senator Murray. After the tabling of the report of the Senate Economics References Committee inquiry into outworking in the garment industry today, in tonight's adjournment debate I would like to update an adjournment speech I gave on 19 November reporting progress towards voluntary industry regulation to stamp out the exploitation of outworkers.

SPEECH.PARA: Since this time, Fair Wear, a national coalition of church and community groups and trade unions, has been formed to educate consumers to make ethical shopping choices, to promote retailers and manufacturers to sign an industry home workers code of practice, and to encourage other retailers to sign such a code. It is hoped that shoppers will be concerned about the exploitation of outworkers in the garment industry who may be working for as little as $2 an hour and that they will buy from retailers who have signed the home workers code of practice. I would like to highlight those retailers who have so far come to the party: Target, Just Jeans, Country Road, Witchery, Ken Done, Australia Post and Jacqueline Eve.

Fair Wear, the coalition, has been mounting demonstrations in shopping centres in the pre-Christmas shopping season to educate consumers and to encourage retailers to sign the code. This coalition is, unfortunately, bitterly disappointed that at the last moment a significant group of retailers backed away from an earlier verbal agreement to support the code of practice. These retailers include: Coles-Myer, Daimaru, Fletcher Jones and Table Eight.

After helping to initiate the home workers code of practice, these retailers have now refused to sign it. Through the Australian Retailers Association, they have proposed a new code which promises complete confidentiality to retailers and manufacturers found to be in breach of award wages and which makes the industry fully self-regulatory. The coalition sees the need for external grassroots monitoring that the unions can provide. They encourage consumers not to think that a code which does not involve any external regulation would actually assist outworkers.

The home workers code of practice was a well thought through and workable proposal originally supported by several retailers, the Council of Textile and Fashion Industries of Australia along with several manufacturers. At this stage, the council is also not agreeing to proceed with the code. I should also indicate that there is also another group of retailers who have been unwilling to be part of any negotiations at this stage. They include: Big W, Sportsgirl, Sussan, Best and Less, and Westco.

I would like to highlight some of the community groups that have been involved with the Fair Wear coalition. These include: the Uniting Church of Australia, the Women's Electoral Lobby, the YWCA of Melbourne, the Textiles Clothing and Footwear Union of Australia, Community Aid Abroad, the Australian National Committee on Refugee Women, Asian Women at Work, the Australia Asia Worker Links, the Sydney Forum of Religious for Justice, the Australian Forum for Justice, the Mercy Foundation, the Institute of Sisters of Mercy of Australia, the Dominican Committee for Justice and Peace, the Good Shepherd Youth and Family Service, the Missionary Sisters of Service, the Good Shepherd Provincialate, the Brigidine Social Action and Awareness Group, the Australian Catholic Social Justice Commission, the Baptist Church Social Justice Group, the Baptist Union of New South Wales, the Church and Trade Unions Committee, the New South Wales Working Women's Centre, Women's Health in Industry, the Dale Street Women's Health in Adelaide, and Women in Industry and Community Health.

Given a fairly broad level of community support and very general community concern about the problem of outworkers in the garment industry and given the fact that the report I tabled today was a consensual report of all senators involved in the committee suggesting that all parties involved in the garment industry—the retailers, the manufacturers, the intermediaries, the workers and the government—facilitate such a voluntary agreement, it is disappointing that we are at this stage. Tonight I urge all those parties to see if some resolution can be reached, particularly before the Senate revisits the matter within the next 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not often speak on the adjournment debate. I know it is late at night, but I think this is the first time in 10 years that I have spoken on the adjournment debate. I do want to raise a matter tonight which has been a dominant political issue in my home state for the past two years—the controversial issue of the state Liberal government handing over the management of South Australia's water supply to an overseas owned company.

BREAK.PARA: This was a deal that was brokered by Premier Olsen, the new Premier. It is a deal that has seen a massive cover up at every step of the process. It is a deal worth $1½ billion over 15 years. Every detail of this deal has been kept secret from the people and the parliament of South Australia. It is also a deal that the public of South Australia are opposed to and about which the public has been persistently misled.

You have to go a long way to find someone to buy South Australian water—that is what the locals say. In this case, they did. They went to Kazakhstan and to France. I turn first to the latest instalment, the latest refusal of the state Liberal government in South Australia to come clean on the embarrassing facts surrounding this ill‐advised $1½ billion deal. This is a story of exotic deals, exotic places and exotic relationships. Who, for instance, knows that Kazakhstan is involved in this particular set of deals?

I think all of these deals and relationships will be slowly revealed against the will of the Olsen government. I have been made aware of some of the information which will ultimately be made public. To me this deal leaves the 1970s loan affair somewhat for dead. It has the capacity to bring down Premier Olsen. If South Australia goes to an early election next year, it will be because Premier Olsen will be afraid of what may be revealed in subsequent months on this particular deal.

In a grievance speech on the last sitting day of the South Australian parliament, Labor leader Mike Rann asked a number of questions. He asked whether the new Premier Olsen still had confidence in the professionalism and ethical conduct of Mr Terry Burke, the consultant paid half a million dollars for his role in the water contract. He asked whether it was true that Mr Burke—despite NCA interest and a South Australian police inquiry—had since been employed by the South Australian government, on John Olsen's instructions, to work on the MFP smart city project.

Mr Burke is an intriguing character. He has been indulged at the expense of the South Australian taxpayers. He has availed himself of massively expensive hotel rooms at taxpayers' expense. He is a character who celebrated the last French nuclear test at the Red Ochre restaurant in Adelaide with Bollinger champagne and then tried to make the South Australian taxpayer pay. He was not paid; he was knocked back for that.

Mr Rann also asked whether the Premier was confident that negotiators working for the government during the water tender did not improperly pass on information from one tenderer to another in order to influence the outcome of the process in favour of United Water. He also asked whether he had informed the then Premier Dean Brown of interest shown in this matter quite some time ago by law enforcement authorities.

On 1 December, John Olsen was quoted in the Australian newspaper denying allegations of police investigations. This is despite the existence of communications between the Commissioner of Police in South Australia and Mike Rann that confirm the existence of a South Australian police inquiry into this matter.

If we go back a little bit further, in July this year Mike Rann was contacted by a citizen of South Australia who was concerned about information she had been given on the water deal. She had informed Rann about serious allegations by a South Australian Water Corporation executive about the bidding process. These included claims that the government's lead negotiator Mr Terry Burke had been involved in unethical and improper conduct during the process. A South Australian Water executive had told her that Mr Burke had involved himself in unauthorised meetings and that he had even socialised with the United Water executives outside the confines of the designated negotiations room for the water contract. These meetings took place, it was said, in Adelaide, Sydney and even on a boat on Sydney Harbour.

There was not just one informant. The senior business leader contacted the South Australian shadow minister for industry, Kevin Foley, with similar claims of irregularities. I have since been told that Premier Olsen and his office were informed of similar allegations at the time, but they failed to take the allegations to the NCA or to the police. Rann, however, advised his principal informant to take her information immediately to the NCA and to the South Australian Auditor-General. She took legal advice and she agreed eventually to give her information only to the NCA, as she wanted to provide the information only to law enforcement officers. She was most concerned about confidentiality, given the nature of the allegations, and her own safety.

The informant asked Mr Rann to intervene for her. He spoke to the NCA's South Australian Director, John Ganley, whom I gather spoke personally to the informant and arranged for her to be interviewed. Sometime later I am told Mr Rann phoned Ganley with additional information, including information concerning an interstate businessman who had volunteered to be interviewed by the NCA. Rann was told that—and I think he has said this as well—the investigation should be more appropriately conducted by the anti-corruption unit of the South Australian Police Force.

On 7 August, Rann was asked by the NCA to prepare a letter giving it the authority to provide his confidential information to the South Australian police. Mr Rann told the NCA he was happy to speak to officers of the South Australian anti-corruption unit to expedite their inquiries, but I gather that since that time he has received no contact from the anti-corruption unit and was informed that the business leader who offered to provide information was not interviewed. I understand that just a couple of days ago Mr Rann lodged a freedom of information request to secure the detailed accounts and receipts of Mr Burke's extravagantly expensive involvement with this contract. It seems that, while the South Australian taxpayer pays, Mr Burke plays.

The Labor Party here and in South Australia—and I do not think it is just the Labor Party; I think it is the South Australian public as well—are starting to be more demanding of answers to this particular problem. Labor could have raised these matters in this place and also in the state parliament back in July, but I think Mike Rann did the right thing in presenting the information to the law enforcement agencies, particularly the NCA at that particular stage. He is concerned. He is disappointed that the key people have not been interviewed, as yet, by the South Australian police. I think his request for a full investigation is one that is warranted.

I think this is just the latest instalment of what is dragging out to be a sorry saga. Public opposition to the water contract in South Australia is so overwhelming that the Liberal government has fought in the courts all year, including this week, to prevent the public release of opinion polls on the issue. The government paid taxpayers' money to a former Greiner staffer, Ian Kortlang, to conduct the polls. Then they refused to tell the public the result. I think this is only a small example of the practices and secrecy that are the hallmarks of this deal.

The $1½ billion contract was awarded to a shelf company called United Water. Neither the contract nor its details have ever been made available to the public or the parliament. We know that South Australians are paying $1½ billion, but we do not know much else. John Olsen told us that United Water would become a majority Australian‐owned concern. It is, in fact, almost wholly owned by the Compagnie Generale Des Eaux De France, CGE, and Thames Water of Britain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that again!

—After an extra glass of wine, I might do it as well as you, Senator. We do not know much about the water contract, but we do know a bit about CGE. Reports of widespread corrupt practices by officials of CGE and its affiliates surfaced in the Australian and in the international press in 1995.

BREAK.PARA: In that year, Premier Olsen was asked in the South Australian parliament about the integrity of a key player in CGE. The opposition leader told parliament—and this is Mr Rann—the CGE's Chairman, Guy Dejouany, had been charged with corruption and released on bail of one million francs in what The Times of London described as `the most intensive corruption investigation' in France for 15 years. That was on 18 June 1995.

Parliament was told that some 20 senior executives of CGE's French based subsidiaries had been named in bribery cases. Olsen's response to the South Australian parliament was that the South Australian government would only sign a contract with companies of the highest integrity—you would wonder what his benchmark was. Shortly after this he announced the preferred tenderer as United Water, and then a few other facts turned up about the tender process that John Olsen did not want to surface. Do you know—and it is intriguing and quite ironic—that Dean Brown has been found guilty, convicted and executed for the offences that John Olsen has committed in South Australia?

Labor discovered that, on the day that the closing bids were due—4 October 1995—United Water was given four extensions of time totalling four hours. The two unsuccessful bidders were not told of the extensions made available to their competitor. They had to get their bids in on time. The whole process was supposed to be videotaped in a secure room to prevent tampering with bids. The security tape ran out almost three hours before United Water's bid was received. It was not replaced. At the same time the contract manager left the building and did not return until after United Water's bid had been received.

The auditor‐general has had concerns about the situation in South Australia. The auditor‐general's report found major flaws in the bid process. We are talking here of a process which has been immensely unpopular in South Australia. South Australians do not want their water supplies run by an overseas company. They are angry at being misled about the level of Australian ownership. They are suspicious about the whole secretive and sordid process. In closing at this particular stage, I will just reiterate the point that I made earlier. This matter will drag out. The information will be brought out over time. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was well punished for trying to break the system.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to speak about wetlands. It is increasingly recognised worldwide just how important and valuable wetlands are. Although wetlands come in many different forms, including lakes, swamps and tidal flats, one feature that is common to them is the enormous biodiversity that is associated with them. Wetlands also provide many other crucial environmental services—for example, flood control and nutrient filtering. They are also major producers of food energy for the wider environment.

On top of all this biological and ecological richness, wetlands are extremely beautiful and spiritually significant places. In a continent like Australia which is largely arid or semiarid, these areas of permanent or semipermanent water feature centrally in both Aboriginal cultural and spiritual life, and also in post‐colonial literature and history. Arguably our most loved national song, Waltzing Matilda, is based in a wetland environment with a name—billabong—that resonates with Aboriginal poetry and cool refreshment.

Another feature of wetlands is the way in which they are connected across the surface of the planet through the miraculous phenomenon of migratory birds. These bird species are, and should be recognised as, international roving ambassadors for the protection of the world's environment and the world's wetlands. Australia forms a vital link in this transnational odyssey. The Japan-Australia migratory bird agreement lists some 90 species of transequatorial birds which rely on Australia for their survival. Through such instruments as the Ramsar convention and the Japan-Australia migratory bird agreement, increasing efforts are being made for international cooperation to protect the world's remaining wetlands.

The remaining wetlands in my home state of Western Australia are a vital part of the local, regional, national and international environment. Wetlands are found throughout Western Australia, including in the most arid desert environments. Wherever they occur they are of great importance.
The 1992 State of the Environment report published by the Environmental Protection Authority states:

Across Western Australia, wetlands provide the most biologically diverse and productive habitats, contain highly specialised plant and animal communities and support complex biological, physical and chemical interactions.
Nine Western Australian wetlands are listed under the Ramsar convention as wetlands of international significance.

It is a matter of tragic record that much of Western Australia's wetland heritage has been destroyed or severely degraded since European colonisation. According to the EPA report, some 70 to 80 per cent of the wetlands of the Swan Coastal Plain in the south‐west of Western Australia have been destroyed or degraded since European settlement. It is even more distressing to know that, in full knowledge of how important these places are, the destruction of Western Australia's remnant wetlands continues with varying degrees of government support.

To give some small indication of how important Western Australia's wetlands are and how threatened they are, here are some examples: the Western Australian coastline, with its associated wetlands, is one of the six recognised major international transequatorial flyways for migratory birds. Important sections of this coastal route are at risk from pollution and development. For example, the wetlands of Roebuck Bay near Broome are in the top five migratory bird sites in the world. Despite this, they are threatened by mineral sands mining.

About 50 of the migratory bird species listed under the Japan‐Australia migratory bird agreement are recorded from the remnant wetlands of the Peel-Harvey region in south‐west Western Australian. Important parts of this wetland system are being destroyed as I speak. Places like the Creery wetlands languish under the threat of canal housing development. The south‐west of Western Australia is particularly rich in wetlands. Even now, entirely new species and even new genera are being discovered in the south‐west wetlands, such as the newly discovered genus of frog known as the `sunset frog'. About 80 per cent of the original wetlands of the south‐west have been destroyed through some combination of clearing, agriculture, mining, housing development, draining, pollution, and invasion by weeds. Although the remaining wetlands of the south‐west are of incalculable value, they continue to be sacrificed for the most base of commercial benefits or ideological motives. For example, the wetlands spread throughout the south‐west forest region are being destroyed by the direct or indirect impacts of forest management practices, including frequent prescribed burning, road construction and dieback.

On top of this, the Court government has recently—as is now a matter of record in this chamber—excised an area of wetland ecosystem from the D'Entrecasteaux National Park on the south coast for mineral sands mining. In a fitting irony, given the Japan‐Australia migratory bird agreement, the company seeking to mine this wetland is the Japanese Nissho Iwai Corporation. In the agricultural region, many surviving wetlands are under grave threat from rising watertables and salinity. Despite this, important remnant wetlands are being destroyed for commercial benefits. For example, the important Lake Chinnocup `A' class nature reserve is under threat from gypsum mining.

Elsewhere in the state, the mining and pastoralism industries have had and are continuing to have profound destructive impacts on surviving wetlands. For example, the mining industry is operating in many places in such a way as to draw down watertables or otherwise interfere with groundwater and drainage systems, thereby disrupting the water systems of adjacent wetlands. Pastoralism is responsible for massive wetlands impacts across much of the semiarid region of Western Australia, with sheep and cattle destroying fringing vegetation and causing erosion and pollution of wetlands.

In recognition of the obvious value of our remaining wetlands and the very strong level of community concern and support for their protection, the coalition parties, prior to the last state election, promised `unprecedented attention to the protection of [WA's] Wetlands.' Wetland conservation was, and continues to be, a priority issue in WA, and the coalition's pre-election commitment to their protection was one of the main reasons they were seen then as a credible potential government.

It is utterly disgraceful that four years later the record shows that not only have they not acted in any comprehensive manner to protect our wetland heritage, but also the Court government has been actively engaged in the ongoing destruction of wetlands. For example, ongoing land clearing is affecting wetlands in urban and agricultural regions. Wetlands have been modified to cater for urban expansion, for example at Canning Vale and Jandakot. Wetlands throughout the metropolitan area are potentially threatened by Perth's increasing reliance on unregulated bore water usage. The Ascot Waters wetlands have been bulldozed for housing and the adjacent salt marsh conservation area has been earmarked for modification.

The Secret Harbour wetlands near Mandurah have been destroyed for a housing estate. Commitments on the creation of a scientific park and the protection of wetlands of Port Kennedy near Rockingham have not been honoured. The Creery Wetlands near Mandurah are a continuing risk of housing development. Some of the state's only surviving near-pristine wetlands in the Kimberley remain unprotected and/or unmanaged and are suffering increasing degradation through feral animals, grazing, fire, unmanaged recreation and tourism and mining. The Lake Chinnocup Nature Reserve is at risk from mining. Nationally recognised wetlands of the D'Entrecasteaux National Park are threatened by sand mining.

The draft state wetland policy, released by the then Labor government in 1992, has not been finalised or implemented despite being promised. The south-west agricultural zone wetlands environmental protection policy has not been finalised or implemented despite being promised. Many Ramsar listed wetlands have too little or no resources for their management.

The Australian Democrats, unlike the coalition government, are deeply committed to the protection and fully resourced conservation management of Australia's remaining wetlands—and I say unlike the coalition government because they made promises and they have not kept them. We are also committed to the repair of those wetlands which are capable of restoration and management.
The Australian Democrats will work at a state, national and international level, to ensure that wetlands, which form such a crucial aspect of our national wellbeing, are not further eroded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following document was tabled pursuant to the order of the Senate of 29 November 1996:

Maritime industry—Shipping Grants Legislation Bill 1996—Report on developments and progress in the Government's pursuit of multilateral agreements relating to maritime safety, seafarers' rights and liability for environmental damage.
The following documents were tabled by the Clerk:
Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act—National Capital Plan—Re‐certification of draft Amendment No. 18.
Bankruptcy Act—Regulations—Statutory Rules 1996 No. 263.
Child Support (Assessment) Act—Regulations— Statutory Rules 1996 No. 273.
Crimes Act—Regulations—Statutory Rules 1996 No. 264.
Designs Act—Regulations—Statutory Rules 1996 No. 270.
Family Law Act—Regulations—Statutory Rules 1996 No. 265.
Federal Court of Australia Act—Regulations— Statutory Rules 1996 No. 266.
Income Tax Assessment Act—Regulations— Statutory Rules 1996 No. 274.
National Health Act—Nursing Homes Financial Arrangements Principles (Amendment No. 2 of 1996).
Patents Act—Regulations—Statutory Rules 1996 No. 271.
Proceeds of Crime Act—Regulations—Statutory Rules 1996 No. 267.
Student and Youth Assistance Act—Regulations —Statutory Rules 1996 No. 275.
Superannuation Act—Regulations—Statutory Rules 1996 No. 268.
Trade Marks Act—Regulations—Statutory Rules 1996 No. 272.
Workplace Relations Act—Regulations—Statutory Rules 1996 No. 269.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 8 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What staff, other than staff employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, were employed in or attached to the office(s) of the Minister and each of his or her Parliamentary Secretaries as at 8 October 1996.
(2) What were the total salary costs of such staff.
(3) What was the financial cost to the Commonwealth of the employment of such staff.
(4) What were the titles, roles and duties of such staff and what public service (or equivalent) classifications did they carry.
(5) Under what programs were they employed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 8 October 1996, there were two staff permanently employed in the office of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, other than staff employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984.

(2) The combined salary costs for the two officers each financial year is $161,330, which includes a ministerial allowance of $11,024 paid to each of them in lieu of the overtime they are expected to work.
(3) The financial cost to the Commonwealth of employing the two officers each financial year is $239,892.
(4) The titles of the staff were Departmental Liaison Officers and their classifications were at the Senior Officer Grade B level. Their roles and duties were to:

PARA.TAB: provide advice and support to the Minister and the Minister's staff on matters related to the portfolio;
liaise with Departmental and Ministerial staff to ensure that priorities are met with the processing of ministerial papers;
proof read and monitor all ministerial papers within the office;
co‐ordinate support services for the Minister's office.

ANSWER.PARA: (5) The officers were employed under program 6.1.6—Ministerial Liaison—Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 8 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What staff, other than staff employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, were employed in or attached to the office(s) of the Minister and each of his or her Parliamentary Secretaries as at Tuesday, 8th October 1996.
(2) What were the total salary costs of such staff.
(3) What was the financial cost to the Commonwealth of the employment of such staff.
(4) What were the titles, roles and duties of such staff and what public service (or equivalent) classifications did they carry.
(5) Under what programs were they employed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One Australian Public Service (APS) officer full‐time being the Departmental Liaison Officer. One officer on a short‐term secondment under the APS Executive Development Scheme (EDS). This scheme is long established and designed to broaden the experience of senior officers in the APS to enhance their effectiveness. One Australian Defence Force officer being the Escort Officer.
(2) $138,650 per annum. One officer is on secondment for four months and that officer's salary has been calculated at one third of the annual rate.

(3) $249,360 per annum. The total financial cost reflects both variable and fixed full on‐costs and overheads and is calculated from the Ready Reckoner of Personnel Costs and Related Overheads, Edition 4, July 1996 (Department of Defence) with the exception of the seconded officer who has been calculated at salary plus superannuation at one third of the annual rate.

(4) One Departmental Liaison Officer (DLO), a Senior Officer Grade C, acts as a contact point for liaison between the Minister's office and the Department; manages correspondence relevant to the Defence portfolio; and coordinates, and where necessary assists with, the development of briefs required by the Minister. One Escort Officer, a Navy Lieutenant, escorts the Minister on visits to Defence establishments and carries out liaison and administrative duties associated with such visits. In addition, a Senior Officer Grade B equivalent is currently on a four‐month professional development rotation in the Minister's office under EDS.

(5) The DLO is from Budget and Management Program of the Department of Defence, and the Escort Officer is from the Forces Executive Program of the Department. The EDS program is administered by the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1)(a) Was Australian Automatic Arms (AAA) at Kempton, Tasmania, established in 1985 with a grant of $30 000 from the Tasmanian Government; and (b) was AAA bought out by the Federal Government in 1992, and did the owners receive compensation totalling $1.986 million.

(2) Has the former owner and manager of AAA, Mr Don Jones, recently surrendered gun parts or whole guns and applied for compensation under the Government's arms buyback scheme; if so: (a) were the gun parts or guns manufactured at AAA or any related company; (b) what amount of compensation is being claimed; and (c) on what basis is compensation being claimed.

(3) Will any payment to Mr Jones or any former owner of AAA for guns or gun parts manufactured at AAA or any related company be ruled out, on the grounds that AAA was more than adequately compensated when the company closed in 1992.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a) This is a matter for the Tasmanian Government and as such, I am not in a position to comment.

(b) In 1991, the Commonwealth Government announced a prohibition on the importation of military-style semi-automatic rifles and components for those rifles. I am advised that the production capacity of Australian Automatic Arms was severely restricted as a result of this. The Commonwealth Government subsequently agreed to compensate AAA for loss of business. The amount of compensation is a commercial‐in‐confidence matter between the Commonwealth and AAA.

(2) I am advised that Mr Jones has surrendered gun parts and whole guns to the Tasmanian authorities and has applied for compensation under the nationwide firearms buyback scheme. Discussions are currently taking place between the Commonwealth Government, the Tasmania Police and Mr Jones's legal representatives in relation to the details of this matter, and it would be inappropriate to disclose any of the details sought in relation to (a), (b) and (c).
(3) As outlined above, discussions are currently taking place between the Commonwealth Government, the Tasmania Police and Mr Jones's legal representatives in relation to the details of this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the number of and proportion of migrants from both non‐English speaking countries and English speaking countries in the 1990‐91 to 1995‐96 financial years.

(2) Please provide the same information in respect to the family reunion part of the program, the preferential family part of the program and the concessional part of the program for each of those years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The classification of main English speaking countries (MESC) includes Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, the United States of America, Canada, the Republic of Ireland and the United Kingdom. Non‐English speaking countries (NESC) includes all other countries. The information in the following tables is classified MESC or NESC based on country of birth.
(1) Total Settler arrivals by MESC/NESC, 1990‐91 to 1995‐96
(2) Preferential Family, Concessional Family and Total Family Settler Arrivals by MESC/NESC, 1990‐91 to 1995‐96
